column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION 85-year-old man
column3: with fasting hyperglycaemia as the only history of interest. Active and independent. He had been admitted a year earlier to the geriatric ward for a first episode of heart failure in the context of lower respiratory tract infection. Clinical evolution was favourable with diuretics and empirical antibiotic therapy. Although he was in sinus rhythm on admission
column4: shortly afterwards he developed atrial fibrillation with slightly elevated ventricular response. An echocardiogram (ECG) was performed with findings of severe ventricular hypertrophy
column5: biauricular dilatation and restrictive diastolic pattern
column6: compatible with infiltrative myocardial disease. He was discharged six days later with acenocoumarol
column7: torasemide 20 mg and bisoprolol 2.5 mg
column8: pending completion of the outpatient study.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG: atrial fibrillation with mean ventricular response of 60 bpm
column9: low voltage in limb leads and pseudoinfarction pattern with QS in V1-V2. ANALYTICS: amino-terminal pro-brain natriuretic peptide (NT-proBNP) fraction: 4
column10: 175 pg/ml
column11: ultra-sensitive troponin T: 65 ng/l. The rest was normal
column12: including haemogram
column13: glycaemia
column14: renal function
column15: liver function
column16: thyroid hormones
column17: ions
column18: lipids and iron study. The protein study was normal
column19: with proteinogram
column20: serum/urine immunofixation and light chains. Control echocardiogram: non-dilated left ventricle
column21: with severe concentric hypertrophy of granular pattern
column22: maximum thickness of the basal septum 28 mm
column23: left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) 45-50%. Severe diastolic dysfunction with restrictive pattern and estimated pulmonary capillary pressure of 30 mmHg. Moderate biauricular dilatation. Hypertrophic right ventricle. Thickened mitral valve
column24: with mild insufficiency. Estimated systolic pulmonary pressure 43 mmHg. Mild pericardial effusion. ABDOMINAL ECOGRAPHY: mild hepatomegaly
column25: without other pathological findings. HOLTER ECG: atrial fibrillation with an average heart rate (HR) of 65 bpm. Minimum HR of 35 bpm during nocturnal rest and maximum of 120 bpm during physical exercise. Nonsignificant pauses predominantly at night (the longest lasting 2 seconds). Isolated ventricular extrasystoles
column26: infrequent. Abdominal fat and salivary gland biopsies: negative for amyloid material. CARDIAC MRI: left ventricle with marked diffuse concentric thickening
column27: mild systolic dysfunction. Mild dilatation of both atria. Diffuse parietal late enhancement in all four chambers. Mild pleural effusion
column28: no pericardial effusion. GRAMMAGRAPHY technetium-diphostat (99mTc-DPD): intense biventricular tracer uptake
column29: grade 2. GENETIC STUDY by Sanger sequencing of the TTR gene: negative.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION During follow-up
column31: with no new admissions or visits to the emergency room for heart failure. He currently reports dyspnoea on moderate exertion
column32: asthenia
column33: two-pillow orthopnoea and mild malleolar oedema
column34: predominantly in the evening. Blood pressure is usually low and there are episodes of non-syncopal dizziness with orthostatic features. In terms of treatment
column35: acenocoumarol has been replaced by a direct-acting anticoagulant due to poor control of the international normalised ratio (INR)
column36: with time in therapeutic range below 30%. Bisoprolol has been withdrawn due to relatively slow heart rate (50-60 bpm) and hypotension (90/60 mmHg). Current medical treatment is rivaroxaban 15 mg
column37: torasemide 10 mg and spironolactone 25 mg
column38: with a flexible diuretic regimen.  DIAGNOSIS Congestive heart failure with mildly depressed ejection fraction
column39: New York Heart Association (NYHA) functional class II. Restrictive cardiomyopathy due to TTR-wild type amyloidosis
column40: with severe biventricular hypertrophy and severe diastolic dysfunction. Permanent atrial fibrillation
column41: with controlled ventricular response. High cardioembolic risk
column42: anticoagulated. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  Personal history 71-year-old patient
column3: with a personal history of: Cardiovascular risk factors: arterial hypertension
column4: dyslipidaemia
column5: type 2 diabetes mellitus. Ex-smoker for more than 15 years. Chronic gastritis. Eradication of Helicobacter pylori in 2010. Stroke with mild sequelae in 2007. Intermittent claudication at 100 metres. Bilateral femoro-popliteal occlusion
column6: without considering surgery by Vascular Surgery. Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. Long history of chronic ischaemic heart disease:  -- Anterior infarction in 2000
column7: implanting a conventional stent in the proximal anterior descending A. (ADA). --Progressive angina in 2005 with left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) of 40%: restenosis of the previous stent in the LAD and severe disease of the circumflex artery (CxA) and right coronary artery (RCA). Bypass of saphenous vein from RCA and internal mammary artery (IMA) to RCA is performed. The RCA was not revascularised due to its small calibre. --In 2012
column8: worsening of functional class (FC) and LVEF (30%)
column9: repeating coronary angiography: chronic occlusion of LAD and RCA
column10: bypass of IMA to LAD and saphenous vein to permeable RCA. Single-chamber defibrillator (ICD) implanted for primary prevention (no criteria for resynchronisation
column11: QRS 125 msec). --In April 2016 he underwent an appropriate ICD shock. --In May and July 2016 he needed short admissions for decompensation of heart failure and in August he was readmitted again
column12: this time with the need for levosimendan perfusion.  Current illness Three weeks after discharge from hospital
column13: the patient attended the Heart Failure outpatient clinic
column14: reporting NYHA III CF
column15: two-pillow orthopnoea and no new data of worsening from the congestive point of view
column16: nor symptoms attributable to low cardiac output. Stable weight around 58 kg.  Since hospital discharge with the following treatment: synthroid
column17: bisoprolol 5 mg (1/24 h)
column18: enalapril 10 mg (1/12 h)
column19: eplerenone 25 mg (2/24 h)
column20: furosemide 40 mg (3/24 h)
column21: atorvastatin 40 mg (1/24 h)
column22: oral iron
column23: metformin 850 mg (1/12 h)
column24: pantoprazole 40 mg (1/24 h).  Physical examination Blood pressure 123/77 mmHg
column25: heart rate 63 bpm
column26: O2 saturation 97 %. Good general condition. Eupneic in decubitus at 40o. No jugular venous engorgement. Good distal perfusion and adequate capillary refill. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic
column27: no murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation: preserved vesicular murmur
column28: no added sounds. Abdomen: no palpable hepatomegaly. No signs of ascites or wall oedema. Lower limbs: no oedema. Trophic changes. Very weak paedial pulses bilaterally.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Electrocardiogram: sinus rhythm at 68 bpm
column29: PR 204 msec
column30: intraventricular conduction disturbance (QRS 128 msec). Echocardiogram: severely dilated left ventricle with severely depressed global systolic function (23% by Simpson biplane). Restrictive mitral filling. Non-dilated right ventricle with function at low limit of normality (TAPSE 15 mm). Mild mitral insufficiency. Mild TR allowing estimation of systolic pulmonary artery pressure of 43 mmHg. Electrode in right cavities. No pericardial effusion. CBC: NTproBNP 6170 pg/mL
column31: haemoglobin 13.4 g/dl
column32: glucose 99 mg/dl
column33: creatinine 1 mg/dl
column34: urea 44 mg/dl
column35: sodium 140 mmol/l
column36: potassium 3.9 mmol/L.  EVOLUTION It was decided to discontinue enalapril and start sacubitril/valsartan 49/51 mg
column37: one tablet every 12 hours
column38: leaving an enalapril washout period of 36 hours. After 3 weeks
column39: the patient was re-assessed in consultation
column40: with BP of 119/60 mmHg and maintaining renal function and potassium levels in the normal range
column41: so it was increased to 97/103 mg. Two months after starting treatment
column42: a new NTpro-BNP measurement was performed
column43: which was 2900 pg/mL. After 6 months of follow-up
column44: the patient has remained in functional class II-III (subjectively somewhat better than before the change in treatment) and has not been admitted for heart failure. He only visited the emergency department on one occasion for mild decompensation of heart failure related to an upper respiratory tract infection
column45: which could be managed from the emergency department and he was discharged early after 24 hours.  DIAGNOSIS Chronic ischaemic heart disease with severe left ventricular dilatation and dysfunction. CF II-III. Intraventricular conduction disorder without criteria for resynchronisation. Partial response to treatment with sacubitril/valsartan
column46: with a decrease in readmissions for heart failure during 6 months of follow-up. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: CURRENT DISEASE AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION An 81-year-old woman
column3: dyslipidaemic
column4: hypertensive
column5: obese
column6: with DDD pacemaker due to complete atrioventricular block (AVB)
column7: chronic venous insufficiency
column8: hypothyroidism and spondyloarthrosis. She attended the emergency department for a single episode of oppressive central thoracic pain
column9: which did not change with palpation
column10: deep inspiration or movement
column11: not radiating or associated with vegetative cortex
column12: onset at rest
column13: after a situation of family stress
column14: of undetermined duration. There was no evidence of orthopnoea
column15: paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea
column16: palpitations
column17: dyspnoea at rest or on exertion
column18: malleolar oedema or reduced diuresis. No dietary transgression or modification of his usual medication. No respiratory
column19: abdominal or genitourinary infections. The patient presented cardiologically stable
column20: with a heart rate of 94 bpm
column21: blood pressure 200/110 mmHg
column22: afebrile and baseline oxygen saturation 95%. She was conscious and oriented
column23: in good general condition
column24: eupneic at rest
column25: normohydrated
column26: normal colour and normal depth. Carotid pulses were rhythmic and symmetrical and we did not detect jugular ingurgitation. Cardiopulmonary auscultation was rhythmic and without murmurs
column27: with preserved vesicular murmur. Abdominal examination revealed a soft and depressible abdomen
column28: no pain on superficial or deep palpation
column29: no masses or megaliths
column31: no peritonism and positive hydro-aerial sounds. The lower extremities showed no malleolar oedema
column32: with symmetrical posterior pedial and tibial pulses present and no stigmata of venous insufficiency or deep vein thrombosis.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Blood tests showed haemoglobin 11.4 g/dl
column33: hcto 35.1%
column34: MCH 29.2 pg
column35: MCV 90 fl
column36: normal leukocytes
column37: normal platelets
column38: normal biochemistry
column39: normal CPK
column40: peak troponin-I 6 ng/ml
column41: normal renal function
column42: normal ions and normal coagulation. The portable anteroposterior chest X-ray showed an increased cardiothoracic index
column43: no alterations of the bronchovascular tract
column44: no alveolar or interstitial infiltrates
column45: with free costodiaphragmatic angles. Electrocardiogram (ECG) revealed sinus rhythm at 81 bpm
column46: PR 200 msec
column47: right bundle branch block (RBBB) and HMAIHH
column48: QRS axis at -60o
column49: isodiphasic T waves from V3-V4 and symmetric negative waves from V5-V6 (dynamic changes from baseline ECG) and QTc 394 msec.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION The patient was admitted to the coronary care unit
column50: where enzyme seriation and ECG were completed
column51: and antianginal treatment was started. The transthoracic echocardiogram showed a left ventricle at the upper limit of normality
column52: not hypertrophied
column53: with strict anteroapical
column54: inferoapical and apical akinesia and compensatory contractility of basal and middle segments
column55: diastolic pattern of impaired relaxation and moderately depressed systolic function (LVEF 40% by Simpson biplane). The right ventricle was neither dilated nor hypertrophied
column56: with normal systolic function (TAPSE > 18 mm)
column57: while the right and left atria were normal in size. The mitral valve had discrete thickening of the valve leaflets
column58: with calcification of the posterior annulus
column59: good opening and a regurgitant jet that was suggestive of mild mitral regurgitation (MR). The aortic valve had trivalve morphology
column60: with good opening and a regurgitant jet
column61: leading to mild aortic insufficiency (AIo)
column62: with no apparent dilatation of the aortic root. Morphologically normal tricuspid valve
column63: with good opening and mild insufficiency
column64: which allowed estimation of pulmonary arterial systolic pressure (PSAP) 50 mmHg. The pericardium had normal thickness and refractoriness
column65: without effusion
column66: and the inferior vena cava was not dilated
column67: and collapsed adequately (>50%) with inspiration. During his stay in the unit he remained cardiologically stable
column68: with a tendency to hypertension
column69: requiring high doses of beta-blockers
column70: angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACE inhibitors) and nitroglycerin perfusion. He had no new episodes of angina at rest or on slight exertion
column71: palpitations or dyspnoea. Preferential catheterisation confirmed anteroapical and apical cap dyskinesia
column72: with moderately depressed systolic function
column73: and showed coronary arteries without angiographically significant lesions. Given the clinical and haemodynamic stability
column74: the patient was discharged to the cardiology ward
column75: where she remained asymptomatic
column76: with a tendency to hypertension. After adjustment of treatment with beta-blockers and angiotensin II receptor antagonist (ARAII)
column77: blood pressure normalised. No periprocedural complications were reported and the patient was discharged with hygienic-dietary recommendations
column78: double antiplatelet therapy
column79: beta-blockers
column80: ARA-II and statins. Three months later the patient remains clinically asymptomatic
column81: and a follow-up echocardiography has revealed full recovery of the segmental alterations described in the acute event.  DIAGNOSIS Non ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) with normal coronary arteries. Hypertensive emergency. Stress cardiomyopathy (tako-tsubo syndrome). |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION A 58-year-old male patient
column3: smoker of one pack of cigarettes/day
column4: with no other medical history of interest
column5: who is referred to the cardiology department for a routine ECG requested by his primary care physician
column6: which turns out to be pathological. In the detailed anamnesis
column7: the patient reported no previous episodes of chest pain
column8: although he did report dyspnoea on moderate exertion
column9: without progression in recent weeks. He also reported that a few days prior to admission he had a sudden episode of loss of strength in the right upper limb and facial paralysis
column10: with subsequent complete recovery
column11: going to his health centre from where he was discharged
column12: citing the cervical origin of the symptoms. Physical examination revealed no findings of interest. An echocardiogram was performed in the consultation room and
column13: in view of the findings
column14: it was decided to admit him to the ward to complete the diagnostic study with cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR). Initially
column15: given the structural cardiac pathology of the patient and the neurological symptoms that he presented days prior to admission
column16: a transient ischaemic attack (TIA) was suspected
column17: so a CT scan of the brain was performed
column18: which was found to be normal. While the patient was on the ward
column19: CMR was performed which confirmed the diagnosis of ventricular pseudoaneurysm with abundant thrombus. He was considered a candidate for surgery and coronary angiography was performed
column20: finding a severe lesion of the mid-distal left main coronary artery (LMCA) and the 3 vessels.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Transthoracic echocardiography: left ventricle (LV) moderately dilated
column21: with moderate global systolic dysfunction (LVEF by Simpson biplanar 35%)
column22: thinning and inferolateral and inferior akinesia and large inferobasal and inferoseptal basal aneurysm
column23: 44 mm neck and 40 mm deep
column24: with an oval mass of 8 x 7 mm hyperechogenic inside suggestive of thrombus. CHEST X-RAY: showing slight cardiomegaly. ECG: Q waves and negative T waves in inferior leads. Complete ANALYSIS: Haemogram: 14.1 g/dl. Leukocytes 13
column25: 500 10^3/μl. Platelets 207
column26: 000 10^3/μl. Biochemistry: glucose 134 mg/dl. Creatinine 0.86 mg/dl. Na 139 mM/l. K 4.7 mM/l. Lipid profile: total cholesterol 149 mg/dl. HDL 33.7 mg/dl. LDL 208U/l. Triglycerides 82 mg/dl. Liver profile: bilirubin 0.42 mg/dl. GOT 17.7 U/l. GPT 29.3 U/l. GGT 29.3 U/l. GGT 49.6 U/l. Alkaline phosphatase 128 U/l. Glycated Hb 6.1. Cardiac MRI: ventricular pseudoaneurysm
column27: with image of abundant thrombus in the cul-de-sac
column28: without compromise of mitral valve function
column29: with ventricular remodelling and moderate systolic dysfunction. CORONARYGRAPHY: left coronary trunk: with severe lesion in the distal middle third affecting the ostium of the anterior descending and circumflex arteries. Anterior descending: with severe stenosis in the proximal third
column30: good distal vessel. Circumflex: significant ostial stenosis
column31: occluded at the level of bifurcation with first obtuse marginal which has severe stenosis at the level of bifurcation with subdivision
column32: both vessels of good diameter. Right coronary: dominant
column33: ostial occluded
column34: filled by heterocoronary collateral circulation
column35: regular distal vessel.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION The patient remained asymptomatic during his stay on the ward
column36: wandering around
column37: without presenting arrhythmic events on telemetry. Subsequently
column38: and despite maintaining the patient on correct levels of anticoagulation
column39: he again presented motor deficit in the left middle cerebral artery (MCA) and right anterior cerebral artery territory of cardioembolic cause and with recovery without subsequent deficit
column40: with no sequelae in the control CT scan performed. The transcranial Doppler study showed significant stenosis in MCA I. Finally
column41: he was transferred to the reference hospital for surgery: by means of median sternotomy and with the aid of extracorporeal circulation
column42: the aneurysmal area was resected
column43: the intraventricular thrombus was removed and the lower wall was reconstructed with a Dacron patch. Subsequent sequential AMI-DA and AMI-OM aortocoronary bypass was performed. Although myocardial protection with antegrade and retrograde cardioplegia was performed
column44: removal of extracorporeal circulation proved difficult
column45: requiring high doses of vasoactive amines (dobutamine + noradrenaline). He was subsequently admitted to the intensive care unit
column46: where he had a torpid evolution
column47: and died 24 hours after admission due to refractory cardiogenic shock.  DIAGNOSIS Silent infarction complicated by inferior ventricular pseudoaneurysm (with mural thrombus inside). Coronary artery disease of LMCA and three vessels. Moderate left ventricular dysfunction. Surgery for resection of the aneurysmal area + AMI-DA and AMI-OM bypass
column48: with torpid postoperative course and death. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  Personal history 47-year-old woman. Cardiovascular risk factors: hypertension
column3: dyslipidaemia
column4: smoking
column5: long-standing type 2 diabetes with poor metabolic control despite treatment with metformin
column6: vidagliptin
column7: glimepiride and pioglitazone. No previous cardiological history. Other personal history: cholelithiasis. Usual treatment: adiro 100 mg
column8: rosuvastatin 10 mg
column9: enalapril/hydrochlorothiazide 20/12.5 mg
column10: metformin/vildagliptin 1000/50
column11: pioglitazone
column12: glimepiride.  Current illness Admitted to Cardiology for acute coronary syndrome with Killip I anterolateral ST elevation. An urgent coronary angiography showed an acute subtotal thrombotic lesion of the proximal anterior descending coronary artery which was treated with the implantation of 1 drug-eluting stent. He also had moderate lesions in OM1 and OM2 and diffuse DC disease. Echocardiogram showed moderate ventricular dysfunction (EF 35%) with anterior
column13: apical and anterior septal akinesia. The patient was discharged after 5 days without significant incidents with the following treatment: adiro 100 mg 0-1- 0
column14: prasugrel 10 mg 1-0- 0
column15: pantoprazole 40 mg 1-0- 0
column16: carvedilol 25 mg 1-0- 1
column17: enalapril 5 mg 1-0- 1
column18: atorvastatin 80 mg 0-0- 1
column19: eplerenone 50 mg 1-0- 0
column20: ivabradine 5 mg 1⁄2-0- 1⁄2 and her usual antidiabetic treatment. He was referred to the cardiac rehabilitation programme.  Physical examination BP: 107/55 HR: 65 bpm. Good general condition
column21: eupneic at rest
column22: afebrile. Head and neck: no signs of jugular venous engorgement. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic tones without murmurs or extratonos. AP: preserved vesicular murmur with no extra sounds. Lower extremities: no oedema. Radial and pedial pulses present and symmetrical. Anthropometric examination: weight: 84.5 kg. Height: 162 cm. BMI: 32.1 kg/m2. Abdominal circumference: 112 cm.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Blood tests: haemoglobin: 12.7 g/dl. Leukocytes: 10300. Platelets: 354000. Normal coagulation. Creatinine 0.9 mg/dl. Urea 70. Na 140.2. K 3
column23: 8. Lipoprotein profile (total cholesterol 125 mg/dl; LDL: 82 mg/dl
column24: HDL: 28 mg/dl
column25: Triglycerides: 223 mg/dl). HbA1C 10 %. Electrocardiogram: sinus rhythm at 68 bpm. signs of anterior necrosis. Chest X-ray: slightly increased cardiothoracic index. No signs of heart failure. Echocardiogram: left ventricle of normal size
column26: slightly hypertrophic. Akinesia of the middle and apical segments of the septal
column27: lateral and anterior face
column28: with hypokinesia of the rest of the segments. All this leads to moderate ventricular dysfunction with an estimated ejection fraction of 35%. Right ventricle of normal size and function. No significant valvulopathies. No pericardial effusion. Catheterisation: TCI: of good calibre
column29: without lesions. LAD: normodeveloped of regular calibre
column30: with subtotal thrombotic lesion in bifurcation with diagonal. Distally very thin vessel. ACX: of good calibre and development
column31: without lesions in the CX itself. The 1st and 2nd OM have moderate ostial lesions. ACD: dominant
column32: diffuse atheromatous involvement
column33: but without severe lesions. PCI With a 3.5 6F XB guide catheter
column34: a BMW guide is passed through the lesion in the LAD. Predilatation with a 2 x 14 mm balloon at 14 atmospheres and implantation of a 2.5 x 16 mm Promus drug-eluting stent at 18 atmospheres with good angiographic results and no complications.  EVOLUTION The patient started a 6-week cardiac rehabilitation programme consisting of motivational talks and physical training 2 days a week. During the programme
column35: the importance of smoking cessation and weight loss was emphasised
column36: but one of the main challenges we had to face was undoubtedly the adjustment of the diabetic treatment. Considering the clinical scenario (young patient with moderate ischaemic ventricular dysfunction and suboptimal diabetic control (HbA1c: 10 %) despite being treated with four oral antidiabetic drugs)
column37: we considered the different options and finally decided to: 1) discontinue: pioglitazone
column38: glimepiride and vidagliptin; 2) maintain: metformin; 3) combine: empaglifozin 10 mg/day and insulin therapy (both slow and rapid insulin). The patient successfully completed the programme and achieved weight loss
column39: remained smoke-free and improved glycaemic control.  DIAGNOSIS Acute ST-elevation myocardial infarction with Killip 1 anterior ST elevation. Severe proximal CAD treated with 1 drug-eluting stent implantation. Moderate left ventricular dysfunction. Arterial hypertension. Type 2 diabetes mellitus with poor control. Dyslipidaemia. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION The patient is a 61-year-old male who consults for dyspnoea.  History No known drug allergies. Ex-smoker. Ex-drinker. Hyperuricaemia with gouty crisis. HYPERTENSION. Dyslipidaemia. Long-standing type 2 diabetes mellitus
column3: under treatment with oral anti-diabetics and insulin
column4: with good control. Stage III chronic kidney disease. Cholecystectomy in 2012 for acute calculous cholecystitis. Repeated nephritic colic
column5: requiring admission to the ICU in one of the episodes. Anxious-depressive syndrome being monitored by Psychiatry
column6: with one admission for decompensation in 2005
column7: and subsequently good clinical control with medication. In 2010
column8: he was referred to Pneumology for dyspnoea and a pathological chest X-ray
column9: being diagnosed with sarcoidosis after completing the study with a high-resolution thoracic axial tomography (TACAR) and a biopsy of the mediastinal adenopathies by mediastinoscopy. He was treated for years with oral corticosteroids
column10: which were subsequently withdrawn due to stabilisation of the disease both clinically and radiologically. Follow-up since 2006 in Cardiology Outpatients
column11: being diagnosed with dilated cardiomyopathy with severe systolic dysfunction. Coronary angiography was performed at that time
column12: which ruled out significant coronary stenosis. The patient admitted to consuming about 40 grams of alcohol per day
column13: which was attributed to the origin of his heart disease. Successive follow-up visits were made; eight months after giving up the alcohol habit
column14: the left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) was found to have recovered to 55%. At that time
column15: he presented an electrocardiogram (ECG) with complete left bundle branch block (LBBB) and a QRS of 120 msec. In 2011
column16: he was admitted to Cardiology for chest pain with typical characteristics. Coronary angiography was repeated
column17: with no significant stenosis in the coronary tree. An echocardiogram was performed
column18: which showed a slightly dilated left ventricle with mild systolic dysfunction (LVEF 45%). On admission
column19: after registering bouts of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation and atrial flutter
column20: anticoagulant treatment was started with acenocoumarol; subsequently
column21: due to a low rate of controls in therapeutic range with dicoumarinic drugs
column22: he was switched to apixaban
column23: without incident. In the following years
column24: during outpatient follow-up
column25: there was evidence of progressive deterioration of LVEF
column26: which fell to 30%
column27: as well as the appearance of signs and symptoms of incipient heart failure. Treatment with angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACE inhibitors)
column28: beta-blockers and aldosterone antagonists was initiated. From then on
column29: in the successive ECGs obtained
column30: he alternates complete right bundle branch block (RBBBH)
column31: with other recordings showing a non-specific intraventricular conduction disorder
column32: and QRS between 140 and 150 msec. Usual treatment on admission: spironolactone 25 mg/24 hours
column33: ramipril 2.5 mg/12 hours
column34: carvedilol 12.5 mg/12 hours)
column35: allopurinol 100 mg/24 hours
column36: apixaban 5 mg/12 hours
column37: atorvastatin 20 mg/24 hours
column38: digoxin 0.25 mg/24 hours
column39: furosemide 80 mg/24 hours (1-1-0)
column40: insulin glargine 16 IU/24 hours
column41: metformin 850 mg-vildagliptin 50 mg/12 hours
column42: omeprazole 20 mg/24 hours
column43: duloxetine 60 mg/24 hours
column44: trazodone 100 mg/24 hours
column45: alprazolam 0.25 mg/24 hours.  Current illness In 2013
column46: she came to the Emergency Department with a 20-day history of progressive increase in her usual dyspnoea (ambulatory class II/IV)
column47: until it became minimal effort
column48: with episodes in the last week of orthopnoea
column49: paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea and bendopnoea limiting any physical activity. He also admits a subjective decrease in diuresis and occasional palpitations at rest
column50: with no history of dizziness or syncope.  Physical examination Normoperfused. Tachypnoea at rest
column51: with use of accessory muscles. Elevation of jugular venous pressure
column52: with positive hepatojugular reflux. O2 saturation 93% with oxygen supply at 3 litres per minute through nasal goggles. Blood pressure 130/70 mmHg. Arrhythmic heart sounds at 100 beats per minute (bpm)
column53: no murmurs. Pulmonary crackles up to midfields. Perimalleolar oedema with fovea in both lower limbs. Abdomen soft
column54: depressible
column55: non-painful
column56: without masses or megaliths
column57: with hydro-aerial sounds present.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS CBC: haemogram: leucocytes 9
column58: 000 10E3/mL (no left shift)
column59: haemoglobin 13 g/dL
column60: haematocrit 39%
column61: MCV 92 fl
column62: platelets 163
column63: 000 10E3/mL. Coagulation: INR 1.3
column64: PT 60 %
column65: TTPa 32 seconds. Biochemistry: glucose 116 mg/dl
column66: urea 70 mg/dl
column67: creatinine 1.6 mg/dl
column68: FGR (MDMR) 49 ml/min/1.73 m2
column69: sodium 134 mEq/L
column70: potassium 4.6 mEq/L
column71: liver function tests normal
column72: protein 7.4 g/dl
column73: albumin 4.7 g/dl
column74: cholesterol 132
column75: triglycerides 129
column76: HDL-cholesterol 31
column77: LDL-cholesterol 75
column78: HbA1c 6 %
column79: thyroid hormones normal
column80: proBNP 5900 pg/ml
column81: ultrasensitive troponin T 14 ng/l. Chest X-ray on admission: increased cardiothoracic index. Bilateral hilar thickening. Alveolar-interstitial oedema in both lung fields. Bilateral costophrenic sinus impingement. Fluid in the fissure. Electrocardiogram: sinus rhythm at 90 bpm
column82: PR 180 msec
column83: QRS 150 msec. There was a non-specific intraventricular conduction disturbance that did not fully meet the criteria for HRBBB. Block of the left anterior subdivision of the His bundle (LADB). Frequent supraventricular extrasystoles. Transthoracic Doppler colour echocardiogram: severely dilated left ventricle (end-diastolic diameter of 68 mm)
column84: with normal wall thicknesses
column85: and severely depressed systolic function (LVEF 25%) at the expense of generalised hypokinesia
column86: with no segmental contractility abnormalities identified. Right ventricle of normal size and function. No significant valvulopathies were detected. No pericardial effusion. No tricuspid insufficiency or other data suggestive of pulmonary hypertension at rest. Ascending aorta of normal size and Doppler flow. No intracardiac shunts were observed. Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI): left ventricular dilatation (LVEDV 260 ml
column87: 140 ml/m2; LVESV 180 ml
column88: 100 ml/m2) with severe deterioration of systolic function (LVEF 30%) due to global hypokinesia. Abnormal movement of the interventricular septum typical of bundle branch block. Perfusion study without pathological findings. Late gadolinium enhancement of intramyocardial distribution in basal and middle segments of the interventricular septum. Right ventricle of normal size and morphology
column89: without abnormalities in global and segmental contractility. Dilated left atrium (36 cm2) and right atrium of normal size (20 cm2). Chest X-ray on admission: increased cardiothoracic index. Improvement of signs of heart failure with respect to the image on admission
column90: with persistent alveolar-interstitial oedema in the lung bases and bilateral hilar congestion. ICD-CRT device in cardiac cavities.  EVOLUTION After initiating diuretic and intravenous vasodilator treatment at high doses
column91: progressive improvement of the signs and symptoms of heart failure was achieved. Once clinical stabilisation was achieved
column92: the study was completed with the echocardiogram and cardiac MRI described above. The findings of these tests
column93: together with the histological characterisation of the biopsy of mediastinal adenopathies performed years earlier
column94: pointed to cardiac sarcoidosis as the most plausible cause of our patient's dilated cardiomyopathy. Due to the severe conduction disturbances (with alternating LBBB and non-specific intraventricular conduction disturbance-LBBB-CCRDHH)
column95: the occurrence of non-sustained ventricular arrhythmias during monitoring
column96: and the presence of non-ischaemic dilated cardiomyopathy with severe ventricular dysfunction
column97: in NYHA functional class III/IV
column98: and with a QRS of 150 msec (despite not having left bundle branch block morphology at the time of admission)
column99: it was decided to implant an ICD-CRT device (cardiac resynchronisation therapy) for primary prevention and to optimise the treatment of heart failure. After titration of the doses of beta-blockers
column100: ACE inhibitors and Aldosterone receptor antagonists to the maximum tolerated doses
column101: and confirmation of the patient's euvolemia and clinical stability
column102: he was discharged for outpatient follow-up. In the first months after admission
column103: the patient's response to the established therapeutic plan was confirmed
column104: and he remained in stable functional class I-II/IV for two years. In the ECG at follow-up
column105: biventricular pacing rhythm
column106: alternating atrial tachycardia / atrial flutter / baseline sinus rhythm
column107: and with a QRS of 110 msec. However
column109: he required a new admission to the Cardiology hospital ward for decompensated heart failure
column110: as well as several visits to the Emergency Department for intravenous diuretic treatment. Therefore
column111: treatment with sacubitrilo-valsartan was started after suspending ACE inhibitors for 36 hours. The response to the new treatment was partial
column112: so a study has been started with a view to a possible heart transplant.  DIAGNOSIS Cardiac and pulmonary sarcoidosis. Dilated cardiomyopathy with severe left ventricular systolic dysfunction. Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction
column113: stage D. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History 65-year-old woman with cardiovascular risk factors such as hypertension
column3: dyslipidaemia and active smoking. As personal history
column4: she has a normofunctioning mechanical aortic and mitral prosthesis with preserved ventricular function in outpatient follow-up. She is in permanent atrial fibrillation with frequency control strategy
column5: anticoagulated with sintrom
column6: diagnosed after emboligenic debut in 2014 with episode of transient ischaemic accident without neurological sequelae. She also has unaffiliated chronic kidney disease and moderate polyarticular osteoarthritis. As treatment she takes acenocoumarol 4 mg daily with good control of the usual INR
column7: enalapril 5 mg daily
column8: bisoprolol 10 mg daily
column9: atorvastatin 20 mg daily
column10: omeprazole 20 mg daily and paracetamol and metamizole alternately for joint pain.  Present illness She presented to the Emergency Department for functional class deterioration 2 weeks after onset. The patient reports dyspnoea that has progressed to rest
column11: orthopnoea previously absent and currently 90 degrees
column12: and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea crisis. She also reports oliguria
column13: oedema up to the knees and a feeling of abdominal distension. He also reported frequent episodes of palpitations and the finding of elevated heart rates of over 100 bpm during his ambulatory blood pressure measurement.  Physical examination Physical examination revealed blood pressure of 130/80 mmHg
column14: heart rate of 140 bpm
column15: tachypnoea with slurred speech and basal saturation of 89%. She presented jugular venous engorgement up to 1/3 mid-cervical with venous repletion up to the mandibular angle due to positive hepatojugular reflux
column16: crackles up to midfields
column17: moderately distended abdomen with painful hepatomegaly of 3 crossings and with semiology compatible with mild ascites
column18: and oedema up to 1/3 distal thighs.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Electrocardiogram: tracing compatible with atypical atrial flutter with ventricular response at 140 bpm and wide QRS with BCRDHH morphology. Blood tests: haemoglobin 14.4 mg/dl
column19: platelets 226
column21: leucocytes 12.100 with normal formula
column22: INR of 3.49
column23: arterial blood gas with pH 7.44
column24: pO2 54
column25: pCO2 36
column26: Sat O2 86 %
column27: lactate 1.9
column28: bicarbonate 29
column29: creatinine 0.89 mg/dl
column31: potassium 4.4
column32: ALT 55
column33: bilirubin 1.6
column34: alkaline phosphatase 267
column35: GGT 99
column36: NTproBNP 5145. Normal C-reactive protein and procalcitonin. Chest X-ray: increased cardiothoracic index. Bilateral pleural effusion and bilateral hilar infiltrate with evidence of vascular redistribution. Transthoracic echocardiogram: mechanical prosthesis in normopositioned mitral position
column37: with mean gradient of 4 mmHg and effective valve area calculated by THP greater than 2 cm2. Mild insufficiency. Mechanical prosthesis in aortic position with maximum gradient of 28 mmHg and mean gradient of 15 mmHg. Mild insufficiency. Morphologically normal tricuspid valve. Mild-moderate insufficiency. Pulmonary artery systolic pressure estimated at 38 mmHg. Left ventricle not dilated
column38: slightly hypertrophic
column39: with severely depressed global systolic function (LVEF 22% by Simpson biplane). Akinesia of the inferior and inferolateral sides
column40: and of the basal and middle segment of the septum. Severe hypokinesia of the rest. Slightly dilated left atrium. Slightly dilated right atrium. Dilated right ventricle
column41: severely hypocontractile. TAPSE: 12 mm. No pericardial effusion. Normal aortic root. Dilated inferior vena cava without inspiratory collapse.  EVOLUTION Given the situation of respiratory compromise
column42: the patient was transferred to the Acute Cardiac Care Unit
column43: initiating non-invasive ventilatory support with Bi-PAP
column44: intravenous diuretic and frequency control strategy with intravenous digitalisation
column45: with suboptimal control despite blood digoxin levels in the high range of the safety margin
column46: so intravenous amiodarone and beta-blockers at low doses were added to the treatment after a decrease in congestive signs. Heart rate control was achieved
column47: but the patient remained in atrial flutter with a ventricular response of around 85 bpm. An echocardiogram was performed after initial heart rate control
column48: which yielded the results that can be seen in the complementary tests. In summary
column49: severe biventricular dysfunction was observed with evidence of right congestion
column50: with normofunctioning mechanical prostheses. No significant biauricular dilatation. In view of these findings
column51: coronary angiography was performed
column52: ruling out significant coronary artery disease
column53: and global heart failure with biventricular dysfunction secondary to tachycardiomyopathy was postulated as the first diagnosis. Progressively favourable evolution with good frequency control and reduction of respiratory work and improvement of congestive symptoms. Intravenous amiodarone was withdrawn and oral impregnation was maintained
column54: beta-blockers were progressively titrated up to a maximum dose of 10 mg per day and oral digoxin was maintained
column55: with good control. Spironolactone 25 mg per day and furosemide 40 mg in the morning were added to the treatment
column56: maintaining enalapril 5 mg every 12 hours
column57: acenocoumarol and the rest of his usual medication. Finally
column58: after discussing the case with electrophysiology
column59: considering a complex approach for ablation of atypical flutter substrate requiring left access
column60: an endovascular electrophysiological study was rejected and unsuccessful electrical cardioversion was scheduled after the application of 3 shocks. In euvolemic and stable condition
column61: in atypical flutter with controlled ventricular response
column62: she was discharged and referred for follow-up in the Cardiology Day Hospital and heart failure consultation. Subsequent follow-up in the Cardiology day hospital showed the patient to be stable
column63: in functional class II with no evidence of heart failure decompensation. However
column64: she returned to the emergency department of our hospital 2 months later with global heart failure again
column65: reporting palpitations and elevated heart rates on the home blood pressure monitor. The ECG showed the same atypical atrial flutter at 140 bpm. He was again admitted to the Acute Cardiac Care Unit
column66: where non-invasive ventilation
column67: intravenous furosemide and perfused amiodarone were started again
column68: maintaining beta-blockers and digoxin
column69: with a progressively favourable evolution
column70: although it was impossible to control the heart rate
column71: maintaining symptoms and semiology of decompensated heart failure. Considering the patient's tachycardiomyopathy
column72: with severe biventricular dysfunction
column73: and after ruling out another flutter substrate approach due to the need for left access with potential associated complications in an anticoagulated patient
column74: the Heart Team decided to implant a pacemaker-cardiac resynchronisation therapy (CCP-CRT) in the first stage and later ablation of the atrioventricular node. Thus
column75: during admission
column76: endocavitary left cephalic endocardial CRT-PCM was successfully implanted
column77: which allowed subsequent titration of bisoprolol up to supramax doses of 20 mg per day with very good tolerance
column78: achieving good heart rate control and resolution of acute heart failure. Finally
column79: he was discharged in stable
column80: euvolemic condition
column81: maintaining treatment with furosemide 40 mg per day
column82: acenocoumarol 3 mg per day
column83: spironolactone 25 mg per day
column84: enalapril 5 mg every 12 hours
column85: and bisoprolol 10 mg every 12 hours. The following month
column86: and as scheduled
column87: atrioventricular node ablation was performed without incident
column88: and the patient was discharged from the Cardiology day hospital without requiring hospitalisation. Subsequent follow-up in heart failure consultations was stable
column89: without new episodes of heart failure
column90: with a control echocardiogram at 6 months in which a recovery of left ventricular function (measured by LVEF) of up to 37% was observed
column91: with normofunction of the right ventricle.  DIAGNOSIS Tachycardiomyopathy secondary to atypical atrial flutter with rapid ventricular response. Severe biventricular dysfunction. Pacemaker implantation-cardiac resynchronisation therapy and nodal ablation. Rheumatic valve disease. Carrier of normofunctioning aortic and mitral valve prostheses. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION Personal history No known drug allergies. Active smoking 40 pack-years. CVRF: hypertensive
column3: obese. Lumbar canal stenosis. During follow-up
column4: right hypernephroma was diagnosed. IQ: herniated disc L5-S1 in 2006.  Cardiological history Permanent atrial fibrillation Rheumatic valve disease. Double mitral lesion with severe stenosis
column5: severe TR and PHT. Intervention in 2006 by mitral valve replacement with mechanical prosthesis (Sorin Bicarbon no 27) and tricuspid annuloplasty.  Usual treatment: omeprazole 20 mg
column6: spironolactone 25 mg
column7: verapamil 80 mg/12 h
column8: acenocoumarol
column9: oxycodone/naloxone
column10: duloxetine 60mg
column11: gabapentin 300 mg/8 h
column12: naproxen. ʟʟ SFB: active life
column13: functional limitation due to lumbosciatica with neurogenic claudication. NYHA I/IV.  Present illness Admitted to Urology for radical right nephrectomy
column14: scheduled for 6 September. Anticoagulated with enoxaparin 60 mg/24 h for 5 days prior to surgery (1 to 5 September) and with enoxaparin 40 mg/24 h for 5 days after surgery (6 to 10 September). On 10 September she began to experience dizziness
column15: dyspnoea on exertion and hypotension. Initially assessed by Cardiology
column16: it was interpreted as decompensation of heart failure
column17: diuretics were started and anticoagulation was increased to enoxaparin 80 mg/12h. On day 13
column18: sudden respiratory worsening
column19: requiring OTI and profound hypotension requiring noradrenaline in continuous perfusion at increasing doses (up to 1.5 μg/kg/min). A CT angiography was performed
column20: without finding PET
column21: showing left renal and splenic infarctions. The patient was transferred to the resuscitation unit and on-call cardiology was notified for assessment.  PHYSICAL EXPLORATION (on admission to the Coronary Unit) BP 106/49 mmHg (IABP + noradrenaline); PAP 63/45 mmHg; PCP 50 mmHg; HR 145 bpm; SatO2 97 % (FiO2 80 %); central temperature 38.7°C. Sedated
column22: well adapted to the ventilator. Peripheral lividity
column23: with acral coldness. Cardiac auscultation: arrhythmic heart at 120 bpm
column24: gallop. Pulmonary auscultation: scattered rhonchi and universal crackles. Abdomen: soft and depressible
column25: no defence on palpation. Lower extremities: lividity
column26: no oedema.   COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Chest X-ray: cardiomegaly
column27: perihilar alveolar infiltrates
column28: compatible with acute pulmonary oedema. Swan-Ganz catheter in pulmonary branch
column29: counterpulsation balloon at the level of the tracheal carina
column30: orotracheal intubation tube in normal position. Mechanical prosthesis in mitral position. Angio-CT scan: ruled out PTE. Data of heart failure and renal and splenic infarcts. ECG: AF with ventricular response at 130 bpm
column31: axis at 0o. No repolarisation alterations. Analysis on admission to the Coronary Unit: PO2 65 mmHg. PCO2 44 mmHg. pH 7
column32: 22. HCO3 18 mmol/l. SaO2 92 %. Lactate 24 mg/dl. Glucose 287 mg/dl. Urea 72 mg/dl. Creatinine 2.45 mg/dl. GPT 55 U/L. CK 89 U/L. LDH 519 U/L. Corrected calcium 8.56 mg/dl. Sodium 133 mmol/L. Potassium 5 mmol/L. C-reactive protein 13.09 mg/dl. Haemoglobin 14.4 g/dl. Haematocrit 44 %. Platelets 227.000/μL. Leukocytes 16
column33: 500/μL (neutrophils 83 %). Prothrombin index 70 %. INR 1.28. TTPA 41.3 s. Transthoracic echocardiogram: left ventricle neither dilated nor hypertrophic
column34: with moderate global dysfunction (estimated LVEF 35-40 %)
column35: without clear asynergies. Trivalve aortic valve
column36: without functional alterations. Metal prosthesis in mitral position with restriction of the opening of the antero-medial disc
column37: leaving the postero-lateral disc fixed. Maximum velocity across the valve 230 cm/s
column38: mean gradient 16 mmHg. Severely dilated left atrium. Poor access to right chambers. No pericardial effusion. Transesophageal echocardiogram: metallic prosthesis in mitral position with restriction of the opening of the antero-medial disc and absence of movement of the postero-lateral disc; leading to an acceleration of flow in systole with maximum velocity and mean gradient coinciding with the TTE. An attempt is made to measure the thrombus
column39: with an approximate diameter of 21.7 mm. Severely dilated left atrium with smoke inside. Left atrial appendage with an image suggestive of thrombus inside.   EVOLUTION On arrival at the resuscitation department
column40: the patient was sedated and intubated
column41: well adapted to the ventilator. Haemodynamically unstable
column42: requiring increasing doses of noradrenaline in continuous perfusion (up to 1.5 μg/kg/min) to maintain TAS 80 mmHg
column43: in atrial fibrillation at 140 bpm. Transthoracic echocardiography (V-Scan) was performed
column44: which showed moderate LV dysfunction
column45: with obstructive thrombus on the mitral prosthetic valve
column46: limiting the opening of the discs. Given the poor clinical and haemodynamic situation
column47: intra-aortic balloon counterpulsation was implanted and the patient was transferred to the Coronary Unit
column48: where right pressures were monitored using a Swan-Ganz catheter. The patient has been in anuria since the onset of the condition. Given the history of major surgery in the previous 8 days
column49: the size of the thrombus
column50: the presence of systemic embolisms and the presence of a thrombus in the atrial appendage
column51: fibrinolysis was rejected and the cardiac surgeon on duty was notified
column52: who agreed to perform urgent surgery. Valve replacement with a biological mitral valve prosthesis (Perimount plus no. 27) was performed. During the postoperative period
column53: in the Coronary Unit
column54: he developed septic shock secondary to pneumonia
column55: without any germ being isolated in the cultures. He was treated with intensive antibiotic therapy
column56: with good evolution. Two weeks later he was transferred to the hospital ward. She was finally discharged from hospital one month after cardiac surgery.  DIAGNOSIS Right radical nephrectomy for hypernephroma. Thrombosis on mechanical mitral prosthesis in relation to perioperative bridging therapy with enoxaparin. Secondary cardiogenic shock. Mitral valve replacement with biological prosthesis. Septic shock due to right basal pneumonia

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION 36-year-old woman
column3: with the following medical history: No known adverse drug reactions. Never smoked. No consumption of alcohol or other intoxicants. No previous cardiological history. No history of heart disease in the family. Pregestational arterial hypertension with debut at 33 years of age
column4: currently on treatment with labetalol 100 mg every 12 hours. Dyslipidaemia (LDL 200 mg/dl). Primiparous woman in recent puerperium after scheduled caesarean section performed 10 days ago
column5: without immediate complications
column6: with a healthy male newborn weighing 2
column7: 930g. The patient consulted the emergency department for several episodes in the last 3 days of oppressive precordial pain without associated irradiation or vegetative cortex
column8: lasting between 5 and 30 minutes
column9: of variable intensity and unrelated to exertion
column10: with a tendency to hypertension during the episodes. Consultation for a new episode of greater intensity and duration. On arrival at the ED
column11: blood pressure (BP) 165/104 mmHg; heart rate (HR) 79 bpm
column12: oxygen saturation 98% FiO2 0.21; temperature 36.5 oC. On physical examination
column13: the patient was conscious
column14: oriented
column15: eupneic at rest
column16: without jugular ingurgitation. Cardiac auscultation with regular tones and no murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation with preserved vesicular murmur without aggregates. Radial and pedial pulses present and symmetrical. Absence of peripheral oedema.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Electrocardiogram 1 (ECG) on arrival
column17: with pain: sinus rhythm at 75 bpm
column18: PR 180 ms
column19: narrow QRS with axis at +30o
column20: ST-segment depression < 0.5 mm in V4 to V6
column21: flattened T in III. Painless ECG 2: sinus rhythm at 60 bpm
column22: PR 180 ms
column23: narrow QRS with axis at +60o
column24: J-point rise of 0.5 mm in V2
column25: biphasic T from V2 to V5
column26: negative in I and aVL. Chest X-ray: normal cardiomediastinal silhouette
column27: without images of consolidation or pleural effusion. Laboratory tests: Myocardial damage marker curve: ultrasensitive troponin T (TnTus) 58.7 to 420 pg/ml at 3h (normal values < 14 pg/ml). N-terminal pro-brain natriuretic peptide (NT-proBNP) 157 pg/ml. D-dimer 1560 ng/ml. Other biochemistry
column28: haemogram and coagulation anodine. Bedside echocardioscopy: non-dilated left ventricle with preserved LVEF and anterior hypokinesia at mid-apical level. Non-dilated right ventricle with good systolic function. Absence of significant valvular heart disease. Absence of pericardial effusion. Abdominal ultrasound: placental debris ruled out. Coronary angiography 1: abrupt decrease in the calibre of the middle and distal anterior descending artery after the exit of the second diagonal developed
column29: image compatible with spontaneous coronary dissection. Distal flow TIMI 3. Rest of arteries without lesions.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION The patient was admitted to the coronary unit with stable
column31: with low-dose nitroglycerine perfusion and controlled blood pressure
column32: and early coronary angiography was performed with the findings described. Given the absence of angina and TIMI 3 distal flow
column33: conservative management in the coronary unit was initially decided. In the following days
column34: the patient presented several short episodes of precordial pain lasting a few minutes
column35: with no electrical changes or increase in markers of myocardial damage. On the third day of admission
column36: she presented a new episode of pain of greater intensity
column37: with an electrocardiogram (ECG 3) showing ST-segment elevation >1mm in V1 to V4 and 0.5mm in III and aVF. It was decided to perform a new coronary angiography (video 2. Coronary angiography 2) which showed distal progression of the dissection
column38: with worsening of the lumen of the artery at the medial level and complete collapse of the same in the apical segment
column39: with weak homolateral collaterals (Rentrop 1). Given the haemodynamic stability
column40: the disappearance of pain with electrocardiographic improvement after medical treatment and the location of the occlusion in the distal-apical segment
column41: conservative management was again decided
column42: with good initial evolution and progressive decrease in markers of myocardial damage. Six days later
column43: the patient presented a new episode of intense precordial pain accompanied by haemodynamic deterioration with hypotension (TAS 70 mmHg) requiring vasoactive drugs
column44: respiratory deterioration
column45: radiological worsening compatible with acute pulmonary oedema (chest X-ray) and new elevation of myocardial damage markers from 500 to 3750 pg/ml. The ECG (ECG 4) shows ST-segment elevation > 2 mm in V4-V5 and 0.5 mm in II
column46: III and aVF. It was decided to perform a new coronary angiography (Coronary angiography 3) which showed progression of the dissection at the proximal level
column47: with complete occlusion of the vessel at the middle level and distal vessel weakly visualised by homocoronary collaterals (Rentrop 1). In view of the shock situation and TIMI 0 flow
column48: it was decided to intervene guided by intravascular ultrasound (IVUS)
column49: and after placing the angioplasty catheter and passing the guidewire to ADA and diagonal
column50: an image of dissection in the distal left coronary artery (possibly facilitated by the tip of the catheter on a susceptible intima) with TIMI 0 flow in all branches was observed. A 3.5 x 28 mm drug-eluting stent was implanted in the coronary trunk to the proximal anterior descending coronary artery and a second 3.5-3.0x60 mm stent was implanted distally
column51: restoring TIMI 3 flow in the distal anterior descending artery although with persistent non-occlusive dissection
column52: and first diagonal with TIMI 1 flow. Finally
column53: conservative management of the circumflex artery ostium was chosen after restoring distal TIMI 3 flow
column54: once the entry port had been sealed. The patient evolved favourably over the following days
column55: with resolution of the shock situation and discharge to the cardiology ward. Regular echocardiography was performed (video 4) and the study was completed with cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (video 5)
column56: showing dilatation of the left ventricle with severe depression of its systolic function (LVEF 34%) secondary to alterations in segmental contractility in apical segments and on the lateral side
column57: transmural necrosis of 4 segments of the LAD territory (apical segments) and non-transmural necrosis on the lateral side. During follow-up at discharge from the heart failure unit
column58: prognostically evident drugs were prescribed and
column59: given the absence of improvement in systolic function
column60: an ICD was placed for primary prevention.  DIAGNOSIS Spontaneous coronary artery dissection associated with pregnancy. Non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome (NSTEACS). column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  We present the case of an 89 year old male with a history of: Arterial hypertension under treatment with good control. Common flutter treated with cavotricuspid isthmus ablation. Implantation of a VDD pacemaker in 2007 after cardiogenic syncope (no reports). Non-ST-elevation acute coronary syndrome in 2013 with coronary angiography showing no significant lesions. Usual treatment: ramipril 2.5 mg at breakfast
column3: omeprazole 20 mg at breakfast
column4: atorvastatin 40 mg at dinner
column5: tamsulosin/dutasteride 0.4/0.5 mg at breakfast
column6: bisoprolol 5 mg at lunch
column7: acenocoumarol as prescribed
column8: calcifediol 0.266 mg monthly. Baseline condition: physically active
column9: no cognitive deterioration. The patient was under cardiological follow-up for aortic stenosis
column10: of degenerative origin
column11: progressing to severe
column12: the patient being asymptomatic. Last echocardiographic control in October/19
column13: where preserved LVEF and severe aortic stenosis were found: aortic valve area (AVA) by continuity equation of 0.72 cm2 (0.38 cm2/m2)
column14: maximum/average gradients of 79/44 mmHg
column15: a maximum velocity of 4.5 m/s and an integral LVOT/aorta ratio of 0.21. In January 2021
column16: a telephone consultation was made in which the patient reported that he continued to carry out his daily activities without difficulty and was asymptomatic
column17: in class I of the New York Heart Association (NYHA). Two months after this consultation
column18: the patient needed to be hospitalised in another centre for acute heart failure in the context of SARS-CoV-2 pneumonia. The patient made good progress on the ward with diuretic oxygen therapy. His doctors contacted our clinic
column19: and the patient was discharged without congestive data and with an appointment for preferential assessment in the week following hospital discharge. However
column20: a few days after discharge
column21: the patient needed to visit the emergency department of our centre due to the appearance of oppressive chest pain triggered by slight exertion
column22: which subsided with rest and which was self-limiting
column23: with none of the episodes lasting more than 5 minutes. In addition
column24: she reports a feeling of dizziness that makes it difficult for her to walk. All this has occurred since the last hospital admission. Physical examination revealed a blood pressure of 160/83 mmHg at 64 beats per minute
column25: saturation of 98% of ambient air and normothermia. There was also an ejection murmur in aortic focus III/VI
column26: radiating to the suprasternal and carotid cavities with effacement of the second tone. Pulmonary auscultation showed bibasal crackles. Oedema with pretibial fovea in both lower limbs.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Last outpatient echocardiogram: severe aortic stenosis with the following additional data: aortic valve area (AVA) by continuity equation of 0.72 cm2 (0.38 cm2/m2)
column27: maximum/average gradients of 79/44 mmHg

column29: without clear parenchymal consolidation. Impression of absence of pleural effusion. Normopositioned pacemaker electrocatheter. Emergency blood tests: CBC: red cells 4.77 xmill/μl

column70: inferior and inferolateral inferoseptal akinesia with severe systolic dysfunction (LVEF 33%). The aortic valve was severely calcified and unstructured with marked restriction of leaflet mobility: AVA 0.48 cm2 (0.26 cm2/m2)
column71: peak/average gradients of 87/52 mmHg

column73: all compatible with severe-critical aortic stenosis. In addition
column74: the tricuspid valve exhibited mild insufficiency allowing an estimated pulmonary arterial systolic pressure of 63 mmHg. Coronary angiography: significant calcification of the coronary tree. Left main coronary artery of good calibre
column75: with mild atheromatosis. Anterior descending artery (LAD) of good calibre and development. Proximal LAD with mild atheromatosis. Mid LAD with moderate focal lesion at the level of the bifurcation with the 2nd dominant diagonal without lesions. Distal LAD without lesions. Non-dominant circumflex with moderate ostial atheromatosis. Dominant right coronary artery with diffuse mild atheromatosis. Study superimposable to the previous one in 2013.   CLINICAL EVOLUTION Given the chest pain with elevated troponin T hs and semiological data compatible with decompensation of heart failure
column76: depletive treatment with intravenous furosemide was started in the emergency department
column77: obtaining a favourable response and subsequently allowing the patient to be started on drugs for ventricular dysfunction. On the other hand
column78: in view of the patient's tachycardia
column79: the pacemaker was interrogated
column80: confirming a pacemaker-mediated tachycardia
column81: which was resolved after extending the post-ventricular atrial refractory period. A new transthoracic echocardiogram showed a non-dilated left ventricle with moderate hypertrophy
column82: alterations of segmental contractility: global hypokinesia and apical
column83: inferior and inferolateral inferoseptal akinesia with severely depressed systolic function (LVEF 33%). The aortic valve was severely calcified
column84: with the following additional data: AVA 0.48 cm2 (0.26 cm2/m2)
column85: peak/average gradients of 87/52 mmHg
column86: peak velocity of 4.7 m/s and an integral ratio of 0.12
column87: all compatible with severe-critical aortic stenosis. In addition
column88: the tricuspid valve exhibited mild insufficiency allowing an estimated pulmonary arterial systolic pressure of 63 mmHg. Given the previous findings
column89: coronary angiography was performed and showed non-significant coronary lesions. The case was discussed in a medical-surgical session and transcatheter valve implantation via the femoral artery (TAVI) was chosen. In addition
column90: the possibility of urgent percutaneous valvotomy was considered if the patient's situation required it at some point during admission. However
column91: the patient evolved favourably and was discharged pending completion of the outpatient TAVI study.   DIAGNOSIS Severe symptomatic aortic stenosis. Pacemaker-mediated tachycardia. Decompensation of heart failure secondary to previous. Acute myocardial infarction without type II ST elevation within the prior. Severe left ventricular systolic dysfunction. Severe pulmonary hypertension. Acute renal failure. Mild hyponatraemia. Nodule in the left upper lobe of about 11 mm with central calcification probably corresponding to previous granuloma. Laminar bibasal atelectasis. Echocardiography: left ventricle with extensive apical aneurysm and pseudoaneurysm. Contained cardiac rupture. LVEF 15%. On the Cardiology ward: Echocardiography (26/12/14): dilated left ventricle with thinned apical region
column71: akinetic and expanded (apical aneurysm). Neocavity at the level of the anterolateral apical region communicating with the left ventricle with a neck of 12 mm and a diameter of 5x3 cm
column72: contained by pericardium with flow passage
column73: compatible with pseudoaneurysm on apical aneurysm. Ejection fraction very severely depressed by visual estimation. Normal left atrium. Right ventricle with normal diameter
column74: walls and ejection fraction. Normal right atrium. Mitral valve with good opening and mild/moderate secondary mitral insufficiency. Aortic valve without significant structural or functional alterations. Right valves without significant structural or functional alterations. Inferolateral pericardial detachment in the peri-pseudoaneurysm area. Inferior cava not dilated with preserved inspiratory collapse  On the Cardiovascular Surgery Ward: Preoperative blood count: haemoglobin 13.4 g/dl
column75: leucocytes 10.4x10 3/L
column76: platelets 384000. Urea 49 mg/dl
column77: creatinine 1 mg/dl
column78: Pro BPN 290. Normal coagulation. Control after surgery: haemoglobin 9.9

column80: anterior and lateral mid-segment with increased echogenicity in endocardial area suggestive of Dacron patch; thickening and increased echogenicity of apical parietal pericardium. column81: around 35-40% by visual estimation. Simpson biplane of 38%
column82: filling pattern suggestive of impaired relaxation. Normal left atrium and right chambers. Left and right valves without significant structural or functional alterations. Aortic root and ascending aorta slightly dilated. Absence of pericardial effusion. Normal inferior vena cava.  EVOLUTION The patient started on 14th November at 23:00 hours with oppressive central thoracic pain radiating to the left arm with sweating. The patient remained at home and decided not to consult the doctor because he did not attach any importance to the situation. After spending the whole night with pain and persisting with the same on the morning of the 15th he decided to go to his reference hospital
column83: where on arrival an ECG was performed (15/11/14 described in complementary tests). STEMI was detected and primary PCI was decided. On the cardiology ward
column84: the patient evolved favourably and a TSH of 9 was discovered
column85: so levothyroxine was increased. Given the good evolution
column86: the patient was discharged with a diagnosis of: Anterior STEMI treated with primary angioplasty and implantation of a stent in the mid LAD. Severe ventricular dysfunction.  Pharmacological treatment on discharge from the Cardiology ward (22/11/14): Usual medication for benign prostatic hypertrophy and dyspepsia. Acetylsalicylic acid: 100 mg
column87: 1 tablet at noon. Clopidogrel 75 mg
column88: 1 tablet at breakfast. Omeprazole 20 mg
column89: 1 tablet at breakfast. Levothyroxine 75 mcg
column90: 1 tablet at breakfast. Ramipril 2.5 mg
column91: half a tablet at dinner. Furosemide 40 mg
column92: half a tablet at breakfast. Eplerenone 25 mg
column93: 1 tablet at midday. Atorvastatin 80 mg
column94: 1 tablet at dinner.  It was decided not to introduce beta-blockers due to asthmatic bronchitis.  The patient came to the emergency department on 11 December due to the onset of chest pain of atypical characteristics lasting hours and exacerbating with respiratory movements. No clinical signs of decompensation of heart failure. The analytical tests performed and the ECG were similar to those on discharge from hospital and the pain subsided with the usual intravenous analgesia (paracetamol
column95: metamizole)
column96: so he was discharged from the emergency department. He returned to the ED on 16 December due to recurrence of atypical chest pain
column97: which caused shortness of breath
column98: increasing with inspiration and lasting for hours
column99: as well as symptoms compatible with heart failure (dyspnoea on minimal exertion
column100: orthopnoea and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea). He also reported cough with whitish expectoration without thermometric fever.  Pneumonia was suspected in the emergency department and he was admitted to Internal Medicine with a diagnosis of pneumonia.  During admission to Internal Medicine
column101: complementary tests were carried out which revealed a pseudoaneurysm on apical aneurysm and so he was referred to a referral hospital with Cardiac Surgery
column102: being admitted under the care of Cardiology. The patient was presented at the medical-surgical session where he was finally accepted for surgery and underwent surgery on 30 December. He had occasional chest pain with pleuro-pericardial characteristics and clopidogrel was withdrawn 5 days prior to surgery. Surgery was performed: resection of the ventricular aneurysm by means of a central incision and implantation of a Dacron patch. The patch was covered with the walls of the pseudoaneurysm
column103: which was reinforced with three Teflon strips
column104: with no intraoperative incidents. During his stay on the Cardiac Surgery ward
column105: he evolved favourably
column106: starting to ambulate
column107: with no signs of decompensated heart failure
column108: and was discharged on 13/01/15.  Pharmacological treatment on discharge from the Cardiovascular Surgery ward (13/01/15): Usual medication for benign prostatic hypertrophy
column109: dyspepsia and hypothyroidism same. Aspirin 100 mg
column117: at breakfast.
