column1: Personal history The patient is a 53-year-old male
column2: with no drug allergies. Type 2 diabetes mellitus of 3 years of evolution
column3: treated with oral antidiabetics with good control
column4: without other classic cardiovascular risk factors. Depressive syndrome under pharmacological treatment  In August 2014 (4 months prior to admission to the emergency department) he underwent an outpatient study in Internal Medicine due to asthenia
column5: anorexia and weight loss with splenomegaly and Raynaud's
column6: positive ANAs 1/640 with homogeneous nucleolar pattern and positive aniScl 70; a diagnosis of systemic sclerosis was established and immunosuppressant treatment
column7: haemorrheological treatment and calcium antagonists were started.  The patient continues chronic treatment with methotrexate 15 mg every 24 hours
column8: pentoxifylline 400 mg every 24 hours
column9: diltiazem 60 mg every 8 hours
column10: calcium folinate 15 mg every 24 hours
column11: omeprazole 20 mg every 24 hours
column12: glimepiride 2 mg every 24 hours and desvenlafaxine 50 mg every 24 hours.  Current illness 48 hours prior to his arrival at the ED
column13: the patient reported marked asthenia and dyspnoea on minimal exertion
column14: for which he discontinued diltiazem on the recommendation of his primary care physician. Despite this
column15: his symptoms persisted and his dyspnoea even worsened the following morning
column16: so his family called 112 and he was attended at home by the SAMU who performed an electrocardiogram (ECG) which revealed complete atrioventricular block (AVB) with wide QRS escape at 30x ́
column17: deciding on superficial sedation
column18: implantation of a transcutaneous pacemaker and transfer to the Emergency Department of our centre.  He denied any other symptoms of heart failure
column19: fever or other symptoms of interest. On arrival at the ED
column20: a new ECG showed complete AVB with wide QRS leakage alternating with transcutaneous MCP rhythm in command mode with no capture failures
column21: and on telemetry
column22: asymptomatic
column23: self-limited bouts of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia of the torsades de pointes type. Urgent admission to the Coronary Unit was decided.  Physical examination in the emergency department Blood pressure: 170/90 mmHg. Heart rate 65 beats per minute with transcutaneous MCP. To 36.2 °C. Sat O2 96% with oxygen goggles at 2 litres per minute. Dark complexion
column24: microstomia
column25: sclerodermic skin on trunk and hands
column26: no telangiectasias
column27: no ulcers
column28: no calcinosis lesions
column29: no tendon rubbing. Complete normal neurological examination. No jugular ingurgitation. Carotid auscultation: no murmurs cardiac auscultation: rhythmic heart sounds without murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation: bilateral dry crackles predominantly in the basal and lateral areas. Abdomen: soft
column31: non-painful
column32: with palpable splenomegaly. Upper limbs: symmetrical peripheral pulses. Lower limbs: no oedema or signs of deep vein thrombosis
column33: with symmetrical pulses.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS During admission: Biochemistry: basal glycaemia 95 mg/dL
column34: urea 55 --> 76 --> 128 --> 160 --> 159 --> 212 --> 212 mg/dL; creatinine 1.97 --> 2.36 --> 3.7 --> 4.52 --> 5.16 --> 7.08 mg/dL; estimated glomerular filtration rate 30 --> 25 --> 21--> 14 --> 12 --> 8 mL/min; sodium ion 132 mmol/L; potassium ion 4.1 mmol/L; creatine kinase 160 --> 140 --> 182 U/L; troponin T 320 --> 370 --> 486 ng/L (cut-off point: 35 ng/L); NT ProBNP 70000; liver function tests normal; albumin 33 g/l; total cholesterol 145 mg/dL; LDL 89; HDL 29; TAG 132; HbA1c 6.5. Thyroid hormones normal. Arterial blood gases: (on admission) pH 7.48

column37: pO2 55

column40: pO2 67 PCO2 35
column41: HCO3 29. CBC: Hb 12.6 --> 11.5 --> 10 --> 12 g/dl (elevated RDW)
column43: TTPA 34.5 sec
column44: fibrinogen 530 mg/d. Immunoglobulins: Ig G: 17
column46: Ig A: 2
column48: Ig M: 3
column53: 18. Autoimmunity: ANA: positive 1/640
column54: homogeneous nucleolar pattern. Anti MPO
column55: Anti MBG

column57: SSA/Ro52
column58: SSB

column61: HCV
column62: HIV: negative. Urine sediment and urine system: pH 5.5
column63: density 1008
column64: protein 1+
column65: blood 2+ (50 red blood cells/field)
column66: rest negative.  Urine electrophoresis: electrophoretic profile of mixed proteinuria: tubular and minor non-selective glomerular proteinuria.  Urine immunofixation: no monoclonal component observed. ECG (prior to the event
column67: at the Internal Medicine consultation): sinus rhythm at 60 beats per minute
column68: with left anterior hemiblock and incomplete right bundle branch block. ECG (SA MU at home): complete atrioventricular block with wide QRS leak at 20 bpm. ECG (ED): Complete AVB with wide QRS escape alternating with transcutaneous MCP rhythm at command without capture failure. Telemetry (ED): bouts of polymorphic torsades de pointes-like ventricular tachycardia
column69: self-limited. ECG (post definitive MCP): sinus tachycardia at 112 bpm with ventricular pacing by MCP with self-paced monitoring. Chest X-ray (on admission): increased cardiothoracic index with vascular redistribution and bilateral diffuse interstitial predominance pattern. Provisional MCP electrode in normal position in the RV.  Chest X-ray (during the episode of PAD): increased cardiothoracic index with bilateral diffuse alveolar pattern
column70: predominantly right and more marked at the perihilar level
column71: compatible with PAD. MCP generator with right atrial and ventricular electrode normally positioned.  Chest X-ray (4 days after admission
column72: 48 hours post-PAE): increased cardiothoracic index with great improvement in the diffuse alveolar pattern
column73: but interstitial pattern with vascular redistribution persists. MCP generator with normopositioned right atrial and ventricular electrode. Transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE): LV of normal size and thickness
column74: with mildly impaired systolic function. Prolonged diastolic relaxation pattern. Severe hypokinesia of mid and apical septal segments. RV of normal size and systolic function. Mitral valve with thickened leaflets
column75: with moderate insufficiency. Tricuspid valve with mild insufficiency. Estimated PSAP of 37 mmHg. Aortic root of normal size. No pericardial effusion.  Abdominal echo: homogeneous splenomegaly of 15 cm in length without other alterations.  Chest CT scan: bicameral pacemaker.  Cardiomegaly. Increase in the calibre of the pulmonary artery compatible with pulmonary hypertension. Increased density in "ground glass" with predominance in posterior segments of both lung fields compatible with pulmonary oedema over underlying pulmonary fibrosis. Calcified mediastinal and bilateral hilar calcified adenopathies of chronic inflammatory character. Coronary angiography: epicardial coronary arteries without significant angiographic stenosis. Left dominance with CD of scarce development and course.  Renal biopsy: marked interstitial fibrosis in 40% of the sample. Tubular atrophy with thickening and folding of the tubular basement membrane. No interstitial inflammatory infiltrate. Medium-sized arteries show marked intimal thickening
column76: with deposition of mucinous material in the intima. Arterioles with media proliferation with severe luminal involvement (90% of arteries). No fibrin thrombi or fibrinoid necrosis. 20 glomeruli were studied
column77: in all of them there was retraction of the ball
column78: with an increase in Bowman's space
column79: folding of the glomerular capillary walls and 2 glomeruli with small aneurysms. No necrotising lesions. Immunofluorescence: C1q: (-)
column80: C3: (+) focal mesangial granular
column82: IgA: (-)
column83: IgG: (-)
column84: IgM:(-)
column85: albumin: (+) in tubular basement membranes and Bowman's capsule
column86: fibrinogen: (-) kappa and lambda light chains:(-).  Summary: tubulointerstitial nephropathy with severe involvement and secondary vascular changes.  EVOLUTION The patient was admitted to the coronary unit where a provisional pacemaker was implanted via the right jugular vein
column87: maintaining the MCP rhythm in a command regime and without any new rhythm alterations being observed in the telemetry. Haemodynamically stable with normal baseline blood gases and BP 160/90
column88: amlodipine 5 mg/12h was added to the usual treatment (without diltiazem). Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) showed a non-dilated LV with severe hypokinesia of the middle and apical septal segments
column89: slightly impaired systolic function
column90: prolonged relaxation with non-high filling pressures
column91: right chambers of normal size and function
column92: mitral insufficiency grade II/IV and PSAP 37+PVC. The following morning
column93: DDDR definitive MCP was implanted
column94: being in MCP rhythm on command and with no new pathological findings on monitoring
column95: but BP 160/95 persisted despite treatment with amlodipine 10 mg/12h and doxazosin 8 mg/24h in a patient with no known chronic hypertension and with elevated renal function figures since admission. On the afternoon of the implant
column96: the patient began sudden dyspnoea with BP 220/130 in a situation of radiological APE with bilateral pleural effusion
column97: respiratory acidosis with global respiratory failure requiring the start of non-invasive ventilation with BIPAP
column98: intensive diuretic treatment
column99: intravenous nitrates and combination with full-dose antihypertensive drugs (amlodipine
column100: doxazosin); ACE inhibitors were not started due to renal dysfunction. A new emergent TTE was performed
column101: which showed the previous findings. After 8 hours of treatment
column102: there was a clear clinical
column103: radiological and blood gas improvement
column104: so non-invasive ventilation was withdrawn and diuretic treatment was reduced; however
column105: persistently high BP levels persisted despite high-dose IV NTG and full doses of amlodipine and doxazosin; and the deterioration of renal function with proteinuria and haematuria was increasing
column106: although with negative balances
column107: accompanied by plateletopenia and anaemia with reticulocytosis. Again 72 hours after the episode of PAD
column108: he suffered a new crisis of dyspnoea accompanied by a hypertensive crisis with figures of 190/100 with worsening renal function and oliguria. At this point
column109: taking into account the patient's history and the complementary tests (see section on complementary tests)
column111: which was later confirmed with definitive diagnostic tests. Specific treatment was prescribed
column112: with improvement of the respiratory symptoms and control of BP levels. However
column113: the deterioration of renal function was persistent and progressive
column114: requiring a right femoral catheter for haemodialysis. Subsequently
column115: a renal biopsy was performed which revealed tubulointerstitial nephropathy and vascular involvement that led to stage V renal disease with the need for renal replacement therapy. A right jugular tunnelled catheter was placed and the patient was discharged home (day 58 since admission) on an outpatient chronic haemodialysis programme. Subsequent outpatient evolution was very unfavourable and despite specific treatment and haemodialysis first every 48 hours and then daily
column116: the patient died two months later.  DIAGNOSIS Diffuse systemic sclerosis with scleroderma renal crisis. Pulmonary fibrosis 2nd to pulmonary involvement of diffuse systemic sclerosis. Complete atrioventricular block

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION 57-year-old woman with a history of hypertension
column3: diabetes mellitus and chronic atrial fibrillation. She has had a mitral valve prosthesis for six months (surgery at a private centre in March 2014) due to a double rheumatic mitral lesion with severe mitral regurgitation (MR). The preoperative echocardiogram also showed a moderate double aortic lesion
column4: moderate pulmonary hypertension and non-dilated left ventricle with preserved systolic function. On chronic treatment with aldocumar
column5: digoxin
column6: metformin/vildagliptin
column7: carvedilol
column8: spironolactone
column9: escitalopram and furosemide. She was referred from a private clinic for progressive dyspnoea in the last three weeks to the point of minimal effort
column10: two-pillow orthopnoea and episodes of paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea. She has not presented chest pain or other associated symptoms. No infectious episodes since surgery
column11: fever or febrile fever. No recent invasive dental or surgical procedures.  On examination she had: ʟʟ BP: 108/74 mmHg. hR: 94 bpm. ʟʟʟ Ta: 36 °C. ʟʟʟ Cardiac auscultation: arrhythmic
column12: with presence of mitral click
column13: systolic murmur in aortic focus IV/VI and systolic murmur in tricuspid focus. pulmonary auscultation: crepitant sounds in both bases. No other relevant findings.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG: atrial fibrillation at 93 beats per minute
column14: with evidence of systolic overload. Blood tests: haemogram within the normal range
column15: biochemistry and renal and hepatic function parameters without alterations
column16: INR 1.9. There was a discrete mobilisation of myocardial damage markers in plateau (troponin I 1.9-1.7 ng/mL); NT-ProBNP 20528
column17: HbA1C 8.6% and ESR 25. Blood cultures were negative in two independent determinations. Chest X-ray on admission: mitral valve prosthesis and reinforcement of the peribronchovascular mesh
column18: with no other significant findings. Initial transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) and serial transesophageal echocardiograms (TEE). Initial TTE: left ventricle slightly hypertrophic
column19: dilated (VTD 154/ VTS 115 ml)
column20: with severe depression of LVEF (by Simpson 25%). Global hypokinesia. MAPSE 8 mm. Mitral filling pattern with single E wave. Dilated LA
column21: AP diameter 68 mm
column22: area 48 cm2. Sclerocalcified aortic valve
column23: with limited opening (M-mode 0.8). Double aortic lesion
column24: both of which appear moderate. Maximum gradient 33
column25: mean 21.5 mmHg; IVT AVAo of 0.9 cm2 (LVOT diameter 18 mm)
column26: with low systolic volume (47 mL). Moderate aortic insufficiency. Mechanical mitral prosthesis with correct opening of both hemidiscs. Maximum velocity 2 cm/s. No significant leaks. Right ventricle with DTD in apical 4C of 40 mm at basal level
column27: midventricular of 31 mm. TAPSE of 10 mm. S" wave 5 cm/s. Dilated RA. Moderate TR. RV-AD gradient of 45 mmHg. IP trivial. Transpulmonary acceleration time 85 ms. Dilated IVC (20 mm) that does not collapse with inspiration. No pericardial effusion. ETE 1: FEVI <20%. Preserved mitral prosthetic opening
column28: maximum velocity 1.7 m/s. Mild periprosthetic leak. Images on mitral annulus of morphology and density compatible with thrombotic tamponade and less probably pannus. Image on ventricular side of prosthetic annulus interposed between disc and annulus
column29: causing mild insufficiency. Dense spontaneous contrast effect in LA and left atrial appendage. Image in the LA roof at the mouth of the left pulmonary veins showing thrombus. Calcified trivalve aortic valve
column30: with severely reduced opening but could be due to reduced transvalvular volume (VAo planimetry 0.7 cm2). Aortic annulus 19 mm. Ascending aorta 31 mm. Dilated RV
column31: tricuspid annulus 45 mm. Moderate TR. No intracardiac shunts. TEE 2: partial resolution of the echodense image around the mitral prosthetic ring. It presents two mobile images: the largest (13x9 mm) anchored in the anterior annulus
column32: retroaortic
column33: low echogenicity
column34: deflected
column35: which prolapses in diastole through the annulus. The smallest in the posterior annulus (4 mm). Compatible in this context with evolution to residual hypermobile thrombus as first option. No periprosthetic insufficiencies. Image compatible with fixed mural thrombus at the entrance of the left atrial appendage. Significant smoke effect in the entire atrium. There is still a mural echodense image at the bottom of the left atrium in relation to the origin of the right pulmonary vein described in the previous study. TEE 3: large echodense image in the atrial side of the mitral prosthesis that generates complete blockage of the anterior prosthetic disc
column36: with transprosthetic gradients: maximum 8.1 and average 3.8 mmHg. Significant smoke effect in the left atrium and in the atrial appendage
column37: the latter presenting an image suggestive of upholstery on its lateral wall. Coronary angiography: non-significant stenosis in the ostial trunk
column38: around 30%. The rest of the coronary arteries had no lesions.  EVOLUTION Patient with the aforementioned history
column39: with a mitral prosthesis for six months
column40: admitted for heart failure. Diuretic treatment was started with a good response and systolic function and valve functionality were re-evaluated. Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) showed severe left ventricular systolic dysfunction with a normally functioning mitral prosthesis and moderate-severe aortic stenosis. In evaluation with transesophageal echocardiography (TEE)
column41: an image compatible with intraventricular thrombus lining the mitral annulus was observed and treatment with sodium heparin and ASA was started. Subsequent echographic controls showed an increase in its size
column42: which came to block the anterior prosthetic disc despite APTT in the appropriate range. Blood cultures were taken and were negative in serial determinations. The patient was stable and afebrile
column43: in good general condition and ambulating around the ward
column44: with no evidence of heart failure. On the tenth day of admission
column45: she presented acute pain in the right lower limb
column46: with a sensation of paraesthesia and distal pallor and echo-Doppler data of acute ischaemia of the right lower limb. Urgent transfemoral embolectomy of the right external iliac artery was performed
column47: with recovery of distal pulses and triphasic Doppler flow on leaving the operating theatre. With the diagnosis of suspected prosthetic thrombosis with poor evolution complicated by peripheral embolism
column48: urgent surgery was requested on prosthetic mitral valve and aortic valve replacement
column49: as the patient met the criteria for this. Surgical cleaning of the mitral prosthesis was carried out
column50: which was found to be covered and partially blocked by a mass that appeared to be a large thrombus
column51: and sent to the microbiology laboratory for analysis. The aortic valve was also replaced with a metallic prosthesis. The patient was admitted to the resuscitation unit sedated
column52: haemodynamically stable and respiratory stable with invasive mechanical ventilation. Eight hours after admission to the unit
column53: a positive result was reported for Aspergillus in the septifast of the "mitral valve thrombus"
column54: so treatment was started with amphotericin B and voriconazole and the case was re-evaluated
column55: and a new urgent surgery was scheduled for removal of the mitral prosthesis. Intracardiac cleaning with amphotericin B and implantation of a new mechanical prosthesis was performed without complications during the procedure. Adequate stabilisation was achieved with suspension of vasoactive agents and extubation was performed after 48 hours
column56: with good tolerance.  Five days after surgery
column57: the patient had decreased visual acuity in the right eye. On neurological examination she presented right homonymous haemianopsia on threat examination
column58: with no other alterations. An urgent cranial CT scan was performed
column59: which revealed a 2.5 cm cystic lesion in the left occipital lobe with adjacent oedema compatible
column60: in the clinical context of the patient
column61: with aspergilloma (figure 1). Overall
column62: the picture is labelled as a stroke in the left posterior cerebral artery territory with a haemorrhagic/infectious component probably related to septic embolus due to Aspergillus. Once the need for neurosurgical intervention was dismissed
column63: antifungal coverage was extended with caspofungin. One week postoperatively
column64: he presented a sudden clinical deterioration with acute respiratory failure requiring invasive mechanical ventilation and intense haemodynamic instability requiring high-dose amine support. Urgent TEE was requested
column65: which showed severe depression of global LV contractility without segmental alterations and normofunctioning prosthetic valves
column66: without definitive data of pulmonary thromboembolism. Finally
column67: exitus was triggered by electromechanical dissociation despite advanced cardiopulmonary resuscitation measures.  Subsequent analysis of the valve revealed the presence of a dense
column68: partially thrombosed structure anchored to the prosthetic disc
column69: composed of thick septate and branched mycelia
column70: compatible with aspergilloma. Aspergillus fumigatus grew in the culture of this mass.  DIAGNOSIS Fungal endocarditis on prosthetic mitral valve
column71: complicated by: Prosthetic valve block. Peripheral embolism with acute ischaemia of the right lower limb
column72: requiring urgent embolectomy. Stroke in left posterior cerebral artery territory of probable septic origin (aspergilloma). Cardiogenic shock
column73: electromechanical dissociation. column1: Background A 37-year-old man of South American origin who had been living in Spain for 5 years. No drug allergies. Active life. No cardiovascular risk factors. No toxic habits. No family history of cardiomyopathy or other hereditary diseases. No relevant medical-surgical history.  Current illness The patient came to the Cardiology department referred by his company doctor after a routine medical examination revealed striking electrocardiographic alterations. He reported only sporadic episodes of regular palpitations of short duration (2-3 minutes) unrelated to exertion that subsided spontaneously
column2: with a weekly frequency. She denies chest pain or dyspnoea. She has not presented syncope.  Physical examination Good general condition. BP: 110/60 mmHg. HR: 60 bpm. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic
column3: fixed splitting of the second sound. No murmurs or extratonos. Pulmonary auscultation: preserved vesicular murmur without rales. Abdomen: soft and depressible
column4: not painful on palpation
column5: no masses or organomegaly. Lower limbs: no oedema. Symmetrical paedial pulses.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG: sinus rhythm at 60 bpm
column6: first-degree atrioventricular block (PR 210 ms)
column7: complete right bundle branch block and left anterior hemiblock
column8: convex ST-segment elevation and T-wave inversion in precordial leads. 24-hour Holter: no supra- or ventricular arrhythmias were detected. No evidence of advanced atrioventricular block. Laboratory tests: glucose 98 mg/dL
column9: urea 32 mg/dL
column10: creatinine 0.86 mg/dL (CrCl 110 ml/ min/1.73 m2 -CKD-EPI)
column11: sodium 143 mEq/L
column12: potassium 4 mEq/L
column13: NT-proBNP 102 pg/ml
column14: CK 387 ng/ml
column15: CK-MB 9.8 ng/ml
column16: TnT 0.01
column17: haemoglobin 14 g/dL
column18: haematocrit 45%
column19: MCV 85 fL
column20: leucocytes 7980 /mm3
column21: platelets 270000 /mm3
column22: INR: 0
column23: 9. Chest X-ray: normal cardiothoracic index
column24: no pulmonary infiltrates
column25: free costophrenic sinuses
column26: normal mediastinum. Transthoracic echocardiography: LV slightly dilated (LVEDD indexed by CS of 3.3 cm/m2) with normal wall thickness. No alterations in segmental contractility. LVEF 52%. Transmitral Doppler filling pattern of impaired relaxation. RV of normal dimensions with systolic function by longitudinal parameters at the lower limit of normality. Cardiac MRI: minimal dilatation of both ventricles (LVEDV 181/VTSVI 96 ml) with slightly depressed biventricular systolic function (LVEF 50%). The late enhancement sequence showed multiple foci of transmural enhancement with patchy distribution of septal
column27: basal lateral and apical predominance suggestive of fibrosis.  EVOLUTION Taking into account that the patient came from a Chagas disease endemic area
column28: serological tests were performed to detect circulating antibodies against Trypanosoma cruzi: both were positive (ELISA 8 and immunofluorescence >1/160)
column29: confirming the diagnosis of chronic infection by this parasite. Oesophagogastric barium transit and abdominal radiography were also performed and ruled out gastrointestinal involvement. The patient was diagnosed with chronic chagasic cardiomyopathy (CCM) based on the results of serology
column31: transthoracic echocardiogram and cardiac MRI; and treatment with benznidazole 100 mg/8h for two months was indicated and completed with good tolerance. Ten months after diagnosis
column32: the patient died suddenly while playing tennis. He was attended by the emergency services who detected asystole as the first rhythm on arrival. Advanced CPR manoeuvres were unsuccessful and the patient finally died. As death occurred in an out-of-hospital environment
column33: a forensic autopsy was performed. Macroscopic and microscopic examination of the heart confirmed the characteristic involvement of CCM.  DIAGNOSIS Chronic chagasic cardiomyopathy. Dilatation and mild biventricular systolic dysfunction with transmural patchy LV fibrosis. Sudden cardiac death. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Personal history We present the case of a patient who consulted for dyspnoea. She was a 69-year-old woman with no adverse drug reactions and type 2 diabetic on treatment with metformin 850 mg and slow insulin 20 units per day. She had no known previous heart or lung disease. She is in a baseline NYHA I condition. He is not limited in physical activity. Present illness For the last week he has been experiencing dyspnoea on moderate exertion. He refers to going out for walks without being able to follow his usual rhythm. Since the day before admission
column2: he has had episodes of nausea
column3: sweating and dizziness with a worsening of the degree of dyspnoea
column4: for which he decides to consult the doctor.  Physical examination BP: 150/72. HR: 91 bpm. Ta afebrile. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic tones. II/VI murmur in aortic focus with 4s. Pulmonary auscultation: teleinspiratory crackles in lung bases. Abdomen: soft and depressible
column5: non-painful on palpation
column6: with no palpable masses or megaliths. Lower limbs: Minimal oedema in the lower limbs.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Complementary examinations in the emergency department: ECG: RS at 75lpm. PR 160ms. Narrow QRS at 60 bpm. QS in V1-2. Negative T wave in V5-6. Low voltages in limb leads. No changes in serial ECG. Urgent CBC: glucose 263 mg/dL; urea 39 mg/dL; creatinine 0.55 mg/dL; sodium 140 mEq/L; K+ 4.0 mEq/L; haemoglobin 14.8 g/dL; haematocrit 42.5%; MCV 89.3 fL; platelets 217.0 10e3/uL; leucocytes 8.47 10e3/uL; INR 1.03; NT-proBNP 4806.0 pg/ mL; serial cardiac enzymes CK 1 247.0; CKMB 1 12.0; troponin T 1: 163.0 pg/ml; CK 2 226.0; CKMB 2 12.0; troponin T 2 168.0 pg/ml; Chest X-ray: cardiomegaly. Congestive hilae. Minimal alveolar infiltrates in lung bases.  Complementary examinations in hospital: Echocardiography: left ventricle of reduced internal dimensions. Concentric hypertrophy. LVEF of 55-60%. Pseudonormal mitral filling pattern. Reduced mitral annulus velocities by DTI that together with a global strain (2D) suggests a study compatible with infiltrative cardiomyopathy. Mild infero-posterior hypokinesia and basal septum. Non-dilated right ventricle with mild hypertrophy and preserved contractility. Dilated left atrium. Normal sized right atrium. Mild mitral insufficiency - mild tricuspid insufficiency allowing an estimated PSAP of 55-60 mmHg. Slightly thickened aortic valve with normal dynamics. Normal pulmonary valve. Inferior vena cava 19 mm with absence of inspiratory collapse. Global pericardial effusion of severe posterolateral predominance. Phasic respiratory filling changes in atrioventricular patterns. Partial collapse of the right atrium. Conclusion: study suggestive of infiltrative cardiomyopathy. LVH with LVEF 55-60%. Severe pericardial effusion. Moderate-severe pulmonary hypertension. ECG: sinus pause with nodal escape rhythm at 40 bpm with narrow QRS
column7: low voltage in frontal leads with flattened repolarisation. Cardiac MRI: biventricular concentric hypertrophy with normal volumes and no contractility alterations. Preserved biventricular systolic function. Severe dilatation of the LA. Diffuse pericardial effusion up to 24 mm thick
column8: lateral to the LV
column9: without haemodynamic repercussions. After administration of gadolinium
column10: there was no adequate suppression of the myocardial signal; it was suboptimally suppressed with T1 at 160 ms (lower than usual in healthy patients) and then there was diffuse patchy mesocardial enhancement in both ventricles. These findings are suggestive of infiltrative cardiomyopathy
column11: including amyloid cardiomyopathy. Coronary angiography: right femoral access. Coronary arteries without significant lesions. Direct Coomb test: negative. Negative irregular antibodies. Thyroid hormones: T4L: 1.11 ng/dl
column12: TSH: 0.756 IUI/ml. Bone marrow aspirate: normocellular marrow. Megakaryocytes present
column13: normal in number and morphology. Infiltration by 23% of small-sized atypical plasma cells with eccentric nucleus without visible nucleolus
column14: moderate cytoplasm without inclusions. No atypical cells are observed in SP. Flow cytometry: CMF 4.37% of the total number of MO cells. Of these
column15: 96.0% show an aberrant/pathological phenotype CD45+weak CD38++ CD138+ CD138+ CD56+ CD27+- weak CD28+ CD19- CD20- CD117+ and monoclonal IgCit of Kappa type
column16: no expression of IgG
column17: IgA or IgM heavy chains is detected
column18: a phenotype compatible with plasma cell dyscrasia of the Kappa light chain secreting myeloma type. Quantification of immunoglobulins: IgG: 693
column19: IgA: 199
column20: IgM: 28
column21: IgD: <23.IEF in blood: Bence-Jones Kappa protein. Free Kappa chains in serum: 1110 mgr/l
column22: free Lambda chains in serum: 34.6 mg/l. Kappa/Lambda ratio: 32. Urine FEF: Bence-Jones positive. Bence-Jones Kappa protein. Free chains Kappa urine 24 hours 222 mg
column23: free chains Lambda urine 24 hours 4.77. ANOE S: anti-parietal G-cell antibodies: positive 1/640. Anti-intrinsic factor antibodies negative. Gastric ATPase positive. ANCAS negative. Oncological bone series: lytic lesions in the skull. Virus serology: HBV negative
column24: HCV negative
column25: CMV: IgG positive. Weak positive IgM. Cardiac biopsy: macroscopic description: five muscle fragments of 0.2- 0.3 cm. Microscopic description: endomyocardial biopsy fragments showing an acellular interstitial deposit atrophying myocytes
column26: sometimes also around vessels in a cracked form. The deposit stains faintly for Masson
column27: not deep blue in areas somewhat purplish. In the posterior slice for Congo-red the sample is very poorly represented and in polarised light only occasionally appears to refract in apple green
column28: which given the clinical data
column29: the pattern with haematoxylin eosin and Masson's technique
column31: is highly suggestive of amyloidosis. No iron deposition is identified with Perls technique and no glycogen deposition with Pas. In other focal areas myocytes show mild hypertrophy changes and little chronic non-specific inflammation.  EVOLUTION Evolution in the emergency department: the clinical picture appears to be the first episode of decompensated heart failure
column32: with characteristic elevation of myocardial enzymes (which do not present a curve in their serialisation)
column33: marked elevation of Pro-BNP and ECG showing low voltages in the limb leads. All this suggests possible infiltrative cardiomyopathy. Evolution on the Cardiology ward: the patient was admitted to Cardiology for treatment of heart failure and study of possible infiltrative cardiomyopathy. As it was impossible to rule out acute coronary syndrome
column34: treatment was started with ASA 100 mg a day and clopidogrel 75 mg a day
column35: ACE inhibitors (ramipril 2.5 mg a day) and beta-blockers (bisoprolol 2.5 mg a day). Complementary tests were performed to complete the study. Forty-eight hours after starting treatment
column36: he suffered an episode of dizziness and general malaise. With BP 90/45 mmHg
column37: HR: 39. Sweating
column38: mucocutaneous pallor and distal coldness. AC: arrhythmic
column39: bradycardic. ECG was performed. The patient was transferred to the ICU and after discontinuation of beta-blockers and once reversible acute process had been ruled out
column40: it was decided to implant a permanent pacemaker in DDD mode. 48 hours after pacemaker implantation
column41: the patient suffered cardiorespiratory arrest in the context of ventricular tachycardia that degenerated into ventricular fibrillation
column42: which ended after defibrillation with 150J. Again in the ICU
column43: the MP was questioned and VT spells were observed before the episode of VF. Finally
column44: it was decided to implant an ICD for secondary prevention.  DIAGNOSIS A diagnosis of Kappa BJ K+ ISS:1 stage IIIA light chain multiple myeloma with primary amyloidosis (AL) with cardiac involvement and Mayo Clinic prognostic stage III (score value: 2) was finally made. Treatment was started with velcade-dexamethasone
column45: associated with treatment of heart failure

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION 79-year-old woman
column3: with no known drug allergies
column4: hypertensive on treatment with olmesartan 40 mg and amlodipine 5 mg per day and independent for ABVD. She presented with oppressive chest pain at rest
column5: not radiating or associated with vegetative cortex
column6: of three days' evolution
column7: accompanied by an increase in her usual dyspnoea until it became minimal effort. On examination she was normotensive and afebrile with preserved vesicular murmur and no pathological sounds
column8: rhythmic and without murmurs. There is no oedema. The neurological and abdominal examination was unremarkable. The ECG showed sinus rhythm
column9: with ST-segment depression in V2-V6
column10: DI and aVL (maximum 2 mm in V2)
column11: which partially corrected after becoming asymptomatic (figure 1). First enzyme measurement: ultrasensitive troponin T 1890 ng/L [0-14]
column12: CK 319 U/L [26-167]. Treatment was started with double antiplatelet therapy (ASA and clopidogrel)
column13: low molecular weight heparin
column14: atorvastatin
column15: candesartan and bisoprolol. The patient was admitted to the cardiology department with a diagnosis of STEMI.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Laboratory tests: glucose 98 mg/dl; urea 60 mg/dl
column16: creatinine 1.71 mg/dl; GFR 31 ml/min; sodium 140 mmol/l; potassium 4.7 mmol/l
column17: CK 319 U/L [26-167]; ultrasensitive troponin T 1890 ng/L [0-14]; leukocytes 9.95x103; neutrophils 5.92x103 (59.4%); lymphocytes 1.38x103 (19.9%); monocytes 1.01x103 (10.2%); eosinophils 1.63x103 (16.4%) [normal 0-6]
column18: basophils 0.01x103 (0.1%) Hb 12.5 g/dl; Hto 38.9%; MCV81.7 fl; platelets 61 x 103; leukocytes and eosinophils were as high as 20.950 and 46% respectively. Chest X-ray: CTI< 0.5
column19: no infiltrates. C costophrenic sinuses were free. Echocardiography: LV not dilated
column20: with slightly depressed systolic function and no contractility alterations. Right chambers not dilated with normal systolic function. LA dilated. Impaired relaxation. Mild MI and TR. Coronary angiography: right dominance. Coronary arteries without significant lesions. Cardiac MR and viability: non-dilated LV with slightly depressed LVEF (50%). Apparent thickening of the wall without being able to specify whether it corresponds to cardiac muscle
column21: which is more significant in the lateral wall
column22: with a maximum end-diastolic thickness of 18 mm. In the early study after intravenous gadolinium administration
column23: an area of hyperenhancement was observed in the lower basal segment and hypocaptive foci of subendocardial location on the lateral wall
column24: which could correspond to small thrombi. Dilated LA. Mild MI and TR. Cerebral MRI: multiple ischaemic lesions affecting both cerebral and cerebellar hemispheres. No images suggestive of intraparenchymal bleeding. The ventricular system is symmetrical and of normal calibre. Parasites in stool: negative. Determination of IgE: negative: ECA: 40; ANA negative Hep-2: 1/320; ANCA IFI positive. P-ANCA and c-ANCA negative. Tumour markers: CA 125: 40 [0-35]; Beta-2-microglobulin 3494 [1200-2500]; CYFRA 21-1: 4.4 (0-3.3) IF plasma/orine: absence of monoclonal peaks. ACS. Antiphospholipids: negative. Bone marrow aspirate: flow cytometry: MO with 19% lymphocytes
column25: of which 73% are T lymphocytes and 16% are B lymphocytes. A TCR Beta sequencing study was performed and no clonal population was identified. Cytogenetics: absence of FIP1L/PDGFRRa and PDGFRb mutations. Helminth serology: Strongyloides
column26: Toxocara
column27: Trichinella
column28: Echinococcus
column29: Fasciola negative. Electroencephalogram: marked destructuring and global slowing of brain activity. These findings indicate the existence of moderate to severe diffuse encephalic involvement. Thoracoabdominal CT: no pulmonary thromboembolism was identified in the main lobar or segmental arteries. Bronchiectasis of the anterior segment of the LSI. Discrete thickening of the subpleural interstitium. Two right apical perilymphatic nodules of 4mm are identified
column30: probably corresponding to intrapulmonary lymph nodes. Global cardiomegaly associated with myocardial thickening in the left ventricle up to 21 mm in its lateral aspect. Minimal bilateral laminar pleural effusion. 10 mm prevascular adenopathy with no evidence of other significant mediastinal adenopathy. No significant retroperitoneal adenopathy. Normal liver. Bilateral cortical renal cysts. Uncomplicated digmoid diverticulosis.  EVOLUTION On admission
column31: coronary angiography showed coronary arteries without lesions. Transthoracic echocardiography showed a non-dilated LV with slightly depressed LVEF (51%). Dilated LA. Impaired relaxation. Mild MI and TR. Due to persistent eosinophilia (16-45%) it was decided to request cardiac MRI which was compatible with eosinophilic cardiomyopathy. Ten days after admission the patient had a stroke with left hemiplegia and decreased level of consciousness. Brain MRI showed multiple infarcts in both cerebral and cerebellar hemispheres. Doppler ultrasound of the supra-aortic trunks was normal. A study of hypereosinophilic syndrome was initiated: ANA 1/320; ANCA (+) IFI; no paraproteins were detected in blood or urine. Bone marrow aspirate ruled out eosinophilic leukaemia. Parasitological stool culture was also negative and IgE values were within normal range. Corticotherapy was started with prednisone 60 mg/day (1 mg/kg/day). Given the persistence of hypereosinophilia with systemic repercussions (cardiac and CNS)
column32: treatment was started with bolus methylprednisolone
column33: without response or neurological improvement. Treatment was started with imatinib while awaiting the results of FIP1L/PDGFRa
column34: obtaining a transitory decrease in the levels of eosinophils in the blood. Imatinib was discontinued after a further increase in eosinophils and hydroxyurea was started. He also presented with a polymicrobial infection of a decubitus ulcer
column35: isolating SAMS. A month and a half after admission
column36: he presented with abundant rectorrhagia
column37: for which 2 red blood cell concentrates were transfused and due to the clinical situation it was decided not to perform a colonoscopy. After 48 hours he presented a new episode of rectorrhagia together with a worsening of his general and neurological condition. In consensus with the family
column38: it was decided to start perfusion sedoanalgesia
column39: and the patient died a few days later.  DIAGNOSIS Primary hypersosinophilic syndrome with severe cardiac and neurological involvement Eosinophilic cardiomyopathy Multiple cerebral ischaemic infarcts Renal failure Thrombocytopenia column2: 51 years old. Arterial hypertension. Chronic glaucoma. No known allergies. No toxic habits. On treatment with telmisartan 80 mg/day. Baseline situation: active. Independent for activities of daily living. Dyspnoea on moderate exertion (NHYA II).  Current illness She visits her family doctor for moderate dyspnoea of about 3 months of evolution. Since then she has also presented oedema in the lower limbs. She reported no previous history of chest pain or palpitations. A chest X-ray was performed and in view of the presence of cardiomegaly
column3: preferential assessment in the outpatient cardiology department was requested.  Physical examination BP: 130/90 mmHg HR: 77 bpm SatO2: 98% Head and neck normal. No IY CA: rhythmic
column4: holosystolic murmur II/VI with R2 splitting AP: VCM in both lung fields Abdomen: nondescript LES: oedema with perimalleolar fovea  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG: sinus rhythm at 75 bpm with signs of AD growth
column5: normal PR
column6: wide QRS (150 msec) with morphology of complete right bundle branch block and secondary repolarisation alterations. Echocardiography: severe dilatation of right chambers. Apical displacement of the insertion point of the tricuspid septal leaflet (about 2.5 cm with respect to the plane of the mitral annulus). Massive TR due to lack of leaflet coaptation. Assessment of RV systolic function is difficult but appears to be severely depressed. The pulmonary trunk is of normal size. The pulmonary valve has no abnormalities. The left chambers are small in size and displaced by the right chambers. LV systolic function is visually at the lower limit of normal. The left valves are normal. Mitral filling pattern of impaired relaxation. No ASD (although assessment is difficult)
column7: no other shunts. Normal aortic arch. Slight systemic venous congestion.  EVOLUTION Furosemide 40 mg/day was added to the treatment
column8: and cardiac magnetic resonance was requested for anatomical characterisation and better assessment of RV function. At the 6-month check-up
column9: the patient was asymptomatic. The result of the cardiac MRI was brought in: a study of very poor technical quality (movement artefacts). Dilatation of the right chambers
column10: with apical displacement of the tricuspid leaflets
column11: which do not coapt. Free tricuspid regurgitation. RVEF 43%. No associated malformations are seen. Left ventricle displaced by the right
column12: with preserved ventricular function. Given the improvement in symptoms
column13: it was decided to maintain medical treatment and outpatient monitoring at 6 months with new echocardiography
column14: new MRI and cardiopulmonary stress test.  DIAGNOSIS Mild heart failure on debut Ebstein's anomaly Severe tricuspid regurgitation and mild RV systolic dysfunction |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: CURRENT DISEASE AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION The patient is 55 years old
column3: with no known drug allergies and no known cardiovascular risk factors.  Personal history ʟʟ Previous heart disease: dilated cardiomyopathy due to Chagas disease with severe systolic dysfunction and implantation of a single-chamber ICD in 2007 for primary prevention. Regular follow-up in the arrhythmia unit of our department (during follow-up he presented an episode of SMVT that subsided with ATP
column4: without requiring shock). On 24 March 2015 he was admitted to our department for ICD generator replacement.  Other history: sensory
column5: axonal and demyelinating polyneuropathy of moderate degree in the upper and lower extremities.  Chronic treatment: ramipril 5 mg/24 hours. carvedilol 25 mg/24 hours. Sintrom according to guideline. Present illness Patient referred to the emergency department of his reference hospital after being found at home disoriented
column6: confused and with sphincter incontinence by his work colleagues. They went to look for him as he had not been at work for the last three days. Anamnesis impossible to perform on the patient due to his neurological deterioration.  Physical examination BP: 85/60 mmHg. HR: 85 bpm. RR: 26 rpm. Sat02: 96% with nasal goggles at 2 bpm. NRL: conscious and oriented in space and person. Lethargic. Fluent language without aphasic components. Pupils isochoric and normoreactive. Left facial paresis. Cranial nerves centred. Preserved strength and sensibility in extremities. Preserved ROTs. CA: very muffled cardiac tones
column7: no murmurs. AP: rhonchi in both lung fields. No other superimposed sounds. Abdomen: soft
column8: depressible
column9: not painful on palpation. No masses or megaliths. No signs of peritoneal irritation. MMII: No oedema. Pulses preserved. General: pterygium over the right eye. Ulcer in the wound of the ICD generator in the left subclavian region.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS In the emergency department of the hospital
column10: the study began with the extraction of blood cultures due to fever (38.5 °C)
column11: and the following complementary tests were performed: CBC: 9000 platelets
column13: 400 leukocytes
column14: INR 10
column17: procalcitonin 24.4
column18: creatinine 1.77
column19: total bilirubin 6.2 (at the expense of direct). Chest X-ray: increased CTI
column20: hilar congestion with bilateral nodular images. Cranial CT: hypodensity in right basal ganglia compatible with old lacunar infarcts. Hypodensity in the left parietal convexity compatible with residual ischaemic lesion. No LOES
column21: contusion images or haemorrhage. Ventricular system within normality. Thoracic-abdominal CT scan: in the mediastinum there were small lymph nodes smaller than 1 cm of doubtful pathological significance. Poorly defined nodular densities can be seen in the lung fields. Although cavitation is not seen
column22: in the clinical context of the patient
column23: the possibility of septic emboli should be considered. Elevation of the right hemidiaphragm. Minimal right pleural effusion/enlargement. Abdomen: normal sized liver with no evidence of focal lesions. Bile duct
column24: pancreas
column25: spleen
column26: kidneys and adrenal glands without significant findings. No free fluid or collections were seen. In view of these findings and with clinical suspicion of severe septic shock
column27: noradrenaline perfusion and empirical antibiotic treatment with imipenem and cloxacillin was started
column28: with poor clinical evolution
column29: and the patient was referred to the ICU of our hospital.  On arrival at the ICU
column30: the following tests were performed: CBC: sodium 135
column32: Cl 101
column33: glucose 187
column34: urea 107
column35: creatinine 1.28
column36: CPK 109
column37: total bilirubin 6.19 (direct 5.86
column38: indirect 0.33)
column39: CRP 26
column40: procalcitonin 17.3
column41: Hb 13.1 g/dl
column43: 9000 platelets
column44: 14850 leukocytes
column45: INR 1.53
column46: AP 52%. ECG: RS at 75 bpm. PR 200msg
column47: QRS 80msg with normal axis and low voltages in frontal leads. No acute repolarisation alterations. Transthoracic echocardiography: dilated LV with apical aneurysm and hypokinesia of the remaining segments
column48: causing moderate-severe systolic dysfunction (LVEF 38%). Trivalve aortic valve
column49: without gradients or pathological flows. Mitral valve with mild central insufficiency. Right chambers of normal dimensions with normal systolic function. LAD cable with abundant hyperechogenic material adhered along its trajectory
column50: with independent movement suggestive of vegetation. Transesophageal echocardiogram: This study confirmed the previous findings. During his stay in the ICU
column51: antibiotic treatment with daptomycin was continued
column52: new blood cultures were taken and the device was removed (generator and ICD cable
column53: by traction) after 48 hours
column54: and samples were sent to Microbiology: Blood cultures (x2): isolation of methicillin-resistant S. aureus (resistant to cloxacillin and penicillin). LAD cable: isolation of methicillin-resistant S. aureus.  EVOLUTION In view of these findings
column55: he was assessed by the Infectious Diseases Department
column56: and the positive blood cultures persisted. Antibiotic treatment was adjusted and he was finally placed on vancomycin
column57: fosfomycin and linezolid. In the following days
column58: a repeat chest CT scan confirmed the presence of septic pulmonary emboli
column59: bilateral pleural effusion and associated compressive atelectasis. And the transesophageal echocardiogram was repeated
column60: which showed a mass attached to the posterior tricuspid leaflet measuring 33x18 mm
column61: hypermobile and with anchorage that progressed to the subvalvular apparatus
column62: with another smaller vegetation on the free edge of the septal leaflet. No pulmonary
column63: mitral or aortic valve involvement. Antibiotic treatment was continued in the following weeks
column64: with progressive normalisation of renal and hepatic function parameters
column65: coagulation and inflammatory markers. Cardiac MRI was requested
column66: which confirmed biventricular dilatation with moderate systolic dysfunction and the presence of an apical aneurysm. A new chest CT scan showed resolution of the septic embolisms; and the various echocardiographies performed showed no persistent valve vegetation. Once antibiotic treatment was completed
column67: and the patient remained clinically stable
column68: a new single-chamber ICD was implanted on the contralateral side without incident.  DIAGNOSIS Severe septic shock secondary to infective endocarditis due to methicillin-resistant S. aureus. Dilated cardiomyopathy of chagasic aetiology. Severe systolic dysfunction. ICD carrier in primary prevention. Explant and reimplantation of single-chamber ICD. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION A 31-year-old male patient from Spain
column3: with a history of anxiety disorder
column4: no other pathological history of interest
column5: no known allergies. No current treatment. He came for consultation due to exertional dyspnoea
column6: presyncopal episodes and anxiety symptoms. She was referred to haematology due to an increase in eosinophils in the haemogram.  Examination revealed: Conscious
column7: oriented
column8: alert. Normal language. Normal cranial nerves. Rhythmic heart sounds without murmurs. Bladder murmur preserved without aggregate noises. With palpable splenomegaly 6 centimetres below the left costal ridge. No oedema in the lower limbs. Normal peripheral pulses.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS The analysis showed an increase in eosinophil values. With suspicion of hypereosinophilic syndrome
column9: a new blood test and extension study were requested. Absence of parasitic infection
column10: allergy or pulmonary disease justifying the eosinophilia. Laboratory tests: leucocytes 3.8x10e3/uL (3.5-12)
column11: haemoglobin 11.9 g/dl (13.5-17.2)
column12: platelets 196x10e3/uL. Creatinine 1.32 mg/dl. Peripheral eosinophilia of 5000 elements/mmc. Troponin 0.020 ng/ml (0-0.056). Genetic study: 4q12 deletion associated with FIP1L1-PDFGFRA rearrangement. Echocardiogram: with signs of endomyocardial infiltration. ECG: sinus rhythm at 56 bpm
column13: narrow QRS of normal configuration
column14: 60o axis and transition in V3. Universal negative T waves. Abdominal ultrasound: homogeneous splenomegaly of 17.5 cm. Thoracic CT scan: no pulmonary infiltrates. Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging 1 (MRI 1): restrictive pattern in the right cavities (small ventricle
column15: preserved ejection fraction
column16: atrial dilatation) with apical myocardial fibrosis. Transmural fibrosis in the mid-apical inferolateral wall of the left ventricle. Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging 2 (MRI 2): two hypointense images of crescentic morphology are observed in the apex that could correspond to thrombi. Late enhancement with areas of signal hyperintensity of the RV apex and inferior aspect of the LV apex that have not changed with respect to the previous description. Findings of hypereosinophilia with biventricular restrictive cardiomyopathy. Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging 3 (MRI 3): control. Morphological abnormalities previously described FE 59%
column17: hypointense areas are observed in the apex of both ventricles of linear morphology that probably correspond to fibrosis raising the differential diagnosis with laminar thrombus.  EVOLUTION Treatment was started with imatinib at a dose of 400 mg daily
column18: well tolerated and with a rapid haematological response that allowed a dose reduction to 100 mg daily after 2 months. A control ultrasound scan of the abdomen showed the absence of splenomegaly. Symptom improvement. Subsequently
column19: arterial hypertension was diagnosed. We started treatment with bisoprolol 2.5 mg daily
column20: which we had to discontinue due to intense asthenia. We replaced bisoprolol with olmesartan 10 mg daily with good tolerance and good control. Studies for secondary causes were negative. Cardiac MRI was requested where a restrictive pattern was observed as described in the complementary tests (MRI 1). In the control cardiac MRI (MRI 2) performed at 12 months
column21: we detected images of crescentic morphology at the level of the apex. The images offer a reasonable doubt between laminar thrombi at the apical level versus artefacts. In favour of thrombi is the fact that they are located over the areas of fibrosis detected in the MRI and the high thrombogenicity of this disease
column22: although the fact that they appear in both ventricles suggests that it could also be an artefact. Echocardiography showed no evidence of intracavitary thrombus. We explained the situation to the patient and decided to start anticoagulation with sintrom
column23: which we again had to suspend due to intense asthenia and osteomuscular pain. We raised the possibility of starting treatment with rivaroxaban 20 mg daily
column24: for off-label use. After explaining to the patient that this is not an indication studied in clinical trials or approved by the Ministry
column25: we decided to treat the patient jointly; in the controls he presented good tolerance and disappearance of the symptoms attributed to the synthroid. In the control MRI (MRI 3)
column26: after 3 months of anticoagulation
column27: the same images continue to appear
column28: which are not present in the echocardiography. However
column29: given that thrombotic phenomena appear in up to 25% of cases and that the current indications for anticoagulation contemplate starting treatment when thrombosis has already occurred
column31: even with an off-label drug.  DIAGNOSIS Myeloproliferative neoplasm with eosinophilia associated with FIP1L1- PDGFR rearrangement. Restrictive cardiomyopathy with apical and inferolateral LV and apical RV myocardial fibrosis. Probable LV apex thrombi in hypersosinophilic syndrome Essential arterial hypertension. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: baker by profession. Cardiovascular risk factors: smoker of more than 25 pack-years
column3: obese and moderate drinker. No HBP

column8: palpitations

column11: PVC 15 with mild RHY. BMI of 34. AC: arrhythmic RsCs at 110 bpm
column12: no murmurs. AP: bibasal crackles. Abdomen globular
column13: without free fluid or megaliths. LES: oedema with fovea in the lower 1⁄2⁄2. Peripheral pulses present and symmetrical. No carotid
column14: abdominal or femoral murmurs.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Blood count
column15: biochemistry and coagulation: normal. Myocardial damage markers: HbA1c
column16: TSH
column17: cholesterol normal. Blood gases on admission: hypoxaemia and hypercapnia (pO2 60
column18: pCO2 47 and bicarbonate 26). Chest X-ray: compatible with heart failure. ECG: rapid atrial fibrillation (AF) on admission
column19: unknown. Echocardiogram: LA moderately dilated. RA slightly dilated. LV slightly dilated and hypertrophic
column20: with global hypocontractility and moderately depressed global systolic function. EF 35-40%. RV with impaired function due to TAPSE
column21: mild TR
column22: estimated PSAP of 26mmHG +PVC. MV with good opening and mild reflux. AO normofunctioning. Dilated vena cava with partial collapse. No pericardial effusion. Moderate biventricular dysfunction with slightly dilated and hypertrophic vi with LVEF 35-40%. Coronary angiography: coronary arteries without significant coronary lesions.  EVOLUTION The patient was admitted with a diagnosis of decompensated heart failure due to unknown rapid atrial fibrillation. Dilatation and moderate biventricular dysfunction were observed. When ischaemic origin was ruled out by coronary angiography
column23: it was attributed as possibly secondary to tachycardiomyopathy or alcohol-induced cardiomyopathy. During admission
column24: telemetry showed a spontaneous pause of 12 seconds coinciding with sleep apnoea
column25: leaving the patient's own rhythm with narrow QRS. The patient was questioned about sleep habits and
column26: with a high suspicion of sleep apnoea-hypopnoea syndrome (SAOS)
column27: a consultation with Pneumology was requested. The patient was diagnosed with COPD GOLD II and severe OSAHS. An outpatient polysomnography also revealed severe associated oxygen desaturation. Prior to admission
column28: the patient was "apparently healthy". Special emphasis is placed on the importance of hygienic dietary measures
column29: which together with CPAP
column30: will be the most important treatment in this case
column31: more than any pharmacological treatment. The patient commits to a change in lifestyle and anticoagulation is started in order to programme electrical cardioversion of AF. Follow-up after 3 months: an effective electrical cardioversion is performed
column32: with the patient going into sinus rhythm and AF therefore becoming persistent. Control echocardiogram after 3 months (in sinus rhythm
column33: without alcohol consumption
column34: with BMI 33.3 and CPAP treatment): non-dilated ventricle with preserved LVEF. It is therefore a reversible ventricular dysfunction. We cannot say whether the dysfunction was secondary to rapid AF
column35: alcohol or even to severe OSAHS itself.  DIAGNOSIS First episode of heart failure. Atrial fibrillation. Effective electrical cardioversion. moderate biventricular isfunction. Tachycardiomyopathy. Severe sleep apnoea-hypopnoea syndrome (SAOS). COPD GOLD II type. Smoking. column12: non-radiating precordial pain

column15: systolic murmur II/IV in aortic and mitral focus. PA: crackles up to bilateral midfields
column16: no other superimposed sounds. Abdomen: soft

column44: without significant lesions. The right coronary artery is the dominant vessel
column45: of great development. In its middle segment there is a very angulated lesion with severe stenosis. Good distal bed. Echocardioscopy performed in the emergency department revealed severe mitral insufficiency due to posterior mitral prolapse and possible rupture of the chordae tendineae
column46: so it was decided to transfer her to the coronary care unit

column48: and the haemodynamicist on duty to perform coronary angiography
column49: with the findings described above. On arrival at the coronary unit

column55: with good vessel quality. Subsequently
column56: access was gained to the left atrium

column60: the patient presented severe pump failure in the first hours
column61: requiring
column62: in addition to inotropic support
column63: intra-aortic balloon counterpulsation
column64: which could be removed after 24 hours

column66: recovered in less than 48 hours
column67: and perioperative atrial fibrillation
column68: which was managed with a course of intravenous amiodarone. Once on the hospital ward
column69: he presented septic symptoms of probable respiratory origin

column71: the patient was finally discharged from hospital

In view of the echocardiographic findings and the diagnosis of endocarditis on the pacemaker lead
column22: antibiotic treatment with rifampicin and daptomycin was started. It was decided to remove the entire MCP system and reimplant a new device as the patient was in full AVB

Diagnosis We present the case of an octogenarian patient with endocarditis on a pacemaker lead with a very torpid evolution.  The postulated pathogenic mechanisms are as follows: Local contamination of the pacemaker. This is the most frequent mechanism. It usually occurs during implantation of the device. Often the infection starts in the generator pocket and spreads to the lead. The clinical course may be acute or larval
column25: manifesting itself even years later. The duration of the procedure
column26: inadequate asepsis and operator inexperience are responsible factors. Skin erosion or necrosis of the generator pocket or the skin adjacent to the electrode
column27: which act as a gateway for microorganisms. Factors involved in this mechanism include inadequate technique and site of implantation
column28: generator size
column29: and patient malnutrition. Haematogenous infection. Arrival of the micro-organism via the blood from another distant infectious source. The source of bacteraemia may be a central venous catheter
column30: a valve prosthesis or invasive therapeutic procedures.  The most frequently isolated microorganisms are staphylococci. S. aureus is the predominant bacterium in cases of acute infection
column31: while coagulase-negative staphylococci are the micro-organisms responsible for the majority of late infections.  Other microorganisms involved include Pseudomonas aeruginosa
column32: enterobacteria
column33: Propionibacterium acnes and Corynebacterium sp.
column34: and polymicrobial infections have been described
column35: especially in diabetic patients or those taking corticosteroids. When the pacemaker infection is secondary to left-sided endocarditis
column36: the microbiological profile is different

column1: A 43-year-old man with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection for at least ten years
column2: on antiretroviral treatment.  History
column3: current illness and physical examination Hepatitis C 1b RNA+ virus infection with hypertransaminasemia. Probable clinically resolved cerebral toxoplasmosis with stable residual lesions in radiological controls. Secondary comic crisis
column4: without recurrence. Ex-smoker. No other history of interest. As usual treatment for his HIV infection the patient had a regimen based on two protease inhibitors (atazanavir + ritonavir) together with a combination of nucleoside analogue antiretrovirals (emtricitabine + tenofovir). The patient was brought to the emergency department after starting a week earlier with symptoms of respiratory infection
column5: followed by rapidly progressive dyspnoea. On arrival
column6: he presented with severe respiratory distress
column7: arterial oxygen desaturation and bronchospasm
column8: so 400 mg of hydrocortisone were administered together with nebulisations of salbutamol and ipratropium bromide. Despite this
column9: he presented a poor clinical evolution
column10: with progressive arterial desaturation (83% despite high-flow oxygen therapy) and marked hypertension (200/100 mmHg). Auscultation showed bilateral crackles up to midfield. Chest X-ray showed severe cardiomegaly and bilateral alveolar oedema compatible with acute pulmonary oedema. An urgent echocardiogram showed a dilated left ventricle with very severe global systolic dysfunction (estimated LVEF of 15%)
column11: with severe generalised hypokinesia
column12: and severe mitral insufficiency of functional origin. He was admitted to the ICU where high-dose intravenous diuretic treatment and non-invasive mechanical ventilation were started
column13: stabilising the patient and initiating progressive clinical improvement over the following hours. Serial analyses showed elevated markers of myocardial damage
column14: with a CPK peak of 3
column15: 300 and troponin I of 6. He presented two febrile peaks of 38.4oC
column16: with several negative blood cultures.  Complementary tests - ECG: On arrival at the ED
column17: sinus tachycardia at 156 bpm. Left axis. Signs of left ventricular hypertrophy. Anterior and inferior Q
column18: with 1 mm ST supradelevation from V1 to V4. - Echocardiogram: severely dilated left ventricle
column19: with severely reduced systolic function (ejection fraction by Simpson biplane of 15%)
column20: due to severe generalised hypokinesia. Severe functional mitral insufficiency. Moderately dilated left atrium. Right ventricle of borderline size with reduced TAPSE (14 mm). Inferior cava not dilated with inspiratory collapse present. Absence of tricuspid insufficiency to estimate pulmonary artery pressure. Minimal detachment of pericardial leaflets. - Coronography: Left common trunk of good calibre with no notable lesions. Anterior descending artery (LAD) with segment with severe atheromatosis that includes its ostium
column21: the proximal-medial LAD and the ostium of the first diagonal. Critical lesion in the middle LAD. Small second ramaseptal with severe disease and very thin calibre. Circumflex of medium calibre and good development with severe lesion (90%) in the proximal third
column22: of complex appearance. Dominant right coronary artery
column23: with diffuse atheromatosis
column24: multisegment. More severe lesion in distal third (60%). Moderate lesion in posterolateral branch (50%)
column25: with distal bed of fine calibre. - Lipid profile: cholesterol 241 mg/dl
column26: HDL-cholesterol 41 mg/dl
column27: LDL-cholesterol 179 mg/dl
column28: triglycerides 104 mg/dl (0.0-150.0).  Clinical course With non-invasive mechanical ventilation and treatment with diuretics and vasodilators
column29: the patient's clinical evolution was favourable over the following days. Once the heart failure was resolved
column30: a study of dilated cardiomyopathy was performed
column31: suspecting
column32: after elevation of markers of myocardial damage
column33: ischaemic origin of the same. Coronary angiography showed diffuse three-vessel coronary artery disease
column34: with severe lesions on the LAD and CX
column35: which were treated by angioplasty and implantation of drug-eluting stents. There were no subsequent complications
column36: and he was finally discharged with medical treatment. column25: with aneurysmal LA. No obvious condensation. Interstitial pattern. - Laboratory tests: Biochemistry and haemacytometry normal. INR 1.07. Chagas serology: Negative. Urine toxicity: Positive for Cannabis. - Echocardiography: severely dilated LV

column1: 61-year-old woman with a history of high blood pressure and smoking. Family history: a sister who "suffers from heart disease"
column2: with no other relevant data.  History
column3: current disease and physical examination Her medical history includes a transthoracic echocardiography in 2010 with the following data: Obstructive hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Moderate MI. Normal LV systolic function. Slightly dilated LA (LA volume: 30 ml/m2). LV hypertrophy mainly at the level of the interventricular septum. Mitral valve function with incomplete SAM and dynamic gradient in LVOT (Baseline: 40 mmHg
column4: which after Valsalva manoeuvres reaches up to 57 mmHg). The patient had not undergone subsequent follow-up. She came to the emergency department in November 2012
column5: reporting a progressive increase in dyspnoea for about four months
column6: which in recent weeks has evolved rapidly to the point of becoming resting
column7: and which is accompanied by intense asthenia. He denies other associated cardiological or infectious symptoms. She denies a history of palpitations or syncope. Examination revealed the presence of an intense systolic murmur on cardiac auscultation
column8: predominantly in the left parasternal border
column9: which increased with Valsalva manoeuvres and did not clear the second tone. There was also a loud regurgitation murmur in the mitral focus radiating to the axilla. Pulmonary auscultation showed crackles up to the apex and generalised wheezing. A symmetrical magnus and celer pulse was palpated. Otherwise he is haemodynamically stable with basal saturation of 90% and blood pressure of 183/89. Heart rate: 73 bpm.  Complementary tests - ECG: On admission with sinus rhythm at 76 bpm. Doubtful ST elevation
column10: 1mm in V1
column11: similar to previous ECG. Criteria for left ventricular hypertrophy. - Chest X-ray: shows borderline CTI and bilateral centrifugal alveolar infiltrate. Laboratory tests showed BNP of 3
column12: 000 with no other relevant alterations. - Transthoracic echocardiogram: Performed during his admission to the Cardiology Department of our hospital. It reflected the following findings: LVH data with interventricular septum of 27 mm
column13: LV posterior wall of 20 mm. Gradient across the LVOT reaching 120 mmHg. Presence of systolic anterior motion of the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve contributing to the mechanism of moderate-severe MI. - 24-hour Holter-ECG: Showing sinus rhythm throughout the recording
column14: with high-density polymorphic ventricular extrasystoles
column15: isolated
column16: sparsely bigeminy and in pairs
column17: as well as several bouts of ventricular tachycardia
column18: the most prolonged of eight beats. No pathological pauses. - Haemodynamic study: hypertrophic cardiomyopathy with a dynamic gradient of 130 to 140 mmHg
column19: accompanied by severe mitral insufficiency (III/IV). Coronary angiography showed no significant lesions and evidenced the existence of an anatomically adequate septal branch for septal ablation.  Clinical evolution With this information
column20: the existing therapeutic possibilities were discussed with the patient
column21: who opted to undergo percutaneous septal ablation. The patient was transferred to the haemodynamics room where
column22: under sedation
column23: the intervention was performed. The MCP cable was placed in the right ventricle with access through the right femoral vein. A balloon catheter was introduced via the arterial route through the left coronary artery until it reached the first septal branch. Subsequently
column24: the expected response to ischaemia induced by occluding the first septal branch by inflating the balloon at that level
column25: together with the injection of echocardiographic contrast
column26: is assessed by echocardiographic support. Induction of ischaemia in the desired proximal septal region is verified
column27: as well as a fall in the gradient across the LVOT
column28: so alcohol is infused in this area. At this point the patient becomes dependent on MCP pacing. After a few minutes
column29: a significant drop in the gradient to 70 mmHg and a decrease in mitral regurgitation was observed. Angiographically
column30: a small sub-branch of the aforementioned septal branch was observed to be permeable
column31: so an additional 1cc of absolute alcohol was infused
column32: bringing the gradient down a further 10 mmHg. The patient was transferred to the Coronary Unit with alternating pacing and pacemaker pacing
column33: and in a stable haemodynamic condition. Enzyme seriation showed a peak troponin level of 90 ng/dL. No malignant ventricular arrhythmias were recorded in the monitoring and given the good evolution of the patient
column34: it was decided to transfer her to the ward after 72 hours. On admission
column35: the woman presented with severe acute pulmonary oedema in the context of heart failure due to severe obstruction of the left ventricular outflow tract and associated mitral insufficiency. Symptomatic treatment was initiated with careful use of diuretics and lusotopics
column36: and after reaching the diagnosis by careful examination and imaging techniques
column37: the patient was offered the available treatment options. At discharge
column38: there was still a high gradient
column39: around 60 mmHg
column40: and moderate mitral regurgitation
column41: but the patient showed a marked symptomatic improvement
column42: being eupneic in decubitus
column43: with good tolerance to the onset of physical activity and in a clinical situation that she described as excellent. She was discharged with generous doses of lusotopic treatment and was soon to be reviewed by the Cardiology Department.  Diagnosis - Heart failure with acute pulmonary oedema. - Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy with severe LVOT obstruction. Treated by percutaneous alcohol ablation of the first septal branch. - Complete AV block during the procedure resolved at discharge. - Moderate mitral insufficiency. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column1: A 71-year-old woman came to the emergency department with a sensation of continuous precordial palpitation accompanied by dyspnoea at rest.  History
column2: current illness and physical examination 71-year-old woman with slowly progressive dyspnoea of 2 years' evolution
column3: reaching functional class II/IV. Arterial hypertension
column4: type 2 diabetes mellitus. She denies toxic habits. Multiple visits to the Emergency Department for non-condensing respiratory infection and bronchial hyperreactivity for approximately 10 years. Habitual orthopnoea for which he uses two pillows. Usual treatment: Metformin
column5: enalapril
column6: hydrochlorothiazide
column7: inhaled bronchodilators irregularly. He presents progressive clinical worsening in the last 2 months
column8: reports occasional chest palpitations
column9: dyspnoea on minimal exertion
column10: worsening of his orthopnoea requiring greater inclination to sleep
column11: oedematisation of the lower limbs
column12: asthenia and adynamia. She denies infectious symptoms and has never presented episodes of chest pain. In the last 3 days she presented with a sensation of continuous precordial palpitation accompanied by dyspnoea at rest

column14: oriented
column15: reactive
column16: perceptive. Heart rate 120 bpm
column17: respiratory rate 30 rpm
column18: BP 117/70 mmHg. Jugular ingurgitation at 45 degrees. Tachycardic and arrhythmic heart tones
column19: fixed split second tone. Opening snap. Diffusely diminished vescicular murmur with expiratory wheezing and crepitant rales up to midfields. Oedema of lower limbs up to middle third of both legs.  Complementary tests - Haemogram: Hb 13 g/dL
column20: HTC 39%
column21: leucocytes 8
column23: platelets 201
column24: 000/mm3. - Biochemistry: glucose 108 mg/dL
column25: creatinine 0.79 mg/dL
column26: sodium 138 mEq/L
column27: potassium 4 mEq/L
column28: chlorine 101 mEq/L. - Electrocardiogram: Atrial fibrillation with RVR at 120 bpm
column29: normal axis
column30: without repolarisation alterations. - Chest X-ray: Cardio-thoracic index increased with dilatation of RA and pulmonary arteries
column31: small aortic button. Increased pulmonary capillary pressure. Pulmonary parenchyma without significant pathological findings. - Transthoracic echocardiogram/transesophageal echocardiogram: Dilated right chambers
column32: LA 46 mm. Thickened rheumatic mitral valve with calcified annulus and reduced opening. Mitral planimetry of 1.15. Aortic valve with normal opening.
