Cavae and suprahepatic normal. - Doppler: Stenotic mitral filling in AF with Hattle area of 1.2 cm2. Mild TR. PSP 50 mmHg. Flow at the level of the fossa ovalis I > D of moderate amount. - Wilkins score: 11 points.  Clinical evolution He was hospitalised in the Cardiology ward where he evolved satisfactorily
column33: responding favourably to the depletive management. She spontaneously reverted to sinus rhythm and showed marked symptomatic improvement
column34: mainly by reducing her dyspnoea. Cardiac catheterisation showed diffuse coronary atherosclerosis without significant coronary lesions. Calcified mitral valve with moderate-severe stenosis. Gorlin area of 1 cm2 with mean gradient of 8 mmHg without end-diastolic gradient due to restrictive ASD. Mean RA pressure of 14 mmHg through which I-D shunt of 2.55 occurs. Moderate mixed passive hyperdynamic passive pulmonary hypertension. Reduced IC. Preserved LVEF. Occlusion test: A significant increase in mean LA pressure was observed with increased transmitral gradients and increased interlocking pressure
column35: demonstrating the presence of severe mitral stenosis. The case was presented at SMQ and it was decided to perform mitral valve replacement and closure of the ASD.  Diagnosis - Severe rheumatic aortic stenosis - Atrial septal defect

column1: 42-year-old male presenting with chest pain.  History
column2: current illness and physical examination Personal history: Rheumatic fever in childhood. IQ: Osteosynthesis in EID. Seaman by profession. No usual treatment. AF: Brother died at 35 years of age due to AMI. Present illness: 42-year-old male presenting with epigastric and oppressive precordial pain associated with vegetative cortex lasting 3 hours. The previous month he had presented with sinusitis treated with antibiotics. In view of his clinical presentation
column3: he went to his health centre
column4: where an ECG was performed.  Physical examination: Patient conscious and oriented. Eupneic. BP 130/90 mmHg
column5: HR 73 bpm. No jugular ingurgitation. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic
column6: no murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation: preserved vesicular murmur. Abdomen: no pathological findings. Lower extremities: no oedema or signs of DVT. Distal pulses present and symmetrical.  Complementary tests - ECG: regular wide QRS tachycardia
column7: 220 bpm
column8: right bundle branch block morphology and superior axis. - Catheterisation: Coronary angiography: No angiographically significant coronary lesions. Left ventriculography: Severe systolic dysfunction. - Laboratory tests: Peak TnT ultrasensitive peak of 267 ng/L. - Echocardiogram 3 days after admission: non-dilated left ventricle with slightly depressed global systolic function and severe hypokinesia of the basal and middle segments of the lateral
column9: inferior and posterior face
column10: without significant valvulopathies. - Cardiac MRI: Hypokinesia of mid-apical segments of the lateral face and akinesia of the basal segment of the lateral face. In the late myocardial enhancement series
column11: subepicardial base uptake is demonstrated
column12: respecting the subendocardium
column13: affecting lateral and inferior segments at basal and mid level. Mild pericardial effusion. Findings compatible with acute myocarditis. - Electrophysiological study: Using a digital anatomical reconstruction system
column14: two areas of subventricular eschar are evident. Ventricular tachycardias of the same morphology as that presented by the patient on admission were induced on several occasions
column15: but with poor clinical tolerance that prevented their mapping and forced them to be terminated with over-stimulation. Finally
column16: it was decided to perform several radiofrequency applications around the bedsores in sinus rhythm.  Clinical evolution In view of the patient's clinical and ECG findings
column17: the Emergency Department was notified
column18: who prescribed sedation and performed synchronised ECV at 100J
column19: reverting to sinus rhythm
column20: and the patient was subsequently transferred to the Intensive Care Unit of his referral hospital. At the centre
column21: coronary angiography and serial analyses were performed
column22: with the aforementioned results. Once clinical stability was achieved
column23: the patient was discharged to the hospital ward and treatment was started with ACE inhibitors and beta-blockers with good clinical tolerance. An echocardiogram was performed
column24: which showed an improvement in left ventricular function compared to the ventriculography performed on admission
column25: and cardiac MRI
column26: with findings compatible with acute myocarditis. Following an electrophysiological study
column27: an ICD was implanted without incident
column28: and the patient was discharged home with ACE inhibitors and beta-blockers.  Diagnosis Sustained monomorphic ventricular tachycardia reverted to sinus rhythm with CVE in the context of probable acute myocarditis. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 47-year-old male patient came to our centre to rule out acute coronary syndrome.  History
column2: current illness and physical examination A 47-year-old male patient from the Philippines
column3: with no known toxic habits or drug allergies. Pathological history: hypertension treated with ARA II. Moderate severe aortic insufficiency with last echocardiogram in 2004 with preserved EF. First degree AV block (PR 300-320 msec). No other history of interest. Current illness: Consultation to the emergency department for cough and fever. He was discharged with a diagnosis of bronchial infection and was prescribed treatment with amoxicillin-clavulanic acid and nebulisations. Ten days later
column4: he re-consulted at another hospital due to persistent cough
column5: to which dyspnoea and mechanical lumbar pain were added. He denied fever
column6: febrile equivalents or symptoms suggestive of bacteraemia. A thoraco-abdominal CT scan ruled out pulmonary thromboembolism and discordant aortic aneurysm
column7: but a pulmonary infiltrate was observed in the left upper lobe. Laboratory tests showed CRP 41 mg/dl
column8: the only determination of TnT US 103 ng/L. At that time he was referred to our centre to rule out acute coronary syndrome. Physical examination in the emergency department: Good general condition
column9: conscious and oriented. BP: 124/50
column10: Axillary T.: 36.4
column11: SatO2: 99% Cardiovascular: Regular sounds
column12: 2/4 pandiastolic murmur. No IY
column13: no RHY. No oedema or signs of deep vein thrombosis. Pulses symmetrical
column14: alive and jumping. No carotid murmurs. Respiratory: Bladder murmur preserved
column15: no other added sounds. Digestive: No signs of peritonism
column16: positive right renal fist percussion. Neurological: No signs of neurological focality or meningism.  Complementary tests - Laboratory tests: Urea 36 mg/dL
column17: creatinine 0.86 mg/dL
column18: sodium 140 mmol/L
column19: potassium 4.04 mmol/L
column20: chlorine 108 mmol/L. CRP 7.4 mg/dL. Hb 10.8 g/dL. Leukocytes 10
column21: 500 cells/mm3. Platelets 280.000
column22: PT 64%. Urine sediment: S5 red blood cells
column23: S0 leukocytes. Sputum BK (1st) negative. Urine Ag (pneumococcus and legionella) negative. - ECG: Sinus rhythm. FC 68 bpm. PR 320 msec (already described). QRS duration 100 msec. QRS 0° QTc axis 420 msec. Criteria left ventricular enlargement. Non-specific intra-ventricular conduction disorder. - Chest X-ray: Condensation in LSI. - Thoracic-abdominal CT angiography (reviewed by the Radiology Department of our centre): Large cardiomegaly with a certain component of heart failure (reflux of contrast towards the hepatic veins) in addition to a focus of sub-pleural condensation in LSI with a ground-glass halo that could correspond to a pneumonic focus. Renal micro-density of less than 1 cm
column24: non-specific. No other findings of note.  Clinical evolution An echocardiogram was performed which showed an image suggestive of vegetation 10 mm in the bicuspid aortic valve. Severe aortic insufficiency. In the mitral valve
column25: perforation of the anterior leaflet with moderate-severe insufficiency. Ascending aorta 45 mm. Global hypokinesia
column26: left ventricular ejection fraction 45%
column27: mild tricuspid insufficiency. Moderate pulmonary hypertension. At that time the Cardiology Service was notified. Physical examination revealed signs of heart failure. Electrocardiogram showed PR lengthening up to 400 msec. Given the suspicion of endocarditis complicated by heart failure
column28: valvular rupture and possible abscess in the aortic annulus
column29: it was decided to transfer the patient to the Coronary Unit to await surgery. Treatment was started with ampicillin
column30: gentamicin and cloxacillin. Blood cultures were negative at all times. Due to intraventricular conduction disturbance
column31: a provisional MCP was implanted and a transesophageal echocardiogram was performed which showed an abscess at the mitro-aortic junction draining into the left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) and fistulisation into the right atrium (RA). Non-invasive digital angiography with pre-surgical multi-detector CT showed no significant coronary lesions and confirmed the LVOT-to-AD fistula. Surgical intervention revealed vegetations in the right coronary and non-coronary leaflets of the aortic valve
column32: with extension to the anterior mitral leaflet of the mitral valve. The aortic valve was replaced with a 21 mm mechanical prosthesis and the mitral valve was replaced with a 27 mm mechanical prosthesis
column33: preserving the mitro-aortic junction. Antibiotic treatment was continued with amipicillin
column34: gentamicin and cloxacillin. Blood cultures
column35: catheter and surgical specimen cultures were negative. Due to persistent episodes of advanced atrioventricular block (AVB)
column36: on the fifteenth post-operative day
column37: a permanent VDD pacemaker was implanted without incident. Due to the appearance of pleural and pericardial effusion
column38: with auscultation of pericardial friction rub
column39: treatment was started with ASA and colchicine. Due to persistent pericardial effusion and the appearance of haemodynamic compromise
column40: pericardiocentesis via the left anterior subcostal route was decided. The puncture was performed without complications. A fluid with haematic characteristics was obtained and sent for analysis. After removal of approximately 800 cc of fluid
column41: a negative pressure drainage system was left in place. Post-procedural ECHO showed a significant reduction in pericardial effusion
column42: with persistent posterior predominance of fluid
column43: now with better expansion of the right cavities compared to the previous ECHO. Since then
column44: haemodynamically stable with blood pressure of 130/70 mmHg and improvement of his general condition. At 24 hours the drain was removed with a total extraction of 950 cc. Echocardiogram after removal of the drain: moderate pericardial effusion predominantly inferoposterior. Despite this
column45: 24:00 hours after removal of the pericardial drain
column46: he complained of intense dizziness and profuse sweating accompanied by hypotension 93/50 mm Hg. In view of the suspicion of new tamponade
column47: a portable echocardiogram was performed which showed anterior pericardial effusion
column48: especially basal (25 mm) with echoes inside suggesting haematoma with compression of the RV
column49: which could not be approached by subcostal puncture
column50: for which reason the patient was again referred to Cardiac Surgery for urgent surgery. The patient evolved favourably after surgery and was discharged home after 2 weeks postoperatively.  Diagnosis Aortic valve endocarditis with negative blood cultures complicated by: - Severe aortic insufficiency - Mitral insufficiency due to perforation of the anterior mitral leaflet - Secondary heart failure - Periaortic abscess - Complete atrioventricular atrial ventricular block secondary to abscess - Left ventricular outflow tract fistula to left atrium secondary to abscess. |O O O O O O column1: A 43-year-old man presented to the Emergency Department with ischaemic chest pain of more than a week's duration.  History
column2: current illness and physical examination Personal history: NAMC. Former cocaine user. Smoker and heavy drinker. Nodal tuberculosis (diagnosed in July 2011) with necrotizing granulomatous lymphadenitis with tuberculous profile. Syphilis. Deep vein thrombosis of DID and portomesenteric thrombosis. Recent anterior AMI. Usual treatment: Sintrom
column3: pantecta
column4: rifampicin/isoniazid
column5: ethambutol
column6: ASA
column7: atorvastatin
column8: coropres
column9: acovil
column10: omeprazole. BFS: Higher functions preserved
column11: autonomous for ABVD. Current illness: Admitted to the Coronary Unit on 11/10/2012 for previous AMI
column12: requesting voluntary discharge without catheterisation or medical treatment. Since then
column13: he has presented recurrent chest pains and so he came to the emergency department again on 20/10/2012 for another episode of pain
column14: referred by his primary care physician. With a diagnosis of advanced AMI
column15: she was again transferred to the Coronary Care Unit. Examination: BP 134/91 mm Hg; HR 100 bpm; Ta 36.2 oC. Conscious and oriented
column16: cooperative. Good peripheral perfusion. Adequate muco-cutaneous colouring. Eupneic at rest. Head and neck: No IY. AC: rhythmic at 100 bpm
column17: systolic murmur in mitral focus. AP: VCM. Abdomen: soft
column18: depressible
column19: not painful on palpation. No evidence of peritoneal irritation. Sounds present. Hepatomegaly. Lower extremities: No oedema or evidence of DVT.  Complementary tests - ECG: Sinus rhythm at 100 bpm
column20: QRS axis at 0o
column21: Q waves in inferior face
column22: ST segment elevation in anteroseptal face and negative T waves in all precordial leads. - Echocardiogram: LV slightly dilated (LVEDD 56 mm) with normal wall thickness. Moderately depressed systolic function (LVED 40%) due to apical aneurysm
column23: akinesia of the mid-apical segments of the septum
column24: inferior and anterior face
column25: hypokinesia of the posterior face
column26: maintaining only the contractility of the lateral face and basal segments of the rest of the faces. A large thrombus is observed adhered to the apex. Pseudonormalised diastolic pattern. Mitral valve with moderate central regurgitation. Aortic root not dilated (35 mm). Aortic valve without detectable functional alterations. Slight biauricular dilatation. RV not dilated and without signs of dysfunction. Moderate tricuspid regurgitation with a RV-AD gradient of 35 mmHg. No pericardial effusion. - Chest X-ray: Cardiomegaly
column27: no pulmonary condensation images
column28: free costophrenic sinuses.  Given that it was an AMI of more than a week's evolution
column29: with necrosis in the ECG and development of apical aneurysm and an intracavitary thrombus in the echocardiogram
column30: urgent catheterisation was not performed and medical treatment was prescribed with antiplatelet therapy
column31: anticoagulation at full doses
column32: lipid-lowering agents
column33: beta-blockers and ACE inhibitors
column34: maintaining his tuberculostatic treatment. The study was completed with: Catheterisation: Left coronary angiography: The common trunk shows no lesions. The anterior descending artery is occluded in its distal segment after the birth of a large diagonal branch. The circumflex artery is of medium development without lesions. Right coronary angiography: It is the dominant vessel and of great extension. Mild atheromatosis in the middle third. Conclusions: Severe single-vessel coronary artery disease due to distal occlusion of the LAD. Cardiac MRI: dilated LV with severe systolic dysfunction. LVEF: 28%. Saccular dilatation at the level of the apex with akinesia of the apical segments of all the faces with heterogeneous density content with liquid areas inside that in the perfusion sequences do not seem to be related to the ventricular cavity. Likewise
column35: the lateral aspect does not show continuity of the myocardium with the saccular area described. Late enhancement sequences show 50% subendocardial enhancement in mid-apical segments of the inferior face and septum
column36: with transmural enhancement in the rest of the apical segments. The patient had a torpid evolution with heart failure that was difficult to manage and systemic embolisation despite anticoagulation
column37: so in view of this clinical picture and given the findings described (anterior AMI evolved with apical aneurysm and thrombus inside
column38: together with doubtful rupture of the LV wall with some associated pericardial effusion)
column39: cardiac surgery was consulted and surgery was scheduled. He underwent surgery on 17/11/2012 and left ventricular aneurysm resection and thrombus extraction
column40: with subsequent closure with a pericardial patch. No rupture of the LV free wall was visualised. In the immediate postoperative period he required vasoactive drugs due to haemodynamic instability
column41: which could be suspended on the 2nd day post IQ. He was extubated and the rest of the postoperative period was uneventful. He was discharged to the ward after 3 days in the Coronary Unit and home a week later.  Diagnosis - Evolved Killip II/IV anterior infarction with severe systolic dysfunction. - Apical aneurysm with intraventricular thrombosis. - Surgical intervention with resection of the LV aneurysm and extraction of the intraventricular thrombus. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column1: Emergency due to dizziness and fall to the floor at home
column2: without loss of consciousness and without injuries secondary to the trauma.  History
column3: current illness and physical examination 78-year-old female patient
column4: allergic to penicillins
column5: with a personal history of obesity
column6: hypertension and dyslipidaemia
column7: on treatment with hydrochlorothiazide 40 mg - olmersatan 25 mg
column8: atorvastatin 20 mg and omeprazole 20 mg. Appendectomised. Baseline situation: NYHA function class I-II. She presented suddenly at 9:00 am
column9: with dizziness and a fall to the floor at home
column10: without loss of consciousness and without injuries secondary to the trauma. She was seen a few hours later by a relative
column11: who found her very anxious due to her inability to get up from the floor after the fall. Emergency services were called and she was transferred to our Emergency Department. On arrival
column12: Glasgow 15
column13: BP 80/40 mmHg
column14: HR 110 bpm
column15: 02 saturation 80%
column16: tachypnoea of 25 rpm. While in the observation room
column17: she presented with self-limited tonic-clonic crises
column18: after which she reported intense central thoracic pain
column19: oppressive
column20: radiating to the interscapular area and significant accompanying vegetative cortex.  Physical examination: Conscious and oriented. Poor general condition. Skin pallor. Central cyanosis. Carotids symmetrical and rhythmic. Jugular ingurgitation. CVM with bilateral crackles up to midfields. Rhythmic heart tones; systolic murmur III/IV in mitral focus
column21: radiating to the axilla. Abdomen without pathological alterations. Palpable and symmetrical paedial pulses. Malleolar oedema II/IV.  Complementary tests - CBC: Leukocytes 13.800 thousands/μl
column22: PMN 70%
column23: HB 12.2 gr/dl
column25: platelets 127 thousands/μl
column26: prothrombin activity 98%
column27: aTTP 27.5 ́ ́
column28: fibrinogen 343 mg/dl
column29: Glu 159 mg/dl
column31: Cr 1 mg/dl
column32: Na 142 mmol/l
column33: K 4.1 4.2 mmol/
column34: Mg 1.8 mmol/L
column35: Cl 116 mmol/L
column36: CPK 810 Ui/L
column37: CKMB 63 ng/ml
column38: troponin I 17.98 ng/ml. - Arterial blood gas: pH 7.38
column39: pC02 27 mmHg
column40: P02 110 mmHg
column41: HC03 13 24.8 mmol/
column44: lactate 12mg/dl. - Chest X-ray: Cardiothoracic index at the upper limit of normality
column45: hilar thickening
column46: fluid in cystic cracks and pinched costophrenic sinuses. - ECG: RS at 90lpm
column47: with generalised ST segment decline and ST rise of 1 mm in aVR. - Urgent TTE: Left ventricle without significant hypertrophy or dilatation
column48: with severely depressed systolic function (15%). Mid-apical hypokinesia
column49: with preserved contractility at the level of the basal segments. Grade III mitral insufficiency. Mild aortic insufficiency and moderate pulmonary hypertension. No dynamic obstruction of the left ventricular outflow tract. No pericardial effusion. Dilated inferior vena cava with inspiratory collapse less than 50%.  Clinical course In cardiogenic shock
column50: the patient was transferred to the Coronary Care Unit (CCU)
column51: starting vasoactive support with noradrenaline (0.6 μg/kg/min) and dobutamine (10-12 μg/kg/min). Coronary angiography showed parietal irregularities
column52: without angiographically significant lesions. Ventriculography showed severe ventricular dysfunction and typical Tako-tsubo morphology. During the procedure
column53: an intra-aortic balloon pump (IABP) was implanted via the right femoral artery. In the first 24 hours of admission
column54: the patient required non-invasive mechanical ventilation due to hypoxaemic respiratory failure related to acute pulmonary oedema. The patient's evolution was favourable
column55: allowing the IABP to be withdrawn 48 hours after admission and ventilatory support to be provided gradually over the following days. The enzyme peak was: CPK 1430
column56: CK-MB 60.2 and troponin I 19.06. Prior to discharge
column57: TTE was repeated and showed recovery of systolic function (LVEF by Simpson biplane 45%) with persistence of discrete hypokinesia of the middle portions. After twelve days in the CCU
column58: she was discharged to the cardiology ward.  Diagnosis Tako-tsubo syndrome complicated by cardiogenic shock. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 48-year-old man came to the emergency department with a sudden episode of non-radiating stabbing chest pain that started suddenly while he was driving. It was not accompanied by dyspnoea
column2: palpitations or syncope.  History
column3: present illness and physical examination 48-year-old male
column4: with no known allergies
column5: with several cardiovascular risk factors including heavy smoking (2-3 packs/day)
column6: untreated hypertension and moderate obesity
column7: with no other history of interest. By profession
column8: Labrador. He came to the emergency department for an episode of non-radiating stabbing chest pain that started suddenly while he was driving. It was not accompanied by dyspnoea
column9: palpitations or syncope. On arrival
column10: he was in poor general condition
column11: with profuse sweating and tachypnoea. Blood pressure was 200/81 mmHg
column12: heart rate 95 beats per minute and oxygen saturation 86%. Physical examination revealed an IV/VI diastolic murmur
column13: more noticeable on the left sternal border
column14: generalised hypoventilation with crackles in both lung bases
column15: tibiomalleolar oedema with fovea and peripheral pulses present and symmetrical. The rest of the physical examination was unremarkable.  Complementary tests - ECG on admission: Sinus rhythm at 90 bpm. Normal PR. Narrow QRS. Voltage criteria for left ventricular hypertrophy. Negative T in lateral face. - Emergency analytical: Highlights glycaemia 185 mg/dl
column16: CRP 60 and elevated myocardial necrosis markers (maximum US TnT 180 ng/ml
column17: without typical curve). - Chest X-ray: Cardiomegaly. Aortic elongation. Hilar thickening. - CT angiography: aortic root and proximal segment of ascending aorta at the upper limit of normality
column18: with the rest of the aorta of normal calibre
column19: without signs suggestive of aortic syndrome. Mild cardiomegaly and small pericardial effusion. At the abdominal level
column20: there was only discrete hepatomegaly with hepatic steatosis. - Transthoracic echocardiogram: The main finding was the presence of moderate-severe aortic insufficiency over the trivalve valve
column21: secondary to dilatation of the aortic annulus. The left ventricle is slightly dilated (end-diastolic diameter of 60 mm) with severe concentric hypertrophy (15-16 mm) and preserved global and segmental systolic function. Both the right ventricle and the rest of the valves show no pathological findings. - Cardiac MRI: The study was of suboptimal technical quality due to lack of cooperation from the patient to correctly perform apnoeas. The left ventricle showed moderate eccentric hypertrophy
column22: dilatation (telediastolic volume of 124 ml/m2 and end-systolic volume of 50 ml/m2) and segmental and global systolic function within normal limits (ejection fraction of 60%). The right ventricle was normal in dimensions and systolic function. There was no evidence of oedema or alterations in perfusion or late gadolinium enhancement. Significant apparent aortic insufficiency was detected
column23: but the poor quality of the study did not allow adequate quantification. Aortic root dilatation (sinuses of Valsalva: 50 mm
column24: 21 mm/m2) and tubular portion of ascending aorta (48 mm
column25: 20 mm/m2) were observed. - Diagnostic cardiac catheterisation: The main finding is in the aortography
column26: where there is evidence of dilatation of the ascending aorta from the root
column27: with effacement of the sinuses of Valsalva
column28: and grade IV aortic insufficiency. The coronary arteries showed no significant angiographic lesions. - Transesophageal echocardiogram: This was interrupted due to poor tolerance given the patient's clinical situation (heart failure). Only a trivalve aortic valve with correct opening was visualised
column29: without being able to assess aortic root or valvular insufficiency. - Analysis on the hospital ward: There was moderate renal failure
column31: creatinine 1.53 mg/dL and an estimated glomerular filtration rate of 48.82 mL/minute. Liver enzymes were slightly elevated
column32: and glycosylated haemoglobin was 7.8%. The rest of the biochemistry
column33: as well as the haemogram
column34: were normal.  Clinical course During his stay in the ED
column35: CT angiography was performed to rule out acute aortic syndrome given the patient's presentation with hypertensive emergency
column36: stabbing pain and troponin elevation. The CT angiography was reported as normal
column37: so the patient was admitted to cardiology to study chest pain with elevated markers of myocardial necrosis and heart failure. On the second day of admission to cardiology
column38: the patient presented a fever peak of 38.5o
column39: with no apparent infectious focus (neither clinically nor in complementary tests)
column40: and with negative blood cultures. Given the presence of moderate-severe aortic insufficiency in the transthoracic echocardiogram
column41: a transesophageal study was performed on suspicion of endocarditis as a possible aetiology of the clinical picture. The patient's clinical condition meant that he did not tolerate the procedure adequately
column42: and although no clear signs of endocarditis were observed
column43: the study was of poor quality and was stopped early. In the following days
column44: the patient does not present fever or infectious symptoms again. There were no new episodes of chest pain; however
column45: in the serial ECGs there was a negative T-wave in the anterior face
column46: so a stress cardiac MRI was requested to assess the presence of necrosis or inducible ischaemia. The MRI was negative
column47: ruling out signs of myocarditis or myocardial necrosis
column48: but aortic insufficiency of severe appearance was again observed. However
column49: given that the patient continued to present progressive elevation of troponin and the electrical changes persisted (deepening of the T wave on the lateral side)
column50: a diagnostic cardiac catheterisation was requested
column51: which showed a non-significant lesion in the RCA and confirmed the severity of the aortic insufficiency. On the 5th day of admission
column52: the patient presented a new febrile peak of 38o
column53: and an episode of rapid atrial fibrillation with failed pharmacological and electrical cardioversion
column54: in the context of mild decompensation of heart failure. Once again
column55: a battery of tests was requested to rule out infection
column56: which was ruled out
column57: with negative blood cultures again. On the 7th day of admission to Cardiology
column58: he presented an episode of desaturation
column59: tachypnoea and hypotension
column60: compatible with acute pulmonary oedema
column61: for which he was admitted to the Coronary Unit and finally required orotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation
column62: as well as inotropic support with vasoactive drugs. A transesophageal echocardiogram was performed with the patient intubated
column63: ruling out endocarditis
column64: and finally a localised dissection of the aortic root responsible for the severe aortic insufficiency was observed
column65: and Cardiovascular Surgery was contacted for urgent intervention. Intraoperatively
column66: a type A dissection was observed
column67: with circumferential intimal rupture at the level of the sinotubular junction causing sagging of all the commissures
column68: this being the mechanism of the aortic insufficiency observed. During his admission to the Coronary Unit after surgery
column69: he evolved slowly but favourably
column70: without new febrile peaks and with improvement in the clinical signs of heart failure
column71: and was discharged on the 7th day post-surgery. One month later
column72: the patient is clinically stable and asymptomatic from the cardiological point of view
column73: with no aortic insufficiency in the outpatient echocardiogram.  Diagnosis Localised aortic root dissection with acute severe aortic insufficiency. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column1: A 59-year-old woman presented to the Emergency Department for sudden dyspnoea.  History
column2: current illness and physical examination A 59-year-old woman from San Juan (Argentina) attended the Emergency Department for sudden dyspnoea
column3: with the following history: Ischaemic heart disease: silent inferior infarction of undetermined date. Previous myocardial infarction 1 year earlier
column4: treated with fibrinolysis and subsequent cardiac catheterisation in which he had an intermediate lesion in the anterior descending and circumflex arteries and chronic occlusion of the DC
column5: not revascularised
column6: dilated left ventricle with depressed LVEF (40%). Cardiovascular risk factors: Arterial hypertension. Dyslipidaemia. Obesity. Ex. smoker of 10 cigarettes/day for the last 3 months. Chronic venous insufficiency of the lower limbs. Family history: Father with Chagas disease and myocardial infarction at the age of 59. Surgical interventions: cholecystectomy
column7: tonsillectomy
column8: appendectomy. Usual treatment: Clopidogrel/acetylsalicylic acid 75/100 mg c/24h
column9: bisoprolol 2.5/24h
column10: ramipril 2.5/24h
column11: ranitidine 150mg c/24h
column12: alprazolam 0.25 mg c/24h. The patient came to the emergency department for sudden and intense dyspnoea of less than 1 hour's duration
column13: at rest
column14: without chest pain. She presented 1 vomit of food coinciding with the dyspnoea. He denies fever
column15: withdrawal of medication or other intercurrent process. He also reports exertional dyspnoea in recent months
column16: which has been progressing until it has become light exertion and nocturnal dyspnoea for weeks. She has been sleeping with three pillows for years. On physical examination the patient was awake
column17: alert
column18: tachypneic
column19: sweating
column20: afebrile. BP 140/80 MMHG
column21: intercostal stretch
column22: intolerance to decubitus
column23: no jugular engorgement
column24: no carotid murmurs. AC: rhythmic
column25: no murmurs. AP: preserved vesicular murmur
column26: isolated wheezing and bibasal crackles. The rest of the physical examination was unremarkable.  Complementary tests - Biochemistry: sodium 145 mmol/L
column27: potassium 3.6 mmol/L CPK-MB 3.7 ng/mL
column28: myoglobin 86* ng/mL (VN: 15-72)
column29: ultrasensitive troponin T 44.5**ng/L (VN: 0-14)
column31: creatinine 1.30 mg/dL. - Haemoglobin 13.1 g/dL
column32: haematocrit 39.8%
column33: leucocytes 9
column35: platelets 244
column36: 00. Coagulation normal. - Blood gas on arrival: Global respiratory failure with acidosis pH 7.145
column37: pCO2 61.3 mmHg
column38: pO2 46.6 mmHg. Bicarbonate 20.6 mmol/L
column39: O2Sat 66.2%. - Blood gases after treatment: pH 7
column41: pCO2 32.6 mmHg
column42: pO2 65.6 mmHg. Bicarbonate 18.2 mmol/L
column43: O2Sat 92.9%. - ECG: Sinus rhythm at 90 bpm. Axis 60o. Inferior Q and QS V3-V6
column44: with negative T. Normal PR. Narrow QRS (110ms) (similar to previous recordings). - Chest X-ray: global cardiomegaly
column45: pulmonary vascular redistribution. - Chest CT: Large cardiomegaly. Signs of apical vascular redistribution. Moderate bilateral pleural effusion. Bilateral basal atelectasis of lung tissue
column46: mainly on the right. Mild signs of bilateral interstitial pattern. No signs of PTE (central/bilateral). - Echocardiogram: Left ventricle severely dilated (Dd 6.9 cm
column47: volume 222 cm3)
column48: with thinning of walls
column49: akinesia of all anterior segments
column50: only basal septum and lateral segments contracting. Estimated LVEF: 31% M-mode and 35% by Simpson. Restrictive mitral pattern (E/A 2.8; deceleration time 170 ms). Dilated left atrium (4.4 cm area 30 cm2). Dilated right chambers
column51: with decreased TAPSE. Aorta not dilated. No significant valvular alterations. Pulmonary acceleration time shortened by 87 ms. Normal pericardium. Inferior vena cava not dilated.  Clinical evolution The patient improved rapidly with the treatment prescribed in the emergency department (high-flow oxygen
column52: nitroglycerine and morphine chloride). Given the suddenness of the symptoms with acute respiratory failure and elevated D-dimers
column53: a chest CT scan was performed to rule out pulmonary thromboembolism. He was subsequently transferred to the cardiology ward where he remained clinically and haemodynamically stable
column54: tolerating increasing doses of beta-blockers
column55: ACE inhibitors and eplerenone and progressive reduction of furosemide. A new cardiac catheterisation was performed which showed no changes in the coronary arteries with respect to the one performed a year earlier. The patient had dilated cardiomyopathy of probable ischaemic origin with progressive deterioration until dyspnoea at rest. However
column56: the patient came from a Chagas endemic area and had a family history of the disease
column57: so it was decided to request serology for Trypanosoma cruzi
column58: which was positive. DNA amplification by PCR of Trypanosoma cruzi in whole blood was also positive and the patient was diagnosed with chronic Chagas disease. Given the severe ventricular dysfunction and poor functional class that persisted despite optimising medical treatment
column59: an implantable cardioverter defibrillator (ICD) was implanted as primary prevention of sudden death. In our case we are left with the doubt as to whether the cardiac involvement is only due to ischaemic heart disease
column60: as seems more likely
column61: or whether there is also chagasic involvement due to the patient being chronically infected with Trypanosoma cruzi. We have not found any case in the literature in which both processes are described together.     Diagnosis - Acute heart failure: Acute pulmonary oedema. - Dilated cardiomyopathy of probable ischaemic origin with severe ventricular dysfunction (LVEF 30-35%) vs. chagasic cardiomyopathy. - Chronic ischaemic heart disease: inferior and anterior necrosis. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column1: Clinical history and current illness A 54-year-old man
column2: of Uruguayan origin
column3: who was living in our health care area for work reasons (as a transporter). He was admitted with heart failure and episodes of back pain.  - No known drug allergies  - Smoker of 1 pack of cigarettes/day  - History of depressive syndrome  - Hypertensive and dyslipidaemic  - Carrier of chronic anti-aggregation atrial fibrillation. No previous cardiology assessment. - No family history of cardiovascular disease of interest  - Home treatment: acetylsalicylic acid
column4: digoxin
column5: furosemide
column6: pravastatin   Patient with the aforementioned history was admitted 4 days ago to the Digestive Service with a clinical diagnosis of cholelithiasis with suspicion of cholangitis
column7: based on clinical manifestations of abdominal pain of increasing intensity
column8: colicky
column9: which intensified with palpation of the right hypochondrium and epigastrium
column10: accompanied by fever and laboratory data compatible with infection (discrete leukocytosis -13450 leukocytes/uL- with left deviation -91% neutrophils with 8% casts). During his stay in the Digestive Department
column11: abdominal pain was controlled with the use of WHO scale 1 analgesics. However
column12: in view of the marked clinical manifestations of right-sided heart failure
column13: an echocardiogram was requested and a referral to the Cardiology Department was made. The transthoracic echocardiogram revealed a type A aortic dissection with a dilated root and severe aortic insufficiency
column14: as well as severe mitral insufficiency with a dilated and dysfunctional left ventricle. In view of these findings
column15: the patient was admitted to the Coronary Unit to complete the study (chest CT scan) prior to surgery. On cross-examination
column16: the patient reported progressive dyspnoea up to NYHA class II for a month and a half
column17: and in the last week several episodes of back pain that required the administration of anti-inflammatory drugs. He did not clearly complain of chest pain.  Physical examination: - Blood pressure: 120/80 mmHg. Heart rate: 88 bpm. Temperature: 36.7 °C. - Good general appearance. Normal hydration
column18: normal colour
column19: normoperfused. Eupneic (SaO2 98% with nasal cannulae at 3 bpm). - Head and neck: no goitre. Carotids rhythmic and without murmurs. No jugular venous engorgement at 45°. - Cardiac auscultation: arrhythmic. Decreasing diastolic exhalation murmur in accessory aortic focus of intensity IV/VI Levine scale. Decreasing holosystolic murmur of IV/VI intensity in mitral focus with irradiation to the axilla. - Pulmonary auscultation: preserved vesicular murmur with bibasal crackles. - Abdomen: globular
column20: soft
column21: depressible. No masses palpable. Hepatomegaly of 2 finger widths. Discomfort on palpation in the right hypochondrium. No signs of acute abdomen. Peristaltic sounds preserved. No abdominal murmurs. - Extremities: pulses present and symmetrical in the upper extremities. In lower limbs
column22: presence of oedema with fovea up to the middle region of both legs
column23: preventing the determination of peripheral pulses. Signs of venous insufficiency with no evidence of deep vein thrombosis. - Neurological: no gross neurological focality.  Complementary tests - ECG: atrial fibrillation at 88 bpm. Signs of left ventricular hypertrophy with evidence of systolic overload. - CBC: haemoglobin 12.7 g/dL
column24: haematocrit 40.7%
column25: leukocytes 13830/uL (85% neutrophils
column26: 8.3% lymphocytes)
column27: platelets 245000/uL; biochemistry: glucose 102 mg/ dL
column28: urea 44.0 mg/dL
column29: creatinine 1.1 mg/dL
column31: GOT/AST/ASAT 41 IU/L
column32: GPT/ALT/ALAT 32 IU/L
column33: GGT 70 IU/L
column34: alkaline phosphatases 191 IU/L
column35: CK 85 IU/L
column36: troponin I 0.09 ng/dL
column37: sodium 130 mMol/L
column38: potassium 4.5 mMol/L; coagulation: quick's time 21.0
column39: ratio 1.86
column40: INR 1.84
column41: aPTT 29.7
column42: aPTT ratio 0.99. - Chest X-ray: enlarged cardiopericardial silhouette with Kerley's B lines and right costophrenic sinus impingement. - Echocardiogram: severely dilated left ventricle (DTD 78/DTS 67)
column43: with normal thickness (septum 10 and posterior wall 9 mm). Global hypokinesia more marked in anterior and septal territory
column44: leading to severe left ventricular dysfunction (LVEF Teich 27%). Aortic valve trivava
column45: with severe regurgitation flow (jet diameter adjusted by outflow tract diameter greater than 70%) secondary to anterior leaflet prolapse. Sclerosed mitral valve
column46: with eccentric holosystolic insufficiency
column47: towards the lateral wall of the left atrium
column48: of severe degree (vena contracta 9 mm)
column49: secondary to dilatation of the mitral annulus (52 mm) with tenting of the posterior leaflet. Dilated left atrium (area 38 cm2). Dilated right ventricle (basal DTD 50 mm). Moderate tricuspid insufficiency
column50: with RV-AD gradient 25 mmHg. TAPSE 16 mm. Dilated vena cava (26 mm) with <50% collapse. Aneurysmal ascending aorta (59 m) with an image suggestive of flap about 20 mm from the aortic root showing double lumen. It is not possible to assess the aortic arch. Slight pericardial effusion at the level of the roof of the right atrium. - Thoracic CT: aneurysm in the ascending thoracic aorta with diameters: in the valvular annulus: 3.7x3.5 cm
column51: in the sinus portion 5.4x5.9 cm
column52: in the sinotubular junction 5.2x5.1 cm
column53: maximum in the ascending aorta: 6.86x6.4 cm
column54: anterior to the brachiocephalic trunk exit: 4.5x4.4 cm
column55: posterior to the brachiocephalic trunk exit: 4x3.4 cm
column56: in the descending aorta: 3.2x3 cm. Type A aortic dissection starting in the sinus plane of the ascending thoracic aorta and extending to the descending thoracic aorta (2 cm distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery). There is a focal haematoma/thrombus at the origin of the dissection which occupies the non-coronary sinus and extends into the region of the sinotubular junction. All three supra-aortic trunks and both carotids originate from the true lumen. Multiple repletion defects in the pulmonary arterial tree in association with pulmonary thromboembolism. At the level of the right pulmonary tree: in the right superior lobar artery with extension to its three segmental branches and several sub-segmental branches and in the bifurcation of the middle lobar artery with extension to its two segmental branches. At the level of the left pulmonary tree: in multiple segmental and subsegmental arteries of the LSI (including lingular arteries) and LII. Multiple peripheral focal pulmonary opacities in the right upper hemithorax and consolidations in the posterior regions of both lower lobes (more prominent in the left) compatible with areas of atelectasis and/or infarction. Bilateral pleural effusion. Hepatomegaly with diffuse altered enhancement in relation to stasis liver. This finding together with an increased calibre of the inferior vena cava (slightly larger than the adjacent abdominal aorta)
column57: the diffuse infiltration of the abdominal subcutaneous fat and the minimal amount of perirenal fluid suggest altered haemodynamic status due to probable right heart failure. Gall bladder stone measuring 2.3x1.7x3 cm in relation to cholelithiasis.  Clinical course A 54-year-old man was admitted to the Coronary Care Unit from the Digestive Department where he had been admitted for cholelithiasis under study. The reason for his transfer was a type A aortic dissection
column58: in the context of biventricular dysfunction with severe aortic and mitral insufficiency
column59: both of them severe. As a serious associated comorbidity
column60: he also presented bilateral pulmonary thromboembolism with acceptable haemodynamic tolerance. Given the coexistence of both entities and the initial clinical and haemodynamic stability of the patient
column61: it was decided to manage the patient conservatively at first
column62: trying to resolve the heart failure data and see the evolution of the pulmonary arterial pathology
column63: as there was a limitation in the use of anticoagulation at recommended doses in the presence of aortic dissection. In addition
column64: a venous echo-Doppler of the lower limbs was performed
column65: which ruled out the presence of deep vein thrombosis that could justify the implantation of a cava filter to prevent recurrence of pulmonary thromboembolism in a patient limited to anticoagulation. However
column66: in subsequent days the patient evolved unfavourably
column67: with recurrent episodes of chest pain and cardiac arrest secondary to electromechanical dissociation that required advanced cardiopulmonary resuscitation manoeuvres
column68: which were successfully resolved. The emergent echocardiogram ruled out cardiac tamponade and the emergent aortic angio-CT ruled out aortic rupture or associated complications
column69: although it showed retrograde progression of the aortic dissection towards the right sinus of Valsalva without involvement of the right coronary artery. In view of this clinical situation
column70: the decision was made to perform urgent surgery. A Bentall procedure was performed with a valved tube and mitral annuloplasty with a Carpentier ring
column71: and the patient died in the operating theatre after unresponsive cardiac arrest.  Diagnosis - Type A aortic dissection - Bilateral pulmonary thromboembolism - Severe biventricular dysfunction - Severe aortic and mitral regurgitation |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column1: Clinical history and current illness 22-year-old woman with a personal history of fibromyalgia
column2: ex-smoker of 6-8 cigarettes a day and elective caesarean section the month prior to the current admission
column3: with subsequent readmission for febrile syndrome secondary to possible infection of the surgical wound. Microbiological isolation of wound exudate was not obtained and she was discharged home. Fever persists associated with catarrhal symptoms of the upper respiratory tract
column4: followed by progressive dyspnoea on exertion until she rested
column5: chest pain with pleuritic characteristics and oedema in the lower limbs.  Physical examination: - On admission
column6: general condition was fair
column7: tachypneic at rest and with slight jugular engorgement. - Blood pressure: 110/80 mmHg. - No abnormal decrease in systolic pressure and pulse amplitude during inspiration (paradoxical pulse) was detected. - Afebrile. - Cardiorespiratory auscultation rhythmic
column8: without murmurs
column9: tachycardic at 140 beats per minute (bpm)
column10: good bilateral vesicular murmur with slight bibasal crackles and left basal hypophonesis. - Abdomen soft and depressible
column11: not painful on palpation and without visceromegaly. - Lower limbs with slight pretibial oedema. - The rest of the examination was unremarkable.  Complementary tests - Electrocardiogram (ECG): sinus tachycardia at 146 bpm
column12: low voltage and low R wave from V1 to V3. - Laboratory tests: biochemistry with normal ions and renal function. Haemogram with normocytic anaemia
column13: normochromic (haemoglobin 8 g/dl)
column14: slight lymphopenia. Coagulation normal. - Chest X-ray: cardiomegaly
column15: slight left pleural effusion. - Transthoracic echocardiography: non-dilated left ventricle (LV) with end-diastolic diameter (EDD) of 42 mm
column16: slight concentric hypertrophy (12-13 mm). Generalised hypokinesia with severely depressed ejection fraction (LVEF) less than 30% measured by Simpson method in apical four chambers. Mild mitral insufficiency. Moderate-severe pericardial effusion (PD)
column17: circumferential
column19: predominantly inferior
column20: posterior and lateral LV. Extension to the free wall of the right ventricle (RV) and right atrium (RA)
column21: with partial collapse. In the diaphragmatic face
column22: a 1.3 cm chamber was observed. No respiratory variations in valvular flows. Inferior vena cava with a diameter of 20 mm
column23: without inspiratory collapse.  Clinical evolution Initially conservative management
column24: with administration of serum therapy
column25: transfusion of 2 red blood cell concentrates (the anaemia was initially related to the recent caesarean section) and oral non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). Elective pericardiocentesis was performed via the left parasternal route
column26: draining 490 ml of serous fluid with biochemical characteristics of exudate and total debit of 790 ml. Low-dose beta-blockers and angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors were started
column27: with good initial tolerance. Subsequently
column28: he began with increased work of breathing and signs of pulmonary congestion
column29: which led to the initiation of intravenous diuretics. Chest X-ray showed an increase in the amount of left pleural effusion
column31: obtaining serous fluid. Poor clinical evolution
column32: even initiating a pre-transplant study protocol. Control transthoracic echocardiography was performed
column33: showing LV with severe systolic dysfunction (LVEF 20-25%)
column34: in addition to severe RV systolic dysfunction
column35: tricuspid regurgitation (TR) grade II over IV and estimated pulmonary systolic pressure (PAPs) of 40 mmHg. Minimal PD. After a targeted re-examination of the patient
column36: and faced with the need to make a differential diagnosis
column37: she reported the appearance of skin lesions related to sun exposure over several years of evolution. This
column38: together with the analytical data of normocytic normochromic anaemia
column39: lymphopenia
column40: febrile syndrome and pleuropericardial serositis
column41: led us to suspect a possible outbreak of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) with myocardial involvement as the aetiology. After further laboratory tests

column43: positive anti-DNA
column44: hypocomplementemia
column45: moderate levels of anticardiolipin antibodies
column46: hypergammagrobulinaemia
column47: elevated LDH and positive Coombs test (sign of haemolytic anaemia) were obtained

column1: Medical history and current illness A 61-year-old man consulted for dyspnoea and chest pain. AP: long-standing IDDM. Diabetic retinopathy (photocoagulation). DLP. Smoker of 1 pack/day until September 2011 (No COPD). Recurrent spixtasis in 2008

column3: MRI and EEG)

column5: renal function and ions normal. Serial CK and TnT US normal. Normal liver profile. ProBNP 1256. Normal haemogram. - ECG: Sinus rhythm at 65 bpm

column1: We describe the case of a 25-year-old male patient admitted to the emergency department of our hospital. The patient was a resident of a rural area in contact with various farmyard animals
column2: with a history of Down syndrome
column3: severe mental retardation and chronic renal failure (left renal atrophy). He consulted for intermittent fever of 3 months' evolution
column4: weight loss and nocturnal diaphoresis. In the last week
column5: he became dyspnoeic
column6: which is why his relatives decided to consult him.  Physical examination findings: blood pressure 120/80mmHg
column7: heart rate 100lpm
column8: respiratory rate 22min and oxygen saturation: 88%. Teeth in good condition
column9: no jugular distension
column10: no cervical lymphadenopathy. Systolic heart murmur grade 2/4 in mitral focus
column11: as well as cramp in both lung bases. Abdomen without alterations. Oedema in the lower limbs
column12: without skin lesions or neurological focalisation.  The initial diagnostic impression was sepsis of pulmonary origin. Treatment was started with piperacillin tazobactam 4.5g iv every 8h (after taking blood cultures) for 4 days.  Paraclinical tests showed normocytic normochromic anaemia (haemoglobin: 9g/dl) associated with thrombocytopenia (100
column14: hypoalbuminaemia (3g/dl)
column15: microscopic haematuria
column16: proteinuria and renal failure (creatinine: 1.6mg/dl)
column17: which led to glomerulonephritis; in addition
column18: the chest X-ray and later a chest CT scan ruled out not only pulmonary infection
column19: but also lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly
column20: although they showed signs of pulmonary congestion. Subsequently
column21: the patient underwent transesophageal echocardiography
column22: which showed: prolapse of the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve
column23: with severe insufficiency and an image of 2.1×1.1cm in the distal third
column24: compatible with endocardial vegetation.  Blood cultures taken on admission reported growth in the 2 bottles (19 and 20h incubation) of Gram-positive catalase-negative cocci
column25: of which phenotypic identification of the species was performed in VITEK2® automated equipment (bioMérieux) as S. pluranimalium
column26: with in vitro sensitivity to penicillin
column27: clindamycin
column28: erythromycin
column29: linezolid
column30: cefotaxime and vancomycin by the Kirby-Bauer method. Based on the modified Duke criteria1
column31: a diagnosis of infective endocarditis was made
column32: meeting one major criterion (presence of vegetation on echocardiography) and four minor criteria (predisposing cardiac condition
column33: fever
column34: glomerulonephritis and positive blood cultures of a germ that did not meet the characteristics of the major criterion).  Because the patient had severe mitral insufficiency with signs and symptoms of heart failure
column35: and the size of the vegetation was greater than 15mm
column36: transfer to surgery for mitral valve replacement (biological valve) was considered. It should be noted that despite being a young patient
column37: biological valve implantation was decided because the patient's social conditions (severe mental retardation and living in a rural area) made it very difficult for him to travel to attend anticoagulation check-ups. Control blood cultures were performed 8 days after the start of antibiotic therapy with no microbiological growth
column38: and antibiotic treatment was completed with ampicillin sulbactam adjusted according to the sensitivity profile for up to 28 days
column39: in accordance with the recommendation of the guidelines for the treatment of streptococcus. He did not receive gentamicin due to renal compromise. The patient was discharged without complications or sequelae. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Medical history and current illness 40-year-old male. Cardiovascular risk factors: untreated dyslipidaemia
column2: smoking (30 cigarettes/day since the age of 18)
column3: obesity. Mother died of stroke at the age of 54. Uncomplicated peptic ulcus 15 years ago. She came to the emergency department for a transient loss of strength in the left hemibody lasting about 30 minutes with deviation of the corner of the mouth and falling to the floor
column4: without loss of consciousness. In the last month she had presented 3 episodes of intense oppressive central thoracic pain
column5: at rest
column6: lasting 30 minutes and spontaneous cessation
column7: for which she did not consult the doctor. Dyspnoea on moderate exertion in recent weeks.  Physical examination: BP 115/79 mmHg
column8: HR 85 bpm
column9: weight 100 kg
column10: height 177 cm
column11: BMI 32. Abdominal circumference 117
column12: AC: rhythmic
column13: minimal protosystolic murmur in the apex. AP: vesicular murmur preserved. Extremities: peripheral pulses present
column14: symmetrical. Rest without relevant findings.  Complementary tests - Electrocardiogram (ECG): sinus rhythm at 100 bpm. PR 200 ms. QRS 90 ms. Q wave in II
column15: III and aVF. ST elevation 0.5 mm in III
column16: aVF and V3. ST-segment elevation 0.5 mm in I
column17: aVL
column18: V5 to V6 with negative T wave in V2
column19: isodiphasic in V3 and flattened from V4 to V6. - Transthoracic echocardiogram: severely dilated left ventricle
column20: without hypertrophy and with severely depressed systolic function (ejection fraction 25%)
column21: with extensive alterations of segmental contractility in the inferior and anterior faces. Restrictive transmitral filling. Basal and apical inferior aneurysms. Apical intraventricular thrombus of 14x18 mm. Moderate ischaemic mitral insufficiency. - Laboratory tests: maximum troponin I 0.43 ng/dL
column22: total cholesterol 223 mg/dL
column23: HDL cholesterol 31 mg/dL
column24: LDL cholesterol 164 mg/dL
column25: triglycerides 142 mg/dL. Basal blood glucose 88 mg/dL. HbA1c 4.9%. Normal haemogram
column26: coagulation
column27: renal function
column28: ions
column29: liver profile
column30: iron profile and thyroid profile. - Cardiac catheterisation (coronary angiography): severe obstructive coronary artery disease of 3 main vessels
column31: multi-segment
column32: with suboptimal distal beds. - Cardiac MRI: dilated left ventricle
column33: with severely depressed systolic function. Apical segments of anterior
column34: inferior and septal face non-viable. Remaining segments viable. Apical thrombus. - Cardiac catheterisation (percutaneous coronary intervention): angioplasty and implantation of 3 drug-eluting stents on proximal and middle anterior descending artery
column35: and angioplasty and implantation of 1 drug-eluting stent on obtuse marginal artery
column36: with good angiographic results. In a second stage
column37: angioplasty and implantation of 1 drug-eluting stent on the distal right coronary artery and posterior interventricular artery and 1 drug-eluting stent at the level of the crux
column38: with good angiographic results.  Clinical course A 40-year-old man was admitted for a transient ischaemic attack in the right carotid artery and a history of chest pain. The diagnostic study revealed an evolved inferior and apical infarction
column39: severe ventricular dysfunction and an intraventricular thrombus
column40: three-vessel multisegment disease with suboptimal distal beds
column41: and viability in the proximal and middle anterior descending and inferior territory. Given the poor distal quality of the anterior descending artery and the absence of diabetes mellitus
column42: percutaneous revascularisation was chosen
column43: and complete revascularisation was achieved with drug-eluting stents. The patient evolved favourably during admission
column44: with no clinical signs of heart failure or new neurological focality.  Diagnosis - Ischaemic heart disease: advanced inferior and apical infarction - Obstructive atherosclerotic coronary artery disease of three main vessels - Severe left ventricular systolic dysfunction - Apical intraventricular thrombus - Transient ischaemic attack due to cardioembolism - Complete percutaneous revascularisation with drug-eluting stents - Dyslipidaemia - Smoking - Obesity |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: Medical history and current illness 61-year-old male
column2: ex-smoker of 10 cigarettes a day for 5 years
column3: hypertensive and dyslipidaemic under pharmacological treatment. He denied a family history of heart disease. A sister of his had only one kidney since birth and a niece had been diagnosed with polysplenia since childhood. Cardiologically
column4: he had been diagnosed 5 years ago with dilated cardiomyopathy in the context of a routine medical check-up
column5: being completely asymptomatic
column6: NYHA functional class I. He had a history of dilated cardiomyopathy. It was a dilated cardiomyopathy with moderate left ventricular dysfunction
column7: with normal coronary arteries and associated mild aortic stenosis and moderate MI due to P2 prolapse. He was asymptomatic and under medical treatment until four years after diagnosis
column8: when
column9: following the onset of moderate exertional dyspnoea
column10: an echocardiogram was performed which revealed severe MR. He underwent surgery with Carpentier mitral annuloplasty. After 3 months
column11: he was readmitted for heart failure with moderate MR that became severe on stress echocardiography. At that time
column12: reintervention was discouraged given the history of previous surgery and the presence of severe ventricular dysfunction. After three months he fell into AF
column13: which could not be cardioverted chemically or electrically
column14: so he was anticoagulated and managed with rate control. He was referred for evaluation of cardiac transplantation.  Complementary tests - ECG: AF and a ventricular response at 80 bpm with a narrow QRS were observed. - Chest X-ray: increased CTI with no evidence of pulmonary congestion. The blood test showed an NTproBNP of 14000
column15: with no other findings of interest. Serology was positive for Toxoplasma IgG and CMV IgG and negative for hepatitis virus and HIV. He had a positive anti-lymphocyte antibody panel of 20%. - Echocardiogram: a dilated LV with an EF of 25%
column16: moderate-severe MR and severe low-gradient aortic stenosis that had not been described in previous echocardiograms (AVA 0.5 cm2; mean gradient 20) with contractile reserve was described. - Ergometry with gas consumption: estimated VO2 PEAK of 8.5 ml/kg/min (20% of the maximum theoretical value). Weber-Janicki functional class: D. In the 6-minute test he performed 320 metres without stopping or desaturation. - Right catheterisation: showed a PCP of 32
column18: and a cardiac index of 2.6 l/min/m2. - Screening with thoracoabdominal CT (with a view to probable cardiac transplantation): showed polysplenia
column19: hepatic and splenic inversion and anomalies in venous drainage (left superior vena cava draining into the coronary sinus; absence of vena cava above the renal veins
column20: draining the entire infrahepatic venous system directly into the right superior vena cava via the azygos system.  Clinical course Without complications during admission
column21: the case was discussed in a medical-surgical session. Aortic and mitral prosthesis surgery was considered an excessive risk and the patient was accepted as a candidate for heart transplant on the elective list.  Diagnosis - Chronic heart failure in advanced NYHA functional class III
column22: with evidence of poor prognosis - Dilated cardiomyopathy of probable valvular origin - Carpentier annuloplasty one year ago - Recurrence of severe MI and current severe aortic stenosis - Severe systolic ventricular dysfunction - Pending decision to be placed on elective cardiac transplant waiting list Polysplenia
column23: hepatic inversion
