column1: A 35-year-old man with a history of upper gastrointestinal bleeding
column2: beta-thalassaemia and spondyloarthropathy
column3: under treatment with certolizumab (anti-tumour necrosis factor [TNF] drug)
column4: who came to the emergency department for congruent left lower homonymous quadrantanopsia
column5: with no other clinical manifestations. Brain computed tomography (CT) showed a right arachnoid cyst as an incidental finding. With a murmur on auscultation
column6: transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) was performed
column7: diagnosing a mass on the right coronary leaflet
column8: with a friable surface
column9: which generated a double aortic lesion: moderate stenosis and severe insufficiency. Laboratory tests showed leukocytosis with neutrophilia. Suspecting IE
column10: he underwent urgent surgery with implantation of a 24 mm bidisc mechanical aortic prosthesis. There were firm pericardial adhesions. The aortic valve was trivalve
column11: dysplastic
column12: with severe thickening of the right coronary leaflet
column13: yellowish-parduous in colour
column14: with necrotic material inside. The left coronary leaflet had a similar implant in proximity to the commissure with the non-coronary leaflet. The non-coronary leaflet was thickened and appeared hypoplastic.  The postoperative course was characterised by the need for reoperation due to late cardiac tamponade
column15: without a bleeding site. Left inferior quadrantanopsia persisted
column16: with normal fundus and brain CT with right occipital hypodensity due to subacute established infarction in the territory of the right posterior cerebral artery
column17: without mass effect or haemorrhagic transformation. Although all microbiological cultures were negative pre-
column18: intra- and postoperatively
column19: empirical antibiotic therapy was maintained with vancomycin and gentamicin
column20: which was subsequently de-escalated to ceftriaxone. The patient had not received antibiotic treatment prior to diagnosis that could have decapitated the blood cultures. Pathology showed polymorphonuclear and histiocyte aggregates surrounding an amorphous basophilic substance
column21: without confirmation of PAS-positive material. The control TTE was unaltered
column22: and the patient was discharged with outpatient follow-up due to complications in the healing of the surgical wound.  He was admitted again at the fourth postoperative month due to complete atrioventricular block
column23: requiring permanent pacemaker implantation. TTE and transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) showed an oscillating mass in the left ventricular outflow tract in the most anterior aspect of the ventricular side of the prosthesis
column24: without clear images of abscess. Presence of mild aortic regurgitation that could not be correctly defined as intra- or periprosthetic due to the acoustic shadow of the prosthesis. In the thoracic CT scan
column25: dehiscence of the prosthesis at the level of the area between the non-coronary sinus and the right coronary sinus
column26: with saccular dilatation of the aorta. In view of the suspicion of early prosthetic endocarditis with pseudoaneurysm
column27: it was decided to re-intervene. Dehiscence was found in the non-coronary sinus area
column28: with disruption of the native aortic annulus and a subannular pseudoaneurysmal cavity. After explantation of the prosthesis
column29: the entire native annulus was affected
column31: requiring complete aortic transection for a successful approach. The pseudoaneurysm was repaired with a pericardial patch
column32: the entire circumference of the native annulus was reconstructed with the same and a new 18 mm bidisc mechanical prosthesis was implanted.   Revision for late cardiac tamponade
column33: as in the first operation
column34: with no bleeding point observed. He completed a new course of empirical antibiotherapy with daptomycin and cloxacillin. The case was re-evaluated jointly with Rheumatology and Infectious Diseases. Certolizumab had been withdrawn after the first operation as a possible cause of alterations in healing and immunity. All requested microbiological cultures
column35: serology and nucleic acid detection were negative
column36: as in the first episode. Detection of Tropheryma whipplei (T. whipplei) in the surgical specimen
column37: saliva
column38: faeces and duodenal biopsy was negative. Cytomegalovirus was also not detected in gastric biopsy. A prolonged platelet aggregation time was found
column39: with no other alterations in haemostasis. Absence of autoimmunity markers. Subsequent TTE detected only moderately elevated prosthesis gradients.  Five months after the second operation
column40: the patient attended the emergency department for progressive dyspnoea with significant congestive symptoms. TTE with very severe aortic regurgitation and reappearance of extensive periprosthetic pseudoaneurysm causing prosthesis nodding. Dilated left ventricle
column41: but with apparently preserved systolic function. The patient underwent urgent surgery
column42: with aortic homograft implantation in the subcoronary position and closure of the pseudoaneurysm with the same stitches. Although the intraoperative TEE showed mild aortic insufficiency
column43: the subsequent TTE showed a probably moderate intrahomograft insufficiency
column44: difficult to quantify as it was an eccentric jet
column45: with no limitation in the mobility of the leaflets at its opening. Dilated left ventricle with moderate-severe depression of function. Reproduction of a cavity in the aortic root. It was decided to complete a new regimen of empirical antibiotic therapy and discharge with outpatient control to repeat complementary tests
column46: while awaiting the results of cultures.  The TEE at one month after the last intervention showed the insufficiency with an eccentric jet in the anterior direction
column47: at least moderate. In the aortic root there was a cavity with systolic expansion compatible with pseudoaneurysm
column48: confirmed by thoracic CT. The polymerase chain reaction of the surgical specimen from the latter procedure was positive for T. whipplei. Given the clinical stability and complexity of the case
column49: it was decided to start treatment for Whipple's disease with doxycycline and hydroxychloroquine
column50: and outpatient monitoring. Currently
column51: in the sixth postoperative month
column52: the clinical situation is stationary
column53: asymptomatic for dyspnoea or other cardiorespiratory symptoms. A new TTE and CT scan showed no changes with respect to previous scans
column54: and conservative management was chosen for the time being
column55: given the complexity of the case.  IE is a serious disease
column56: which requires rapid management based on a diagnosis of suspicion for optimal medical and surgical treatment
column57: with decisions made by a multidisciplinary team. It may be a consequence of previous antibiotic treatment or due to fungi and bacteria of demanding culture. Microorganisms requiring serology for diagnosis
column58: such as Coxiella burnetii
column59: Bartonella
column60: Aspergillus
column61: Mycoplasma pneumoniae
column62: Brucella and Legionella pneumophila
column63: and microorganisms requiring polymerase chain reaction tests such as T. whipplei
column64: Bartonella and fungi stand out. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column2: 70 years of age
column3: white
column4: agricultural worker
column5: with no remarkable pathological history. He presented with fever
column6: vomiting and dehydration
column7: interpreted as bacterial bronchopneumonia
column8: for which he was treated with antimicrobials. Two weeks later
column9: he complained of general malaise
column10: malaise and dizziness. He was re-evaluated and a second-degree atrioventricular block was detected
column11: so the heart rate was regulated with a transient pacemaker (PM)
column12: to later implant the permanent generator. The referred symptoms worsened and dyspnoea appeared. A transthoracic echocardiographic (TTE) study detected an intracardiac mass and he was referred to our centre. Physical examination revealed a diminished vesicular murmur towards the lung bases
column13: with wheezing
column14: and a diastolic murmur towards the tip that appeared to change with changes in the patient's position. The baseline electrocardiogram showed a rhythm of MP to 80 beats per minute
column15: and the chest X-ray showed a small left pleural effusion with pulmonary oedema. There was anaemia and mild leukocytosis with a predominance of polymorphonuclear cells. Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) showed the tumour mass attached to the anterior mitral leaflet on its atrial side
column16: which prolapsed into the left ventricle (LV) in diastole
column17: producing a peak transvalvular mitral diastolic gradient of 20 mmHg
column18: and a mean of 10 mmHg
column19: with a left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) of 60.5%. Coronary angiography showed no significant coronary lesions
column20: and the patient was prepared for urgent surgery.  In the operating theatre
column21: after longitudinal median sternotomy
column22: arterial and venous cannulation for extracorporeal circulation (ECC)
column23: right atriotomy
column24: aortic clamping and anoxic arrest with isothermal haematic cardioplegia
column25: the interatrial septum (AIS) was opened with extension to the roof of the left atrium (LA). This exposed a yellowish-brown oval tumour mass
column26: approximately 8 cm in diameter
column27: with an implantation base extending into the mitral annulus involving its anterior leaflet and causing loss of mitral annulus integrity. The tumour was completely resected next to the mitral leaflet and a Sorin/Carbomedics Standard 25 mm bi-disc mechanical prosthesis was implanted. The procedure was completed in a conventional manner
column28: without difficulties
column29: using 87 minutes of aortic clamping and 120 minutes of cardiopulmonary bypass. He was extubated 2 hours after arrival at the Surgical Intensive Care Unit
column30: transferred to the conventional ward on the second day
column31: and discharged on the sixth postoperative day. At three months follow-up the patient was asymptomatic
column32: in sinus rhythm (inhibited PM) and TTE showed a left LA free of tumour masses
column33: a normofunctioning mechanical prosthesis
column34: with a transvalvular gradient of 12 mmHg and LVEF of 58%. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 77-year-old male patient with a clinical history of arterial hypertension
column2: permanent atrial fibrillation with anticoagulation
column3: and a surgical history of implantation of a definitive endocavitary VVI pacemaker several years ago.  The patient suddenly presented with language impairment
column4: characterised by difficulty in uttering and understanding language
column5: and behavioural changes
column6: for which he was taken to the emergency department.  Physical examination revealed a fever of 38.1 °C. Pulmonary auscultation showed slight crackles
column7: predominantly in the left base
column8: with no signs of bronchospasm. Cardiac auscultation revealed protodiastolic acoustic vibration in the pulmonary focus. The neurological examination showed the patient to be conscious
column9: not speaking and obeying simple commands.  A CT scan of the brain showed left frontal intraparenchymal haemorrhage and doubtful left fronto-parietal hypodensity. Chest X-ray showed left pleural effusion. Blood cultures showed S. bovis type I (gallolyticus).  To rule out possible endocarditis
column10: an echocardiogram was performed
column11: showing aortic sclerosis with double aortic lesion
column12: nodular and mobile images that prolapse in diastole to LV outflow chambers of half a centimetre in diameter
column13: indicative of aortic vegetation. Preserved LV systolic function. 2 cm × 1.1 cm image in hypermobile pulmonary valve prolapsing in protodiastole into the right ventricular outflow tract and generating the protodiastolic acoustic vibration described on auscultation.  The case was referred to the Cardiac Surgery Department; due to the context of his haemorrhagic stroke
column14: we decided to wait at least 4 weeks with antibiotic treatment before performing surgery. During his hospitalisation the patient remained stable
column15: aortic and pulmonary vegetations persisted in the control echocardiograms.  A thoraco-abdominal CT scan was performed; the chest showed a small bilateral pleural effusion and a probable repletion defect of 7.5 mm
column16: compatible with vegetation at the level of the aortic valve. Its appearance is rounded and suggests a simple cyst or hamartoma rather than an infarct; multiple diverticula are observed in the colon
column17: and colonoscopy is recommended. In the colonoscopy
column18: diverticula and polyps are found; polypectomy is performed. The results of the pathological anatomy report a tubulovillous adenoma with low-grade dysplasia.  After 4 weeks of antibiotic treatment
column19: the patient underwent surgery. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 48-year-old man with no medical history presented with dyspnoea on slight exertion and malleolar oedema of 15 days' duration. Examination showed bibasal crackles and blood tests showed 11
column2: 600 leukocytes with 78.5% segmented
column3: 13.4% lymphocytes and 7.2% monocytes
column4: in addition to normal biomarkers. The electrocardiogram showed previously known left bundle branch block. Chest X-ray revealed cardiomegaly and bilateral interstitial infiltrates and chest CT showed diffuse interstitial thickening over "ground glass" images ("crazy paving" pattern). Given the findings suggestive of interstitial pneumonitis
column5: it was decided not to initiate antibiotic therapy. Transthoracic echocardiography revealed ventricular dilatation with severe systolic dysfunction
column6: so he was transferred to cardiology. Coronary angiography showed severe lesions in the distal anterior descending
column7: proximal circumflex and acute marginal arteries
column8: which did not justify myocardial dysfunction. Cardiac MRI was performed one month after symptom onset and showed anterolateral hyperintensity with late subepicardial enhancement
column9: left ventricular dilatation and LVEF of 13%
column10: compatible with subacute myocarditis. Anti-CMV IgM and IgG antibodies and anti-CMV PCR were positive
column11: so treatment with oral valganciclovir was started for two weeks. He progressed satisfactorily and three months later remained clinically stable
column12: with baseline NYHA class II dyspnoea and LVEF of 45% according to control echocardiography. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the case of an 80-year-old patient with endocarditis on a biological prosthetic valve
column2: of uncertain aetiology
column3: which caused an abscess on the valve with dehiscence of the annulus. The patient had no known allergies. He had been an ex-smoker of 20 cigarettes/day for more than 20 years
column4: and consumed 2 glasses of wine per day. Independent for basic activities of daily living. Two years ago he went to the emergency department of his reference hospital for progressive dyspnoea to the point of minimal effort. At that time
column5: the patient had a personal history of glaucoma
column6: hyperuricaemia
column7: DM II and hypercholesterolaemia. Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) performed during admission revealed a silent myocardial infarction in the inferolateral wall (akinesia with thinning of the wall)
column8: moderate mitral insufficiency
column9: dilated left ventricle (LV) (end-diastolic volume 155 ml) and hypertrophic (interventricular septum in diastole 13 mm) with a left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) of 60% by the Simpson biplanar method. He was discharged with a diagnosis of emphysema-type COPD with bilateral subpleural pulmonary bullae (FEV1/FVC 40.94% post-BD) and established infarction of uncertain chronology inferolaterally.  At the one-year follow-up TTE
column10: severe eccentric mitral regurgitation was detected with a drop in ejection fraction and worsening dyspnoea: LVEF 47% by Simpson biplanar. The patient was proposed for cardiac surgery. Preoperative coronary angiography showed significant 2-vessel coronary artery disease (severe stenosis in the LAD and proximal DC)
column11: and he underwent aortocoronary bypass: left internal mammary to anterior descending
column12: and replacement of the mitral valve with a Labcor No. 31 biological prosthesis
column13: preserving the posterior leaflet of the native valve (non-revascularised DC
column14: non-viable territory).  In the immediate postoperative period he presented a postcardiotomy syndrome with good response to depletive and anti-inflammatory treatment (colchicine for 6 months). The patient remained asymptomatic. In the control echocardiography 6 months after surgery
column15: a 19 x 11 mm thrombus was detected on the atrial side of the septal leaflet of the biological prosthesis. Anticoagulation therapy was optimised. Nineteen days after admission
column16: he presented a fever peak of up to 38.5 oC with no apparent focus. Serial cultures were taken (all negative) and empirical antibiotic treatment was prescribed for 10 days. 25 days after optimisation of anticoagulant treatment
column17: an echocardiographic check-up was performed and it appeared that the thrombus was no longer present.  Two months later the patient presented with an episode of weakness
column18: unilateral loss of vision and nausea. During his admission
column19: the reappearance of the intraprosthetic thrombus was observed
column20: and anticoagulant treatment was optimised again: inflammation parameters and serial cultures were negative. Before discharge
column21: he presented an episode of isolated febrile fever of 37.4 oC
column22: so serial cultures were repeated and TEE was repeated
column23: showing a sessile and mobile endocardial wart on the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve
column24: measuring 8.5 mm. In the area where the thrombus had developed
column25: a new finding was detected: pseudoaneurysm of the mitral valve annulus measuring 20 x 6 mm (high suspicion of endocardial process). Given the suspicion of infective endocarditis in the TEE
column26: empirical antibiotic treatment was started. Cultures were negative
column27: as were serologies and PCR. A PET-CT study was performed which showed images suggestive of infective endocarditis on the mitral prosthetic valve. In addition
column28: a follow-up TEE performed 1 month later showed a new-onset mitral valve annulus perforation: severe periprosthetic insufficiency. The patient required further depletive treatment.  Given the diagnosis of endocarditis with negative blood cultures
column29: in addition to repeating the different cultures
column31: Brucella
column32: Chlamydia
column33: Coxiella
column34: Legionella
column35: Mycoplasma and Borrelia was performed. Serology for Bartonella henselae was positive on two occasions (IgG 1/2048
column36: IgM 1/40). In view of these results
column37: antibiotic treatment was adjusted. In addition
column38: given the presence of a local complication in early prosthetic endocarditis
column39: the patient was proposed for surgery. The patient decided not to undergo surgery. For this reason
column40: oral doxycycline treatment was maintained indefinitely (B. henseale). A control transthoracic echocardiography performed 1 month after the start of treatment revealed a mitral perivalvular abscess with partial "disinsertion" of the mitral annulus rocking motion. Given the patient's decision
column41: medical treatment was optimised again. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History 48-year-old woman. Cardiovascular risk factors: hypertension under medical treatment. Ex-smoker (accumulated 20 packs/year). Overweight (body mass index: 29 kg/m2). Habitual ethanol consumer (20 grams/day).  Cardiological history: Bicuspid aortic valve diagnosed in childhood due to murmur
column3: with evolution towards severe aortic stenosis. In 2005 aortic valve replacement (St Jude Regent No19 prosthesis) and 30 mm ascending aorta graft. Subsequent follow-up in cardiology outpatient clinic with good functional class (NYHA: I-II) and reporting occasional palpitations. The last echocardiogram in 2016 showed preserved left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) and a normofunctioning prosthesis although with slightly elevated gradients (maximum gradient of 47 and mean gradient of 24
column4: estimated aortic valve area [AVA] of 1.5 cm2).  Other history: Anxiety-depression disorder to mental health follow-up since 2016. Assessed in neurology in 2015 for visual phenomena
column5: with small lacunar infarcts and microembolism on cranial magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). Bronchial asthma. Psoriasis.  Surgical interventions: Gastric bypass (Roux-en-Y) and eventroplasty as a treatment for morbid obesity in 2008. Cholecystectomy and hysterectomy in 2009.  Home medication: Acenocoumarol according to guideline
column6: amiodarone 200 mg/24 h
column7: enalapril 20 mg/24 h
column8: diltiazem 60 mg/8 h
column9: furosemide 40 mg/24 h
column10: almotriptan 12.5 mg/24 h
column11: escitalopram 20 mg/24 h
column12: ketazolam 15 mg/24 h
column13: omeprazole 20 mg/24 h
column14: formoterol/budesonide/24 h
column15: 5 mg folic acid/24 h
column16: lorazepam 1 mg/24 h
column17: salbutamol if required.  Present illness A 48-year-old woman attended the emergency department of our centre due to sudden dyspnoea in the last few hours
column18: accompanied by dizziness
column19: general malaise and palpitations. She reported good adherence to medical treatment
column20: although higher than usual ethanol consumption in recent months and regular control of anticoagulation levels with significant fluctuations.  Physical examination Vital signs: blood pressure 80/40 mmHg
column21: heart rate 110 bpm
column22: saturation 90%. General condition: fair
column23: sweating and respiratory work. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic heart sounds
column24: systolic murmur in aortic focus
column25: no auscultation of prosthetic click. Pulmonary auscultation: scattered crackles and rhonchi. Jugular ingurgitation. Absence of oedema in the lower limbs.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Laboratory tests: CBC: haemoglobin 14.1 g/dl
column26: leukocytes 6.55 x10E3/μl
column27: platelets 128 x10E3/μl. Biochemistry: Na 138 mmol/l
column28: K 4.5 mmol/l
column29: Cr 0.93 mg/dl
column31: NTproBNP 13000. Coagulation: INR 1.10. Arterial blood gas: pH 7.45
column32: pO2 51 mmHg
column33: pCO2 33 mmHg
column34: HCO3 23.5 mmHg. Electrocardiogram (ECG): sinus tachycardia at 100 bpm with diffuse repolarisation alterations. Chest X-ray: normal cardiothoracic index. Middle sternotomy wires and aortic ring. No data of acute pathology. Angio-CT of pulmonary arteries: no evidence of TEPA. No signs of congestion. Transthoracic echocardiogram: non-dilated left ventricle with mild hypertrophy and mildly impaired systolic function. High filling pressures. Right ventricle of normal size and function. Slightly dilated left atrium. Mechanical aortic prosthesis with severe double lesion
column35: very high gradients (maximum gradient of 100 and mean of 75 mmHg). Moderate mitral insufficiency. Moderate tricuspid insufficiency allowing estimation of a PSAP of 55. Fluoroscopy: absence of movement of one of the prosthetic discs. Transesophageal echocardiogram: image compatible with thrombus on the ventricular side of the most posterior disc and another image on the aortic side of the most anterior disc
column36: indicating very severe aortic stenosis and severe aortic insufficiency in the context of prosthetic thrombosis.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION On arrival at the emergency department
column37: the patient presented with significant dyspnoea associated with respiratory distress. Initially
column38: given the clinical situation and normal chest X-ray and prior to the arrival of the analytical results
column39: an angio-CT scan of the pulmonary arteries was performed which ruled out pulmonary thromboembolism and showed no evidence of fluid overload. Urgent cardiology assessment was requested and a transthoracic echocardiogram (described above) was performed
column40: showing a severe double aortic lesion with very high gradients. Suspicion of acute prosthetic thrombosis led to fluoroscopy
column41: which confirmed the diagnosis. However
column42: for a better aetiological affiliation
column43: a transesophageal echocardiogram was performed which showed images suggestive of thrombus in both discs. The patient was transferred to the cardiac intensive care unit and remained in a poor haemodynamic condition
column44: hypotensive and tachycardic
column45: with little response to diuretic treatment. Urgent assessment by cardiac surgery was requested
column46: who decided to perform emergency aortic valve replacement. Intraoperative findings showed blockage of the prosthetic discs due to the presence of organised thrombus in both hinges. Finally
column47: an ATS No 18 mechanical prosthesis was implanted
column48: given the impossibility of implanting a biological prosthesis due to the size of the annulus
column49: without complications. The postoperative period passed without complications
column50: allowing early discharge to the ward. The control echocardiogram showed a normally functioning mechanical prosthesis (maximum gradient 27.5 and mean gradient 14.6 mmHg) and hospital discharge was therefore decided.  DIAGNOSIS Acute mechanical aortic prosthetic prosthesis thrombosis. Cardiogenic shock secondary to the same. Implantation of a mechanical aortic prosthesis ATS No18. LVEF preserved at discharge. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column2: CURRENT DISEASE AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION The patient in our clinical case is a 40-year-old woman from León
column3: with no contact with the rural environment or animals. She has no drug allergies and her relevant history includes epidemiological contact with tuberculosis that required chemoprophylactic treatment in childhood
column4: with no evidence of subsequent development of the disease
column5: and a benign ovarian tumour being followed up by gynaecology.  She attended her referral hospital with a clinical picture of one week's evolution consisting of general malaise
column6: dyspnoea and suprasternal pain with palpitations. She also reported an episode of generalised urticaria that resolved after taking antihistamines at home. Suspecting thyroid pathology
column7: she was discharged under beta-blocker treatment
column8: pending analytical results.   Due to persistent symptoms
column9: she requested a second opinion at another centre
column10: where she underwent a transthoracic echocardiogram that showed dilatation of the right chambers and pulmonary hypertension
column11: together with cystic images in the liver. She was referred to the emergency department of her referral hospital to rule out acute pulmonary thromboembolism.  Physical examination on arrival: BP: 102/55 mm Hg. HR: 100 bpm. Ta: 36.2oC. SpO2: 93% basal. Regular general condition. Conscious
column12: oriented in the 3 spheres and cooperative. Normal colour
column13: normohydrated and normoperfused. Discreetly tachypnoeic at rest
column14: with good respiratory dynamics. Head and neck: absence of jugular ingurgitation. No palpable goitres or adenopathies. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic
column15: tachycardic heart sounds. No murmurs or extratonos are heard. Pulmonary auscultation: preserved vesicular murmur in both hemithoraxes
column16: no extra sounds. Abdomen: hydro-aerial sounds present and of normal characteristics. Soft
column17: depressible
column18: not painful on superficial or deep palpation
column19: with no signs of peritoneal irritation. Lower extremities: pedial pulses present and symmetrical. No oedema or signs of deep vein thrombosis.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Laboratory tests at the referral hospital: elevated NT proBNP (5981 pg/ml)
column20: D-dimers (20887 ng/ml). Other parameters in normal range. Angio-CT scan at the referral hospital: hypodense mass was observed occupying the left pulmonary artery and extending obstructing all ipsilateral lobar and segmental arteries
column21: as well as a second mass of similar characteristics in the right interlobar artery
column22: in addition to an area in the right lower lobe suggestive of pneumonitis or pulmonary infarction and a cavity with a mass inside it in the meniscus sign in the left lower lobe. There was also dilatation of the pulmonary artery trunk and evidence of right ventricular overload
column23: findings suggestive of pulmonary hypertension. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the liver at his referral hospital: a large cystic lesion with calcified wall in the right hepatic lobe corresponding to a hydatid cyst with daughter vesicles
column24: with rupture of the capsule with focal extension and invasion of the inferior vena cava. Transthoracic echocardiogram in our centre: mild right ventricular dysfunction
column25: with severe pulmonary hypertension (estimated PSAP: 60-65 mmHg)
column26: showing intraluminal masses in the pulmonary artery and extrinsic compression of the vena cava. Normal left ventricular function and absence of significant valvular heart disease.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION In view of these findings
column27: serology for hydatidosis was performed
column28: which was positive
column29: so antiparasitic treatment was started with albendazole 400 mg/12 h and oral praziquantel 600 mg/8 h. Initial evolution was favourable
column30: although he persisted with hypoxaemia dependent on oxygen therapy. The patient was transferred to our centre for assessment by the multidisciplinary pulmonary hypertension unit.  On arrival at our centre
column31: the patient was haemodynamically stable. Laboratory tests showed discrete elevation of NT-proBNP (2612 pg/ml) and acute phase reactants (leukocyte count at the upper limit of normal with significant neutrophilia
column32: C-reactive protein 24.5 mg/dl
column33: fibrinogen 1320 mg/dl). Positive serology for hydatidosis was confirmed by ELISA test. A new transthoracic echocardiogram was repeated (images 7-9)
column34: showing mild right ventricular dysfunction
column35: with severe pulmonary hypertension (estimated PSP 60-65 mmHg)
column36: intraluminal masses in the pulmonary artery and extrinsic compression of the vena cava
column37: as well as normal left ventricular function and no significant valvular heart disease. After reviewing the tests performed at his referral centre
column38: the case was presented at a multidisciplinary session involving the cardiology
column39: radiology
column40: infectious diseases unit
column41: cardiac surgery
column42: thoracic surgery and general surgery departments. At this session
column43: a two-stage approach was decided: initially cyst extraction and scheduled hepatectomy and subsequently pulmonary endarterectomy of hydatid cysts. While awaiting this intervention
column44: admitted to the cardiology ward
column45: the patient presented symptoms compatible with anaphylactic shock requiring administration of intramuscular adrenaline and steroid boluses and the start of intensive fluid therapy
column46: despite which she remained unstable both respiratory (SpO2 < 70%) and haemodynamic (BP 50/40 mmHg)
column47: so she was transferred to the coronary unit
column48: where a central line was started and adrenaline and noradrenaline perfusion was started. She was also connected to non-invasive mechanical ventilation (EPAP 2
column49: IPAP 9
column50: FiO2 100%). Given the persistence of haemodynamic deterioration despite adequate support measures
column51: a new transthoracic echocardiogram was performed
column52: showing severe left ventricular dysfunction. The electrocardiogram showed no evidence of ischaemia and no significant elevation of myocardial damage markers (troponin T hs 84 ng/l
column53: CK 152 U/l). With the suspicion of stress cardiomyopathy in relation to the episode of anaphylactic shock requiring high doses of catecholamines (which at this time included the administration of dobutamine)
column54: the possibility of implantation of veno-arterial ECMO was assessed. However
column55: the implantation of the device was rejected for various reasons: the presence of left ventricular dysfunction that made the risk of the surgical intervention that the patient needed to cure her unacceptable at that time; the risk of new dissemination or rupture of cysts with the manipulation of lines and cannulas in the venous territory
column56: and the complexity of the management of assistance in a patient with severe pulmonary circulation alteration. In this context
column57: expectant management was decided
column58: awaiting spontaneous recovery to reactivate the initial plan. During the hours immediately after the episode
column59: the patient showed discrete haemodynamic improvement that allowed suspension of adrenaline perfusion and a decrease in noradrenaline to 0.2 μg/kg/min with progressive improvement of the distal hypoperfusion data. Under low doses of dobutamine
column60: a new echocardiogram was performed where severe left ventricular dysfunction persisted. Respiratory stability was such that ventilatory support could be reduced with acceptable clinical tolerance. However
column61: 24 hours after the anaphylactic shock episode
column62: she presented a sudden episode of desaturation
column63: with associated hypotension and spontaneous recovery after starting support with high-flow glasses with FiO2 of 1
column64: with data compatible with pulmonary congestion on chest X-ray. Hours later
column65: he presented with frank haemodynamic deterioration
column66: with associated episodes of desaturation and urticaria suggesting a new case of anaphylaxis
column67: probably due to the release of hydatid vesicles. Initially
column68: doses of vasoactive drugs were increased
column69: intramuscular adrenaline and bolus corticotherapy were started
column70: despite which she presented with new haemodynamic deterioration
column71: with moderate-severe dilatation of the right ventricle on urgent echocardiography
column72: maintaining severe left ventricular dysfunction. The patient presented with a new episode of desaturation
column73: associated urticaria and loss of consciousness that required orotracheal intubation
column74: after which electromechanical dissociation was observed
column75: which could not be reversed after 25 minutes of advanced CPR manoeuvres. When these manoeuvres were stopped
column76: asystole and thrombosis of both ventricles were observed on transthoracic echocardiography. Relatives were informed and the possibility of performing an autopsy was explained
column77: which they rejected.  DIAGNOSIS Severe pulmonary hypertension secondary to compromise of the pulmonary arterial tree by hydatid vesicles
column78: probably secondary to migration from a giant hepatic hydatid cyst. Right ventricular dysfunction in the context of the above. Anaphylactic shock in relation to disseminated hepatic hydatid disease
column79: with stress cardiomyopathy with development of secondary severe left ventricular dysfunction. Cardiorespiratory arrest in electromechanical dissociation. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History 65-year-old woman. Allergy to methimazole. No known cardiovascular risk factors. No history of known heart disease. Primary hyperthyroidism due to Graves-Basedow disease
column3: treated with radioactive iodine (I-131). Current situation of hypothyroidism under replacement therapy. Left breast nodule with histology compatible with solid pattern carcinoma with multifocal neuroendocrine differentiation (somatostatin and chromogranin receptors positive)
column4: undergoing conservative surgery in 2011 and sentinel node biopsy
column5: which was negative. Subsequent follow-up by oncology
column6: with stability of the disease until 2014
column7: when in the context of diarrhoeal syndrome
column8: the diagnosis of carcinoid syndrome due to metastatic liver disease with positive gammagraphic uptake for somatostatin analogues was established. Stability by imaging studies since the start of treatment with somatostatin analogues
column9: although an increase in analytical biomarkers that led to changes in the usual treatment.  Usual treatment: levothyroxine sodium 75 mcg orally every 24 hours
column10: lanreotide autogel 120 mg injectable every 21 days.  Present illness He came to the emergency department for marked swelling of the lower limbs and weight gain (5 kg) in the last month
column11: although without greater dyspnoea than usual (on exertion).  She also reported an increase in the frequency of diarrhoeal episodes in the last 6 months
column12: since the last oncology check-up. She denies other symptoms.  Physical examination Conscious and oriented in time
column13: space and person. Facial flushing. Blood pressure 125/68 mmHg. Eupneic at rest
column14: with saturation by pulse oximetry 99% without contributions. Pulmonary auscultation: physiological vesicular murmur. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic tones at 78 bpm
column15: with pansystolic murmur (intensity III/VI) predominantly in the left parasternal border
column16: which increases with inspiration. Abdominal examination: not painful on palpation
column17: with discrete hepatomegaly
column18: without signs of ascites. Examination of the extremities: oedema with fovea up to the middle third of the lower limbs
column19: with preserved and symmetrical distal pulses. No acute inflammatory data.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Electrocardiogram: sinus rhythm at 72 bpm. QRS axis 60o. PR interval 160 msec. QRS of normal voltage and amplitude. Minimal non-significant ST-segment underleveling in inferior leads. Corrected QT interval (Bazett) 460 msec. Chest X-ray: slightly increased cardiothoracic index. No costophrenic sinus impingement. No infiltrates or condensation. No images suggestive of masses. Laboratory tests (in the emergency department): mild hyperbilirubinaemia (total bilirubin 1.5 mg/dl) and hyponatraemia (Na+ 133 mmol/l). Blood count
column20: coagulation
column21: renal function parameters and the rest of the ionogram in normal ranges. Laboratory tests on the hospital ward: normal thyroid hormone profile. Normal iron profile. 5-hydroxyindolacetic acid 355 μmol/orine 24 h (normal values: 10-40 μmol/orine 24 h). Chromogranin A (serum) 1697 ng/ml (normal values: up to 100 ng/ml). NT-proBNP 767 ng/ml. Transthoracic echocardiogram: left ventricle (LV) neither dilated nor hypertrophic
column22: with preserved global systolic function (LVEF 60%)
column23: without alterations in segmental contractility. Transmitral filling pattern with impaired relaxation (E: A 0.7). Slightly dilated left atrium (32 ml/m2). Mitral valve morphologically normal
column24: with no organ involvement of interest or significant functional alterations. Tricuspid aortic valve
column25: without organic involvement of interest
column26: with jet of aortic regurgitation of central origin and direction that conditions mild aortic insufficiency. Aortic root of normal dimensions (26 mm). Proximal ascending aorta and aortic arch of normal size (28 mm and 26 mm
column27: respectively). Right ventricle slightly dilated at mid-basal level (dimensions: basal diameter 43 mm
column28: mid diameter 37 mm
column29: length 68 mm
column31: distal outflow tract diameter 24 mm)
column32: with decreased longitudinal function parameters (TAPSE 15 mm
column33: S" wave 9 cm/sec). Slightly dilated right atrium (area 20 cm2). Tricuspid valve with fibrosis at the leaflet level and restricted movement of the leaflets causing a central coaptation deficit and a tricuspid regurgitation jet leading to severe tricuspid regurgitation
column34: with a maximum gradient (possible underestimation due to severity of regurgitation) of 50 mmHg. Pulmonary valve adequately visualised
column35: with normal appearance. No evidence of shuntintracardiac. Inferior vena cava with dimensions in the upper normal range (20 mm) and inspiratory collapse greater than 50%. Trivial pericardial effusion.  Whole body gammagraphic study of somatostatin receptors: in comparison with the previous study (18 months earlier)
column36: multiple bilobular liver lesions were observed. The largest lesion (segment VII) shows an increase in volume (136 x 94 x 136 mm in anteroposterior-transverse-craniocaudal diameters
column37: compared to 110 x 70 x 115 mm in the previous study). There were no other new lesions compared to the previous study. Conclusion: scintigraphic study compatible with progression of the disease.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION The patient was admitted for a complete study
column38: confirming the progression of the disease by means of a somatostatin receptor scintigraphy study. Given the clinical suspicion of cardiac involvement due to carcinoid syndrome (clinical symptoms and new onset murmur)
column39: a transthoracic echocardiographic study was requested
column40: which revealed severe tricuspid insufficiency
column41: confirming the diagnosis of carcinoid heart disease. After initiation of depletive treatment with diuretics and intensification of treatment with somatostatin analogues
column42: the patient progressed favourably
column43: with symptomatic improvement (reduction of oedema in the lower limbs
column44: reduction in the number of bowel movements
column45: no episodes of hot flushes). The case was discussed in a clinical session with the participation of medical oncology and cardiology
column46: estimating a vital prognosis of less than 12 months
column47: and it was decided to discharge the patient from hospital with an increase in the dose of somatostatin analogues. Despite this
column48: the patient had a torpid subsequent evolution
column49: with several readmissions in the following months for episodes similar to the one described
column50: finally leading to her death.  DIAGNOSIS Stage IV mammary neuroendocrine neoplasia. Carcinoid syndrome with cardiac involvement (severe tricuspid insufficiency). Cardiac insufficiency of right predominance. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History Cardiovascular risk factors (CVRF): untreated dyslipidaemia
column3: overweight grade 2. Cardiological history: 11 years ago an echocardiogram was performed which showed no abnormalities during an admission for pneumonia.  Other history: Chronic hepatitis C virus genotype 1 liver disease
column4: non-responsive to interferon and ribavirin therapy. Treatment was started with ledipasvir and sofosbuvir with prior withdrawal of omeprazole from her usual treatment to avoid interaction. She finished treatment 2 months ago
column5: totally asymptomatic
column6: with sustained viral response. Systemic sarcoidosis secondary to treatment with interferon
column7: which was treated with corticosteroids and interruption of interferon therapy
column8: with no current activity. Usual treatment: omeprazole 20 mg 1 tablet per day.  Current disease A 74-year-old female patient was being followed up by hepatology outpatients for chronic HCV infection. During a follow-up visit to the hepatology outpatient clinic (2 months after finishing treatment with anti-HCV)
column9: the patient reported deterioration of functional class to dyspnoea on moderate exertion
column10: with two-pillow orthopnoea
column11: peripheral oedematisation and subjective decrease in daily diuresis volume
column12: for which reason she was referred to cardiology. She reported no chest pain at rest or on exertion
column13: no presyncopal episodes and no infectious symptoms due to equipment. At the cardiology outpatient clinic
column14: anamnesis was performed
column15: in accordance with the above
column16: and NT- proBNP and transthoracic echocardiogram was requested
column17: which showed dilated cardiomyopathy with severe left ventricular dysfunction. Treatment was started with sacubitril/valsartan 24/26 mg every 12 hours
column18: bisoprolol 2.5 mg daily
column19: furosemide 40 mg 1 tablet every 12 hours and atorvastatin/ezetimibe 80/10 mg daily. Due to evidence of iron deficiency anaemia in decompensated heart failure (HF)
column20: treatment was started with IV iron carboxymaltose in 15 minutes each dose (1
column21: 500 mg in total; 1
column22: 000 mg in the first week and 500 mg in the following week). Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is requested and a new appointment is made in one month.  Physical examination Conscious and oriented in the three spheres
column23: normohydrated
column24: cutaneous-mucosal pallor
column25: good general condition. Blood pressure 107/65 mmHg
column26: heart rate 75 bpm
column27: O2 saturation 98% room air
column28: temperature 36.3 oC. Cardiac auscultation: regular
column29: third sound
column30: no murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation: preserved vesicular murmur (VCM)
column31: humid bibasal crackles. Extremities: tibiomalleolar oedema with fovea
column32: no signs of deep vein thrombosis (DVT).  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS AP chest X-ray: signs of venous congestion
column33: with perihilar interstitial infiltrate
column34: no pinching of costophrenic sinuses
column35: cardiothoracic index (CTI) not assessable by projection. Electrocardiogram (ECG): RS at 75 bpm
column36: PR 160 ms
column37: QRS 100 ms
column38: Axis 0o
column39: LVH criteria (Sokolov-Lyon)
column40: flattened T-waves in V5-V6
column41: aVL  Blood tests: CBC: red blood cells 4.52 10*12/l. Haemoglobin 9.6 g/dl. Haematocrit 32.8%. MCV 77.3 fl. MCH 22.1 pg. MCHC 26.4 g/dl. ADE 14%. Leukocytes 6.8 10*9/l. Neutrophils 3.3 10*9/l. Lymphocytes 2.9 10*9/l. Monocytes 0
column42: 4 10*9/l. Eosinophils 0
column43: 2 10*9/l. Basophils 0.1 10*9/l. Platelets 280 10*9/l. Haemostasis: prothrombin time (PT) 11.1 sec. Quick index 100%. INR 0.97. APTT 26.9 sec. Ratio (aPTT) 0.9. Derived fibrinogen 311 mg/dl. Biochemistry: glucose 105 mg/d. Sodium 141 mEq/l. Potassium 5 mEq/l. Chlorine 103 mEq/l. Total birubin 0.54 mg/dl. Aspartate aminotransferase GOT 26 U/l. Alanine aminotransferase GPT 13 U/l. Alkaline phosphatase 73 U/. Gamma-glutamyl transferase 13 U/l. Creatinine 0.94 mg/dl. Estimated GFR CKD-EPI 60.8 ml/min/1.73 m. Uric acid 4.8 mg/dl. Protein 7.2 g/dl. Creatine phosphokinase 119 U/l. Iron profile: ferritin 54 μg/l. Iron 94 μg/dl. Total Fe fixation capacity 371 ug/dl. Transferrin saturation index 12.3%. Latent Fe binding capacity 277 ug/dl. Immunological markers: rheumatoid factor 9 U/ml. C-reactive protein 0.0 mg/dl. Lactate dehydrogenase 374 U/l. Angiotensin converting enzyme 60 U/l. Congestion markers: NT-proBNP 3407 pg/ml. Ag. Carbohydrate 125 (CA125) 107 IU/ml. Lipid profile: total cholesterol 319 mg/dl. Triglycerides 90 mg/dl. HDL cholesterol 72 mg/dl. LDL cholesterol 229 mg/dl. Total cholesterol/HDL cholesterol 4.4. Hormones: thyrotropin (TSH) 1.77 uIU/ml. Calciuria 24 hours: within normal limits.  Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE): severely dilated left ventricle (LV) with severe systolic dysfunction (LVEF 30%) due to global hypokinesia. Normal sized atria. Mild central functional mitral regurgitation. Aortic valve without findings of interest. Right ventricle (RV) slightly dilated at baseline with preserved contractility. Trivial TR with PAPs 25 mmHg. Inferior vena cava not dilated.  Cardiac MRI (videos 2
column45: 4 and 5): LV volumes at the upper limit of normal (IVTDVI = 93 l/m; IVTSVI = 52 ml/m) with eccentric hypertrophy (IMVI = 84 g/m) and moderately depressed systolic function (LVEF = 44%). Generalised mild hypokinesia. Absence of myocardial oedema. Normal RV volumes (IVTDVD = 69 ml/m2; IVTSVD = 26 ml/m2) with normal systolic function (RVEF = 62%). Atria and great vessels of normal size. Lung resistance within normal values (2.6 U. Wood). First-pass perfusion at rest with e.v. gadolinium. - meglumine gadoterate 0.15 mmol/kg - no complications. Absence of significant perfusion defects. Focal late gadolinium enhancement in the medial inferior septum at the intersection with the right ventricle. Although small necrosis cannot be ruled out as it also affects the subendocardium
column46: it could also be a focal sarcoid lesion. In summary: findings of dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) of uncertain origin
column47: probably not ischaemic although it presents a focal lesion compatible with necrosis vs. sarcoid lesion.  Catheterisation: right dominance. Coronary tree without angiographically significant lesions.  High-resolution pulmonary CT scan: mediastinal structures centred with small right paratracheal lymph node not exceeding one centimetre in maximum diameter
column48: without appreciable lymph node growths in the hilar or axillary hollows. No pleural or pericardial effusions. No pulmonary nodules
column49: masses or intraparenchymal infiltrates. Free main tracheobronchial tree. Cardiac MRI (control in 6 months): LV of normal volumes (VTD 70 ml/m
column50: VTS 34 ml/m
column51: IMVI 74 g/m2) without significant hypertrophy of its walls or alterations of segmental contractility at rest and with slightly depressed global systolic function (LVEF 51%). Abnormal septal motion. Non-dilated RV (RVOT 66 ml/m
column52: STV 25 ml/m) with preserved global systolic function (LVEF 62%). Aorta and great vessels of normal diameter and morphology. Atria of normal dimensions. Normal pulmonary vascular resistance (mean pulmonary velocity 14.3 cm/sec). Compared with the August 2017 examination
column53: the LV volumes improved
column54: as did LVEF.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION Continuing with the study of the left ventricular dysfunction detected at the outpatient level
column55: cardiac MRI was performed 3 weeks after the consultation
column56: showing improvement in ventricular function
column57: with moderate dysfunction
column58: and catheterisation was performed (due to the late gadolinium enhancement image suggestive of necrosis)
column59: which showed no significant angiographic lesions. The patient did not report catarrhal or other symptoms prior to the current process suggestive of myocarditis prodrome. Only the introduction and completion of HCV antivirals coincided in time. Given the findings of late gadolinium enhancement that could be partially explained by sarcoidosis in a patient with a history of iatrogenic sarcoidosis secondary to the use of interferon
column60: a high-resolution CT scan of the lungs was performed
column61: which showed no data suggestive of pulmonary or adenopathic sarcoidosis
column62: nor analytical data of activity (ACE
column63: calciuria or elevation of acute phase reactants). A literature search was conducted on cardiotoxicity due to direct antivirals against HCV. Although there is no reference to toxic myocarditis in the data sheet
column64: articles were found referring to toxicity from drugs that act on the same targets and were withdrawn from clinical trials
column65: reversible global longitudinal destrain worsening after sofosbuvir and exclusion of patients with heart disease and without adequate controls (with echocardiography) of cardiovascular safety in pivotal trials of antiviral drugs against HCV. Because of this
column66: left ventricular dysfunction is attributed to the use of HCV antivirals. After starting treatment
column67: the patient was asymptomatic
column68: with no dyspnoea for activities of daily living. A follow-up cardiac MRI was requested after 6 months
column69: showing normalisation of left ventricular volumes without hypertrophy and improvement in left ventricular function
column70: with mild dysfunction remaining. Subsequently
column71: in echocardiographic controls up to the present
column72: LVEF has normalised and diameters are at the upper limit of normality. The study of iron deficiency anaemia showed three polyps in the right colon at colonoscopy
column73: which were removed without significant histopathological findings. In summary
column74: this is a case of severe left ventricular dysfunction secondary to reversible dilated cardiomyopathy. Although the findings could be explained by a past asymptomatic myocarditis
column75: we consider more likely the possibility of toxic myocarditis related to direct antivirals against HCV
column76: a pathology little studied in our environment
column77: and with drugs widely used in our health system.  DIAGNOSIS Non-ischaemic dilated cardiomyopathy with severe left ventricular dysfunction
column78: recovered. Suspected toxic myocarditis due to HCV antivirals. Iron deficiency anaemia secondary to colonic polyps. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History No known drug allergies. No known classical cardiovascular risk factors. Obesity type 1. Toxic habits: ex-smoker since youth

column45: TDE 130 msec. Septal E' 4.8 cm/sec
column46: lateral E' 9.6 cm/sec
column47: average E/e' 11.8. Right cavities not dilated. ICD electrode. TAPSE 21 mm. Light IP. PAP m 20 mm Hg. Normal IVC. Absence of effusion. Conclusions: dilated cardiomyopathy with severe left ventricular dysfunction (LVD) and mild functional mitral regurgitation (MR). Ergospirometry (November 2018): the test was performed according to the modified Bruce ramp protocol without complications. Exercise time 12:24 min
column48: stopped due to fatigue. It reached 129 bpm
column49: 77% of the FCMT. The RER at peak effort was 1.05 which confirms that this is a conclusive test. The test shows a slightly decreased functional capacity with respect to predicted (Weber Stage B
column50: peak oxygen consumption 19.6 ml/kg/min
column51: 76% with respect to theoretical)
column52: ventilatory class II (VE/VCO2 slope 30.6) having reached ventilatory threshold 2. Baseline CO2 PET 36 increasing to 40 mmHg. No EOV. No alteration of the ventilatory reserve
column53: not suggesting concomitant ventilatory alteration. From the ECG point of view
column54: there were no dynamic changes. Isolated EV in the recovery phase. Normal blood pressure behaviour (baseline 124/80 mmHg and at maximum effort 150/90 mmHg). Conclusions: slight decrease in functional capacity with no data of poor prognosis in ergospirometry.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION Since the administration of intravenous iron carboxymaltose (in 2017)
column55: the patient has remained asymptomatic and without the need for medication readjustments
column56: with only one admission for decompensation of heart failure in a period of 2 years. On an outpatient basis
column57: being in a stable phase of heart failure
column58: regular monitoring of iron metabolism has been carried out
column59: as well as the state of the iron deposits
column60: which at all times has maintained stable figures. In the last analytical control (November 2019)
column61: as we can see in PPCC
column62: she again presented data of iron deficit with depleted deposits
column63: without associated anaemia
column64: and it was decided to prescribe a new cycle of intravenous iron carboxymaltose with a dose adjusted according to the patient's weight
column65: and in the last outpatient review by the advanced heart failure and heart transplant unit of our centre she reported an improvement in her current functional situation (currently NYHA II).  DIAGNOSIS Advanced chronic heart failure. Severe LV systolic dysfunction in a patient with chronic ischaemic heart disease in NYHA functional class II. Carrier of single-chamber ICD in primary prevention with no events during follow-up. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History We present a 68-year-old man
column3: with no known drug allergies
column4: a former smoker for three months and with alcohol consumption only at weekends. His personal history includes arterial hypertension on treatment with torasemide 5 mg/24 hours
column5: dyslipidaemia on treatment with simvastatin 20 mg/24 hours and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease GOLD 1A (last spirometry performed in 2017: TI 75%
column6: FVC 104%
column7: FEV1 83%) under follow-up by his primary care physician. She has no history of known heart disease.  In 2018 he underwent a right inguinal hernioplasty and in July 2019 he underwent a retropubic prostatic adenomectomy for benign prostatic hyperplasia with repeated acute urinary retention
column8: having subsequently presented with episodes of haematuria.  Present illness The patient was initially referred to the emergency department from his primary care physician for progressive exertional dyspnoea of one month's duration that began after prostate surgery. The dyspnoea was accompanied by two-pillow orthopnoea
column9: occasional episodes of paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea and bilateral oedema with fovea in the lower extremities. His regular physician had increased the dose of torasemide to double (10 mg/24 hours)
column10: after which he presented with a weight loss of 3 kg. On arrival at the emergency department
column11: the patient was haemodynamically stable
column12: tachycardic at 110 bpm and had a baseline saturation of 95%. Given the presence of congestive signs (hypoventilation in the right base with bilateral crackles
column13: discrete hepatomegaly and oedema with bilateral fovea up to the thighs) and an elevation of NT-proBNP up to 4623 pg/ml (normal range 0-300 pg/ml)
column14: he was admitted to the cardiology department to study the first episode of heart failure.  Physical examination On admission to the cardiology department
column15: the patient was haemodynamically stable
column16: with a blood pressure of 114/75 mmHg
column17: tachycardic at 110 bpm and oxygen saturation around 96% baseline. There was no jugular plethora. On cardiac auscultation he was rhythmic
column18: with no murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation (posterior plane) showed decreased vesicular murmur in the right base with bilateral crackles. He had a hepatomegaly of 3-4 cm
column19: and on the extremities there was bilateral oedema with pitting up to the thighs.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Electrocardiogram: sinus rhythm at 100 bpm
column20: normal PR
column21: QRS axis at 0o
column22: narrow QRS
column23: with known flattened T waves and frequent supraventricular extrasystoles.  Laboratory tests on admission: Venous blood gas: pH 7.51
column24: pCO2 32 mmHg
column25: bicarbonate 26 mEq/ml. Biochemistry: glucose 112 mg/dl; urea 56 mg/dl; creatinine 1.00 mg/dl; GPT 25 U/l; bilirubin 1.4 mg/dl; calcium 8.9 mg/dl; sodium 145 mEq/l; potassium 3.6 mEq/l; chloride 108 mEq/l; CRP 2.28 mg/l; creatine kinase 71 U/l; lactate dehydrogenase 188 U/l; NT-proBNP 4623 pg/ml. Haemoglobin 10.8 g/dl; haematocrit 34.4%; mean corpuscular volume (MCV) 96.1 fl; mean corpuscular haemoglobin concentration 31.4 g/dl; mean erythrocyte corpuscular haemoglobin (MCH) 30.2 pg; erythrocyte distribution amplitude (EDA) 14.5%; platelets 209 *10^3/ƒÊL; leucocytes 6.61 *10^3/ƒÊL. Coagulation: INR 1.3.  Other laboratory tests of interest: Lipid profile: total cholesterol 142 mg/dl
column26: triglycerides 85 mg/dl
column27: HDL cholesterol 36 mg/dl
column28: LDL cholesterol (calculated) 89 mg/dl
column29: non-HDL cholesterol 106 mg/dl
column30: urate 6.2 mg/dl. Iron profile: iron 38 ug/ml
column31: transferrin 345 mg/dl
column32: transferrin saturation index (TSI) 8%
column33: ferritin 50 ng/ml. Vitamin B12 406 pg/ml
column34: folate 4.6 ng/ml. Glycosylated haemoglobin 5.8%. Thyrotropin (TSH) 2.61 mU/l. Serology: HCV negative
column35: HIV negative
column36: CMV negative
column37: parvovirus B19 Ig-G positive (Ig-M negative)
column38: enterovirus negative
column39: adenovirus pending. Chest X-ray on admission: cardiothoracic index at the limit
column40: with pinching of both costophrenic sinuses without other condensations. Chest X-ray prior to discharge: minimal impingement of the right costophrenic sinus with significant improvement compared to the previous one. Transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) (videos 1
column42: 3): severely dilated left ventricle
column43: with severely reduced systolic function (LVEF estimated by Simpson biplane 15-21%) due to severe global hypokinesia. Doppler transmitral flow pattern suggested restrictive physiology. Mildly dilated right ventricle with mildly depressed function. Moderately dilated left atrium and mildly to moderately dilated right atrium. Mitral valve leaflets thickened
column44: with moderate mitral insufficiency. The tricuspid valve had moderate-severe insufficiency
column45: with a maximum RV-AD gradient of 60.7 mmHg
column46: and an estimated PSAP of 75 mmHg. Inferior vena cava was dilated and inspiratory collapse was less than 50%. The aortic valve was trivalve
column47: with sclerodegenerative leaflets with only mild-moderate aortic insufficiency
column48: without aortic root dilatation. Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) performed during outpatient follow-up: severely dilated left ventricle with severely depressed global function with diffuse hypokinesia (LVEF 29%). Mildly dilated right ventricle with mild systolic dysfunction (LVEF 44%). Late enhancement sequence shows linear intramyocardial enhancement in the basal septum and septal insertion points
column49: non-ischaemic. In addition
column50: a mild bilateral pleural effusion was observed as an extracardiac finding. Catheterisation via the right radial artery: Left coronary angiography: common trunk without lesions. The anterior descending artery shows diffuse calcified atheromatosis with mild stenosis without any significant stenosis. The circumflex artery of medium extension and ectatic calibre at the proximal level also shows diffuse calcified atheromatosis with moderate stenosis at the marginal proximal level. Right coronary angiography: the right coronary artery is the dominant vessel
column51: very atheromatous and with an ectatic and irregular calibre all the way to the lumen. There is a severe ulcerated lesion at the proximal level (70%). At the end of the middle segment there is a calcified focal stenosis with severe stenosis (85%). The posterior descending branch is of medium extension and with severe focal stenosis proximally. Pressure guidewire in the circumflex: the moderate circumflex lesion is explored with pressure guidewire without adenosine (RFR
column52: parameter at rest) and is found not to cause ischaemia (RFR 0.96-0.98) and is therefore not treated. Coronary intervention: the stenosis described in the middle segment of the DC is predilated with a 4.0 mm balloon with subsequent implantation of a pharmacoactive usntent with post-dilatation with a 4.5 mm balloon at 20 atm with good results. Subsequently
column53: after predilatation with a 4.0 mm balloon
column54: another drug-eluting stent was implanted over the ulcerated lesion described in the proximal segment. A severe residual stenosis is evident at its proximal edge
column55: which makes it necessary to implant another stent at this level
column56: covering the vessel ostium. These last two stents were post-dilated with a 4.5 NC balloon at high pressure with a good final result (slight under-expansion at the ostial level of around 20%).  CLINICAL EVOLUTION The patient was a 68-year-old man admitted for a first episode of heart failure following planned prostate surgery. During admission
column57: diuretic treatment was started
column58: initially intravenously
column59: and was later changed to oral therapy due to the excellent response to it
column60: with rapid resolution of the congestive signs. In addition
column61: after the acute phase
column62: neurohormonal treatment was started progressively with good tolerance (nebivolol 5 mg half tablet every 12 hours as he was a bronchopathic patient
column63: spironolactone 25 mg and finally sacubitril/valsartan 24/26 mg every 12 hours)
column64: with no alterations in renal function or symptomatic hypotension. An echocardiogram showed dilated cardiomyopathy with severe left ventricular dysfunction due to severe global hypokinesia
column65: and the aetiological study of this entity was initiated. A directed anamnesis was performed
column66: in which a significant history of enolism and exposure to toxins
column67: previous chest pain or angina pectoris
column68: and data suspicious of myocarditis were ruled out. Due to the characteristics of our centre and the availability of performing a catheterisation more quickly than a cardiac magnetic resonance imaging
column69: cardiac catheterisation was performed first
column70: which revealed severe stenosis of the right coronary artery in which three drug-eluting stents were implanted. A cardiac magnetic resonance imaging was still to be performed at the time of discharge. On the other hand
column71: blood tests showed normochromic normocytic anaemia with a normal range of red blood cell distribution
column72: but with low iron
column73: ferritin and transferrin saturation index. The digestive tract was ruled out as the origin of the anaemia
column74: as there were no clinical signs to suggest this and the faecal occult blood test performed during admission was negative. In addition
column75: vitamin B12 and folic acid deficiency were ruled out as possible alternative causes (although the characteristics of the anaemia did not suggest this aetiology). The anaemia was interpreted in the context of the previous episodes of haematuria and the recent surgery
column76: and it was decided to start treatment with intravenous iron in the form of iron carboxymaltose at an initial dose of 1000 mg
column77: without complications during the infusion. At discharge
column78: the patient was euvolaemic
column79: with no congestive signs
column80: and the heart failure unit of our hospital was contacted
column81: who decided to include the patient in the remote telemonitoring programme for close patient follow-up. During subsequent follow-up in the heart failure unit
column82: the patient reported being stable since discharge
column83: with NYHA II-III/IV dyspnoea
column84: stable weight
column85: minimal oedema in the ankles and good tolerance to neurohormonal treatment. Approximately two months after discharge
column86: the patient again began to show signs of congestion (he reported an increase in his baseline dyspnoea and oedema with fovea in the lower limbs) which led to an increase in oral diuretic treatment
column87: with a good clinical response. In addition
column88: a control blood test showed anaemia (haemoglobin 12.6 g/dl) with a ferritin level of 49 ng/ml and a transferrin saturation index of 11.1%
column89: without the patient reporting bleeding at any level
column90: so it was decided to start a new course of intravenous iron carboxymaltose with the aim of improving the patient's exercise capacity and quality of life. After the administration of an initial dose of 1000 mg in the day hospital of our centre
column91: with no incidents during the same
column92: a new evaluation of the patient is pending to assess the need to complete the regimen with intravenous iron.  DIAGNOSIS Heart failure
column93: first episode. Dilated cardiomyopathy
column94: non-ischaemic
column95: with severely depressed LVEF (LVEF estimated by Simpson biplane 15-20%). Moderate functional mitral regurgitation. Moderate-severe tricuspid regurgitation with severe pulmonary hypertension. Severe single-vessel coronary artery disease (right coronary) treated with implantation of three drug-eluting stents
column96: and moderate single-vessel coronary artery disease (obtuse marginal). Normocytic normochromic anaemia with iron deficiency. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O column1: Background Cardiovascular risk factors (CVRF): arterial hypertension (HT) with target organ damage
column2: type 2 diabetes mellitus (DM) with macro and microvascular involvement
column3: LBP
column4: active smoker (estimated IPA: 135). Stage II chronic kidney disease of probably mixed aetiology (hypertensive and diabetic)
column5: with estimated glomerular filtration rate around 60 ml/min and proteinuria in non-nephrotic range (1.1 g/24 hours). Chronic ischaemic heart disease with severe three-vessel disease surgically revascularised in 2016 (AMI-DA and VSI-OM grafts
column6: the latter chronically occluded)
column7: with mild LV systolic dysfunction. Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation (AF) anticoagulated with acenocoumarol. Ischaemic stroke in the right posterior cerebral artery (PCA) territory of probable cardioembolic aetiology. Moderate sleep apnoea-hypopnoea syndrome (SAHS). Chronic grade IIA ischaemia in the right lower limb.   Home treatment: Atorvastatin 80 mg 0-0-1
column8: acetylsalicylic acid (ASA) 100 mg 0-1-0
column9: bisoprolol 5 mg 1-0-1
column10: acenocoumarol according to INR controls
column11: ivabradine 5 mg 1-0-1
column12: amlodipine 5 mg 1-0-0
column13: candesartan 4 mg 1-0-1
column14: spironolactone 25 mg 1-0-0
column15: metformin 850 mg 1-0-0
column16: furosemide 40 mg 2-0.5-0
column17: omeprazole 20 mg 1-0-0.  Present illness The patient is a 60-year-old man with the aforementioned history
column18: including multiple CVRF and established vascular disease
column19: with chronic ischaemic heart disease
column20: surgically revascularised and with mild residual LV systolic dysfunction
column21: who is admitted to the neurology department for ischaemic stroke of atherothrombotic aetiology in the left middle cerebral artery (MCA)
column22: with mechanical thrombectomy and destent implantation at the level of the left carotid artery. During admission
column23: the patient presented an episode of decompensation of heart failure and was transferred to the cardiology department for monitoring
column24: study and intensive diuretic treatment.  Physical examination On assessment by cardiology: General condition is fair. Conscious
column25: oriented in all 3 spheres and cooperative. Normal colour
column26: normohydrated and normoperfused. Afebrile to the touch. Tachypneic at rest
column27: with intolerance to decubitus. Blood pressure (BP): 160/70 mm Hg. Heart rate (HR): 73 bpm. SpO2: 91% with low-flow oxygen therapy (nasal cannulas). Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic heart sounds. No murmurs
column28: extratonos or pericardial friction rub. Pulmonary auscultation: generalised hypoventilation in both lung fields. Lower extremities: pedial pulses present and symmetrical. Edema with bilateral fovea up to the knees.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Electrocardiogram (ECG) on admission: sinus rhythm
column29: PR 160 ms
column31: without repolarisation alterations suggestive of acute ischaemia. Chest X-ray: AP projection. Bilateral pleural effusion (minimal left
column32: more evident on the right). Congestive hilarity and vascular redistribution.  Laboratory tests on admission: Biochemistry: glucose 186 mg/dl
column33: creatinine 0.98 mg/dl
column34: sodium 140 mEq/l
column35: total protein 7.5 g/dl
column36: potassium 4.59 mEq/l
column37: albumin 4.0 g/dl
column38: chlorine 102 mEq/l
column39: ALT (GPT) 21 U/l
column40: AST (GOT) 25 U/l
column41: gamma-GT 34 U/l
column42: alkaline phosphatase 125 U/l
