column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History No known drug allergies. Cardiovascular risk factors (CVRF): diabetes mellitus 2 (DM2). No known hypertension or dyslipidaemia. Toxic habits: ex-smoker (previously smoked 1.5 packs/day from the age of 12 to 46 years). No current drinker
column3: previously a weekend drinker of 5-6 beers and 4-5 drinks. No previous cardiological history. Surgical interventions: conisation in 2010. Previous home treatment: metformin 850 mg/12 hours.  Current illness 50-year-old woman
column4: ex-smoker
column5: with no previous cardiological history
column6: who for the last 4 months
column7: in relation to exertion
column8: has had episodes of non-radiating central thoracic oppression associated with dyspnoea
column9: without accompanying vegetative cortex and relieved by rest. These episodes were initially triggered by heavy exertion
column10: and the level of exertion at which they appear has progressively decreased
column11: with these changes being more pronounced in the last two weeks. They now appear with small efforts (walking more quickly or climbing stairs). Curiously
column12: she does daily bicycle exercise of about 30 minutes without the onset of symptoms. Given that the baseline electrocardiogram showed complete left bundle branch block (LBBB)
column13: exercise testing was ruled out and the patient was admitted to cardiology to complete the study.  He denied orthopnoea or episodes of paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea (PND). There was no increase in peripheral oedema or reduction in diuresis. She reported weight gain in recent months. No syncope/presyncope.  Physical examination Good general condition
column14: well hydrated and perfused
column15: conscious and cooperative at all times. Clinically and haemodynamically stable on admission to the cardiology ward. Afebrile. Blood pressure 136/81 mmHg. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic tones at a good frequency. No murmurs were heard. Respiratory auscultation: good vesicular murmur without pathological noises. Abdomen: soft
column16: depressible
column17: without visceromegaly or other noteworthy findings. Lower limbs: no oedema or signs of deep vein thrombosis. The rest of the examination was unremarkable.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Electrocardiogram (ECG): sinus rhythm at 78 bpm. PR 160 ms. Normal axis. Wide QRS (120 ms) with LBBB image. Secondary repolarisation alterations. Chest X-ray: cardiothoracic index not increased in size. No images of pulmonary condensation. Free costophrenic sinuses. Analysis: Glucose 143 mg/dl. Creatinine 0.84 mg/dl. Urea 41 mg/dl. Sodium 148 mEq/l. Potassium 4.8 mEq/l. Lipid profile: total cholesterol 148 mg/dl
column18: HDL cholesterol 62 mg/dl
column19: LDL cholesterol 68 mg/dl
column20: triglycerides 90 mg/dl. Normal liver profile. Normal thyroid hormones. Glycated haemoglobin: 7.3%. No mobilisation of myocardial damage markers: peak ultrasensitive cTnT 9 ng/dl. Haemogram with 4
column21: 990 leucocytes (normal formula)
column22: Hb 13.2 g/dl and 203
column23: 000 platelets. Coagulation normal. Echocardiography: moderately dilated left atrium (LA) (42 mm AP diameter; Vol 42 ml/m2). Normal mitral valve morphology
column24: with fibrocalcification of the posterior annulus and 2) restriction of the posterior leaflet mobility
column25: with central insufficiency grade II (ORE 0.15 c.m.) Dilated left ventricle (DTD 61 mm; DTS 48 mm; VTD 197 ml; VTD index 98 ml/m2; VTS 120 ml)
column26: normal myocardial thickness (septum 6 mm; pp 7 mm). LVEF 40% calculated by Simpson Biplane
column27: with akinesia of the basal and middle segments of the septum and inferior face
column28: as well as hypokinesia of the anterior face
column29: with better contractility of the apical segments and lateral-inferior face. GLS -15% with more diminished values in the septal and inferior segments. Mitral filling E/A 1.3: E 108.7 cm/s; A 84 cm/s; e' sept 5.15 cm/s; e' lat 8.7 cm/s. E/e' 15 . Trivalve aortic valve
column31: without insufficiency. Annulus 20 mm. Sinuses of Valsalva 32 mm. Right ventricle (RV) of normal dimensions (RVDVD 29 mm)
column32: with preserved systolic function. TAPSE 26 mm. S' 12.6 cm/s. Trivial IT that does not allow estimation of pulmonary gradient. Pulmonary flow with acceleration time of 110 ms. Inferior vena cava (IVC) not dilated
column33: with adequate inspiratory collapse. No pericardial effusion. Conclusions: 1) dilated cardiomyopathy with moderate dysfunction and the described contractility alterations. 2) Diastolic dysfunction (dilated LA
column34: E/e' >14; e' <10). 3) Functional mitral regurgitation (MR) grade II. 4) RV with preserved systolic function. Coronary angiography: right radial access. Angiographically normal coronary arteries. Right dominance. Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI): normal relationships and anatomical arrangement of the central cardiovascular structures. No interatrial septal defects or anatomical alterations in cardiac valves. Normal systemic and pulmonary venous drainage. Systolic area AD 20 cm2; left atrium 21.6 cm2 (4C plane estimate). Right ventricle neither dilated nor hypertrophic
column35: without alterations in segmental contractility
column36: with preserved systolic function (EF 66 %). Dilated left ventricle (dTD 61 mm; VTD 126.2 ml/m)
column37: without alterations in segmental thickness (images 4-5). No alterations in segmental thickening were observed. Dyssynchronous movement of the septum with respect to the non-septal wall of the LV
column38: attributable to HH bundle branch block
column39: to be correlated with ECG findings. Moderately depressed systolic function (EF 40%).Jet of central mitral insufficiency. Estimated regurgitant fraction between 13.6% (by calculation from ventricular volumes) and 17.8% (by calculation from LVlat and aorta). In the black myocardial sequences
column40: a subtle linear intramyocardial enhancement is recognisable in the basal and middle septum
column41: as well as in some areas of free wall
column42: especially in the lateral and lower middle basal wall. Assessment in several sequences is very limited by respiratory motion. Conclusions: non-ischaemic left dilated cardiomyopathy
column43: associated with moderate systolic dysfunction (LVEF 40%). Dyssynchronous movement of the septum. Non-coronary late enhancement pattern
column44: as described above. Compatible with sequelae of myocarditis. Mitral insufficiency (RF 13.6%-17.8%).  CLINICAL EVOLUTION On admission
column45: after echocardiography detected findings of dilated cardiomyopathy with the segmental alterations described
column46: the next step in the diagnostic algorithm was coronary angiography
column47: which ruled out the presence of coronary artery disease. In view of this
column48: cardiac MRI was requested for the aetiological study of the ventricular dysfunction
column49: the result of which suggested a non-ischaemic origin of the condition (with a pattern of enhancement compatible with the sequelae of myocarditis). The response during admission to depletive treatment was adequate
column50: and treatment with beta-blockers
column51: angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACE inhibitors) and mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists (MRAs) was initiated
column52: with good tolerance and consequent disappearance of the symptoms that led to admission. On discharge from hospital
column53: treatment was prescribed with enalapril 5 mg/12 hours
column54: spironolactone 25 mg/24 hours and bisoprolol 2.5 mg/12 hours. As for anti-diabetic treatment
column55: the patient was under treatment with metformin 850 mg/12 hours and
column56: despite this
column57: she had a glycosylated haemoglobin of 7.3%
column58: above the target recommended by the guidelines in patients such as the one we present (7%). In this regard
column59: dapagliflozin was added based on the results of cardiovascular efficacy obtained with this drug in recent studies on patients with heart failure. In addition
column60: in order to improve adherence to treatment
column61: both hypoglycaemic drugs were prescribed in a single presentation: metformin 850 mg/dapagliflozin 5 mg every 12 hours. After discharge
column62: the patient remains asymptomatic 11 months later and has not had any new hospital readmissions to date. In addition
column63: the last blood test showed an objective decrease in HbA1c to 6.5%
column64: below the recommended target level.  DIAGNOSIS Idiopathic dilated cardiomyopathy with moderate dysfunction (EF 40%) probably in the context of old myocarditis. Coronary arteries without angiographically significant lesions. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History Cardiovascular risk factors: hypertension
column3: type 2 diabetes mellitus
column4: ex-smoker. Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation (CHA2DS2-VASc = 7) in treatment with acenocoumarol. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Stroke in 2010
column5: without sequelae. Stage 3a chronic kidney disease (secondary to diabetic nephropathy). Deep vein thrombosis in lower limbs in 2006. Usual treatment: insulin glargine 10 IU at dinner; atorvastatin 10 mg; acenocoumarol 4 mg as prescribed; tiotropium bromide 18 mcg 1-0-0; alogliptin/metformin 12.5/1
column6: 000 mg 1-0-0; ranolazine 375 mg 1-0-1.  Present illness 83-year-old male under follow-up in cardiology for stable angina. The patient reports that despite adjustment of medical treatment
column7: he persists with oppressive precordial pain
column8: radiating to the jaw and left arm
column9: which is triggered when he climbs more than two flights of stairs and which disappears after approximately 5 minutes' rest. No dyspnoea
column10: palpitations or syncope. The last transthoracic echocardiogram showed a left ventricle with an ejection fraction of 38%
column11: akinesia of the lower basal and middle segments with thinning of the wall and an image of scarring. He was referred to our hospital for catheterisation.  Physical examination Blood pressure (BP) 150/95 mmHg. Heart rate (HR) 70 bpm. Oxygen saturation 98% on room air. Good general condition. Conscious and oriented
column12: eupneic
column13: well perfused.  Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic
column14: no murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation: preserved vesicular murmur with no extra sounds. Lower limbs: no oedema or signs of deep vein thrombosis (DVT)
column15: pulses present and symmetrical.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Baseline electrocardiogram (ECG): sinus rhythm with PR 280 ms
column16: QRS 140 ms with left bundle branch block (LBBB) and secondary repolarisation alterations. CBC: haemoglobin 12.4 g/dl. Leukocytes 8
column17: 700 μl N 82.3%. Platelets 163
column18: 000 μl. INR 1.1. Creatinine 1.85 mg/dl. Glomerular filtration rate 45 ml/min/1.73 m. Sodium 140 mmol/l. Potassium 3.6 mmol/l. AST 377 IU/l. ALT 88 IU/l. Alkaline phosphatase 48 IU/l. GGT 30 IU/l. Total bilirubin 1.11 mg/dl. CK 1018 IU/l. Protein 5.3 g/dl. HbA1c (NGSP) 7.9%. Total cholesterol 100 mg/dl
column19: HDL 26 mg/dl
column20: LDL 48 mg/dl
column21: triglycerides 133 mg/dl. Chest X-ray: CTI within normal limits
column22: lung parenchyma without alterations. Echocardiogram on admission: left ventricle with ejection fraction 38%
column23: akinesia of lower basal and middle segments with wall thinning and scar image. Hypokinesia of the inferolateral side. Coronary angiography 1: multivessel coronary artery disease. Chronic occlusion of the middle right coronary artery (RCA). Severe atheromatosis of proximal-middle anterior descending artery (AD)
column24: percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) and implantation of overlapping drug-eluting stents. Severe atheromatosis of proximal circumflex artery (Cx) - first obtuse marginal (OM1) treated with drug-eluting stent implantation. Acute stent thrombosis resolved during the procedure. Coronary angiography 2: proximal Cx stent thrombosis with new implantation of two drug-eluting stents. Echocardiogram at discharge: left ventricle with ejection fraction 28%
column25: extensive inferoposterolateral akinesia
column26: with anterior hypokinesia. Moderate-severe ischaemic mitral regurgitation.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION Catheterisation programmed due to angina and ventricular dysfunction. Prior to the procedure
column27: the patient was being treated with acenocoumarol
column28: which was discontinued 48 hours before admission
column29: and 250 mg of acetylsalicylic acid was administered without the addition of a P2Y12 inhibitor
column30: pending confirmation of the need for percutaneous coronary revascularisation. Coronary angiography revealed a severe lesion in the proximal LAD
column31: a moderate-severe lesion in Cx-OM1 and chronic occlusion of the LMCA
column32: with little likelihood of viability in its territory. Clopidogrel 600 mg was administered and revascularisation of the LAD and Cx was performed. She presented with periprocedural AMI due to hyperacute thrombosis of the Cx stent and treatment was started with IV cangrelor. Admitted to the coronary unit
column33: presenting acute heart failure
column34: acute pulmonary oedema with arterial hypotension
column35: requiring oxygen therapy with high-flow glasses
column36: perfusion of furosemide and noradrenaline at low doses. In addition
column37: renal function deterioration was observed with a pre-renal component and in relation to contrast nephropathy. After 48 hours of admission
column38: the patient presented an episode of self-limited sustained monomorphic ventricular tachycardia (SMVT) followed by several bouts of non-sustained ventricular tachycardia (NSVT) with ST-segment depression in V3 to V6. In view of these findings
column39: a repeat diagnostic coronary angiography showed thrombosis of the Cx stent
column40: which was revascularised
column41: with a new cangrelor perfusion and a change in antiplatelet therapy from clopidogrel to ticagrelor. He was subsequently transferred to the hospital ward where he presented good clinical evolution
column42: without new episodes of arrhythmias
column43: with improvement in renal function (GFR 48 ml/min). He was discharged with triple antithrombotic therapy with rivaroxaban 10 mg daily
column44: adiro 100 mg daily and ticagrelor 90 mg every 12 hours for 1 month; to continue with double therapy with rivaroxaban 10 mg and ticagrelor 90 mg for 6 months and then only with rivaroxaban 15 mg daily if the GFR remained below 50 ml/min.  DIAGNOSIS Ischaemic heart disease
column45: CCS class II stable exertional angina with moderate LV systolic dysfunction. Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. Elective cardiac catheterisation: Three-vessel coronary artery disease. Percutaneous revascularisation of LAD and Cx. Periprocedural AMI due to hyperacute stent thrombosis in Cx. Acute pulmonary oedema resolved. SMVT in the context of new subacute Cx stent thrombosis. Severe LV systolic dysfunction. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION 57-year-old male
column3: no known allergies
column4: active
column5: currently unemployed.  History Cardiovascular risk factors (CVRF): obesity grade II (BMI of 39). Active smoker of 10 cigarettes/day (12 packs/year). Hypertension diagnosed 3 years ago. Dyslipidaemia diagnosed 10 years ago. Diabetes mellitus (DM) type 2 diagnosed at 38 years of age
column6: with poor metabolic control over the years. As a result
column7: she has diabetic retinopathy and diabetic nephropathy. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) GOLD 2 and sleep apnoea hypopnoea syndrome (SAHS) treated with nocturnal continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP). From the cardiological point of view
column8: in 2017 he had presented an episode of persistent atrial fibrillation associated with tachycardiomyopathy (LVEF 35% with normal sized LV) with LVEF recovery to normal after effective reversion to sinus rhythm and without subsequent cardiology follow-up. He is currently on home treatment with: acenocoumarol 4 mg as prescribed; atorvastatin 20 mg/24 hours; fenofibrate 145 mg/24 hours; bisoprolol 5 mg/24 hours; olmesartan-amlodipine 40/5 mg/24 hours; formoterol-budesonin 160/4.5 mg inhaled/12 hours; insulin novomix 30: 36-36-34 IU breakfast-lunch-dinner sc; dulaglutide 1.5 mg/weekly sc; metformin 1000 mg/24 hours; salbutamol on demand; bromazepam 3 mg/24 hours.  Present illness Consultation at the emergency department of our centre due to increased dyspnoea for approximately 4-6 weeks
column9: with two-pillow orthopnoea
column10: bendopnoea and episodes of paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea. She does not report subjective oliguria but progressive oedematisation of the lower limbs. No palpitations or chest pain. No loss of appetite. No associated fever or other concurrent symptoms.  Physical examination Blood pressure (BP) 90-95/60-65; heart rate (HR) 156 bpm; oxygen saturation in ambient air 90%
column11: temperature 36.2 oC. Conscious
column12: oriented
column13: sweating
column14: with skin pallor
column15: although not deep. Tachypneic
column16: with abdominal breathing. No jugular ingurgitation. Cardiac auscultation: arrhythmic and tachycardic
column17: no audible murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation: generalised hypophonesis with bilateral crackling rales up to midfields. Abdomen distended
column18: soft
column19: not painful on palpation. No visceromegaly. Hydro-aerial sounds present. Oedema with fovea up to both knees
column20: no signs of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and weak symmetrical pedal pulses.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Laboratory tests on admission: Haemogram Hb 12.7 g/dl. Red cells 6.29 x10E6/μl. MCV 70.3 fl. MCH 20.2 pg. MCHC 28.7 g/dl. Leucocytes 14.18 x10E3/μl. Neutrophils (blood-%): 65.4%. Neutrophils 9.27 x10E3/μl. Lymphocytes (%) 22.8%. Lymphocytes 3.24 x10E3/μl. Monocytes (blood-%) 10.8%. Monocytes 1.53 x10E3/μl. Eosinophils (blood-%) 0.6 %. Basophils (blood-%) 0.4%. Immature granulocytes % 1.10 %. Immature granulocytes 0.15 x10E3/μl. UPLAQ platelets 205 x10E3/μ. VPM 11.5 fL. SR R.D.W. coefficient of variation 19.3%. Haematocrit 44.2%. Biochemistry: glucose 146 mg/dl. Urea 76 mg/dl. Creatinine 1.87 mg/dl. FGR (CKD-EPI) 39 ml/min/1.73 m . Sodium ion 141 mmol/l. Plasma potassium ion 7 mmol/l
column21: Creatine kinase 404 U/l. Troponin T 112 ng/l. NT-proBNP 2298. Procalcitonin 0.08. Heparin plasma C-reactive protein 0.5 mg/dl. Coagulation: Prothrombin T. 27.10 sec
column22: INR 2.36. Prothrombin T. (%) 31.0%. Partial thromboplastin time 32.30 sec. Derived fibrinogen 457. D-dimer: 616 ng/m. Blood gases: pH (arterial blood gas) 7.43. pO2 (arterial blood gas) 75 mmHg. pCO2 (arterial blood gas) 31 mmHg. Total CO2 (arterial gas) 21.9 mmol/l. Bicarbonate (arterial gas) 22.4 mmol/l. Excess bases (arterial gas) -3.3 mmol/l. Oxyhaemoglobin saturation (arterial gas) 95%. Electrocardiogram (ECG) on admission: atrial fibrillation at 150 bpm with narrow QRS and secondary repolarisation disorders. Postcardioversion ECG: sinus rhythm at 70 bpm with normal PR
column23: P wave widening suggestive of atrial enlargement. Late progression of R in precordial leads. Intraventricular conduction disturbance with QRS 110ms. QTc 443 ms.  Chest X-rays PA and LAT on admission: very enlarged CTI
column24: no condensation or masses were observed. Diffuse interstitial pattern with perihilar deflections suggestive of heart failure. Free costophrenic sinuses. Echocardiograms during admission: dilated left ventricle (DTd 6.3 cm; VolTd 203 ml)
column25: slightly hypertrophic
column26: with severe left ventricular systolic dysfunction (EF by Simpson bp 29%) and transmitral pattern suggestive of pseudonormalisation with high filling pressures. Right ventricle with slightly reduced systolic function (TAPSE 15 mm). Biauricular dilatation. No significant valvular heart disease. No pericardial effusion. Coronary angiography: coronary arteries with diffuse atheromatosis without significant lesions.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION In the history prior to admission
column27: the patient had taken a certain amount of hypoglycaemic drugs over the previous 4 years: Until 2015 the patient was taking metformin 1000 mg every 12 hours
column28: with poor follow-up and therapeutic adherence during years of illness. At the end of that year
column29: after visiting the health centre
column30: his primary care doctor managed to recover some follow-up and associated insulin therapy: Lantus SoloStar 100 IU/ml
column31: 30 IU in the morning
column32: and referred him to the endocrinology department. In February 2016
column33: he had an Hb1Ac of 10.8%
column34: BMI of 40 and weight of 110 kg
column35: eGFR of 55 ml/min/1.73 m
column36: so the endocrinologist implemented a diabetology education course
column37: and changed Lantus to Novomix 30/70 at 20-20-18 IU breakfast-lunch-dinner
column38: while associating metformin/vildagliptin 50/1000 mg every 12 hours. June 2016
column39: insulinisation takes effect and Hb1Ac is reduced to 8.5%. BMI remains at 40. Novomix 30 is maintained
column40: increasing the doses to 26-26-24 IU breakfast-lunch-dinner. The analysis showed a GFR estimated by CDK-EPI of 40 ml/min/1.73 cm2
column41: so it was decided to discontinue metformin/vildagliptin 50/1000 mg
column42: maintaining only metformin 1000 mg/24 hours. In June 2017 during admission to cardiology for an episode of rapid atrial fibrillation
column43: associated with tachycardiomyopathy. Hb1Ac is 7.1%. The eGFR had decreased by 28 ml/min/1.73 m . Metformin was discontinued. In February 2018 after cardiology review she had fully recovered LVEF. Renal function had improved (eGFR 51 ml/min/1.73 m2). Hb1Ac 8.3%. BMI was still 40. Discussion with endocrinology
column44: the patient's profile is optimal for starting a GLP1 analogue: diabetic with > 10 years of evolution
column45: with metabolic syndrome
column46: obesity (BMI > 35 kg/m2) and previous cardiovascular disease. It was decided to start dulaglutide 0.75 mg weekly subcutaneously and progressively increased to 1.50 mg weekly
column47: without gastrointestinal side effects
column48: with good adaptation and tolerance to the drug. Metformin was restarted at the same time. Novomix therapy was maintained. Six months later
column49: the patient was reviewed and reported a weight loss of 5 kg
column50: he was more animated
column51: with Hb1Ac 7%. Metformin was again discontinued due to reduced glomerular filtration rate. Returning to the current cardiology admission in 2020
column52: the patient presented adequate clinical evolution in hospitalisation after intravenous diuretic treatment
column53: improving from the point of view of heart failure. A transthoracic echocardiogram was performed showing a dilated left ventricle (DTd 6.3 cm; VolTd 203 ml) with severe left ventricular systolic dysfunction (EF by Simpson bp 29%) and transmitral pattern suggestive of pseudonormalisation with high filling pressures. Right ventricle with slightly reduced systolic function (TAPSE 15 mm). Biauricular dilatation. No significant valvular heart disease. No pericardial effusion. Coronary angiography with diffuse atheromatosis in the coronary arteries without significant lesions. It was therefore interpreted as suggestive of a priori non-ischaemic dilated cardiomyopathy decompensated by rapid AF
column54: and outpatient magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) was requested to complete the study. He was treated with amiodarone 200 mg/24 hours orally
column55: remaining in sinus rhythm
column56: without new falls in atrial fibrillation. In the admission blood test
column57: Hb1Ac was 8.1%. The BMI was 39.7. On discharge
column58: as this was a male with a clear metabolic syndrome and diabetes mellitus with poor control
column59: the treatment was optimised as much as possible
column60: and as an option
column61: treatment with dulaglutide was replaced with semaglutide 0.5 mg weekly (and progressively after 4 weeks the dose was increased to 1 mg) in an attempt to improve weight loss and metabolic control
column62: maintaining the same insulin units
column63: as blood glucose levels during admission were in range and his HbA1c was >8%. Metformin is not associated as the glomerular filtration rate at discharge is 39 ml/min by CDK-EPI
column64: with urine albuminuria of 146 mg/g. Finally
column65: atorvastatin 40 mg/24 hours
column66: which the patient was taking
column67: was replaced by rosuvastatin 20 mg/24 hours. Over the last 4 years
column68: the patient has undergone various hypoglycaemic treatments
column69: with frequent changes
column70: mainly due not to side effects but to variable renal function. The advantage of GLP1 analogues is that they are not limited by this fact. CKD is often present in long-standing diabetic patients with poor control
column71: since
column72: as we know
column73: diabetic nephropathy is one of their vascular complications. This can lead to frequent changes in medication
column74: which are associated with treatment errors and poorer long-term adherence of patients to medications. To get the most benefit from therapy
column75: it is important to know the indications
column76: limitations
column77: adverse effects and to tailor the decision of which drug to prescribe to the patient's profile.  DIAGNOSIS Type 2 diabetes mellitus that is difficult to control. Metabolic syndrome. Heart failure with reduced LVEF. Non-ischemic dilated cardiomyopathy decompensated by rapid AF (associated tachycardiomyopathy component). Persistent cardioverted persistent atrial fibrillation electrically anticoagulated with vitamin K antagonists. Stage IIIb A2 chronic kidney disease. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION Male
column3: 75 years old.  History Cardiovascular risk factors (CVRF): hypertension (HT). Type 2 DM with baseline glycosylated haemoglobin (HbA1c) around 8.5%. Dyslipidaemia. Ex-smoker. Obesity (body mass index [BMI] 34 kg/m2).  Cardiological history: Chronic ischaemic heart disease: admission for acute myocardial infarction (AMI) not inferior Q 4 years earlier. *** Catheterisation: left main coronary artery normal. Anterior descending artery (AD) with significant severely calcified lesion in proximal and middle segment. Right coronary artery (RCA) with significant lesion in proximal segment. Conclusions: two-vessel disease. Percutaneous coronary interventionism (PCI) with balloon and implantation of 2 stents in the proximal RCA and proximal-middle LAD. Implantation of a definitive bicameral pacemaker (MCP) 2 years ago due to syncope and atrioventricular block Mobitz II and 2:1 (programmed in DDD). Last echocardiogram 1 year ago: preserved left ventricular (LV) systolic function
column4: with no alterations in segmental contractility. No significant valvulopathies.  Other: renal colic. Surgical interventions: appendectomy
column5: cholecystectomy.  Usual treatment: Empagliflozin 10 mg
column6: 1 tablet daily. Metformin 850 mg
column7: 1 tablet every 12 hours. Bisoprolol 2.5 mg
column8: 1 tablet daily. Ranolazine 500 mg
column9: 1 tablet every 12 hours. Nitroglycerin 15 mg
column10: 1 transdermal patch daily. Clopidogrel 75 mg
column11: 1 tablet daily. Omeprazole 20 mg
column12: 1 capsule daily. Atorvastatin + acetylsalicylic acid (ASA) + ramipril 20/100/5 mg
column13: 1 capsule daily.  Current disease Chronic stable angina (CCS II/IV) with worsening in the last month
column14: until the onset of angina with mild exertion (walking 10 metres)
column15: associated with progressive dyspnoea until it became mild exertion
column16: orthopnoea and oedema in the lower limbs (lower limbs). He reported poor blood pressure control at home (around 150-160/100 mmHg).  Physical examination On arrival at the hospital the patient was in good general condition
column17: eupneic at rest. Blood pressure (BP) 170/95 mmHg
column18: heart rate (HR) 84 bpm
column19: oxygen saturation (SatO2) 96% on room air
column20: afebrile. Presence of jugular engorgement. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic tones
column21: systolic murmur II/VI in aortic focus. Pulmonary auscultation: mild bibasal crackles. Lower limbs: slight perimalleolar oedema
column22: no signs of deep vein thrombosis
column23: pulses preserved.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Complementary tests during admission:  Electrocardiogram (ECG): rhythm stimulated by bicameral pacemaker at 60 bpm. Chest X-ray: cardiomegaly
column24: right costophrenic sinus impingement and vascular redistribution to upper fields.  Laboratory tests: Blood count: haemoglobin 11 g/dl. Haematocrit 30%. Leukocytes
column25: leukocyte formula and platelets without alterations. Coagulation: no alterations. Biochemistry: glucose 161 mg/dl. HbA1c 8.3%. Urea 50 mg/dl. Creatinine 1.2 mg/dl. Ions in normal range
column26: liver function without alterations. CRP 1.1 mg/dl. Lipid study: total cholesterol153 mg/dl
column27: triglycerides 77 mg/dl
column28: HDL 44 mg/dl
column29: LDL 94 mg/dl. Iron metabolism: ferritin 59 μg/l. Iron 48 μg/l. IST 13.9%. Biomarkers of myocardial damage: hsTnI 80 ng/l --> 170 ng/l --> 60 ng/l (normal < 19.8 ng/l). Heart failure markers: NT-proBNP maximum 6
column31: CA125 30 IU/ml. Echocardiogram: left ventricle slightly dilated
column32: with generalised hypokinesia of all its segments and severely depressed global systolic function (LVEF by Simpson 28%). Mild mitral insufficiency. Sclerosed aortic valve
column33: with normal opening and normal transvalvular gradients. Dilated left atrium. Normal diastolic pattern
column34: with no increase in LV filling pressures. Slightly dilated right ventricle with borderline systolic function (TAPSE 17 mm). Mild tricuspid insufficiency (TI) allowing an estimated PAP of 46 mmHg. Inferior vena cava (IVC) not dilated with inspiratory collapse less than 50%. Coronary angiography
column35: left radial artery: stents in CD and DA permeable and without restenosis. Significant stenosis in diagonal branch of reduced calibre
column36: not susceptible to revascularisation.  Complementary tests at 3 months:  CBC: Blood count and coagulation: haemoglobin 14 g/dl. Haematocrit 44%. Leukocyte formula
column37: platelets and coagulation without alterations. Biochemistry: glucose 150 mg/dl
column38: HbA1c 7.5%. Urea 47 mg/dl. Creatinine 1.22 mg/dl. GFR Estimated CKD-EPI 59 ml/min/1.73 m . Ions in range. Liver function without alterations. Lipid study: total cholesterol 182 mg/dl
column39: triglycerides 200 mg/dl
column40: HDL 45 mg/dl
column41: LDL 85 mg/dl. Iron metabolism: ferritin 190 μg/l. Iron 70 μg/L. IST 35%. Heart failure markers: NT-proBNP 2
column42: 503 pg/ml
column43: CA125 17 IU/ml. Echocardiogram: left ventricle slightly dilated
column44: with generalised hypokinesia of all its segments and moderately depressed global systolic function (LVEF 32%)
column45: with asynchrony due to RV stimulation. Absence of significant valvulopathies. Normal diastolic pattern. Right ventricle with preserved function. Non-dilated IVC with adequate inspiratory collapse.  Complementary tests at 6 months:  CBC: Blood count and coagulation: no alterations. Biochemistry: glucose 140 mg/dl
column46: HbA1c 6.7%. Urea 42 mg/dl. Creatinine 1.17 mg/dl. GFR Estimated CKD-EPI 60 ml/min/1.73 m . Ions in range. Liver function without alterations. Lipid study: total cholesterol 162 mg/dl
column47: triglycerides 225 mg/dl
column48: HDL 46 mg/dl
column49: LDL 70 mg/dl. Iron metabolism: ferritin 180 μg/l
column50: iron 68 μg/l
column51: IST 32%. Heart failure markers: NT-proBNP 1
column52: 153 pg/ml
column53: CA125 14 IU/ml. Echocardiogram (videos 3 and 4): non-dilated left ventricle with preserved LVEF (LVEF by Simpson 61%). Preserved diameters and volumes
column54: basal anterior septal hypokinesia. Mild mitral regurgitation. Diastolic pattern of impaired relaxation with no increase in end-diastolic pressures. Normofunctioning RV with trivial TR and systolic pulmonary artery pressure (PAPs) 40 mmHg. IVC 15 mm. Absence of pericardial effusion.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION This is a patient with chronic ischaemic heart disease and a bicameral CCM
column55: who presented progression of his angina to minimal effort angina
column56: as well as deterioration of functional class
column57: associated with the appearance of severe left ventricular dysfunction (previously preserved LVEF)
column58: for which it was decided to admit him to cardiology for study and treatment. During his stay in the cardiology ward
column59: depletive and antianginal treatment was administered
column60: with a progressive decrease in dyspnoea
column61: without new episodes of chest pain
column62: tolerating ambulation. Coronary angiography showed progression of the non-revascularisable coronary artery disease
column63: so it was decided to optimise the antianginal and heart failure medical treatment. Spironolactone and sacubitril/valsartan were started without incident. Given the presence of poorly controlled diabetes associated with obesity and difficult-to-control hypertension in a patient with ischaemic heart disease and heart failure
column64: it was decided to add liraglutide 0.6 mg daily to the treatment and the statin dose was increased. Given the iron deficiency anaemia
column65: treatment was associated with intravenous ferrotherapy
column66: with a good response. At hospital discharge
column67: BP 100/66 mmHg
column68: HR 84 bpm
column69: SatO2 99%
column70: in a state of euvolemia. He was admitted to the heart failure unit for close outpatient monitoring. After 3 months
column71: severe ventricular dysfunction persisted and cardiac resynchronisation therapy (CRT) was decided given the contribution to the dysfunction of continuous RV pacing (pacemaker-dependent patient). After 6 months of optimal medical treatment titrated to maximum tolerated doses and 3 months of CRT implantation
column72: the patient was re-evaluated clinically
column73: analytically and echocardiographically. The patient presented NYHA I without symptoms of heart failure or signs of pulmonary or peripheral congestion
column74: normalisation of ventricular function
column75: absence of chest pain and adequate blood pressure control at home. Significant weight loss (BMI 28) and marked improvement in glycaemic control were also confirmed
column76: reaching target HbA1c. The patient has had no new decompensations or admissions during the current 2-year follow-up.  DIAGNOSIS Main diagnosis: Chronic ischaemic heart disease. Unstable angina Ib with myocardial damage in AMI range. 2-vessel coronary artery disease with permeable stents and new non-revascularisable lesion in diagonal branch. Heart failure with severely depressed ejection fraction of multifactorial origin (diabetic
column77: ischaemic and post RV pacing myocardiopathy). Other diagnoses: Iron deficiency anaemia. Arterial hypertension. Poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus. Dyslipidaemia without meeting LDL targets. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History Patient aged 43 years with no personal or family cardiological history. Active smoking of 1 pack/day
column3: no other toxic habits. No recent trips. No regular medication.  Current illness Patient referred from the emergency department of a regional hospital for an abrupt picture of language alteration
column4: with subtle nominative difficulties
column5: paraphasia and fragmented and incoherent speech together with a tendency to somnolence of 12 hours of evolution. The previous day the patient had been skiing
column6: without incident. A cranial computerised axial tomography (CAT) scan was performed
column7: showing only an old left subthalamic infarction
column8: and a lumbar puncture
column9: with normal biochemistry (according to protocol
column10: PCR for viruses was not indicated). On suspicion of an evolving cerebrovascular accident (CVA)
column11: he was referred to our hospital. On arrival he was assessed by the emergency department. In the anamnesis
column12: the family commented that they had had a mild upper respiratory catarrh two months ago
column13: which had resolved. However
column14: our patient had presented with a persistent non-productive cough for the last 30 days
column15: which she did not attach particular importance to. In addition
column16: in the last week
column17: intolerance to decubitus together with slight oedematisation of the extremities
column18: all compatible with cardiac decompensation. A joint assessment by neurology and cardiology was requested.  Physical examination Initially
column19: the patient was assessed neurologically. Of note: Hypofluent language
column20: with subtle nominative disorder
column21: isolated phonetic paraphasia
column22: with preserved repetition and execution of complex commands. Emotional lability with a tendency to cry
column23: fluctuating. Slightly reduced attentional spaming with alteration of working memory and minimal tendency to pronation without claudication of the right upper extremity. MIS 0/8. The rest of the neurological examination was normal. Subsequently
column24: the cardiology examination was performed: Blood pressure (BP) 152/100 mmHg
column25: tendency to sinus tachycardia
column26: oxygen saturation with nasal goggles at 3 bpm 95%. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic at 95 bpm
column27: third sound
column28: systolic murmur in mitral focus. Pulmonary auscultation: crackles to right midfield and left base. Abdomen without semiology of ascites
column29: hepatomegaly of medial predominance of two traverses. Jugular ingurgitation +. Slight bimalleolar oedema in decubitus. Urine toxins
column31: RSV and influenza serology were requested
column32: all negative. Admission to cardiology with joint management by both specialties.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Electrocardiogram: sinus rhythm at 93 bpm
column33: normal PR
column34: QRS 90 ms
column35: QTc 416 ms. Sokolow-Lyon criteria for LVH. Negative T wave in III
column36: AVF
column37: V5-V6. Chest X-ray: cardiomegaly
column38: signs of vascular redistribution. Pinching of both costophrenic sinuses in relation to small bilateral pleural effusion. Blood tests: urea 29 mg/dl
column39: creatinine 1.02 mg/dl
column40: calcium 8.2 mEq/l
column41: magnesium 2 mEq/l
column42: chlorine 108 mEq/l
column43: sodium 137 mEq/l
column44: potassium 3.9 mEq/l
column45: GGT 70 U/l
column46: GOT 84 U/l
column47: GPT 111 U/l
column48: total bilirubin 1.58 mg/dl
column49: leukocytes 7300/mm
column50: haemoglobin 12.9 g/dl
column51: haematocrit 37.5%
column52: platelets 173000/mm
column53: prothrombin activity 95%
column54: NT-proBNP 12396 pg/ml
column55: CRP 2.66 mg/dl
column56: ultrasensitive troponin I 1346 ng/l
column57: D-dimer 2511 ng/ml. Negative urine toxins. Lumbar puncture: biochemistry 5 red blood cells
column58: 0 nucleated cells
column59: chlorine 130
column60: glucose 0.68
column61: protein 0.37. Gram: no microorganisms found. Bacterial culture negative. Microbiology: nasopharyngeal swab negative for influenza
column62: enterovirus and respiratory syncytial virus. Rectal smear negative for enterovirus. CT scan of the brain on admission: midline structures centred. Symmetrical ventricular system of normal size and morphology. Cortical sulci
column63: peritroncular cisterns and cranial base without alterations. No haemorrhagic lesions were observed. Bedside echocardiogram on admission: dilated left ventricle (LV) (LVED 60 mm) with normal wall thickness
column64: severe ventricular dysfunction with estimated LVEF 15-20%. Global hypocontractility with no clear contractile asymmetries. Mitral valve (MV): thickened leaflets
column65: tenting of both leaflets leading to severe secondary or functional mitral regurgitation. Competent aortic valve. Right ventricle (RV) of normal size
column66: good longitudinal function but CAF 25%. Severe PI. Mild TR allowing estimation of RV-RA gradient 35 mmHg. Dilated inferior vena cava with abolished inspiratory collapse
column67: moderate pulmonary hypertension. Minimal pericardial effusion lamina Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain: craniovertebral junction of normal morphology. No midline abnormalities detected. Posterior fossa of normal configuration. Ventricular system of normal size and morphology. Base cisterns free. Vascular structures of correct configuration
column68: dural venous sinuses permeable. T2 signal alteration in the left thalamic region with a distribution suggesting lacunar infarction by lenticulostriate artery
column69: with almost complete restitution of diffusion. It suggests subacute infarction. A small subcortical T2 hypersignal is detected in the right insula
column70: in the posterior frontal cortex
column71: predominantly in the left hemisphere and in the right occipital juxtacortical white matter. Some small diffusion brightening is observed in the left frontal cortex
column72: indicating acute cortical infarction at present. Conclusion: subacute lacunar infarction in the left thalamic region and acute cortical microinfarcts in the left posterior frontal cortex. Cardiac MRI: poor image quality and impossibility of completing the study due to the patient's neurological condition. Dilated LV with severely depressed LVEF (20%). Failure of isovolumetric relaxation. Normal myocardial thickness and global hypocontractility. No oedema/swelling in myocardial thickness. Late enhancement not acquired because the patient was unable to complete the examination. Right ventricle of normal size with mild hypocontractility. Atria of normal size. Pericardial effusion 10 mm thick. Echocardiogram at discharge: moderately dilated left ventricle with normal thickness (DTDVI 60 mm
column73: indexed VTD 94 ml/m2). Moderate LV systolic dysfunction (LVEF estimated by Simpson biplanar 35%). Global hypocontractility. Pseudonormal diastole. Slightly dilated A.I. MV: thickened cusp leaflets (4 mm). Dilated annulus (38 mm). Preserved opening with posterior leaflet restriction. MI of central origin with jet directed towards the posterolateral wall of LA reaching the roof of the same
column74: without reverse systolic flow in PVs with decreased systolic component (VC 6 mm
column75: estimated ORE 0.30 cm2 and RV 51 ml)
column76: which by all data is estimated in grade III/IV. Right ventricle of normal size and function. Tricuspid valve normal in structure and function. Mild TR. Non-dilated IVC with preserved inspiratory collapse. Estimated normal PAPs. Left and right catheterisation: coronary arteries without angiographically significant lesions. Normal pulmonary pressures. Endomyocardial biopsy (EMB): insufficient material. Myocardial fragments with preserved structure. Interstitial inflammatory infiltrate consisting of neutrophilic polymorphonuclear neutrophils and lymphocytes
column77: without myocyte damage. There were polymorphonuclear cells/mm2 and 3 CD3+ lymphocytes/mm. Viral PCR negative. Echocardiogram at follow-up 6 months after discharge: LV indexed slightly dilated
column78: normal wall thickness. Global systolic function preserved (LVEF 60%)
column79: without regional contractile abnormalities. Both atria of normal size. RV of normal size and function. MV: preserved opening
column80: mild MI. Estimated pulmonary pressure normal. Absence of pericardial effusion.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION Given the multidisciplinary management during admission
column81: the neurological and cardiological evolution of our patient will be differentiated:  Neurological evolution MRI was requested on admission showing a lesion compatible with left anterior thalamic infarction and EEG with no findings of interest. She remained alert and cooperative
column82: mild bradypsychia
column83: and showed some despair when faced with cognitive tests when she could not remember. MOCA 16/30
column84: mainly in TE orientation
column85: language fluency and delayed counting. Reads
column86: but does not achieve full comprehension. Maintains some abstract thinking. Pending assessment by neuropsychologist after discharge. Subsequent periodic neuropsychological studies should be carried out in order to determine whether there is an evolutionary recovery of the cognitive disorders or to conclude her diagnosis as thalamic vascular dementia.  Cardiological evolution Admission with frank heart failure with orthopnoea
column87: bilateral pleural effusion
column88: hepatomegaly and oedema. Treatment was started with levosimendan and furosemide with progressive improvement of congestive signs. Once stabilised
column89: given acute HF of < 3 months of evolution with a history of upper respiratory tract infection
column90: a cardiac MRI was performed which estimated severely depressed ventricular function (LVEF 20%)
column91: with no evidence of myocardial oedema
column92: limited by the impossibility of administering gadolinium given the patient's neurological condition. Subsequently
column93: coronary angiography was performed
column94: with no lesions
column95: right catheterisation showing normal pulmonary pressures and PVR and endomyocardial biopsy of the RV. The biopsy showed an interstitial inflammatory infiltrate consisting of polymorphonuclear (6/m) and CD3+ T lymphocytes (3/mm2) but myocytes with preserved structure. Echocardiogram at discharge showed improvement in ventricular function
column96: estimated at 35%. Once stabilised
column97: neurohormonal treatment was started with sacubitril/valsartan
column98: carvedilol and spironolactone
column99: pending a new control echocardiography three months after discharge
column100: which showed complete recovery of ventricular function and normalisation of repolarisation in the patient's ECG.  DIAGNOSIS Dilated cardiomyopathy with recovered severe ventricular dysfunction; suspected acute myocarditis (borderline). Congestive heart failure of subacute onset. Left thalamic stroke of cardioembolic origin: strategic location for cognitive impairment. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History  Male
column3: 73 years old
column4: independent
column5: with an active life. No known drug allergies. Cardiovascular risk factors: ex-smoker until 30 years ago of about 30 packs/year. High blood pressure (HBP) under pharmacological treatment with good control. Type 2 diabetes mellitus (DM) treated with oral medication with good control. Dyslipidaemia under pharmacological treatment. No alcohol habit. Previous cardiological history: diagnosed in October 2017 due to episode of oppressive chest pain of degenerative aortic valve disease with double lesion (severe aortic stenosis and moderate aortic insufficiency)
column6: ascending aortic aneurysm (52 mm) and 1-vessel coronary artery disease (diffusely diseased DC with poor distal bed). In February 2018
column7: valve replacement was performed
column8: with a number 21 Magna Ease biological aortic prosthesis and a Hemashield No 28 supracoronary tube.  Other history: Duodenal ulcus requiring Billroth II gastrectomy. Synchronous lower rectal and pulmonary neoplasia in 2016. Received radio and chemotherapy; subsequently pulmonary lobectomy and rectal resection. Grade II chronic lower limb ischaemia due to femoropopliteal obstruction in MID and distal popliteal stenosis in MMII. Neurinoma of the left acoustic nerve causing hypoacusis in the left ear
column9: therapeutic attitude pending decision.  Usual treatment: rosuvastatin 10 mg (0-0-1)
column10: clopidogrel 75 mg (0-1-0)
column11: omeprazole 20 mg (1-0-0)
column12: oxycodone 5 mg 1 cp c/4h sp
column13: paracetamol sp and lactulose sp.  Present illness 73-year-old patient admitted to neurology in April 2019 for diplopia and gait instability. In the previous month
column14: he had presented with a general syndrome with weight loss and asthenia
column15: accompanied by febrile fever. Twenty-four hours after admission to neurology to complete studies
column16: having previously been asymptomatic from the cardiological point of view
column17: he began with oppressive central thoracic pain with electrocardiographic changes: right bundle branch block (RBBB) not previously seen and ST elevation on the anterolateral side. The infarction code was activated and loading doses of antithrombotic treatment were administered. A few minutes later
column18: he presented complete atrioventricular block with bouts of prolonged asystole and haemodynamic instability
column19: so orotracheal intubation and connection to mechanical ventilation was performed. He required noradrenaline to maintain blood pressure. On arrival at the haemodynamics ward
column20: a transient pacemaker was placed via the right femoral vein and a coronary angiography was performed showing 100% stenosis of the anterior descending artery as the vessel responsible for the infarction. Primary angioplasty and pharmacoactive destent implantation was performed with good angiographic results. He was then admitted to the cardiac intensive care unit.  Physical examination On admission to neurology: Neurological examination: unstable gait with lateropulsion to the right
column21: right palpebral ptosis and diplopia in various gaze positions. Blood pressure (BP) 135/73 mmHg. Oxygen saturation (SatO2) 97% basal. Temperature 37.4 oC. Pulmonary auscultation: preserved vesicular murmur
column22: without added noises. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic with systolic murmur II/VI in aortic focus. Abdomen soft
column23: depressible and non-painful. No oedema in the lower limbs.  On admission to the cardiac ICU: SAPS-3 (Simplified Acute Physiology Score-3): 76 points (67.4% probability of death on admission). BP 115/56 mmHg with noradrenaline perfusion at 0.7 μg/kg/min. Heart rate (HR) 70 bpm. Temperature 36o C. SatO2 100% (FiO2 0.5). Respiratory rate (RR) 19 rpm. Under sedoanalgesia
column24: pupils half reactive. Upper limb flexion (MMSS) to algesic stimulus. Pulmonary auscultation: preserved vesicular murmur
column25: without added noises. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic with systolic murmur II/VI in aortic focus. Abdomen soft and depressible
column26: not painful on palpation with preserved peristalsis
column27: with no signs of peritoneal irritation. No masses or megaliths were palpable. The lower extremities were well perfused
column28: with preserved and symmetrical pulses
column29: with no signs of deep vein thrombosis.   COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Cranial CT scan without contrast: no signs of bleeding
column30: compressions or displacements in the endocranial structures visualised. Hypodense lesions in the periventricular white matter with a subacute ischaemic appearance. Laboratory tests: blood biochemistry: glucose 255 mg/dl
column31: urea 49 mg/dL
column32: creatinine 0.95 mg/dl
column33: CK 5
column35: TnT 14
column36: 890 ng/l. Haemoglobin 9.3 g/dl
column37: haematocrit 27.4%
column38: leucocytes 14
column39: 550/mm (neutrophils 91.9%)
column40: platelets 149
column41: 000/mm. Coagulation: PT 61%
column42: TTPa 15.9 s
column43: fibrinogen 432 mg/dl. Electrocardiogram (ECG) with chest pain: sinus rhythm at 97 bpm. BRDHH. ST elevation on the anterolateral side. Emergent coronary angiography: Implantation of a transient balloon pacemaker via right femoral vein. Left main coronary artery: no stenosis. Anterior descending: 100% stenosis
column44: TIMI 0 flow in proximal segment. Circumflex: no stenosis. Right coronary artery: severe stenosis of 99% in its distal segment and 100% stenosis in its middle segment
column45: with impression of chronic occlusion
column46: with bad distal bed. Primary angioplasty: via the right femoral artery
column47: with JL4 guidewire
column48: guidefloppy is advanced to the distal LAD
column49: recovering arterial flow. Subsequently
column50: direct implantation of a Resolute Onyx 3.5 x 22 mm drug-eluting device was performed in the proximal segment with success and without complications. Good angiographic result and final TIMI 3 flow. Transesophageal echocardiography: Study performed in ICU with patient on mechanical ventilation. Biological prosthesis in aortic position with a large wart (about 24 mm)
column51: multilobulated and irregular
column52: which moves from LVOT to aorta with the cardiac cycle. Mild valvular insufficiency. Peak gradient of 43 and mean of 30 mmHg (previous 14 and 6 mmHg) with VTI ratio 0.26. Perivalvular aortic abscess extending to mitro-aortic junction. Moderate-severe mitral insufficiency due to de-structuring of the valvular annulus in relation to abscess in the mitro-aortic junction. Severe systolic dysfunction due to extensive akinesia of all apical segments
column53: anterior face and mid-septal and basal segment of anterior septum. No pericardial effusion. Blood cultures: taken on admission. Multisensitive Staphylococcus epidermidis.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION The patient was admitted to the cardiac ICU in shock with high suspicion of infective endocarditis due to febrile fever
column54: being a biological prosthesis holder and the characteristics of the lesion of the anterior descending artery suggesting embolic origin. Transthoracic echocardiography was performed on admission and progressed to transesophageal echocardiography which confirmed the diagnosis of late prosthetic infective endocarditis. In addition
column55: the results of the blood cultures taken on admission were positive for multisensitive Staphylococcus epidermidis. Joint assessment with cardiac surgery. Given the situation of cardiogenic shock
column56: emergency surgery was ruled out. Despite antibiotic treatment
column57: inotropes at increasing doses and intra-aortic balloon counterpulsation implantation
column58: the patient was unable to overcome the shock situation. Acute renal failure
column59: in anuria. Haemofiltration was performed
column60: without improvement. He developed multi-organ failure and finally died.  DIAGNOSIS Death due to late prosthetic infective endocarditis caused by Staphylococcus epidermidis
column61: complicated by: Previous STEMI in haemodynamic Killip-Kimball IVs(cardiogenic hock). 2-vessel coronary artery disease. Chronic right middle coronary artery occlusion. Embolic occlusion of proximal anterior descending artery
column62: primary angioplasty with drug-eluting stent implantation. Severely impaired left ventricular systolic function. Shock of mixed origin
column63: cardiogenic and septic. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column2: CURRENT DISEASE AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION We present the case of a 42-year-old man who was admitted to cardiology for a first episode of heart failure
column3: with a diagnosis of dilated cardiomyopathy. His personal history includes abuse of various intoxicants (GHB [gamma-hydroxybutyric acid]
column4: mephedrone and methamphetamines on a regular basis; occasional cocaine; smoker of 10 cigarettes a day; occasional testosterone cycles). He is HIV positive with good immunovirological control under treatment with dolutegravir/rilpivirine
column5: and had syphilis which was correctly treated. He came to the emergency department for one week of progressive dyspnoea until he became resting
column6: associated with orthopnoea and episodes of paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea. She also presented with neurological symptoms consisting of dyschromatopsia and retroocular headache. She had not suffered from chest pain
column7: palpitations or other cardiovascular symptoms. Physical examination revealed the presence of jugular venous engorgement
column8: with a gallop rhythm in the third tone and crackles up to midfield on pulmonary auscultation.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Electrocardiogram (ECG): sinus tachycardia at 125 beats per minute. Narrow QRS
column9: axis deviated to the left. Poor R growth in precordial leads. Flattened T waves with normal QTc interval. Chest X-ray: increased cardiothoracic index. Signs of pulmonary congestion. Transthoracic echocardiogram on admission: very dilated left ventricle
column10: with severe systolic dysfunction. LVEF 12%. Mobile images in apex
column11: at least 3
column12: maximum 1.8 x 1.0 cm
column13: hypermobile
column14: compatible with thrombi. Dilated right ventricle
column15: with severe systolic dysfunction. Signs of elevated filling pressures. Moderate mitral insufficiency. Moderate pulmonary hypertension. Laboratory tests on admission: NT-proBNP 15678 ng/dl. Undetectable HIV load.   Cranial computerised axial tomography (CAT): appearance of cortico-subcortical hypodensity in the right PCA territory
column16: probably related to an ischaemic event of uncertain evolution. Cranial magnetic resonance imaging (MRI): cortical lesions with contrast uptake and mild diffusion restriction suggesting subacute phase infarcts
column17: the largest right basal occipital with haemorrhagic transformation. There are also three millimetric cortical lesions with intense restriction (right frontal
column18: left frontal and right parietal) that also suggest infarcts but with a shorter evolution time. Cardiac MRI: severely depressed biventricular systolic function (LVEF 12%
column19: RVEF 14%). Mild-moderate mitral insufficiency. Severe left atrial dilatation. No intracavitary thrombi. Pathological late enhancement in the insertion region of the right ventricular free wall and linear intramyocardial uptake in the basal septum of non-ischaemic aetiology. Diagnostic coronary angiography: coronary arteries without significant lesions. Genetic study: negative.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION From the point of view of heart failure
column20: the patient evolved favourably with diuretic treatment until complete resolution of the congestive symptoms. Disease-modifying treatment was started with sacubritril/valsartan
column21: low-dose bisoprolol due to suboptimal tolerance
column22: spironolactone and ivabradine. On monitoring
column23: episodes of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation were detected
column24: as well as episodes of non-sustained monomorphic ventricular tachycardia. Therefore
column25: in view of the negative ventricular remodelling and the presence of late enhancement on MRI
column26: it was decided to implant an implantable cardioverter defibrillator (ICD) for primary prevention. As a study of ventricular dysfunction
column27: ischaemic aetiology was ruled out by coronary angiography and familial aetiology by genetic study; the possibilities were toxic or HIV-associated cardiomyopathy. Regarding antithrombotic treatment
column28: anticoagulant treatment was started on admission with low molecular weight heparins due to the presence of intracavitary thrombi and paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. It was discontinued during admission after brain MRI showed haemorrhagic transformation of the cerebral infarction. At discharge
column29: in the absence of new bleedings and once the absence of interactions with antiretroviral treatment had been verified
column30: oral anticoagulation with rivaroxaban was started.  DIAGNOSIS First episode of heart failure. Severe biventricular dysfunction. Coronary arteries without significant lesions. Non-sustained monomorphic ventricular tachycardia. Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. Intracavitary thrombus (left ventricle)
column31: not seen in cardiac MRI after initiation of anticoagulation. Subacute ischaemic stroke in the right PCA territory of probable cardioembolic aetiology
column32: with subsequent haemorrhagic transformation. HIV infection under treatment with good control. Intake of toxic substances. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History We present a 78-year-old male patient
column3: non-smoker
column4: with no known cardiovascular risk factors (CVRF) or other toxic habits. In 2013 he presented an episode of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation
column5: with no alterations in the echocardiogram or ergometry
column6: for which he was discharged. The patient was not anticoagulated as he had a CHA2DS2-Vasc of 1 point at that time. Since then
column7: the patient's only treatment was occasional lorazepam.  Oncological history: In October 2016
column8: the patient started with intermittent dysphonia. Computed tomography (CT) scan showed a lung mass in the right hemithorax measuring approximately 33 mm and multiple homolateral hilar and mediastinal hilar adenopathies. A right pleural effusion with multiple pseudonodular images and segmental atelectasis in the middle lobe were also seen. Due to these findings
column9: the patient was referred to the pulmonologist
column10: who performed bronchoscopy with aspiration and positron emission tomography (PET)
column11: which confirmed a hypermetabolic mass in the right upper lobe compatible with a primary pulmonary neoplasm. The patient also presented hypermetabolic adenopathies at different levels
column12: including a right supraclavicuar adenopathy
column13: a right pleural effusion and hypermetabolic lesions in the sixth costal arch. Anatomo-pathological study revealed adenocarcinoma (ADC) of the lung
column14: and genetic analysis identified ALK translocation
column15: which has been found to be strongly associated with the genesis of this type of tumour. Finally
column16: the patient was diagnosed with stage IV lung adenocarcinoma (T2aN2M1) with ALK translocation
column17: and first-line palliative treatment with crizotinib
column18: a tyrosine kinase inhibitor
column19: was initiated. After two cycles of chemotherapy
column20: a control CT scan showed a partial response with reduction of the lung mass (20 mm)
column21: reduction of the size of the paratracheal adenopathies and disappearance of the pleural effusion. From January 2017 to June 2017
column22: he received a total of 6 cycles of crizotinib (500 mg/24 hours) and the patient achieved stable disease. During this period
column23: the patient had no relevant adverse events. Since then
column24: the patient was clinically monitored every month and a follow-up CT scan was performed every six months. He had no adverse effects related to the oncological treatment and the disease remained stable according to RECIST criteria.  Current disease In November 2019
column25: during a follow-up oncology consultation
column26: the patient reported slow but progressive onset of oedema in the lower extremities and weight gain of up to 5 kg in the last few months. He also reported noticing an even slower heart rate than usual
column27: around 30-40 beats per minute without dizziness or syncope
column28: and mild dyspnoea without clear orthopnoea. A follow-up CT scan showed that the lung mass remained stable
column29: but a mild pleural effusion
column30: a laminar pericardial effusion and a periportal hypodensity compatible with oedema were observed. It was decided to temporarily suspend crizotinib
column31: treatment with a loop diuretic was started and the patient was referred to the cardio-oncology department to rule out congestive heart failure.  Physical examination At the first visit to the cardio-oncology department
column32: the patient was hypertensive (187/91 mmHg) and oxygen saturation was normal. Physical examination revealed no jugular plethora but he had hepatojugular reflex and oedema with pitting in both lower extremities. Cardiac auscultation was rhythmic at about 40 beats per minute
column33: with no murmurs.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS The electrocardiogram showed sinus rhythm at 43 beats per minute
column34: with first degree atrioventricular block and normal QT (QTc 422 ms). No significant alterations were evident in the blood tests: glucose 82 mg/dl
column35: urea 38 mg/dl
column36: creatinine 1.15 mg/dl
column37: glomerular filtration rate (CKD-EPI) 60 ml/min/1.73 m
column38: sodium 145 mEq/l
column39: potassium 4.6 mEq/l
column40: magnesium 2.2 mg/dl
column41: albumin 3.8 g/dl
column42: cholesterol 177 mg/dl
column43: haemoglobin 14 g/dl
column44: leucocytes 4.41 x 103/ml
column45: platelets 149 x 103/ml. NT-proBNP was determined once diuretic treatment had been started and the patient's clinical situation had improved
column46: and the value was 115 pg/ml (normal range 0 to 300 pg/ml). An echocardiogram was also performed and showed mild to moderate septal hypertrophy with preserved left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) (estimated LVEF 58%). The aortic root was mildly dilated (42 mm ascending aorta) with mild aortic and mitral valve regurgitation. The left atrium was mildly dilated. The right ventricle was normal in size and function. There was mild tricuspid regurgitation without significant pulmonary hypertension
column47: and mild pericardial effusion.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION After the first visit
column48: the patient's condition was suspected to be heart failure secondary to bradycardia. Bradycardia is a common cardiovascular adverse effect of crizotinib
column49: which can also cause heart failure. According to the Framingham criteria for heart failure
column50: the patient met two major and three minor criteria. The diagnosis was further supported by echocardiographic findings of mild-to-moderate septal hypertrophy with preserved LVEF and mild pericardial effusion. Differential diagnosis was made with other entities that could cause systemic congestion: Systemic congestion can be caused by both renal disturbances and nephrotic syndrome. The association between lung cancer and paraneoplastic syndromes is frequent
column51: including nephrotic syndrome. As we can see from the laboratory results
column52: the patient's renal function was normal and albumin and cholesterol were within normal ranges. Liver failure can also be a cause of oedema
column53: but the patient had no history of ethylism
column54: and both bilirubin and liver enzymes were normal. It should also be noted that venous compression due to tumour progression could cause oedema in the lower extremities. However
column55: no abdomino-pelvic or inguinal adenopathies were seen on the follow-up CT scan in October 2019. Some medications that are part of the different oncological treatments can cause systemic congestion (e.g. corticosteroids
column56: analgesics such as ibruprofen
column57: naproxen...). Our patient
column58: however
column59: was not receiving treatment with any of them. By the time the patient was referred to the cardio-oncology department
column60: crizonitib had already been discontinued and the loop diuretic was started. Since then
column61: the patient progressed favourably
column62: losing up to 2-3 kilograms. In addition
column63: enalapril 5 mg/24 hours daily was started due to the hypertension observed in the consultation. The patient was finally diagnosed with symptomatic bradycardia secondary to crizotinib and congestive heart failure with preserved LVEF. After one week of treatment the patient lost 5 kg and had no congestive signs. He also reported an increased heart rate. Holter blood pressure monitoring showed that the patient had grade 1 hypertension
column64: and treatment was adjusted. The loop diuretic could be withdrawn because the patient evolved favourably
column65: the congestive signs resolved
column66: no serious heart disease was observed in the tests performed
column67: and his heart rate was around 60 beats per minute. After a multidisciplinary consultation
column68: and considering the spectacular response he had previously shown
column69: it was decided to restart crizotinib with close monitoring.  DIAGNOSIS Heart failure with preserved LVEF secondary to sinus bradycardia. Sinus bradycardia secondary to crizotinib. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History  Social and family history: 22-year-old male patient
column3: medical student. Thin. Smoker of 1 cigarette a day for 3 years. Occasional cannabis user. Maternal grandfather with heart attack at the age of 60. Mother diagnosed with familial hypercholesterolemia with positive genetic study.  Personal history: Cardiovascular risk factors (CVRF): no known arterial hypertension (AHT)
column4: diabetes mellitus (DM) or dyslipidaemia (DL). No cardiological history of interest. Other history: Irritable colon. Migraine. Usual medication: Does not take any medication.  Present illness The patient came to the emergency department due to oppressive chest pain of great intensity
column5: which started at rest
column6: radiating to the left arm
column7: unchanged with inspiratory movements
column8: accompanying vegetative symptoms. On arrival at the emergency department
column9: the patient had been in pain for more than an hour
column10: with no improvement since onset. He reported symptoms of precordial oppression with exercise since 3 months earlier. No symptoms suggestive of catecholaminergic release.  Physical examination On arrival at the ED he was afebrile
column11: normoperfused
column12: with chest pain. SatO2 96% on room air
column13: blood pressure 123/84 mm/Hg
column14: heart rate 92 l/min. Neck: symmetrical
column15: no jugular ingurgitation or hepatojugular reflux. No murmurs on carotid auscultation. Cardiac auscultation: regular heart sounds without murmurs or extratonos. Pulmonary auscultation: vesicular murmur present
column16: well ventilated fields
column17: no extra sounds. Abdominal examination: nondescript. Lower limbs: symmetrical
column18: no signs of DVT or oedema.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS  Blood count: haemoglobin 17.2 g/dl
column19: haematocrit 49.5%
column20: red blood cells 5.66x10
column21: leukocytes 21
column23: neutrophils 11
column25: lymphocytes 8
column27: eosinophils 520
column28: platelets 429
column29: 000. Biochemistry: glucose 124 mg/dl
column31: creatinine 1.19 mg/dl
column32: glomerular filtrate > 90 ml/min/1.78 m
column33: sodium ion 142 mmol/l
column34: potassium ion 3.2 mmol/l
column35: troponin T 7 ng/l
column36: creatine kinase 225 U/l
column37: urate 6.8 mg/dl
column38: alkaline phosphatase 121 U/l
column39: AST 37 U/l
column40: ALT 59 U/l
column41: GGT 45 U/l
column42: total bilirubin < 1.0 mg/dl
column43: total cholesterol 98 md/dl
column44: HDL 41 mg/dl
column45: triglycerides 43 mg/dl
column46: calculated LDL cholesterol 49 mg/dl
column47: HbA1C 5.6%
column48: TSH 2.33 mU/l. Coagulation: normal in all parameters. Urine toxicity: benzodiazepines
column49: opiates
column50: cocaine
column51: cannabinoids and methamphetamines negative. Electrocardiogram: sinus rhythm at 80 L/min
column52: normal PR interval
column53: narrow QRS
column54: normal axis at +40
column55: ST-segment elevation up to 3 mm on the anterolateral side with mirror image on the inferior side. Coronary angiography: CD artery without angiographic lesions. Cx artery without angiographic lesions. DA artery with thrombotic occlusion in its middle third
column56: immediately distal to the exit of the first diagonal. Angioplasty: with XB 3.5 Sion is advanced to distal DA recovering flow. Due to abundant thrombotic content
column57: tirofiban is administered i.v. (bolus + perfusion). Direct implantation of a Synergy 4 x 20 mm drug-eluting stent was performed in the mid-proximal segment. Due to an image of under-expansion at mid-stent level
column58: post-dilatation with a 4.5 mm NC balloon was performed
column59: achieving adequate expansion. A thrombus floating distal to the stent was found floating intra-arterially
column60: so it was decided to perform thromboaspiration with a Pronto device
column61: extracting a large red thrombus. Excellent angiographic result after thromboaspiration and final TIMI 3 flow. Echocardiogram: non-dilated left ventricle (LV) with extensive anterior
column62: anteroseptal and lateral akinesia (middle segments and apical cap) with normal contractility of the inferior territory
column63: infero-lateral and basal inferior septum.   Extended CBC: Serial myocardial damage markers (on admission
column64: at 3 hours
column65: 12 hours and 36 hours
column66: respectively): Ultrasensitive troponin T (ng/l): 7 -> 7.611 -> 9.234 -> 3.215 Creatinine kinase (U/l): 225 -> 3.764 -> 3.546 -> 912 Genetic study for familial hypercholesterolemia: negative. Liporpotein A: 90.7 mg/dl (normal < 30 mg/dl). Chromatography and electrophoresis: acid diuresis: 1.850. Collection time (chromatography): metanephrine 24 hours: 198
column67: 7 μg/24 hours. Normetanephrine 24 hours: 377.4 μg/24 hours. Toxicology: metanephrine 30. Normetanephrine 122 Serology antiphospholipid syndrome: anti-cardiolipin IgG and IgM negative (< 1.6 GPL U/ml and 0.8 MPL-U/ml
column68: respectively)
column69: anti-beta2 glycoprotein IgM and IgG negative (< 1.4 U/ml and 1.5 U/ml
column70: respectively). Endocrinology consultation: metanephrine and metanephrine levels in urine were normal and plasma levels were only slightly elevated in normetanephrine
column71: which
column72: together with the absence of compatible clinical manifestations
column73: makes the presence of pheochromocytoma or parnaganglioma highly improbable.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION We present the case of a very young 23-year-old patient admitted to cardiology for an acute coronary syndrome with ST-segment elevation (STEACS) in extensive anterior face
column74: for which the heart code is activated. An emergent coronary angiography showed coronary artery disease in one vessel
column75: with thrombotic occlusion of the middle LAD coronary artery
column76: and angioplasty was performed with implantation of a drug-eluting stent
column77: perfusion of tirofiban and aspiration of the remains of the thrombotic material. During his stay on the hospital ward
column78: the patient remained asymptomatic
column79: and the causal study of this acute coronary syndrome was carried out. It is noteworthy that the patient's cardiovascular risk factors were that he was a smoker with a cumulative consumption of less than 1 packet/year
column80: with no other known metabolic disorders. There is a maternal history of ischaemic heart disease and his mother is diagnosed with familial hypercholesterolaemia. The patient underwent a lipid profile analysis which did not show any markedly elevated total cholesterol or LDL values
column81: but rather a low CV risk profile. Urine toxins were requested and were negative
column82: and a study of coagulopathies was carried out
column83: also negative. Serum and urine metanephrines were requested and the patient was referred to endocrinology
column84: who considered that there was a low probability of pheochromocytoma. Finally
column85: it was decided to expand the lipid profile with a lipoprotein A (Lp(a))
column86: which was found to be elevated for cardiovascular risk with a value 3 times the upper limit of normal. The patient evolved satisfactorily
column87: with no clinical signs of heart failure
column88: although on discharge he presented moderate LV dysfunction
column89: due to extensive anterior
column90: anteroseptal and lateral akinesia (middle segments and apical cap).   DIAGNOSIS Extensive anterior STEACS. Haemodynamic status KK1. Single vessel coronary artery disease (SCAD). Percutaneous total revascularisation using a drug-eluting stent. Moderate LV dysfunction (LVEF 44%).
