column2: CURRENT DISEASE AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION We present the case of a 47-year-old woman with cardiovascular risk factors: hypertension
column3: smoking and dyslipidaemia. History of chronic stable angina in functional class II without previous treatment. She consulted a centre in the city of Buenos Aires (Argentina) due to atypical and characteristic precordial pain at rest of 1 hour's duration. Physical examination on admission showed blood pressure (BP) 120/65 mmHg
column4: heart rate (HR) 130 bpm
column5: SatO2 90% on room air. Jugular ingurgitation 3/3 without inspiratory collapse. Rhythmic heart sounds
column6: no murmurs. Regular ventilatory mechanics at the expense of tachypnoea and use of accessory muscles
column7: generalised hypoventilation and regular bilateral air entry
column8: with intolerance to decubitus. Good peripheral perfusion with positive symmetrical pulses. Bilateral malleolar oedema.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Electrocardiogram (ECG): sinus tachycardia at 130 bpm
column9: PR 120 ms
column10: QRS 80 ms. ST-segment depression less than 1 mm in DII
column11: DIII
column12: aVF and from V3 to V6. Initial Q wave in DI and aVL with ST elevation of 1 mm. CBC: haematocrit 29%
column13: haemoglobin 9.5 g/dl
column14: leukocytes 19
column16: platelets 212
column17: 000/μl. Baseline coagulation
column18: renal function and ions normal. Myocardial damage markers: Troponin T US 15 ng/l and 24 ng/l (normal 0-14 ng/l). CK/CK-MB: 550/180 IU/l. Cardiac catheterisation: right dominance. Right coronary artery without lesions. Patent anterior descending and circumflex arteries
column19: with non-significant lesions in the middle third. Transthoracic echocardiogram: left ventricle (LV) not dilated
column20: mild LV systolic dysfunction. Parasternal short axis shows pseudoaneurysm in the lateral aspect of the LV. No significant valvular heart disease. Chest X-ray: left paracardiac radiopacity probably compatible with the location of the ventricular pseudoaneurysm
column21: bilateral pleural effusion. Chest CT scan: saccular image on the lateral aspect of the LV compatible with ventricular pseudoaneurysm.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION ECG showed sinus tachycardia at 130 bpm with high lateral subepicardial lesion (image 1) and positive troponin
column22: so emergency coronary angiography was performed
column23: showing patent arteries with non-significant lesions in the anterior descending and circumflex arteries
column24: so angioplasty was not performed and medical treatment was started. After 72 hours
column25: the patient presented with new precordial pain of intensity 10/10
column26: and an ECG was performed with no changes with respect to the previous one and negative biomarkers. An echocardiogram was performed which revealed a ventricular pseudoaneurysm in the lateral aspect of the left ventricle
column27: for which urgent referral to our centre for cardiovascular surgery was requested. Chest X-ray showed left cardiac radiopacity compatible with probable pseudoaneurysm and chest CT scan showed a large saccular formation measuring 59 x 68 x 75 mm depending on the lateral wall of the LV
column28: contained by pericardium and connected by an orifice to the myocardium with the presence of thrombi adhering to the inner wall of this formation
column29: associated with haemopericardium and bilateral pleural effusion
column30: predominantly on the right. Emergency surgery was performed with closure of the aneurysm neck
column31: placement of a Dacron patch and Prolene reinforcement at the edge of the rupture (image 6). In the immediate postoperative period
column32: the patient presented hypovolemic shock and subsequent right ventricular failure
column33: which evolved favourably with volume expansion and inotropic drugs. Prior to discharge
column34: a new echocardiogram was performed which showed good ventricular function
column35: with slight pericardial effusion.  DIAGNOSIS Acute coronary syndrome with ST-segment elevation (STEMI) in the upper lateral face. Coronary arteries without acute thrombotic occlusion. Ventricular pseudoaneurysm as a mechanical complication
column36: with signs of imminent rupture and requiring emergency surgical repair. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION We present the case of a 77-year-old man who
column3: after eating fresh fish
column4: developed severe anaphylaxis requiring the administration of intramuscular adrenaline with subsequent chest pain and ST-segment elevation
column5: accompanied by clinical and laboratory data of low cardiac output.  History No known drug allergies. Cardiovascular risk factors: ex-smoker
column6: hypertension (HT)
column7: type 2 diabetes mellitus (DM2)
column8: high blood pressure. No known heart disease or bronchopathy. Chronic ischaemia syndrome of both lower extremities
column9: grade IV. Transphalangeal amputation of the second toe of the left lower extremity (IBD) in June 2017. Amputation of the fourth toe of the right lower extremity (EID) in October 2018. Infracondylar amputation of EID on 26/08/2019. Previous surgical interventions: cataract of right eye. Usual treatment: insulin glargine
column10: 20 units at dinner; metformin 850 mg
column11: 1 tablet every 12 hours; sitagliptin 50 mg
column12: 1 tablet every 12 hours
column13: repaglinide 1 mg
column14: 1 tablet breakfast
column15: lunch
column16: dinner; acetylsalicylic acid 100 mg
column17: 1 tablet at lunch; enalapril/lercanidipine 20/20 mg
column18: 1 tablet at breakfast; atorvastatin 20 mg
column19: 1 tablet at dinner; allopurinol 300 mg
column20: 1 tablet at breakfast; etoricoxib 120 mg
column21: 1 tablet per day; metamizole 575 mg; paracetamol 1 g
column22: on demand. Baseline functional status: cognitive functions preserved. Wheelchair-bound due to recent infracondylar amputation of DID. No angina or dyspnoea in his usual life.  Present illness A 77-year-old man
column23: who after having dined on fresh hake and clams
column24: started after 4 hours with generalised erythema
column25: intense palmo-plantar pruritus
column26: genital pruritus and tongue oedema with slight dysphonia. On arrival of basic life support
column27: he was administered intravenous dexchlorpheniramine and Actocortin (i.v.)
column28: despite which
column29: on arrival at the emergency department of his hospital of reference
column30: he persisted with slight pruritus and notable tongue oedema
column31: so it was decided to administer adrenaline 0.5 mg intramuscular (i.m.)
column32: starting instantly with intense chest pain radiating to the left upper limb. An electrocardiogram (ECG) was performed showing anteroseptal ST elevation with specular decrease in the inferior face
column33: which did not improve after sublingual nitroglycerine
column34: with accompanying signs of low cardiac output (arterial hypotension
column35: acral coldness and obnubilation)
column36: so continuous perfusion of dobutamine (DBT) and noradrenaline (NAD) was started. Suspicion of ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome (STEMI) anteroseptal Killip IV
column37: the infarction code was activated and the patient was transferred to the haemodynamics ward of our hospital for emergent percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI). On arrival
column38: the patient was conscious and oriented

column40: under continuous perfusion of NAD (at 0.8 mcg/kg/min) and DBT (at 5 mcg/kg/min) with a tendency to arterial hypotension (blood pressure [BP] 75/50 mmHg) and sinus tachycardia (heart rate [HR] 120 bpm). The ECG showed persistent anteroseptal ST elevation
column41: and on arrival echocardiography
column42: moderate LV dysfunction with akinesia of all mid-apical and anterior segments. He was transferred directly to the haemodynamics ward. Time of onset of chest pain: 5:15 am. Time of arrival at the emergency room: 5:30 am. Time of opening of the artery: 7:08 hours. TIMI risk scale: 12 points (35.9%). CRUSADE risk scale: 59 points
column43: 19.5% (high haemorrhagic risk).  Physical examination On admission to the coronary unit BP 75/50 mmHg; HR 120 bpm; baseline SatO2 95%; afebrile. Somnolent. Poor distal perfusion with lividity in the lower extremities and acral coldness. Head and neck: no jugular ingurgitation. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic

column45: depressible
column46: not painful on palpation

column48: no oedema in the lower extremities
column49: palpable left foot.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG in the emergency department of the regional hospital: sinus rhythm at 70 bpm
column50: long PR

column52: ST elevation of V1-V5
column53: I and AVL

column55: with specular decrease in inferior face. ECG on admission to the coronary unit: sinus tachycardia at 115 bpm

column85: with the rest of the vessel with mild atheromatosis
column86: TIMI 2 flow. The 1st and 2nd diagonals present moderate ostial stenosis. Circumflex (Cx): proximal moderate lesion and distal moderate long atheromatosis. column92: long PR

CLINICAL EVOLUTION The patient is admitted to the coronary unit after emergent catheterisation where severe bivascular coronary artery disease with acute thrombotic lesion of the ostial LAD is detected and treated with a stent in the LAD-CT with good results. Immediate haemodynamic improvement was observed and dobutamine could be discontinued in the haemodynamics room. He was admitted to the coronary unit in a stable condition and was able to completely discontinue noradrenaline 2 hours after admission. On admission
column101: he reported some residual mild chest discomfort that resolved in the first 4 hours. Suspicion of anaphylaxis (tongue oedema
column102: pruritus
column103: etc.) led to serial tryptase determinations during the first 24 hours
column104: which were positive. He was maintained during his admission to the coronary unit with corticoid and intravenous dexchlorpheniramine (Polaramine) with complete resolution of genital itching and tongue oedema in the first 12 hours
column105: remaining asymptomatic thereafter. He was assessed by the allergology department
column106: which analysed him for specific IgE and found elevated IgE for Anisakis and negative IgE for hake and clams. According to the recommendation of the allergology department
column107: the intravenous glucocorticoid doses were reduced and Polaramine (antiH1) was maintained throughout the hospital stay until 5 days after the acute event. She was also forbidden to eat fish or seafood until further assessment by her after discharge from hospital. Haemodynamically
column108: he remained stable during the 48 hours of admission with a tendency towards asymptomatic mild hypotension (TAS 90-100 mmHg) and sinus tachycardia (95-110 bpm)
column109: without new exploratory or analytical data of low perfusion
column110: with moderate LV dysfunction persisting at discharge
column111: and the introduction of beta-blockers or angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACE inhibitors) not being possible due to mild hypotension. Spironolactone is started
column112: with good tolerance. Respiratory status remained stable
column113: with the appearance on the first day of admission of mild heart failure (bibasal crackles) without dyspnoea or desaturation. A daily dose of oral furosemide was started and was well tolerated. He presented a single febrile peak up to 38.3oC without shivering on the third day of admission (11/9/2019) with no clinical evidence of infection. Samples were taken for culture (blood/urine culture) and empirical amoxicillin/clavulanic acid was prescribed. During his admission
column114: he was assessed by the vascular surgery department for evaluation of the recent surgical wound of amputation of DID
column115: the wounds were found to be in a good state of healing with some necrotic spots but with no evidence of infection
column116: and intradermal suture removal was pending. Once the condition had stabilised
column117: it was decided to transfer the patient to the ward for evolutionary control and to perform a new catheterisation in the second stage
column119: which was successful. During his stay on the ward
column120: the patient remained haemodynamically and respiratory stable
column122: and after re-evaluation by the allergology service
column123: the patient was discharged with an outpatient appointment for joint follow-up by allergology and cardiology.  DIAGNOSIS Main diagnosis: Killip IV STEACS (Kounis syndrome type II). Severe Anisakis anaphylaxis (in the context of fresh fish ingestion). Severe two-vessel coronary artery disease: DA and CD. Acute thrombotic lesion in ostial LAD with severe stenosis. Primary PCI with drug-eluting stent implantation in TC-DA axis. Second stage PCI with drug-eluting stent implantation in DC-PVI with moderately depressed LVEF.  Secondary diagnoses: Cardiovascular risk factors: ex-smoker
column125: DM2. Grade IV chronic ischaemia syndrome of the LVES. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  A 73-year-old woman attended the emergency department of our centre due to dyspnoea.  History The patient had the following medical history: Cardiovascular risk factors: dyslipidaemia in treatment with a lipid-lowering drug in monotherapy
column3: with last LDL-C of 80 mg/dl. Cardiological history: medical records show detection of a heart murmur more than 20 years ago in check-ups by a primary care doctor
column4: never studied. Other relevant medical history: locally advanced adenocarcinoma of the left breast at the age of 38
column5: treated with radical mastectomy
column6: lymphadenectomy and chemoradiotherapy
column7: free of disease since then with no recurrences. Usual treatment: simvastatin 20 mg every 24 hours.  Present illness On arrival at the emergency department
column8: the patient reported a clinical picture of approximately 4 weeks of progressive deterioration of functional class to the point of presenting dyspnoea at rest (NYHA IV)
column9: as well as orthopnoea that forced her to sleep in a sitting position. She also reported a subjective decrease in the volume of diuresis
column10: without associated swelling of the lower limbs. She had no anginal chest pain either at rest or on exertion. He denied any infectious symptoms when questioned by apparatus.  Physical examination Blood pressure (BP) 122/70 mmHg
column11: heart rate (HR) 100 bpm
column12: O2 Sat 95% with FiO2 35%. Jugular venous pressure increased (15 cm). Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic
column13: with systolic murmur in aortic focus radiating to IV/VI carotid arteries
column14: with abolition of the second sound. Systolic murmur in mitral focus radiating to axilla III/VI. Pulmonary auscultation: mediobasal crackles. Abdomen: soft and depressible
column15: not painful on deep palpation
column16: no masses or megaliths
column17: Blumberg and Murphy negative. Positive hepatojugular reflux. Extremities: no oedema in the lower extremities
column18: peripheral pulses preserved and symmetrical
column19: no signs of phlebitis. Echoscopy was performed at the bedside in the emergency department
column20: which showed calcification of the aortic valve with severely limited opening
column21: as well as calcification of the mitral valve apparatus with significant regurgitation
column22: so it was decided to admit the patient to the cardiology ward for stabilisation
column23: complete the study and assess therapeutic options.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Portable chest X-ray on admission: cardiomediastinal silhouette not assessable. Left costophrenic sinus impingement. Prominent pulmonary hilarity with a vascular appearance. Signs of vascular redistribution. Electrocardiogram: sinus tachycardia at 110 bpm. Normal PR. Normal axis. Voltage criteria of left ventricular hypertrophy. QRS 120 ms with intraventricular conduction disturbance type BRI. Signs of systolic overload.  Laboratory tests on admission: Haemoglobin 16.2 g/dl
column24: no leukocytosis or left shift
column25: platelets 232 x 10^9/l. Haemostasis: INR 1.2
column26: APTT 30.1 sec. Biochemistry: glucose 127 mg/dl
column27: creatinine 1.00 mg/dl
column28: GFR 55.8 ml/min/1.72 m
column29: sodium 137 mEq/l
column31: total bilirubin 1.2 mg/dl
column32: GOT 45 IU/l
column33: GPT 35 IU/l
column34: C-reactive protein 0.1 mg/dl. Blood tests after clinical deterioration: Haemoglobin 15.4 g/dl
column35: no leukocytosis or left shift
column36: platelets 195 x 10^9/l. Haemostasis: INR 1.9
column37: aPTT 40 sec. Biochemistry: glucose 150 mg/dl
column38: creatinine 1.94 mg/dl
column39: GFR 25.1 ml/min/1.72 m
column40: sodium 143 mEq/l
column41: potassium 4.2 mEq/l
column42: total bilirubin 2.7 mg/dl
column43: GOT 150 IU/l
column44: GPT 263 IU/l
column45: C-reactive protein 2.3 mg/dl. Echocardiogram: non-dilated left ventricle (LV) with mild concentric hypertrophy. Global hypokinesia of septal and anterior predominance with severely depressed GSF (LVEF 25%). Dilated left atrium. Double aortic lesion on severely calcified valve: severe stenosis (planimetry 0.5 c
column46: mGm 52 mmHg). Moderate regurgitation (THP 260 ms). Moderate mitral regurgitation (II-III/VI) on sclerodegenerative valve (ERO by PISA 0.25 cm2). RV with non-enlarged diameters and preserved GSF (TAPSE 18 mm). Moderate tricuspid regurgitation that allows estimating PsAP at 70 mmHg. Inferior vena cava (IVC) plethoric. Coronary angiography 1: calcification of ascending aorta
column47: intensely calcified sigmoid arteries with reduced opening
column48: severe stenosis (peak gradient 55 mmHg). Coronary arteries: normal trunk. Anterior descending artery with 80% lesion in the middle segment. Circumflex artery with irregularities without stenosis. Right coronary artery with 90% lesion in proximal segment. Thoracic CT without contrast: marked calcified atheromatosis in the thoracic aorta
column49: especially in the location of the aortic button. Calcification of the aortic valve
column50: tricuspid valve and right coronary artery. Coronary angiography 2: percutaneous transluminal coronary angioplasty (PTCA) was performed on the LAD and RCA lesions with implantation of everolimus-eluting drug-eluting stents
column51: with good angiographic results. TAVI implantation: after balloon valvuloplasty
column52: a 23 mm SAPIEN ULTRA prosthesis was implanted. After implantation
column53: electromechanical dissociation without identifying coronary occlusion
column54: contrast extravasation to the pericardium
column55: aortic rupture or prosthetic embolisation.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION After admission to the cardiology ward
column56: the patient initially evolved favourably
column57: but subsequently presented clinical deterioration due to a new increase in dyspnoea associated with a marked decrease in the volume of diuresis (< 10 ml/kg/h) and hypotension (BP 73/35 mmHg)
column58: so that in view of the situation of cardiogenic shock it was decided to admit her to the coronary unit for stabilisation. Vasoactive support was started with noradrenaline at 12 mcg/min and inotropic support with dobutamine at 10 mcg/kg/min
column59: as well as intensive diuretic therapy with iv perfusion of furosemide at 20 mg/h
column60: with an initial favourable response that allowed negative balances to be maintained without the need to start ultrafiltration therapy. The echocardiographic study confirmed the presence of severe ventricular dysfunction and severe aortic stenosis (and moderate aortic regurgitation) and diagnostic coronary angiography detected severe two-vessel coronary artery disease
column61: as well as significant calcification of the ascending aorta
column62: which was confirmed by non-contrast thoracic CT. With these findings
column63: the case was presented at the medical-surgical session
column64: and surgical valve replacement by the HEART Team was rejected given the patient's clinical situation
column65: with an excessive surgical risk (EuroSCORE II 80.35%)
column66: as well as her anatomical characteristics
column67: with very marked aortic calcification that unacceptably limited the possibilities of cannulation for extracorporeal circulation. In addition
column68: given the presence of at least moderate aortic regurgitation
column69: aortic balloon valvuloplasty as a bridge to TAVI was ruled out and it was decided to initially stabilise the patient in the OCU and
column70: depending on the evolution
column71: to consider two-stage treatment with percutaneous revascularisation of the coronary lesions and subsequent percutaneous aortic valve replacement. During his stay in the OCU
column72: the evolution was slowly favourable and
column73: after treatment with IV levosinendan
column74: inotropic support could be withdrawn
column75: requiring only vasopressor support with low doses (0.1 - 0.2 mcg/kg/min) of NA. Percutaneous revascularisation of the AD and DC lesions was performed. Finally
column76: percutaneous valve replacement via the right femoral artery was attempted
column77: and after expansion of the bioprosthesis
column78: the patient presented cardiac arrest due to electromechanical dissociation
column79: with no immediate complications derived from the technique (coronary occlusion
column80: pericardial contrast extravasation
column81: aortic rupture
column82: or prosthetic embolisation)
column83: so advanced cardiopulmonary resuscitation manoeuvres were started
column84: resulting in exitus after 40 min without achieving recovery of spontaneous circulation.  DIAGNOSIS Double sclerodegenerative aortic lesion: severe stenosis and moderate regurgitation. Moderate mitral regurgitation on sclerodegenerative valve. Severe ventricular dysfunction (LVEF 25%). Ischaemic heart disease: two-vessel disease: CDp 90%
column85: DAm 80%. PCI with implantation of two everolimus-eluting drug-eluting stents. Porcelain aorta. Cardiogenic shock. Failed percutaneous aortic bioprosthesis implantation due to death during the procedure. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION Male
column3: 79 years old.  History High blood pressure. Altered basal glycaemia. Valvular heart disease consisting of severe degenerative mitral insufficiency
column4: severe tricuspid insufficiency and severe pulmonary hypertension. Preserved left and right ventricular function. Permanent atrial fibrillation. Moderate-severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Sleep apnoea-hypopnoea syndrome
column5: in treatment with nocturnal CPAP. Stage 3a chronic kidney disease secondary to nephroangiosclerosis. Bronchial carcinoid tumour T2 N0 M0
column6: operated by right lower lobectomy and currently in complete remission. Polymyalgia rheumatica. Gouty arthritis. Usual treatment: telmisartan/hydrochlorothiazide 80/25 mg 1 tablet every 24 hours; furosemide 40 mg 1 tablet at breakfast and half a tablet at lunch; spironolactone 25 mg 1 tablet every 24 hours
column7: amlodipine 5 mg 1 tablet every 12 hours; acenocoumarol 4 mg according to INR; bicarbonate 500 mg every 12 hours; resin calcium 15 mg 1 tablet every 24 hours.  Present illness Referred from pulmonology for increased dyspnoea on exertion and worsening of functional class in recent months
column8: with a recent admission for decompensated failure. No exertional angina. In stable condition
column9: he reported minimal effort dyspnoea (NYHA class III/IV)
column10: orthopnoea on 2 pillows.  Physical examination At the outpatient clinic: Blood pressure (BP) 130/65 mmHg. Heart rate (HR) 72 bpm. Baseline SatO2 94%. Afebrile. Good general condition
column11: normohydrated
column12: normoperfused. Jugular ingurgitation. Cardiac auscultation: arrhythmic tones
column13: systolic murmur in mitral focus III/VI. Pulmonary auscultation: preserved vesicular murmur
column14: generalised hypoventilation
column15: no crackles. Abdomen: soft
column16: depressible
column17: non-painful
column18: with no signs of ascites. Oedema with perimalleolar fovea. Distal pulses present and symmetrical. No signs of deep vein thrombosis in the lower extremities.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Electrocardiogram (in consultations): atrial fibrillation at 74 bpm
column19: narrow QRS with normal axis
column20: flattened T wave in inferolateral face without other repolarisation alterations. Chest X-ray: post-surgical alterations with volume loss in the right hemithorax and fracture calluses of the costal arches (history of right lower lobectomy). No pulmonary consolidations were observed. Cardiothoracic index (CTI) increased. No pleural effusion. Transthoracic echocardiogram: absence of pericardial effusion. Left ventricle slightly dilated (DTD 67 mm
column21: VTD 142 ml) with normal wall thickness and normal systolic function (LVEF 67%)
column22: without alterations of segmental contractility. Severe dilatation of both atria. Dilated right ventricle (tricuspid annulus 52 mm
column23: basal diameter 4C 57 mm) with preserved systolic function. Trivalve aortic valve with leaflet sclerosis and adequate opening movements. Mild-moderate aortic insufficiency. Mitral valve with thickening of the anterior leaflet without clear atrial prolapse by this technique and restrictive systolic motion of the posterior leaflet; calcification of the posterior portion of the annulus and the subvalvular apparatus. Mitral insufficiency that appears severe with a very eccentric jet in a postero-lateral direction
column24: significant coanda effect
column25: up to the atrial roof
column26: ORE estimated by PISA of 0.50 cm. Tricuspid valve with large central coaptation defect. Massive tricuspid insufficiency allowing an estimated PSAP of 63 mmHg. Aortic root (43 mm) and ascending aorta (41 mm) slightly dilated. Severely dilated inferior vena cava (31 mm) with abolished inspiratory collapse. Transesophageal echocardiogram (pre-procedure): moderate calcification of the mitral annulus with normal opening. Restrictive systolic movement of the posterior leaflet
column27: with a maximum length of 13 mm and associated prolapse of the anterior leaflet (A2 scallop) with an image of probable rupture of the chordae tendineae at this level. Severe mitral insufficiency codne codne eccentric pansystolic regurgitation that runs along the lateral wall of the left atrium
column28: reaching its roof and causing inversion of the S wave in the pulmonary veins. Contracted vein of 7 mm
column29: ORE by PISA 0.81 cm. No image of ruptured cord is visualised. Mitral annulus 34 mm. Trivalve aortic valve with slightly thickened leaflets
column30: normal opening and mild insufficiency. Tricuspid valve with normal structure and large dilatation of the annulus (55 mm)
column31: causing a large central coaptation defect with severe insufficiency. Normal pulmonary valve. No intracavitary masses and/or thrombi are visualised. Thoracic aorta of normal dimensions with some small uncomplicated atherosclerotic plaque. Septum intact. Rest of the study unchanged with respect to the transthoracic echocardiogram. Transesophageal echocardiogram (haemodynamic monitoring): transseptal ultrasound-guided puncture was performed without incident. A first clip was implanted in a central position that clearly limited the eversion of the A2 scallop
column32: with moderate residual insufficiency persisting in the medial region. It was decided to implant a second clip medial to the first
column33: with good results. The overall insufficiency after the procedure was considered grade II (mild-moderate)
column34: with gradients of around 3 mmHg
column35: without haemodynamically significant stenosis. After removal of the material
column36: an atrial septal defect with diameters of 11 x 5 mm was observed by 3D planimetry
column37: with predominant right-to-left Doppler shunt
column38: which was finally sealed with a 12 mm Amplatzer device
column39: leaving a residual
column40: non-significant intradevice minimohunt. Good left ventricular systolic function after the procedure
column41: with no pericardial effusion. Transthoracic echocardiogram (pre-discharge): severely dilated left atrium. Severely dilated right atrium. Mitral valve closure by means of two mitral clips that behaves as a double residual lesion: mild-moderate mitral insufficiency and mild mitral stenosis. The right ventricle is moderately dilated with preserved systolic function. Left ventricle with moderate hypertrophy
column42: not dilated and with hyperdynamic contractility (LVEF 73%). Ascending aorta slightly dilated. Double aortic valve lesion mild. Severe tricuspid insufficiency. Moderate pulmonary hypertension. Closure of atrial septal defect (ASD) secondary to intervention by means of Amplatzer percutaneous device without residual shunt. No pericardial effusion.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION This is a patient under cardiological follow-up for his valvular heart disease
column43: consisting of severe mitral insufficiency
column44: who was referred to our clinic preferentially due to worsening functional class and recent admission for heart failure. At this time
column45: mitral valve treatment is being considered. Taking into account the patient's comorbidities (moderate surgical risk
column46: EuroSCORE II 4.46%) and history of pulmonary resection with severe chronic lung disease
column47: he was considered the best candidate for percutaneous mitral valve treatment. Thus
column48: the patient is admitted on a scheduled basis for the procedure. It is performed in the cath lab under general anaesthesia and monitored by transesophageal echocardiography. Two mitral clips are released with reduction of the mitral regurgitation grade to mild-moderate (grade II/IV)
column49: maintaining a good opening area without significant increase in valve gradients (mean gradients of 3 mmHg). The procedure was terminated
column50: but when the catheter was removed
column51: the patient presented significant desaturation with hypoxaemia in the arterial blood gas analysis
column52: with the rest of the vital signs remaining stable. The transesophageal echocardiogram showed that the mitral clips had not embolised
column53: biventricular systolic function was good and there was no pericardial effusion. However
column54: a significant right-to-left Doppler flow was observed at the level of the atrial septal defect secondary to the transseptal puncture. The decrease in left atrial pressure as the degree of mitral regurgitation decreased
column55: together with the very high right atrial pressures due to severe pulmonary hypertension and tricuspid regurgitation
column56: explains this phenomenon. Since the patient persisted with hypoxaemia despite 100% oxygen concentrations on the ventilator
column57: it was decided to percutaneously close the atrial septal defect with an Amplatzer device. The patient's oxygenation improved and he was transferred to the post-surgical critical care unit where he was extubated without incident. In the following days
column58: the patient evolved favourably and did not present any complications at the vascular access level or deterioration of renal function or clinical signs of heart failure. A control echocardiogram was performed which showed good placement of the mitral clips
column59: mild to moderate insufficiency and normal gradients. The patient was discharged from hospital on the fourth day of admission. On subsequent cardiology reviews
column60: he remained clinically stable
column61: in NYHA II/IV with mild heart failure predominantly on the right
column62: which was controlled with a daily tablet of furosemide 40 mg.  DIAGNOSIS Severe organic
column63: degenerative mitral regurgitation
column64: effectively treated percutaneously with the implantation of two mitral clips (MitraClip). Residual mitral regurgitation grade II (mild-moderate). Significant right-to-left atrial septal defect and secondary hypoxaemia. Effective closure of the defect with Amplatzer device. Severe tricuspid regurgitation. Severe pulmonary hypertension. Preserved left ventricular function. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History Hereditary family diseases: Father died at 78 years of age suddenly with unspecified heart disease. There were 7 siblings
column3: 5 of them died approximately in the neonatal period. Surviving is an older brother aged 70 with unspecified heart disease
column4: not a carrier of Val26Ala in the emerin gene mutation (EMD). She has 3 children
column5: the first of whom died suddenly at the age of 38
column6: diagnosed with DCM. The second is a 39 year old male who is not a carrier and has no heart disease. Finally
column7: a 27 year old male
column8: a carrier and apparently without heart disease.  Previous illnesses: No known drug allergies. Toxic habits: non-smoker and non-drinker. No cardiovascular risk factors. Fibromyalgia. Chronic venous insufficiency in lower limbs. Cardiological history: Dilated cardiomyopathy diagnosed in 2007. Val26Ala mutation in DME in heterozygosis. Last transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE): severe LVSD (LVEF 27%)
column9: right ventricle (RV) with mildly depressed systolic function
column10: severe functional MR
column11: severe functional tricuspid regurgitation (TR). Pattern of Pulmonary hypertension (PH) at least moderate. Advanced heart failure with poor prognostic data: restrictive filling. Ergospirometry with O2 consumption of 10.8 ml/kg/min (56% of predicted theoretical)
column12: class C-D. Refractory congestion with need for high dose diuretics. Cardiorenal syndrome type 2 with frequent episodes of renal function deterioration with intolerance to neurohormonal drugs. Persistently elevated biomarkers despite optimal medical treatment. NT- proBNP 7739 pg/ml. Left bundle branch block (LBBB) with implantation of Boston ICD-resynchroniser in 2013 in primary prevention. Events related to ventricular arrhythmias: one episode of ventricular tachycardia (VT) requiring therapies. Paroxysmal AF. Medication: bisoprolol 1.25 mg one tablet every 12 hours; furosemide 40 mg one tablet every 24 hours; torasemide 10 mg one tablet every 8 hours; levosulpiride 25 mg every 8 hours; lormetazepam 1 mg at dinner; omeprazole 20 mg at breakfast; sintrom 4 mg as prescribed.  Present illness 60-year-old woman with the previously described history
column13: who in the last year required admission on three occasions due to HF and low cardiac output
column14: requiring levosimendan perfusion and intensive diuretic treatment with good response. After three attempts at titration
column15: sacubitril/valsartan was discontinued due to progressive deterioration of renal function up to Cr 3.18 mg/dl and GFR 20 ml/min. In view of the poor prognosis data
column16: a pre-transplant study was started at his reference centre and he was transferred to our centre to assess treatment options. On admission to our centre she was clinically and haemodynamically stable with no evidence of low cardiac output. Currently in NYHA functional class (FC) III. He climbed two flights of stairs without dyspnoea

column18: bendopnoea
column19: DPN. No oedema in the lower limbs
column20: no increase in abdominal perimeter
column21: no weight gain (weight 68 kg) and no decrease in diuresis rate since discharge from the last admission a month ago.  Physical examination Systolic blood pressure (SBP) 85 mmHg

column27: systolic murmur II-III/VI in tricuspid and mitral focus
column28: 3R. Pulmonary auscultation: preserved vesicular murmur (VCM) without added noise. Abdomen: RHA+
column29: soft
column31: not painful on palpation
column32: no masses or megaliths. No signs of peritonism. Lower limbs: no oedema or signs of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Pedial pulses present and symmetrical.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Laboratory tests: CBC: red cells 4.01 xmill/μl

column82: remodelled

column84: in relation to annular dilatation and with electrode. Moderately elevated pulmonary pressures. Mild aortic insufficiency. Left catheterisation: right dominance. In CF III of the NYHA
column85: INTERMACS 6. Renal function stable with creatinine around 1.7 mg/dl with good diuresis rate under his usual oral diuretic treatment. The iron profile showed ferritin 103 ng/ml with transferrin saturation 14.0% and haemoglobin 11.5 mg/dl
column86: so 1000 mg of iron carboxymaltose were administered. A right heart catheterisation was performed in euvolemic conditions
column87: showing slightly elevated filling pressures with moderate post-capillary pulmonary hypertension with decreased CO (thermodilution: CO 3.41 l/min- CI 1.82 l/min/m. Fick: CO 4.1 l/min-IC 219 l/min/m2) with PVR at the high limit with PWG of 10 mmHg. The patient has been evaluated by the familial heart disease unit as a carrier of the Val26Ala mutation in the emerin gene in heterozygosis (detected in a Sanger). However
column88: the age at presentation and sex raise doubts about a possible secondhit. Moreover
column89: the family history is also inconsistent with the finding of only one emerin
column90: so a complete genetic panel is requested. The genetic study by NGS panel only reports the previously described mutation
column91: with no evidence of a secondhit. In this context
column92: it is possible that the picture corresponds to random X inactivation with involvement (possible but unlikely) in a heterozygous female. For the moment
column93: without other positive results
column94: it is considered that this mutation is responsible for the family history After completing the pre-transplant study
column95: confirming the presence of data on advanced heart failure
column96: and given the absence of significant comorbidity (only stable CKD with mild proteinuria in probable relation to type 2 cardiorenal syndrome) on 23/08/2019 she was presented at the multidisciplinary session and included on the elective waiting list for heart transplant. One month later
column97: the patient was readmitted with decompensation after catarrhal symptoms (sputum culture and rhinovirus negative) with increased dyspnoea of 3 days' evolution until becoming resting and marked orthopnoea without peripheral congestion. During the first weeks of admission
column98: he presented clinical worsening with fine B lines of significant size in the lung ultrasound and data of low postprandial output. For all these reasons
column99: and after optimising diuretic treatment
column100: it was decided to start dobutamine at low doses (2.5 mg) with evident clinical improvement
column101: which was maintained for a week. Subsequently
column102: she received a new course of levosimendan. Given the patient's evolution and the presence of severe MI
column103: she was assessed for MitraClip implantation
column104: which was performed without incident on 16/10/2019
column105: leaving mild to moderate MI. After this
column106: intravenous diuretics were withdrawn and the patient was discharged euvolaemic
column107: without orthopnoea
column108: in CF-II and having observed a decrease in NT-proBNP. ARA-II was reintroduced at low doses with good clinical and analytical tolerance. At discharge
column109: treatment was as follows: candesartan 4 mg (half a tablet) at dinner

column114: lormetazepam 1 mg one tablet at dinner
column115: omeprazole 20 mg one capsule at breakfast
column117: 000U one tablet every 24 hours and sintrom 4 mg (according to INR control).  DIAGNOSIS Main diagnosis: Advanced chronic heart failure CF III NYHA - INTERMACS 6 due to familial dilated cardiomyopathy (Val26Ala mutation in the EMD gene in heterozygosis) with severe LVSD (LVEF 24%) and included in elective waiting list for heart transplantation.  Other diagnoses: Severe functional mitral insufficiency and moderate functional tricuspid insufficiency. MitraClip holder. Moderate postcapillary pulmonary hypertension. Carrier of ICD-CRT Boston in primary prevention. NSMVT on Holter. Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION A 70 year-old man attended the emergency department of our centre due to dyspnoea.  History Cardiovascular risk factors: no arterial hypertension
column3: no diabetes mellitus
column4: no dyslipidaemia. Active smoker of 1 pack a day since the age of 20 (50 packs/year). Obesity grade II (body mass index [BMI] 37 kg/m2). No previous cardiological history. Moderate chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
column5: chronic bronchitis type (FEV1 51% of predicted)
column6: non-exacerbating. Follow-up in outpatient pulmonology department. Stage IIIb colon adenocarcinoma (p3T3N1M0) diagnosed in 2015
column7: treated with laparoscopic right colectomy + adjuvant chemotherapy with 5-fluoruracil + oxaliplatin which ended in 2017
column8: free of disease with normal serial colonoscopies to date. Benign prostatic hypertrophy. Usual treatment: tamsulosin + solifenacin 0.4/6 mg
column9: 1 tablet per day. Salmeterol + fluticasone 25/250 mcg
column10: 1 inhaled capsule per day.  Present illness Progressive increase in baseline dyspnoea of 2 weeks' evolution (usual CF NYHA II
column11: in the context of bronchopathy) until presenting dyspnoea at rest
column12: associated with orthopnoea that forced him to sleep in a sitting position
column13: oedematisation of the lower limbs and subjective decrease in the volume of diuresis.   Physical examination Blood pressure (BP) 137/70 mmHg
column14: heart rate (HR) 90 bpm
column15: Sat 2O89% on room air. Jugular venous pressure at 12 cm H2O. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic
column16: with a systolic murmur in mitral focus III/VI
column17: radiating to the axilla. Pulmonary auscultation: bilateral crackles in midfields and bases. Abdomen: soft and depressible
column18: not painful on palpation
column19: no masses or megaliths. Hepatojugular reflux positive Extremities: oedema up to the knees +++/++++
column20: peripheral pulses preserved and symmetrical
column21: no signs of phlebitis. Echocardioscopy performed at the bedside in the emergency department revealed dilatation and biventricular dysfunction
column22: as well as significant mitral regurgitation
column23: so it was decided to admit the patient for stabilisation and study.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Electrocardiogram: sinus rhythm at 90 bpm. Narrow QRS
column24: axis at 30o. ST-segment depression of 1 mm from V3 to V5 with negative T wave. Asymmetric negative T wave in lateral face as a sign of systolic overload. Chest X-ray on admission: posteroanterior projection. Increased cardiothoracic index. Free costophrenic sinuses. Prominent pulmonary hilae. Signs of vascular redistribution to upper fields. Laboratory tests on admission: Haemoglobin 14.7 g/dl
column25: MCV 89 fl
column26: MCH 28.3 pg
column27: leukocytes 5.5 x 10`9/l
column28: platelets 183 x 10^9/l. Haemostasis: I. Quick 93.7%
column29: INR 1.1
column31: HbA1c 5.6%
column32: sodium 141 mEq/l
column33: potassium 3.9 mEq/l
column34: creatinine 1 mg/dl
column35: urea 41 mg/dl
column36: NT-proBNP 6
column37: 789 pg/ml
column38: LDL-C 92 mg/dl. Myocardial damage biomarker curve (hsTnI
column39: normal < 19.8 ng/l): 32.6 - 37.8 - 35.4 ng/l. Echocardiogram: moderately dilated left ventricle
column40: with normal thickness. Global hypokinesia
column41: with LVEF 30%. Transmitral filling type relaxation disturbance with estimated normal left ventricular end-diastolic pressures (E/E' = 7). Severely dilated left atrium. Moderate functional mitral regurgitation with ORE by PISA of 0.2 cm. Sclerosed
column42: normofunctioning aortic valve. Aortic root not dilated. Right ventricle of normal diameters and mild ventricular dysfunction (TAPSE 15 mm). Mild tricuspid insufficiency that allows estimating PSAP of 60 mmHg. Inferior vena cava 19 mm with respiratory variation < 50%. Coronary angiography 1: calcified left main coronary artery with 20-30% stenosis distally. LAD with severe proximal and middle disease with stenosis around 80%. Borderline lesion in the ostial circumflex artery (50%) and significant lesion in the first marginal branch. Right coronary artery with 70% lesion in the proximal segment and 50% at the level of the crux cordis. Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI): left ventricle with increased volumes (VTD 107 ml/m
column43: VTS 75 ml/m) with mild eccentric hypertrophy (IMVI 97 g/m2)
column44: generalised global hypokinesia and severe depression of global systolic function (LVEF 30%). No myocardial oedema is seen on STIR sequences. Non-dilated right ventricle (RVOT 58 ml/m
column45: STV 33 ml/m) with slightly depressed global systolic function due to generalised hypokinesia (RVEF 43%). Aortic root diameters at the upper limit of normal (sinus portion 38 mm) with moderate dilatation of the tubular portion of 47 mm. Fallen 32 mm. Descending aorta 29 mm. Left atrium slightly dilated (maximum diameter 50 mm
column46: area 15 cm2/m2). Increased pulmonary vascular resistance
column47: estimated at 6 UW (mean pulmonary velocity 8.4 cm/sec). No perfusion defects detected at rest. Necrosis and viability detection study: presence of late gadolinium enhancement suggestive of linear intramyocardial fibrosis at septal-anterior basal and medial level and focal at septal-inferior and inferior basal and medial level
column48: at the LV and RV junction. Coronary angiography 2 (videos 5-7): Impella device is positioned by right femoral access. Angiography is performed via left radial access. Severe LAD lesions are pre-dilated and everolimus-eluting drug-eluting stents 3 x 48 mm and 3.5 x 18 mm are implanted. The distal circumflex guidewire was crossed and IVUS aostium was performed
column49: detecting a luminal area > 6 mm2 and therefore not significant. The lesion was treated in the first obtuse marginal area with a constant everolimus-releasing drug 2.5 x 33 mm with good results. The guidewire was crossed to the distal DC
column50: predilatation of the lesion in the proximal segment and implantation of a 3.5 x 15 mm everolimus-eluting drug-eluting stent. Good result. Finally
column51: the Impella device is removed according to protocol. Femoral haemostasis with Proglide intravascular suture device.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION On admission to the cardiology ward
column52: intensive depletive treatment was started
column53: with 40 mg of i.v. furosemide every 6 hours
column54: with excellent response to the same
column55: with dyspnoea disappearing at rest and progressive toleration of ambulation without incident. A regulated echocardiogram confirmed the presence of severe left ventricular dysfunction
column56: so treatment was started with enalapril 2.5 mg daily
column57: bisoprolol 2.5 mg daily and spironolactone 25 mg daily with good tolerance. As part of the aetiological study of the ventricular dysfunction
column58: elective coronary angiography was performed
column59: which revealed 3-vessel disease
column60: with a SINTAX score of 26. The case was presented at a medical-surgical session. Given the patient's comorbidities (moderate-severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease [COPD]
column61: obesity
column62: severe ventricular dysfunction
column63: STS score 3.7%
column64: EuroScore II of 6.7%)
column65: despite the SINTAX score favourable to surgical revascularisation
column66: it was decided to perform percutaneous revascularisation assisted with Impella device as the procedure was considered high risk
column67: to be performed on an outpatient basis. The patient was discharged with the following medical treatment: acetylsalicylic acid 100 mg per day
column68: enalapril 2.5 mg per day
column69: bisoprolol 2.5 mg per day
column70: spironolactone 25 mg per day
column71: furosemide 40 mg 1 tablet at breakfast and lunch for 2 weeks followed by 1 tablet at breakfast
column72: tamsulosin + solifenacin 0.4/6 mg 1 tablet per day
column73: salmeterol + fluticasone 25/250 mcg 1 inhaled capsule per day
column74: atorvastatin 40 mg per day
column75: pantoprazole 20 mg per day. The importance of weight loss
column76: physical exercise and smoking cessation was stressed. She consulted the emergency department one week after discharge due to palpitations lasting 2 hours
column77: with new onset paroxysmal atrial fibrillation detected on electrocardiogram. A rhythm control strategy was followed
column78: achieving pharmacological cardioversion after an intravenous bolus of 300 mg of amiodarone. At discharge
column79: treatment with apixaban 5 mg every 12 hours was added due to CHADs-VASc of 3 and oral amiodarone 200 mg 5 days a week. Subsequently
column80: percutaneous revascularisation was programmed with mechanical assistance with Impella CP device
column81: which was performed without incident. He received clopidogrel 300 mg the night before admission. After 24 hours of hospitalisation
column82: he was discharged with the addition of clopidogrel 75 mg per day to the aforementioned treatment. After 1 month of triple therapy (ASA + clopidogrel + apixaban)
column83: treatment with acetylsalicylic acid was discontinued. Six months after revascularisation
column84: the patient attended a clinical control visit
column85: and was found to be practically asymptomatic for dyspnoea or other symptoms of heart failure
column86: in NYHA functional class I. He is currently awaiting echocardiography. He is currently awaiting a follow-up echocardiogram. No further visits to the emergency department were required due to decompensation.  DIAGNOSIS Acute heart failure due to ischaemic dilated cardiomyopathy with severe left ventricular dysfunction (LVEF by cardiac MRI 30%). Three-vessel coronary artery disease with a SINTAX score of 26 points. Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation (CHADs-VASc = 3
column87: HAS-BLED = 2). High risk device assisted PCI with Impella CP device with complete revascularisation (proximal LAD
column88: mid LAD
column89: distal DC and 1OM with excellent angiographic outcome). Moderate COPD phenotype chronic bronchitis. Smoking on admission. column1: 56-year-old patient with a history of type 2 diabetes and obesity. He was admitted for several weeks of fever
column2: chills
column3: general malaise
column4: vomiting and diffuse pain in the thorax and lumbar region. On examination
column5: the general condition was acceptable
column6: temperature 39oC
column7: and a systolic murmur of intensity II/VI in the mitral focus radiating to the left axilla
column8: while the rest of the examination was normal. Blood tests showed white blood cells 11
column9: 400/mm3 (69% granulocytes)
column10: platelets 92
column12: erythrocyte sedimentation rate 52mm in the first hour
column13: glucose 281 mg/dl
column14: triglycerides 279 mg/dl and alkaline phosphatase 322 IU/l
column15: while the rest of the blood count
column16: biochemistry and coagulation were normal. In the urine
column17: 100 mg/dl protein
column18: 250 mg/dl glucose and 25 red blood cells per field were detected in the sediment. The electrocardiogram showed an anterior haemiblockage as the only abnormality. Chest and spine X-rays
column19: abdominal ultrasound and computed tomography were normal. Echocardiography shows an unstructured mitral valve with prolapse of both leaflets. Blood cultures showed Streptococcus agalactiae
column20: so treatment was started with cefotaxime at a dose of 1 gram every 8 hours intravenously. Initially there was a good clinical response
column21: with disappearance of the fever
column22: but 5 days after starting treatment the patient began to experience palpitations
column23: dyspnoea and orthopnoea
column24: and the fever reappeared. At this time
column25: the systolic murmur was IV/VI
column26: and there was abundant crackles in both thoracic bases. New chest X-rays showed changes highly suggestive of acute pulmonary oedema. Follow-up echocardiography revealed further mitral valve destructuring
column27: vegetations on both mitral valve leaflets and severe mitral regurgitation. Despite intensive treatment with diuretics
column28: vasodilators
column29: synotropic agents
column31: she progressed unfavourably
column32: developed third-degree atrioventricular block
column33: requiring the implantation of a temporary pacemaker
column34: and died about 12 hours after the onset of dyspnoea
column35: while preparations were being made for surgical treatment. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION 46-year-old female
column3: civil servant
column4: with no illnesses of interest or regular medication. Never smoked. No cardiovascular risk factors or consumption of alcohol or other toxic substances. No family history of heart disease or sudden death. Intervened tonsillectomy in infancy
column5: caesarean section and hysterectomy. Cardiovascular asymptomatic until the previous 2 weeks
column6: who begins with moderate exertional dyspnoea that prevents her from carrying out her normal life
column7: together with orthopnoea
column8: oliguria and the appearance of progressive oedema in the lower limbs. At all times he denies chest pain
column9: palpitations
column10: dizziness or syncope. Neither did he present febrile syndrome or infectious symptoms. Physical examination revealed a blood pressure of 130/60 mmHg
column11: a heart rate of 90 bpm
column12: afebrile and eupneic with nasal spectacles at 2 bpm. On auscultation
column13: she had a bibasal crackles and a diastolic murmur II/IV at mitral level with an occasional "plop". Abdomen with no findings and lower extremities with oedema with distal fovea
column14: with no evidence of venous thrombosis.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Electrocardiogram (ECG): sinus rhythm at 90 bpm
column15: normal PR (152 ms) with bimodal P in relation to left atrial enlargement. Narrow QRS with normal axis without repolarisation alterations. Chest X-ray: normal cardiothoracic index with discrete vascular redistribution.    Analyses: Biochemistry: glucose 98 mg/dl (70-110)
column16: urea 16 mg/dl [10-50]
column17: creatinine 0.78 mg/dl (0.7-1.2)
column18: glomerular filtration rate > 60 ml/min (MDRD-4) (> 60)
column20: K 3.9 mmol/l [3.5-5.1]. ProBNP 2110 pg/ml (10-125). Normal liver function tests. Thyroid hormones normal. CBC: leukocytes 9
column21: 400/cc (normal formula) (4
column25: platelets 211
column28: 000). Coagulation: INR 1.13 (0.8-1.3)
column30: aPTT 24.4s (24.8-40.3).  PET CT scan protocol: no repletion defects in the pulmonary trunk or main or segmental branches suggestive of thromboembolism were observed. A well-defined hypodense mass measuring 5 x 4 cm located at the level of the left atrium
column31: which crosses the valve towards the left ventricle
column32: is striking
column33: ruling out myxoma or large thrombus. It is accompanied by bilateral pleural effusions and a linear interstitial pattern
column34: with thickening of interlobular septa compatible with heart failure.  Transthoracic echocardiogram: left ventricle (LV) of normal size and thickness
column35: with preserved LVEF (>60%) and no segmental contractility abnormalities. Right ventricle (RV) of normal size and function (TAPSE 20 mm). Moderate left atrial dilatation with a large round heterogeneous mass measuring 5 x 3 cm
column36: adhered to the interatrial septum which in diastole is introduced through the mitral annulus producing a moderate-severe stenosis (maximum gradient of 24 mmHg and mean of 14 mmHg
column37: estimated area of 1.4 cm2)
column38: without insufficiency. Aortic and tricuspid valve without significant dysfunction.  Transesophageal echocardiogram: rounded intra-atrial mass measuring 5 x 3.5 cm
column39: heterogeneous
column40: with a wide pedicle measuring 2.7 x 1 cm that adheres to the inferior interatrial septum below the fossa ovalis
column41: which it respects
column42: which in diastole is introduced into the mitral annulus producing a significant stenosis (effective area of 1.4 cm2)
column43: with a mitral valve with thin leaflets without alterations. This mass is compatible with an atrial myxoma. The atrial appendage is free of thrombus. Haemodynamic study: coronary arteries without significant stenosis.   CLINICAL EVOLUTION The patient attended the emergency department where
column44: given the presence of dyspnoea in a patient with no known heart disease
column45: it was decided to perform a CAT scan with PET protocol
column46: which ruled out the presence of pulmonary thromboembolism but revealed a striking mass in the left atrium
column47: for which reason cardiology was consulted and admitted to his care as the debut of heart failure. Based on the CT scan findings and pathological auscultation
column48: with a clear clinical suspicion
column49: a transthoracic and transesophageal echocardiogram was performed which showed the presence of a giant pedunculated mass in the left atrium compatible with a myxoma which
column50: in diastole
column51: protruded into the left ventricle causing significant mitral stenosis. The case was presented to cardiac surgery and it was decided to remove the mass. Intraoperatively
column52: a tumour with a base of implantation inferior to the fossa ovalis in continuity with the posterior mitral annulus was observed and complete excision was performed
column53: including part of the interatrial septum
column54: with subsequent closure of the defect with a patch of autologous pericardium. The mitral valve is morphologically normal
column55: with thin leaflets
column56: and intraoperative transesophageal echocardiography shows normal function after removal of the mass.  She was extubated a few hours later without incident and
column57: after a few days
column58: was discharged. The results of the pathological anatomy confirmed the presence of atrial myxoma
column59: with no evidence of malignancy. She is currently being monitored on an outpatient basis by the cardiology department. A follow-up echocardiogram was performed one year later
column60: which showed no abnormalities
column61: with no recurrence of the myxoma
column62: and since then she has been stable and asymptomatic.  DIAGNOSIS Congestive heart failure. First episode. Giant atrial myxoma. Moderate-severe dynamic mitral stenosis. Excision of the mass and repair of the septum with pericardial patch. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column1: We present the case of a 72-year-old male pacemaker user with complete atrioventricular (AV) block who presented to the emergency department with heart failure and constitutional syndrome.  HISTORY
column2: CURRENT DISEASE AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History Cardiovascular risk factors: hypertension (HT)
column3: dyslipidaemia and type 2 diabetes mellitus (DM2) treated with oral antidiabetics. No toxic habits. Cardiologic history: VDD pacemaker holder since 2003 due to complete AVB. Generator replacement in March/2019. Last cardiology consultation in January 2020
column4: when severe ventricular dysfunction was observed with marked asynchrony due to ventricular stimulation by MCP
column5: and he was referred to the arrhythmia unit for evaluation of upgrade to tri-chamber pacemaker (TRC).  Other medical and surgical history: Obstructive sleep apnoea syndrome (OSA) with nocturnal continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP). Anaemia and dysphagia under study by digestive medicine and internal medicine. Gastroscopy and colonoscopy negative. Pending thoraco-abdomino-pelvic CT scan and oesophageal manometry. Current treatment: atorvastatin 30 mg 1 tablet at dinner
column6: vildagliptin/metformin 50/850 mg 1 tablet per day
column7: omeprazole 20 mg 1 capsule at breakfast
column8: ramipril 10 mg 1 tablet per day. Since the January consultation: bisoprolol 5 mg 1 tablet at breakfast
column9: eplerenone 25 mg 1 tablet at breakfast
column10: furosemide 40 mg 1 tablet at breakfast.  Present illness A 72-year-old man came to the emergency department for dyspnoea. He reported progressive deterioration of his functional class (basically NYHA I) for 5 months
column11: with marked worsening in the last two months
column12: presenting dyspnoea on minimal effort
column13: subjective decrease in diuresis and nocturia
column14: without orthopnoea
column15: PND
column16: oedema or other symptoms of congestion. He had asthenia
column17: intermittent dysthymic sensation and weight loss of 20 kg during this period. Absence of improvement after initiation of diuretics by departmental cardiology following echocardiographic findings.  Physical examination Blood pressure (BP) 100/60 mmHg
column18: heart rate (HR) 85 bpm
column19: SpO2 93% (with O2 through nasal goggles at 2 L/min). Afebrile. Good general condition. Conscious and oriented. Skin pallor. Eupneic at rest
column20: tolerates decubitus. No jugular engorgement. Cardiac auscultation: regular heart sounds
column21: systolic murmur III/VI in left sternal border and mitral focus. Pulmonary auscultation: bibasal crackles
column22: rest of lung fields with preserved vesicular murmur. Abdomen soft and depressible
column23: no palpable masses or megaliths
column24: no peritoneal irritation
column25: preserved peristalsis. Lower limbs with discrete tibiomalleolar oedema.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Electrocardiogram (ECG) on admission: sinus rhythm at 75 bpm with ventricular conduction mediated by electrostimulation
column26: wide QRS with morphology of left bundle branch block
column27: secondary repolarisation alterations. Ventricular extrasystoles. Chest X-ray on admission: slightly increased cardiothoracic index (CTI)
column28: prominent hilarity
column29: no alveolar consolidation or pleural effusion. Pacemaker lead normally positioned in the right ventricle.  Laboratory tests: CBC: red cells 4.19 10*12/l; Hb 10.2 g/dl (nadir 8); Htc 31.6%; MCV 75.3 fl; leukocytes 6000/L (PMN 76.7%; nadir 100 cells/μL); platelets 109000/l; MPV 8.8 fl; platelets (citrate) 89 10*9/L (nadir 31000). Biochemistry: glucose 139 mg/dl; sodium 135 mEq/l; potassium 3.9 mEq/l; chlorine 101 mEq/l; urea 74 mg/dl; creatinine 0.98 mg/dl
column30: estimated GFR (CKD-EPI) 76.71 ml/min/1.73 m2; total bilirubin 0.82 mg/dl
column31: GPT 26 U/l
column32: GOT 21 U/l
column33: GGT 24 U/l; protein 5.8 g/dl; CRP 10.9 mg/dl. Coagulation: prothrombin time (PT) 15.6 sec; Quick index 69%; INR 1.33; aPTT 30.2 sec; ratio (aPTT) 1.01; derived fibrinogen 410 mg/dl. Serial blood cultures during the entire admission
column34: in standard and special media
column35: for bacteria and fungi: negative. Bacterial and viral serologies: negative. Autoimmunity
column36: including ANA
column37: ANCA
column38: rheumatoid factor
column39: antiphospholipid antibodies: negative. Haemolysis markers such as LDH
column40: haptoglobin and reticulocytes: negative. Bone marrow aspirate: no significant alterations observed. Correct myeloerythroid quotient. Microbiological cultures and parasite study negative. Cultures of resected valve material and explanted pacemaker wire: negative.  Thoracic-abdominal-pelvic CT with contrast: thorax: both main and lobar pulmonary arteries show normal morphology and calibre. No repletion defects are observed. No axillary
column41: mediastinal or hilar adenopathies of significant size are identified. Hypoventilation bands in both lower lobes. No pleural effusion. Abdomen-pelvis: liver with lobulated contours and slightly heterogeneous density
column42: suggestive of chronic liver disease. Pancreas and adrenal glands are normal. Bilateral simple renal cysts. Lithiasis in the right kidney
column43: with no significant impact on the excretory tract. Splenomegaly of 16.6 cm with several foci of infarction inside. No retroperitoneal or mesenteric adenopathy. No free intra-abdominal fluid. Diverticulosis of the sigma.  Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) and transthoracic echocardiography (TTE): left ventricle with moderate eccentric hypertrophy (TIV and PPVI 14 mm
column44: DTDVI 62 mm)
column45: increased volumes (VTD BP 170 mL) and severe depression of global systolic function (LVEF BP 27%) with marked asynchrony
column46: wide anomalous septoapical movement by electrostimulation. Slight aortic root dilatation without valve dysfunction. endocarditis over native pulmonary valve: large pedunculated vegetation with a maximum diameter of 40 mm
column47: with deflected edges
column48: with great mobility and systodiastolic protrusion over the pulmonary valve. No significant valvular involvement was observed. No vegetations or other pathological changes were observed on the tricuspid valve or pacemaker lead. endocarditis on mitral valve with vegetation image on anterior mitral leaflet of 11 mm. Moderate mitral insufficiency (ORE by PISA 0.3 cm2) due to slight eversion of the leaflet
column49: with rupture of the chordae tendineae and eccentric jet directed to the posterior face of the atrium. Diastolic pattern compatible with impaired relaxation (E 90 cm/s
column50: A 113 cm/s)
column51: with significant increase in filling pressures (E/e' 17). Biauricular dilatation. Right ventricle of normal diameters with preserved global systolic function (TAPSE 22 mm). Mild TR allowing estimation of PAPs of approximately 50 mmHg (moderate PHT). Inferior vena cava plethora (IVC). Coronary angiography: Truncus description: normal. Anterior descending description: severe stenosis in proximal segment. Diagonal branch distal to the lesion very developed (double DA system). Circumflex description: normal. Right coronary description: dominant. No stenosis.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION The patient was initially admitted to the cardiology ward with depletive and disease-modifying treatment for heart failure. In view of the constitutional syndrome
column52: a thoracic-abdominal-pelvic CT scan was requested to rule out concomitant neoplasia. There were no findings compatible with neoplastic disease. However
column53: splenomegaly with foci of splenic infarction was noted. In view of these findings
column54: a repeat TTE was performed
column55: which revealed
column56: in addition to the ventricular dysfunction already observed in the study performed in the previous 3 weeks
column57: a large mobile mass in the pulmonary valve and moderate mitral insufficiency on a valve with a small mass compatible with endocarditis. Transesophageal echocardiography was performed
column58: confirming the diagnosis
column59: so serial blood cultures were taken and empirical antibiotic therapy was started with vancomycin (20 mg/kg/12 hours i.v.) and gentamicin (3 mg/kg/day i.v.). In the first days of admission
column60: the patient remained very symptomatic
column61: with dyspnoea on minimal exertion and episodes of sudden dyspnoea
column62: although afebrile. Chest CT angiography was performed on suspicion of septic embolism
column63: which was ruled out. The case was discussed at a medical-surgical session and scheduled for surgery. However
column64: the patient evolved unfavourably
column65: presenting an episode of acute pulmonary oedema and requiring transfer to the coronary unit for stabilisation. Progressive blood tests showed significant anaemisation
column66: with a drop to 8 g/dl
column67: requiring transfusion given the clinical condition. In addition
column68: severe neutropenia and thrombopenia were observed (nadir of 100 cells/μl and 31000/l
column69: respectively). Because of this
column70: it was decided to postpone surgery. He was assessed by haematology
column71: started on treatment with granulocyte colony-stimulating factors (G-CSF)
column72: and a bone marrow aspirate was performed. Due to neutropenia
column73: meropenem 1g/8h i.v. was added to the treatment
column74: with the appearance of a generalised maculopapular rash that forced its interruption. Meanwhile
column75: the result of the aspirate showed no pathological findings
column76: so it was considered that the origin of the haematological alteration could be drug-related
column77: and it was decided to replace vancomycin with daptomycin (10 mg/kg/day i.v.). With this measure and the administration of G-CSF
column78: the patient showed progressive analytical improvement. Coronary angiography was performed as part of the preoperative study
column79: showing a severe lesion in the proximal anterior descending artery
column80: which was left for surgical revascularisation. All blood cultures in standard and special media for fungi and bacteria were negative. Serology and even autoimmunity tests were performed
column81: all of which were negative and the microorganism responsible could not be identified. Nuclear medicine tests were considered in view of the lack of an aetiological diagnosis; however
column82: given the patient's clinical situation
column83: they were not carried out. Finally
column84: clinical stability was achieved
column85: and surgery was performed to replace the mitral and pulmonary valves with biological prostheses. In addition
column86: the pacemaker lead and generator were removed and epicardial leads were implanted in the AD
column87: RV and LV for resynchronisation
column88: with placement of a new generator in the right abdominal subcostal region. Bypass over the LAD was ruled out as the vessel could not be adequately exposed due to the presence of abundant epicardial fat
column89: so percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) over the LAD will be performed at a later date. The valve debris and the distal end of the wire were sent to microbiology. The patient was transferred to cardiac resuscitation
column90: where he progressed favourably
column91: was transferred to the ward and was discharged after 2 weeks
column92: with follow-up in the heart failure unit and arrhythmia unit.  DIAGNOSIS Endocarditis on native pulmonary and mitral valves
column93: with moderate mitral insufficiency with eversion of the anterior leaflet due to rupture of the chordae tendineae. Heart failure with depressed ejection fraction with marked asynchrony due to ventricular electrostimulation. Splenic infarcts secondary to infective endocarditis. Agranulocytosis and thrombopenia of probable drug origin. Toxicoderma due to meropenem. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
