column1: A 67-year-old woman came to the emergency department of our centre referred by her primary care physician with a one-week history of dyspnoea
column2: orthopnoea and oedema in the lower limbs. Her personal history included arterial hypertension
column3: diabetes mellitus treated with oral antidiabetics
column4: dyslipidaemia
column5: permanent atrial fibrillation anticoagulated with acenocoumarol and prosthetic mitral valve replacement 6 years ago due to rheumatic stenosis with severe pulmonary hypertension. It should be mentioned that the patient had no history of known nephrourological pathology
column6: with analytical studies prior to admission showing normal renal function
column7: without proteinuria or sediment alterations. He was admitted to Cardiology with the diagnosis of a first episode of decompensation of heart failure
column8: with no clear trigger.  A transthoracic echocardiogram was performed showing a normal functioning mitral prosthesis
column9: aortic valve calcification and severe right ventricular dysfunction
column10: with no other significant findings. On the third day of admission he presented with a fever peak related to peripheral phlebitis
column11: so blood cultures were taken
column12: the IV was changed and empirical antibiotic therapy with Ceftriaxone was started. In the following 24 hours
column13: the growth of SAMS was confirmed in the blood cultures
column14: and Ceftriaxone was replaced by intravenous Cloxacillin. A transesophageal echocardiogram was performed to rule out infective endocarditis
column15: revealing an anchored vegetative image at the level of the posterolateral mitral annulus and another
column16: smaller
column17: anterolateral filiform image. In view of these findings
column18: a diagnosis of infective endocarditis due to methicillin-sensitive S. aureus (SAMS) on the prosthetic valve was made
column19: and Rifampicin was added to the aforementioned treatment. The patient was assessed by the Cardiac Surgery Department and it was decided to surgically replace the prosthesis. Since then
column20: she has had a long and complicated postoperative period
column21: with initial multi-organ dysfunction in the context of cardiac tamponade that required urgent reintervention. In a situation of severe haemodynamic failure
column22: with no evidence of sepsis and maintaining antibiotic coverage
column23: he developed acute oligoanuric renal function deterioration attributed to hypoperfusion with the need for extra-renal depuration by continuous venovenous haemofiltration for a week.  Urine studies performed at this time showed decreased sodium excretion (FENa < 1%) without proteinuria or sediment alterations. In the following days
column24: haemodynamic recovery is accompanied by a progressive increase in diuresis and improvement in renal function parameters (Crp 0.8 mg/dL)
column25: and haemofiltration can be withdrawn. He developed multiple complications during the following months
column26: of which the most relevant are highlighted below. Eight weeks after the operation
column27: he suffered an episode of upper gastrointestinal bleeding
column28: for which an endoscopic study was carried out
column29: revealing millimetric gastric erosions of uncertain origin. Two weeks later
column30: non-pruritic raised petechiae were found on the trunk
column31: extremities
column32: folds and slopes. Coinciding with the above
column33: the urinary sediment showed proteinuria of less than 1 gram per day
column34: with normal renal function (Crp 0.84 mg/dl). Urgent determination of anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCAs) and anti-glomerular basement membrane antibodies (anti-GBM) was requested
column35: which were negative. The dermatology department was consulted and a skin biopsy was taken
column36: which was compatible with leukocytoclastic vasculitis
column37: and treatment with Prednisone at a dose of 0.5 mg/kg/day was indicated.  One week later he presented with anaemia without externalisation of bleeding and a chest X-ray showed bilateral de novo interstitial infiltrates.  All this coincided with a new deterioration of renal function (Crp 1.78 mg/dL)
column38: oliguria
column39: proteinuria of 850 mg/day
column40: macroscopic haematuria and the presence of dysmorphic red blood cells and haematic and leukocyte casts in the urinary sediment.  Given the suspicion of pulmonary haemorrhage in an anticoagulated patient
column41: fibrobronchoscopy was performed
column42: confirming the presence of fresh haematic debris in both bronchial trees
column43: suggestive of alveolar haemorrhage. Renal function progressively deteriorated
column44: and the patient remained in a situation of oligoanuria and secondary hydrosaline overload
column45: with persistent haematuria and proteinuria. Given the clinical diagnosis of nephritic syndrome with pulmonary haemorrhage
column46: an immunological study was completed
column47: highlighting a decrease in C3 (78.8 mg/dL) and C4 (14.4 mg/dL) levels
column48: the presence of circulating immunocomplexes and positive rheumatoid factor (190 mg/dL)
column49: with negative ANAs
column50: antiDNA
column51: ANCAs and antiMBG
column52: as well as negative cryoglobulins. The patient's respiratory condition progressively deteriorated
column53: anticoagulation was discontinued
column54: and it was decided to start treatment with plasmapheresis
column55: oral cyclophosphamide (100 mg/day) and increasing the dose of prednisone (1 mg/kg/day) in view of the renopulmonary syndrome. Prior to the start of the immunosuppressive regimen
column56: blood cultures were taken on several occasions and were persistently negative
column57: although all of them were removed and the patient continued with antibiotherapy. With these measures
column58: there was a slight improvement from the respiratory point of view
column59: both clinically and radiologically
column60: but the progressive deterioration of renal function persisted
column61: again requiring extra-renal depuration by means of continuous venovenous haemofiltration. Finally
column62: as there was no improvement in the following days
column63: a renal biopsy was performed with the suspicion of acute glomerulonephritis related to the infection. The renal biopsy showed areas of increased mesangial matrix and presence of thickening in the membranes of the glomerular capillaries. Direct immunofluorescence techniques showed granular mesangial IgA and C3 fixation
column64: with a predominance of IgA deposits
column65: and therefore compatible with infection-related IgA-dominant glomerulonephritis.  In view of these findings and the extrarenal manifestations characteristic of Henoch-Schönlein purpura
column66: we requested an extension of the immunofluorescence of the skin biopsy
column67: which also showed IgA deposits. All these findings were therefore compatible with IgA-dominant glomerulonephritis related to infective endocarditis due to SAMS with manifestations of Schönlein-Henoch purpura ("Schönlein-Henoch like"). Despite therapeutic measures
column68: the patient had a torpid evolution with massive alveolar haemorrhage and no recovery of renal function
column69: finally leading to exitus. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History 74-year-old male. No known drug allergies. Cardiovascular risk factors (CVRF): hypertension. Dyslipidaemia. Ex-smoker. Previous cardiological history: Chronic ischaemic heart disease with normal LVEF
column3: two-vessel coronary artery disease with complete percutaneous revascularisation. Unstable angina in 1999
column4: implantation of two drug-eluting stents in the right coronary artery and circumflex artery. Aortic valve sclerosis. Single episode of self-limited atrial fibrillation during treatment with brentuximab for Hodgkin's lymphoma. It was decided not to anticoagulate due to the high haemorrhagic risk and because the paroxysm of atrial fibrillation was considered reactive to treatment. Follow-up in cardio-oncology consultations. Last check-up in December 2019
column5: without angina. Infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm operated on in 2003
column6: complicated by acute renal failure secondary to right renal ischaemia
column7: with the need for haemofiltration in the postoperative period. Stage 3 chronic kidney disease
column8: secondary to ischaemic nephropathy (functional annulment of the right kidney). Secondary hyperparathyroidism. Repeated nephritic colic. Haematological history: Hodgkin's lymphoma nodular sclerosis type
column9: probable stage IV due to pulmonary involvement. Treatment within the BREPEM clinical trial (brentuximab with cyclophosphamide
column10: procarbazine
column11: prednisone and mitoxantrone)
column12: suspended due to toxicity (febrile neutropenia of abdominal focus and water overload). Subsequently two cycles of ABVD (adriamycin
column13: bleomycin
column14: vinblastine
column15: dacarbazine). Remission with the exception of lung nodule DS 4
column16: biopsied and without findings. Recent computed tomography (CT) scan of the chest with suspected progression
column17: pending histological confirmation at present. Usual medication: atorvastatin 40 mg/24 hours
column18: ezetimibe 10 mg/24 hours
column19: clopidogrel 75 mg/24 hours
column20: nitroglycerin patch 5 mg
column21: atenolol 25 mg/24 hours
column22: furosemide 60 mg/24 hours
column23: allopurinol 100 mg/24 hours
column24: omeprazole 20 mg/24 hours
column25: trimethoprim/cotrimoxazole 160/800 mg/24 hours
column26: folic acid 5 mg/24 hours
column27: hydroferol 0.266 mg monthly.  Present illness She attended the emergency department for an episode of oppressive central thoracic pain that started at rest
column28: accompanied by general malaise and sweating
column29: self-limited in 30-40 minutes. On arrival at the emergency department
column30: she presented a new episode similar to the previous one
column31: although of shorter duration. At the time of cardiology assessment
column32: he was already asymptomatic for chest pain. In addition
column33: he reported a fever peak of 38.5oC the day before the consultation
column34: accompanied by cough with scant yellowish expectoration.  Physical examination Blood pressure (BP) 107/63 mmHg. Heart rate (HR) 110 bpm. Temperature 38.3 oC. Oxygen saturation 94% with nasal goggles at 1.5 litres. Eupneic at rest
column35: tolerating decubitus at 30o. Jugular venous pressure (JVP) in the middle third of the neck. Cardiac auscultation: arrhythmic tachycardia
column36: systolic murmurs II/IV in aortic focus with preserved second tone. Pulmonary auscultation: crackles in the lower third of both hemithoraxes and disseminated wheezing. Oedema with fovea in the lower third of both legs.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Electrocardiogram (ECG) with pain: atrial fibrillation with ventricular response at 120 bpm
column37: narrow QRS
column38: abrupt R wave transition in V4
column39: ST elevation in V1 and aVR and diffuse ST descent in the rest of the leads. ST segment alterations corrected in ECG without pain. Blood tests on admission: Haemoglobin 8.1 g/dl
column40: MCV 101.4 fl
column41: leucocytes 13
column42: 700/mcl
column43: neutrophils 11
column44: 800/mcl
column45: platelets 100.000/mcl. INR 1
column47: APTT ratio 1
column48: 07. Glucose 83 ml/dl
column49: creatinine 1.72 mg/dl
column50: GFR 51 ml/min/m
column51: sodium 136 mEq/l
column52: potassium 3.9 mEq/l
column53: magnesium 1.9 mEq/l
column54: phosphate 2.9 mEq/l
column55: bilirubin 1 mg/dl
column56: alkaline phosphatase 96 U/I
column57: GGT 70 U/I
column58: ALT 37 U/I
column59: CRP 8 mg/dl
column60: procalcitonin 0.5. NT- proBNP 7
column61: 490 pg/ml. Troponin I ultrasensitive 831-> 1
column62: 600 ng/l (normal < 34 ng/l). CK 47 U/I. Lipid profile: triglycerides 89 mg/dl
column63: total cholesterol 81 mg/dl
column64: HDL 29 mg/dl
column65: LDL 34 mg/dl. Iron profile: iron 26 mg/dl
column66: ferritin 2
column67: 703 ng/ml
column68: transterrin saturation index 20%. TSH 1.01 mcIU/ml. Glycosylated Hb 6.4%. Microbiology: Blood cultures: sterile after 5 days incubation. Nasopharyngeal exudate: negative for influenza and RSV. Urine culture: negative. Legionella and Pneumococcus antigens in urine: negative. Chest X-ray: cardiothoracic index at the upper limit of normality. Perihilar and peribronchovascular thickening and costophrenic sinus impingement
column69: compatible with heart failure. White left lung (already present in previous cases). Transthoracic echocardiogram: non-dilated left ventricle
column70: with slight concentric hypertrophy
column71: hyperdynamic
column72: with normal global systolic function
column73: despite basal inferior akinesia and inferior septal akinesia. Transmitral filling pattern with single wave. Left atrium slightly dilated. Non-dilated right atrium. Right ventricle not dilated
column74: hyperdynamic
column75: with normal global systolic function. Aortic valve slightly sclerosed
column76: with maximum transvalvular velocity of 2.1m/s
column77: without insufficiency. Mitral valve functionally normal. Morphologically normal tricuspid valve with mild insufficiency. Pulmonary artery systolic pressure estimated at 43 mmHg. Inferior vena cava not dilated with physiological inspiratory collapse. Slight circumferential pericardial effusion
column78: with no evidence of haemodynamic compromise
column79: with epicardial fat. Diagnostic coronary angiography: access via right radial artery
column80: contrast 100 cc. Left main coronary artery (LMCA) atheromatous with significant lesion (70%) distal involving the bifurcation. Anterior descending artery (AD): of good development and calibre
column81: with diffuse mild atheromatosis without significant lesions. Circumflex (Cx): well-developed and of good calibre
column82: composed mainly of a main marginal branch with a permeable stent without lesions
column83: vessel with diffuse mild atheromatosis
column84: without significant lesions. Right coronary artery (RCA): dominant
column85: chronic occlusion in its proximal segment; distal vessel of moderate calibre with no significant lesions due to collateral circulation. Therapeutic coronary angiography: access via the right femoral artery guided by ultrasound
column86: contrast 227 cc. Intervencionsimo on the left coronary trunk: guidewire is crossed to circumflex and anterior descending artery. DK-Crush technique. Drug-eluting implant in TCI-Cx. First kissing-balloon and second drug-eluting stent is implanted in LMCA-AD. Second kissing-balloon is performed. Good angiographic and IVUS results. Vascular closure with percutaneous closure device
column87: checking correct common femoral puncture by fluoroscopy and persistence of flow by echo-Doppler.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION A 75-year-old man with the aforementioned history was admitted for an episode of angina at rest. He also presented with semiology of decompensated heart failure and rapid atrial fibrillation of uncertain onset. All this in the context of a possible relapse of the underlying haematological pathology
column88: symptoms of respiratory infection and anaemisation with respect to baseline haemoglobin levels. ECG suggestive of TCI disease and elevation of markers of myocardial damage with ascending curve. Asymptomatic for chest pain when assessed by cardiology. Initially
column89: two red blood cell concentrates were transfused
column90: intravenous depletive treatment was started and
column91: given the respiratory infection in an immunocompromised patient
column92: empirical broad-spectrum antibiotic treatment was started with piperacillin-tazobactam. Double antiplatelet therapy was also started with acetylsalicylic acid and clopidogrel
column93: initially without anticoagulation. Coronary angiography showed significant distal LMCA disease involving the bifurcation with LAD and Cx
column94: in addition to chronic LMCA occlusion. As this was a highly complex patient
column95: with significant comorbidity and high ischaemic and haemorrhagic risk
column96: it was decided not to intervene until the case was presented to the heart team. Comorbidity included Hodgkin's lymphoma with suspected progression at present (probable stage IV due to pulmonary involvement in recent CT scan)
column97: although histological confirmation was pending. During admission
column98: an assessment by haematology was requested
column99: who estimated a poor medium-term prognosis. In addition
column100: our patient had chronic multifactorial normocytic-normochromic anaemia (haematological disease
column101: chronic disorders
column102: chronic renal disease
column103: chronic treatment with trimethoprim/cotrimoxazole) with usual Hb levels of 10 mg/dl
column104: presenting on arrival with anaemisation up to Hb 8.1 mg/dl. Despite transfusion with stabilisation of Hb levels around baseline
column105: negative balance
column106: controlled ventricular response and titration of antianginal medical treatment
column107: the patient persisted with minimal effort angina in the cardiology ward. The case was presented to the heart team
column108: who decided to perform percutaneous revascularisation of the LMCA
column109: given the high surgical risk. A new coronary angiography was performed via the right femoral artery with implantation of two drug-eluting stents in the LMCA-AD and LMCA-Cx using the DK-Crusch technique
column110: without immediate complications and with resolution of angina. Following the PIONEER strategy
column111: antithrombotic treatment was maintained with simple antiplatelet therapy with clopidogrel 75 mg/24 hours and anticoagulation with low-dose rivaroxaban (10 mg/24 hours adjusted to renal function). After discharge
column112: the patient remains asymptomatic for angina and without haemorrhagic complications. However
column113: pulmonary progression of Hodgkin's lymphoma was confirmed and he died one month after discharge.  DIAGNOSIS Acute myocardial infarction without ST elevation
column114: Killip II. Revascularisation of distal left main coronary artery with two drug-eluting stents. Chronic ischaemic heart disease with preserved LVEF. Coronary artery disease partially revascularised percutaneously
column115: chronic occlusion of the right coronary artery. Persistent atrial fibrillation. Decompensation of heart failure secondary to previous events. Respiratory infection in immunosuppressed patient. Chronic multifactorial exacerbated anaemia. Stage IV Hodgkin's lymphoma due to pulmonary involvement. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION 24-year-old male
column3: working in a hardware store
column4: with no known drug allergies or toxic habits. No cardiovascular risk factors (CVRF). Hypothyroidism on replacement therapy. In June 2008
column5: he consulted for cough and progressive dyspnoea of 6 months' evolution
column6: and was diagnosed by the pulmonology department as having sarcoidosis with grade II pulmonary involvement
column7: with associated bronchial hyperresponsiveness. Immunosuppressive treatment with corticosteroids was started. In September 2008 he was admitted for sustained monomorphic ventricular tachycardia with haemodynamic instability. During admission
column8: a dilated left ventricle with severe systolic dysfunction was observed. A haemodynamic study showed coronary arteries without stenosis. Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging showed a dilated left ventricle with a maximum telediastolic diameter of 60 mm
column9: apical thinning with apical inferior
column10: anterior and lateral akinesia
column11: medial lateral
column12: medial anterior hypokinesia and medial inferior hypokinesia
column13: with severe systolic dysfunction (LVEF 20%). Late subendocardial enhancement in basal inferior and basal lateral face
column14: with extension to papillary muscles; and transmural in mid and apical lateral
column15: mid and apical inferior
column16: and apical anterior face. Implantable cardioverter defibrillator (ICD) implantation was performed in October 2008. He was admitted in December 2008 due to infection of the surgical wound of the ICD
column17: the system was explanted and antibiotics were administered
column18: despite which the infectious clinical symptoms persisted with febrile syndrome
column19: and the studies were extended and tricuspid endocarditis was detected
column20: complicated with pulmonary embolisms. With progressive deterioration of his functional status and refractory heart failure
column21: associated with several episodes of non-sustained and sustained ventricular tachycardia (VT) with poor haemodynamic tolerance. On 9 February 2009
column22: he suffered cardiorespiratory arrest (CRA) due to primary ventricular fibrillation (VF)
column23: recovered after 2 shocks
column24: with no sequelae. She was referred to the reference centre for evaluation for cardiac transplant
column25: which was performed on 20/02/2009. During admission
column26: he presented with complications such as avascular necrosis of both hips
column27: probably related to corticosteroid treatment. Subsequently
column28: in May 2011
column29: he underwent bilateral hip replacement surgery. During the following years
column30: he was admitted on multiple occasions for infectious complications (lung abscess in 2010
column31: thoracic herpes zoster in 2010
column32: repeated UTI
column33: gastroenteritis). In January 2013 he presented with an episode of acute grade 3R rejection symptomatic for dizziness
column34: dyspnoea on minimal exertion and complete atrioventricular block (AVB). After treatment with corticosteroid boluses
column35: the condition was reversed
column36: with disappearance of AVB and clinical improvement. In the control biopsy
column37: the acute cellular rejection was in resolution. Prior to discharge
column38: he presented an episode of atrial deflutter
column39: treated with atrial overstimulation. A control biopsy was repeated 6 months later
column40: with no evidence of rejection. He was admitted on 23/06/2013 for self-limited epigastric pain radiating to the back
column41: associated with a feeling of breathlessness
column42: lasting about 15 minutes
column43: after walking for 10 minutes. Previously
column44: the patient had been suffering from asthenia for a week
column45: with no other associated cardiovascular symptoms. He denied any infectious symptoms or fever. He suffered an episode of alimentary vomiting in the emergency department. On physical examination
column46: the patient had a good general appearance
column47: was haemodynamically stable
column48: with no congestive symptoms
column49: and was eupneic at baseline. On cardiac auscultation
column50: he was tachycardic
column51: with no murmurs or friction rubs. Abdomen painful on palpation in the right hypochondrium
column52: soft
column53: depressible and with no evidence of peritoneal irritation.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Electrocardiogram (ECG): sinus tachycardia at 135 bpm
column54: normal PR
column55: narrow QRS
column56: ST rectification of V1-V4 and convex ST in inferior face. ECG: sinus tachycardia at 105 bpm
column57: inferior ST elevation
column58: ST depression of V1-V3
column59: inferior-posterior Q wave. ECG: complete VAB spells in the context of myocardial ischaemia. CBC: blood count: leukocytes 13
column60: 600/μl (normal leukocyte formula)
column61: haemoglobin 13.7 g/dl
column62: haematocrit 43.9%
column63: platelets 206
column64: 000/μl. Coagulation: To. T. Partial Activated 29.9 s
column65: INR 1.22
column66: prothrombin rate 77%. Biochemistry: glucose 80 mg/dl
column67: urea 58 mg/dl
column68: creatinine 1.10 mg/dl
column69: GFR 79 ml/min
column70: sodium 142 mEq/l
column71: potassium 4.6 mEq/l
column72: chlorine 109 mEq/l
column73: GOT(AST) 109 U/l
column74: GPT (ALT) 58 U/l
column75: amylase 35 U/l
column76: total bilirubin 1.3 mg/dl. Serialisation of myocardial damage markers: ultrasensitive troponin 1919 ng/l - 1964 ng/l - 1990 ng/l [ 0 - 13]. Coronary angiography: three-vessel coronary artery disease
column77: with poor distal beds and diffuse disease
column78: with thrombotic occlusion of the proximal right coronary artery (RCA). During percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI)
column79: multiple dilatations with balloon angioplasty were attempted to recanalise the coronary artery
column80: but no flow was achieved due to severe no reflow phenomenon.   CLINICAL COURSE The patient was admitted with initial suspicion of acute myocarditis versus acute coronary syndrome type NSTEMI
column81: with flat enzyme mobilisation in the following 12 hours. The ECG on admission showed sinus tachycardia
column82: with subtle changes in the repolarisation of ST rectification in V1-V4 and convex ST in the inferior face. At 21:00h on the day of admission
column83: the patient began with dyspnoea
column84: tachypnoea and vegetative symptoms. The ECG showed sinus tachycardia with lower ST elevation
column85: with self-limited spells of complete AVB
column86: and an emergent haemodynamic study was performed. Catheterisation revealed three-vessel coronary artery disease
column87: with poor distal beds and diffuse disease
column88: with thrombotic occlusion of the proximal DC. During PCI
column89: multiple dilatations with balloon angioplasty were attempted
column90: but no flow was achieved due to no reflow. During the procedure the patient suffered complete AVB with severe haemodynamic deterioration Killip IV
column91: which triggered ventricular fibrillation. Despite multiple shocks at 200J and advanced CPR for a prolonged period
column92: the patient did not respond to these measures and died.  DIAGNOSIS Acute coronary syndrome with ST-segment elevation (STEACS) lower Killip IV. Complete AVB due to myocardial ischaemia. CRP due to VF. Graft vascular disease in heart transplant patients. Proximal DC thrombotic occlusion. Death.  Previous: Sarcoidosis with pulmonary and cardiac involvement
column93: on corticosteroid treatment. Infiltrative cardiomyopathy in dilated phase due to sarcoidosis
column94: with severe systolic dysfunction
column95: ACC/AHA stage D CHF. Multiple infectious complications probably related to immunosuppressive treatment. Acute tricuspid infective endocarditis. Cardiac transplant. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  PERSONAL HISTORY No known drug allergies. Long-standing high blood pressure
column3: although in recent years her medication has had to be reduced and is currently controlled only with dietary measures. Diabetes mellitus type 2. Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. Mild chronic kidney disease with a baseline glomerular filtration rate of around 48 ml/min. Hepatitis C. Under digestive follow-up for hiatus hernia and history of duodenal ulcer. Lumbar canal stenosis. Surgical history: right knee prosthesis and bilateral carpal tunnel surgery. Usual treatment: acenocoumarol for INR 2-3
column4: metformin 875 mg every 12 hours
column5: paracetamol 1 g every 8 hours
column6: omeprazole 20 mg daily and lorazepam 1 mg before bedtime.  CURRENT ILLNESS The patient is an 85-year-old woman with symptoms of biventricular heart failure
column7: reporting dyspnoea and orthopnoea as well as oedema of progressive intensity in the last month. She also refers cough with greenish expectoration and fever peaks in the last 3 days
column8: for which her primary care physician has prescribed amoxicillin-clavulanic acid for 7 days. The patient also reports abdominal distension and a burning sensation after meals (more intense in the last few weeks)
column9: facial pain
column10: especially when eating
column11: and pain in both knees with a mechanical profile.  PHYSICAL EXAMINATION Vital signs: blood pressure 116/69 mmHg
column12: oxygen saturation 95% with nasal goggles at 2 l/min
column13: temperature 36.8 ̊C. Usual weight 48 kg
column14: height 1.50 m
column15: body surface 1.41 m2. Weight on admission 60 kg. Neck: increased jugular venous pressure with hepatojugular reflux. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic and systolic murmur III/VI in aortic focus that does not clear the second tone. Pulmonary auscultation: crackles up to midfield and abolition of vesicular murmur in both bases. Abdomen: increased abdominal perimeter with no evidence of peritoneal irritation. Lower extremities: oedema in both lower limbs up to the groin.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS CBC: creatinine 1.2 mg/dl (estimated GFR 32 ml/min)
column16: potassium 4.5 mEq/l
column17: sodium 132 mEq/l
column18: BNP 1
column19: 890 pg/ml
column20: leukocytes 12
column22: haemoglobin 12.3 g/dl
column23: platelets 210
column25: INR 2.8. Electrocardiogram (ECG): sinus rhythm. QRS of 120 ms with normal axis. Low voltages in limb leads. Millimetric negative T wave in V5-V6. Echocardiography: Cavities: non-dilated left ventricle of small cavity with severe concentric hypertrophy. Mild-moderate right ventricular hypertrophy. Valves: Mild mitral and tricuspid insufficiency. Moderate pulmonary hypertension (40-45 mmHg estimated systolic pulmonary pressure). Moderate-severe aortic stenosis. Valvular area by continuity equation is 0.97 cm2
column26: with a mean gradient of 30 mmHg and peak of 47 mmHg. Diastolic function: restrictive mitral filling. Clear increase in filling pressures. Other: bilateral pleural effusion and mild pericardial effusion
column27: predominantly at the right retroatrial level. The study was completed with a longitudinal deformation analysis. 99mTc-DPD scan: moderate uptake of the radiomarker at cardiac level
column28: diffuse and biventricular. Cardiac magnetic resonance: images corresponding to late enhancement sequences and extracellular volume mapping are attached.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION After intravenous treatment with diuretics
column29: a weight reduction of 10 kg was achieved with marked improvement in the patient's clinical condition and oedema. Self-limited episode of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation at 100-110 bpm during admission. Once again in sinus rhythm and with a good response to oral diuretics
column30: she was discharged with oral furosemide (80 mg per day) in addition to her usual treatment
column31: to continue studies and outpatient treatment. However
column32: 3 days later
column33: the patient returned to the emergency department for syncope with mild cranioencephalic trauma on getting out of bed. She did not recall any prodromal symptoms
column34: but reported increased asthenia in the last few days. After ECG monitoring for 24 hours and reduction of furosemide treatment to 40 mg per day
column35: the patient was discharged with clinical improvement. She is currently under clinical follow-up
column36: with persistent joint pain and abdominal discomfort
column37: although with a significant improvement in the semiology of heart failure.  DIAGNOSIS Heart failure with preserved systolic function. Respiratory infection as a probable trigger for exacerbation. Transthyretin amyloidosis with cardiac involvement. Moderate-severe aortic stenosis. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  PERSONAL HISTORY 77-year-old woman
column3: allergic to propifenazone
column4: with a history of arterial hypertension for more than 20 years and dyslipidaemia
column5: both under medical treatment with good control. No other cardiovascular risk factors.  Cardiological history Diagnosed with persistent atrial fibrillation in October 2011
column6: with mild hypertensive heart disease (left ventricle [LV] of normal size
column7: slightly hypertrophic
column8: normal left ventricular ejection fraction [LVEF] with moderately dilated left atrium [LA] on transthoracic echocardiography [TTE])
column9: which required pharmacological cardioversion in March 2012 and pulmonary vein ablation in October 2012. He initially remained in sinus rhythm under antiarrhythmic treatment with flecainide (50 mg
column10: half a tablet every 12 hours)
column11: which was discontinued in October 2013
column12: and anticoagulation with dabigatran (150 mg every 12 hours). He subsequently presented arrhythmic recurrence in the form of atrial fibrillation and left flutter in early June 2014
column13: which required reablation of the left atrial substrate
column14: atrial roof line and mitral isthmus. Recurrence of left flutter at the end of June 2014
column15: which required new electrical cardioversion in the same month. On admission
column16: antiarrhythmic treatment was started with a loading dose of intravenous amiodarone with facial flushing and discomfort
column17: so the infusion was stopped and outpatient management with oral flecainide (100 mg
column18: half a tablet every 12 hours) and atenolol (50 mg
column19: one and a half tablets every 24 hours) was decided. She was reviewed in February 2015 for an episode of clumsiness in the right leg that temporarily coincided with arrhythmic recurrence in the form of atrial fibrillation. In view of this situation
column20: a referral to neurology was requested and a diagnosis of transient ischaemic attack was made following a cranial MRI in which acute/subacute ischaemic lesions were ruled out. Since then
column21: amiodarone 200 mg every 8 hours was started as a loading dose for a week and then 200 mg every 24 hours. Since then in sinus rhythm. In August 2015 antiacogulation is changed from dabigatran (150 mg every 12 hours) to rivaroxaban (15 mg
column22: every 24 hours) due to worsening renal function. Other relevant background information On the other hand
column23: in January 2016
column24: there were episodes of copious and recurrent anterior epistaxis with significant anaemisation
column25: despite the treatment applied by the otorhinolaryngology department (cauterisation with silver nitrate and placement of spogostan and bactroban film). In view of this situation
column26: percutaneous closure of the left atrial appendage was decided in February 2016 with a 28 mm Amulet device. Treatment was started with acetylsalicylic acid 100 mg and clopidogrel 75 mg every 24 hours and anti-clotting agents were discontinued. In April 2016
column27: double antiplatelet therapy was discontinued and single antiplatelet therapy was maintained with acetylsalicylic acid (100 mg
column28: every 24 hours).  Medical treatment Amiodarone 200 mg (1 tablet at breakfast)
column29: acetylsalicylic acid 100 mg (1 tablet at lunch) and valsartan 50 mg (1 tablet at breakfast).  CURRENT ILLNESS Asymptomatic for dyspnoea
column30: palpitations and chest pain until August 2018
column31: at which time she attended the emergency department reporting progressive exertional dyspnoea and dry cough
column32: which prevented her from carrying out her daily activities.  PHYSICAL EXAMINATION Blood pressure (BP) 150/90 mmHg
column33: heart rate (HR) 65 bpm
column34: SatO2 92%
column35: temperature 37.5 ̊C. Acceptable general condition. Conscious and oriented in the three spheres. Normal colour
column36: normohydrated and normoperfused. Carotids rhythmic and symmetrical. No jugular ingurgitation. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic tones without murmurs or extratonos. Pulmonary auscultation: vesicular murmur abolished in lung bases with dry crackles up to midfields. Abdomen: hydro-aerial sounds present
column37: soft and depressible
column38: not painful on deep palpation. No masses or megaliths. Lower extremities: No oedema. Peripheral pulses present. No signs of deep vein thrombosis.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS CBC: glucose 88 mg/d
column39: urea 44 mg/dl
column40: Cr 1.2 mg/dl

column61: neutrophils 8.31 109/l. Electrocardiogram: sinus rhythm at 65 bpm. Left axis. Left anterior hemiblock. Posteroanterior and lateral chest X-ray: atheromatosis of the aortic arch. Aortic elongation. Borderline cardiothoracic index with percutaneous left atrial appendage closure device. Areas of bibasal consolidation with interstitial pattern up to midfields and mild bilateral pleural effusion. Rest of lung parenchyma with acceptable aeration. TTE 08/18: left ventricle slightly dilated
column62: mild hypertrophy and normal systolic function. Ejection fraction 62%. No regional contractility abnormalities. Pseudonormal filling pattern
column63: high filling pressures (E/E ́ 19). Right ventricle with normal morphology and systolic function. Severe left atrial dilatation. Minimal mitral and aortic regurgitation. Minimal tricuspid insufficiency that allows estimating a systolic pulmonary artery pressure (PAPs) within the normal range. No signs of pericardial pathology. Vena cava of normal calibre collapsing with inspiration. Atrial appendage closure device. Chest computed tomography (CT) 08/18: pulmonary involvement characterised by areas of pulmonary consolidation with alveolar pattern and air bronchogram predominantly peripheral and in lower lobes
column64: patchy foci of ground glass and small nodular opacities. It is associated with a peripheral coarse reticular interstitial pattern and traction bronchiectasis
column65: suggestive of chronicity. Compatible with cryptogenic organised pneumonia. No pleural effusion is observed. Left atrial appendage closure device. Main trunk of pulmonary artery of 29 mm
column66: at the high limit of normality. Multinodular goitre at the expense of the left lobe
column67: partially endothoracic
column68: with the largest nodule measuring 20 mm in the left thyroid lobe. Diffuse increased attenuation of the liver parenchyma (study without contrast). Bronchoscopy: normal. Bronchoalveolar lavage with predominantly neutrophilic phenotype
column69: no microbiological isolates and pathological anatomy with fatty macrophages. Respiratory function tests 08/18: mild restrictive ventilatory abnormality. Severe decrease in diffusing capacity. 6 minute walk test 08/18: Respiratory function tests after corticosteroid treatment 09/18: normal respiratory function tests. Isolated moderate decrease in diffusing capacity. Improvement of 3 ml/mmHG/min in diffusing capacity compared to previous tests. 6-minute walk test after corticosteroid treatment 09/18: Chest CT scan 10/18: persistent peripheral pattern of predominance in bases
column70: interstitial
column71: ground glass and with thickening of interlobar septa
column72: which shows a clear improvement compared to the August scan
column73: with almost complete disappearance of the areas of consolidation. Nodular goitre predominantly on the left with some endothoracic component. Left atrial closure device. Dilatation of the left atrium. No pleural or pericardial effusion was observed.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION In view of the elevated inflammatory parameters and the radiological pulmonary alterations (areas of bibasal consolidation and bilateral pleural effusion)
column74: it was decided to admit the patient to the cardiology ward for aetiological study and treatment. Due to increased inflammatory parameters
column75: it was decided to administer intravenous amoxicillin/clavulanic acid 1
column76: 000 mg every 8 hours and oral azithromycin 500 mg every 24 hours for three days. In addition
column77: despite no clinical signs of systemic congestion
column78: given the mildly elevated pro-BNP and the possible association of incipient heart failure in the context of primary pulmonary pathology
column79: intravenous furosemide was added as part of the initial treatment. Amiodarone was also suspended due to suspicion of pulmonary toxicity until the aetiology of the pulmonary involvement and its evolution were known. During the first 48 hours
column80: there was no improvement in her clinical condition
column81: and a thoracic CT scan was completed
column82: which showed a pulmonary pattern compatible with cryptogenic organised pneumonia with fibrotic changes of chronic profile. The patient was assessed by pulmonology during admission and studies of interstitial lung disease were completed. Respiratory function tests showed a mild restrictive ventilatory abnormality
column83: and a severe decrease in diffusing capacity
column84: with a 6-minute walk test with desaturation of up to 83-84% over a maximum distance covered of 390m. They also performed a bronchoscopy which revealed no pathological findings
column85: with bronchoalveolar lavage showing a predominantly neutrophilic phenotype
column86: no microbiological isolates and pathological anatomy with fatty macrophages. With the diagnosis of cryptogenic organised pneumonia probably related to amiodarone (suspended on admission)
column87: corticosteroid treatment with intravenous methylprednisolone (40 mg/24 hours) was started during admission. Prior to discharge
column88: a thyroid ultrasound was requested
column89: which showed multiple benign nodules with normal thyroid function. She was discharged after 7 days of admission
column90: with partial improvement of her respiratory symptoms with outpatient steroid treatment (oral methylprednisolone
column91: 40 mg until further review in one month). The rest of the treatment at discharge was as follows: pantoprazole 40 mg at breakfast
column92: acetylsalicylic acid 100 mg at lunch
column93: valsartan 80 mg at dinner and calcium and vitamin D3 1250 mg at breakfast. She came for a check-up at the end of September 2018
column94: reporting a clear improvement in respiratory function. Complete respiratory function tests were repeated
column95: showing an improvement in respiratory function (normal function
column96: with an improvement in diffusion capacity of 3 ml/mmHg with respect to the previous test) and in the 6-minute walk test in which she was able to complete 445 metres. A chest CT scan was performed in October 2018 in which a peripheral interstitial pattern persisted
column97: predominantly basal
column98: in ground glass
column99: with thickening of the interlobar septa
column100: although with a clear improvement compared to the previous CT scan
column101: with almost complete disappearance of the areas of consolidation.  DIAGNOSIS Interstitial pneumonitis probably secondary to pharmacological toxicity due to amiodarone. Hypertensive heart disease with normal ventricular function
column102: without signs of heart failure. Systemic arterial hypertension with good pharmacological control. Persistent atrial fibrillation treated by ablation in 2012 and 2014. Arrhythmic recurrence with low afterload. Currently in sinus rhythm. History of recurrent epistaxis under treatment with oral anticoagulation. Carrier of Amulet 28 mm atrial appendage closure device and on treatment with simple antiplatelet therapy. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  BACKGROUND Male patient aged 77 years. No known allergic reactions to medication. Cardiovascular risk factors: hypertension
column3: dyslipidaemia. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) secondary to bilateral calcific pachypleuritis (flour factory worker)
column4: with no need for home oxygen therapy. Mild cor pulmonale. Ischaemic stroke in the territory of the left middle cerebral artery in November 2016. Stage 3A chronic kidney disease. Spinal canal stenosis
column5: right hip prosthesis.  Usual treatment Rabeprazole 20 mg (every 24 hours)
column6: bisoprolol 2.5 mg (every 24 hours)
column7: diosmin 500 mg (every 12 hours)

column13: he presented fever up to 38.4 oC

column17: with fovea.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Chest X-ray (posteroanterior and lateral projections): increased cardiothoracic index. Right costophrenic sinus impingement. Pleural and probably pericardial plaques. Increased bronchoalveolar tract. CBC: leucocytes 8900 u/ml

column48: with moderately depressed global systolic function. Generalised hypokinesia
column49: without segmental alterations. Septal hyperrefringence. Restrictive filling pattern. Mild mitral insufficiency of central origin
column50: without notable alterations in the aortic valve. Dilated left atrium (48 mm in M mode). End-diastolic velocity of pulmonary insufficiency 17 mmHg
column51: allowing calculation of a diastolic pulmonary artery pressure (PAP) of 27 mmHg. Slightly dilated right ventricle without hypertrophy with preserved systolic function. Right atrium not dilated. No tricuspid insufficiency. Pericardium with posterior effusion of 5 mm. Inferior vena cava 21 mm
column52: with respiratory collapse greater than 50%. Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI): right atrium 63 x 54 mm. Right ventricle (RV) 94 x 51 x 69 mm. Left atrium 69 x 56 mm. Left Ventricle (LV) 48 x 49 x 93 mm. Interatrial Septum 8 mm. Minimal circumferential pericardial fluid tab. LVEF 35%. Beat volume 33.4 ml/m2
column53: cardiac output 5.1 l/min; end-diastolic volume (EDV) 96.6 ml/m2
column54: end-systolic volume (ESV) 63.2 ml/m2. LV wall mass 155.6 g/m2. RV ejection fraction 27%; LV stroke volume 57.2 ml/m2; cardiac output 4.3 l/min; end-diastolic volume 106.1 ml/m2
column55: end-systolic volume 77.5 ml/m2. LV with moderate-severe concentric hypertrophy
column56: predominantly septal hypertrophy
column57: with wall thickness in IVS up to 23 mm
column58: anterolateral segment 18 mm and inferior segment 15 mm at baseline. Global generalised hypocontractility
column59: more accentuated at the basal level of the RV with hypertrophy up to 6-7 mm thick. After intravenous contrast administration
column60: diffuse global subendocardial pathological enhancement is observed
column61: as well as transmural enhancement in septobasal. T1 values: mid-level levels of 1194 ± 103 ms in the lateral aspect showing some focal areas within the lateral aspect levels of up to 1224 ± 85 ms
column62: ECV 48.1% in the lateral aspect and up to 54.7% in focal areas of the lateral aspect. Pyrophosphate scintigraphy: increased uptake of the radiotracer at cardiac level
column63: more intense than in bone structures
column64: compatible with transthyretin amyloidosis (Perugini grade 3). Genetic test: negative result for genetic variants related to cardiac amyloidosis.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION The patient was admitted to the pulmonology department with suspected acute COPD. During his admission he did not present complete symptomatic resolution and a chest computed tomography (CT) scan was requested to assess the progression of his disease. This test showed the presence of pericardial effusion and signs of heart failure
column65: so transthoracic echocardiography was performed. After finding an echocardiographic pattern suggestive of cardiac amyloidosis
column66: the patient was transferred to the cardiology department. Cardio-MRI was requested
column67: which again showed a pattern compatible with cardiac amyloidosis. In addition
column68: a fat biopsy was requested (the patient refused a rectal biopsy)
column69: which was negative
column70: a 48-hour Holter recording with no alterations
column71: a proteinogram and detection of light chains in serum and urine
column72: which was negative
column73: and a scintigraphy with technetium-99-diphosphonate (Tc99-DPN) with intense uptake. With these results (see section on complementary tests) the patient was diagnosed with cardiac amyloidosis due to transthyretin. A genetic study was performed which did not detect any pathogenic variants and the diagnosis was therefore made as senile or wild-type. The patient was discharged with furosemide 80 mg every 24 hours and bisoprolol 2.5 mg every 12 hours
column74: in addition to his usual treatment. Spironolactone and renin-angiotensin axis antagonists could not be added due to impaired renal function and hyperkalaemia. At the outpatient level
column75: the patient was in New York Heart Association (NYHA) functional class III. Treatment of systolic dysfunction was optimised by adding low doses of sacubitril/valsartan
column76: as the patient reported no evidence of orthostatic hypotension or other manifestations of dysautonomia. On subsequent examinations
column77: renal function remained stable
column78: as well as blood pressure and potassium levels
column79: so he was maintained on sacubitrile/valsartan 24/26 m /12 hours. He did not present orthostatic hypotension and finally low doses of eplerenone every 48 hours could be added to the treatment. The patient reported relative clinical improvement
column80: as well as a decrease in NT-proBNP levels from 11
column81: 562 pg/ml to 6
column82: 244 pg/ml. The same treatment was continued and to date the patient has not been admitted to hospital.  DIAGNOSIS Heart failure with depressed LVEF. Cardiac amyloidosis due to transthyretin

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  PERSONAL HISTORY We present the case of an 80-year-old female patient
column3: autonomous and without cognitive impairment. She had a history of hypertension under treatment with lisinopril/hydrochlorothiazide 20/12.5 mg daily; type 2 diabetic with good metabolic control and without micro or macrovascular complications under treatment with metformin 1000 mg/sitagliptin 50 mg at breakfast and dinner; and dyslipidaemia under treatment with simvastatin 20 mg at dinner. In addition
column4: he has stage IV colorectal adenocarcinoma with lung metastases (metastatic debut in 2015) on third-line treatment with binimetanib and nivolumab since September 2018.  Current history She consulted the ED three weeks after initiation of immunotherapy for progressive picture of exertional dyspnoea and two-pillow orthopnoea along with anorexia
column5: asthenia and dizziness. He denied angina
column6: syncope
column7: as well as infectious focality or fever. He also reported no palpitations or other typical cardiological symptoms.  PHYSICAL EXAMINATION Blood pressure (BP) 95/63 mmHg. Heart rate (HR) 85 bpm. External jugular ingurgitation in the middle third
column8: eupneic in decubitus at 45 ̊ with O2 saturation 94% ambient air. Rhythmic cardiac auscultation without murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation with good bilateral ventilation
column9: moist crackles in the bases. Oedema with bilateral pretibial fovea.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Electrocardiogram (ECG) on arrival at the emergency department: sinus rhythm at 80 bpm
column10: normal PR. Wide QRS of 120 ms with BRD morphology and secondary repolarisation alterations. QTc 465ms. PA and lateral chest X-ray on admission: cardiothoracic index not increased
column11: bilateral perihilar thickening with vascular redistribution without occupation of costophrenic sinuses. Emergency laboratory tests: haemoglobin 9.9 g/dl

column14: platelets 132000/μl. INR 0.93

column27: NT-proBNP 1509 ng/l. Transthoracic echocardiogram: left ventricle neither dilated nor hypertrophic
column28: normofunctioning with hypokinesia of basal and medial inferolateral segments. Mitral filling pattern with impaired relaxation. Non-dilated left atrium. Normal right chambers. Normal mitral valve. Trivalve aortic valve
column29: with mild sclerosis and slightly elevated gradients (peak 20 mmHg). No evidence of pulmonary hypertension. IVT in RV outflow tract=23 cm (normal). No pericardial effusion. Inferior cava not dilated
column30: physiologically collapsed. Cardiac MRI with contrast: left ventricle of normal size
column31: with slightly increased wall thickness. No alterations of segmental contraction. Practical systolic collapse of the distal cavity
column32: hyperdynamic
column33: with left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) 72%. In STIR sequences
column34: predominantly mid-distal signal hyperintensity. Data suggestive of diffuse inflammation in T2 maps. Late enhancement without alterations. Triceps muscle biopsy: H-E shows several necrotic fibres with myophagocytosis and scant clustering of nuclei. The HE technique identifies a slight inflammatory infiltrate composed mainly of histiocytes. Immunohistochemistry revealed CD68 positive and HLA-1 positive patchy HLA-1 predominantly in the perifascicular region. CD3 negative. Findings globally compatible with the diagnosis of necrotising inflammatory myopathy. ECG at discharge (image 6): sinus rhythm at 70 bpm with normal PR and normopositioned narrow QRS with adequate progression in precordials without repolarisation alterations. Blood tests at discharge: haemoglobin 10.4 g/dl

column51: and given the suspected diagnosis
column52: empirical treatment was started with high-dose corticosteroids (methylprednisolone 2 mg/kg/day)
column53: oral diuretic at medium doses and telemetry monitoring. During admission
column54: there was a progressive normalisation of electrocardiographic alterations and markers of myocardial damage
column55: as well as an evident parallel clinical improvement
column56: tolerating a subsequent tapering regimen of systemic corticosteroids. Transthoracic echocardiography and magnetic resonance imaging showed preserved biventricular function
column57: without valvular heart disease or late enhancement. Diffuse oedema predominantly mediodistal on T2-STIR sequences compatible with a myocarditis-type inflammatory process with no apparent sequelae. In addition
column58: the positive result of anti-striated muscle antibodies and triceps brachii biopsy were consistent with the diagnosis of myositis. It is worth mentioning that neither coronary angiography nor endomyocardial biopsy was necessary in this case since the clinical
column59: analytical and ECG alterations
column60: completely reversible with anti-inflammatory drugs
column61: together with the autoimmunity
column62: the muscle biopsy and the data from the T2-STIR sequences and maps are sufficiently important to establish the diagnosis of myocarditis due to immunotherapy (nivolumab). Months later
column63: she is still under outpatient follow-up in cardio-oncology outpatient clinics
column64: asymptomatic
column65: with normal ECG and troponins. Nivolumab
column66: suspended after admission
column67: has not been restarted.  DIAGNOSIS Myocarditis and myositis due to nivolumab. Metastatic colorectal adenocarcinoma. Essential arterial hypertension. column1: A 71-year-old male patient with a history of prostatectomy for Gleason 7 prostate adenocarcinoma (2 years ago)
column2: not carrying a Foley catheter and who was regularly monitored by the Urology Department after the operation. One year ago
column3: he underwent cystoscopy for recurrent UTIs and underwent surgical dilatation for vesicourethral stenosis. Subsequently
column4: she was diagnosed with paroxysmal atrial fibrillation due to severe aortic insufficiency caused by a bicuspid valve
column5: and a valve prosthesis was fitted. Three months after the surgery
column6: he came to the emergency department complaining of arthralgia
column7: fever and new onset postvoid drip. Physical examination revealed splenomegaly and initial laboratory tests showed CRP: 26.9 mg/dL (reference values: 0-8 mg/dL)
column8: abundant bacteria and pyuria in the urinary sediment. Abdominal CT scan showed splenic infarction and biochemistry was expanded with troponin T: 319.6 ng/L (reference values: 0-14 ng/L)
column9: and pro-BNP: 45
column10: 140 pg/mL (reference values: 0-100 pg/mL). Microbiological study of urine in CLED culture medium showed no growth and Gram staining of urine identified gram-positive cocci. A blood agar culture was performed and gram-positive cocci colony growth was observed. Identification to genus and species level
column11: Aerococcus urinae
column12: was performed by MALDI-TOF mass spectrometry. In the 4 bottles of the two blood cultures there was also growth and the same micro-organism was identified. The antibiogram was as follows: sensitive to penicillin (MIC = 0.012 mg/L)
column13: cefotaxime (MIC = 0.064 mg/L)
column14: levofloxacin (MIC = 0.25 mg/L)
column15: vancomycin and linezolid. Transesophageal echocardiography showed evidence of prosthetic valve with perivalvular abscess. The patient initially received cloxacillin + gentamicin and later continued with ceftriaxone + daptomycin
column16: with subsequent negative blood cultures. However
column17: the clinical evolution
column18: inflammatory markers and myocardial function were compatible with sepsis and acute pulmonary oedema
column19: with fatal evolution towards irreversible ventricular failure. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  PERSONAL HISTORY No allergic drug reactions. No hypertension or diabetes mellitus. Dyslipidaemia. Ex-smoker for more than 20 years. No alcoholism. Obesity. Cardiological history: not reported. Other history: Last admission to neurology (one year ago): cortical cerebral venous thrombosis with associated parietal subarachnoid haemorrhage. Negative thrombophilia study. ANA Positive 1/160
column3: no apparent autoimmune symptoms. G3 P3 C0 A0. Hypermenorrhoea due to uterine myoma. Previous surgical interventions: cholecystectomy 20 years ago. Usual treatment: atorvastatin 20 mg (0-0-1)
column4: citicoline 1g (1-0-0). On treatment with acenocoumarol until 10 days before the current event. As there were no pathological findings requiring indefinite maintenance of anticoagulation
column5: anticoagulation treatment was discontinued.  CURRENT DISEASE A 44-year-old woman came to the emergency department with oppressive chest pain of 24 hours' duration. She reported moderate intensity epigastralgia with subsequent irradiation to the central thoracic region and neck associated with vegetative cramping
column6: which did not subside after taking several tablets of non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs. No dyspnoea or presyncope. She denied previous episodes of chest pain. Given the persistence of the pain
column7: she decided to go to the emergency department. On arrival
column8: an electrocardiogram (ECG) was performed showing a subepicardial lesion current in the inferolateral and anterior face (V3-V6 and II
column9: III and aVF). A haemodynamic alert was activated and emergent catheterisation was performed via the left radial route according to the usual technique with a 6F introducer. Right dominance. Evidence of thrombosis at the level of the ostial anterior descending (AD) artery. Thromboaspiration was performed with extraction of scarce white thrombus but recovering distal flow TIMI 2-3. The lesion was predilated with a balloon
column10: a drug-eluting stent was implanted and the proximal segment of the stent was post-dilated with a balloon with good results. However
column11: there was later evidence of TIMI 1 distal mid-distal LAD flow that did not improve despite multiple doses of intracoronary nitroglycerin (icNTG) or percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) balloon/guidewire manipulation (no-reflow effect). Periprocedural complications included ventricular fibrillation with haemodynamic instability requiring electrical cardioversion and vasoactive support. Given the patient's history of cavernous sinus thrombosis and subsequent subarachnoid haemorrhage (SAH)
column12: it was decided not to administer potent antiplatelet therapy or abciximab
column13: so acetylsalicylic acid (ASA) 250 mg and clopidogrel 600 mg were administered. After transfer to the coronary unit
column14: a portable transthoracic echocardiography showed severe ventricular dysfunction and an image suggestive of apical thrombus. Given the suspicion of apical thrombus
column15: enoxaparin is maintained at anticoagulant doses. Two hours after the percutaneous procedure
column16: the pain recurred and a new ST-segment elevation was observed
column17: so it was decided to activate a second haemodynamic alert. Emergent coronary angiography was performed. Acute thrombosis of the stent in the LAD was evidenced and balloon predilatation was performed
column18: restoring TIMI 3 flow with good expansion of the stent
column19: with no images of dissection of the distal edge of the stent; however
column20: there was still a large mobile thrombotic cast. Tirofiban is administered. After several minutes the thrombotic component persists with TIMI 3 flow
column21: so thromboaspiration is performed with a good final angiographic result. He was transferred to the coronary unit.  PHYSICAL EXAMINATION Blood pressure (BP) 90/50 mmHg
column22: heart rate (HR) 120 bpm

column24: at 120 bpm
column25: with 3R and 4R. Bladder murmur preserved with no over-additions. Lower extremities without oedema
column26: peripheral pulses preserved and symmetrical
column27: no signs of phlebitis.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG: Emergency ECG (image 1): sinus tachycardia at 140 bpm
column28: normal PR. Narrow QRS. Q wave in II
column29: III and aVF
column30: V3-6 with ST rise in these leads and fall in I
column31: aVL V1-2. ECG 2 hours after catheterisation with recurrence of pain: sinus tachycardia at 125 bpm
column32: normal PR. Narrow QRS. ST elevation in II
column33: III and aVF as well as in V4-6 with Q wave in II
column34: III and aVF and ST descent in I

column78: anterior and mid-lateral segments. Contractility more preserved in bases. Estimated LVEF 30%. RV of normal size with preserved contractility. Mitral pattern with E minor A. At discharge: severe left ventricular dysfunction (LVEF 34%) secondary to apical aneurysm and marked hypokinesia of anterior
column79: lateral and septal mid segments. Absence of apical thrombus. Mild to moderate mitral regurgitation (grade II/IV) secondary to posterior leaflet retraction. Filling pattern compatible with increased end-diastolic pressures. Normal right ventricle with indirect signs of increased PAP. Cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR): LV with normal volumes (VTD 78 ml/m2
column80: VTS 52 ml/m2
column81: IMVI 54 g/m2) without significant hypertrophy of its walls
column82: with anterior and anteroseptal akinesia basal and medial and anterior and apical septal and strict apex with hypercontractility of the remaining segments and severe depression of global systolic function at rest (LVEF 33%). STIR sequences show myocardial oedema in the akinetic segments. Non-dilated RV (RVOT 37 ml/m2
column83: STV 14 ml/m2) with preserved global systolic function (RVEF 64%). Aorta and great vessels of normal diameter and morphology. Atria of normal dimensions. Perfusion study (video 10): Gadoteric acid (0.15 mm/kg) is administered and well tolerated by the patient. Resting perfusion defects are detected in the akinetic segments. Necrosis and viability detection study: presence of myocardial LGE suggestive of transmural necrosis at the anterior and anteroseptal basal and mid and anterior and apical septal level and strict apex with presence of microvascular obstruction in these segments (absence of viability in 7 segments out of 17
column84: DA-dependent). Presence of minimal pericardial and pleural effusion. Conclusion: acute ischaemic LV heart disease with preserved volumes and severe depression of GSF (LVEF 33%) with contractile alteration
column85: oedema
column86: perfusion defect and transmural necrosis with MVO at the level of 7 proximal LAD-dependent segments. Absence of intraventricular thrombus. Total Body CT: Thoracic CT: centred mediastinum with no evidence of ganglionic formations of significant size. No pulmonary nodules or condensations are observed. No pleural or pericardial effusion is observed. Abdominopelvic CT scan: heterogeneous uterus
column87: enlarged probably due to the presence of myomas. Nodular image of 17 mm with peripheral contrast uptake in left dense topography theoretically suggestive of corpus luteum. Liver of normal size and morphology with no evidence of focal lesions or dilatation of the intra- or extrahepatic bile duct. Cholecystectomy. Spleen
column88: pancreas
column89: adrenal glands and both kidneys were normal. No lymph node formations of significant size were observed in the abdominopelvic chains. Normal calibre and distribution of intestinal loops. No signs of metastatic bone involvement were observed by this technique.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION After readmission to the coronary unit
column90: he presented haemodynamic lability requiring increased vasoactive support with noradrenaline and dobutamine
column91: so it was decided to implant an intra-aortic balloon counterpulsation device. Progressive weaning of haemodynamic support was achieved
column92: with withdrawal of balloon counterpulsation and dobutamine on the third day. On the fourth day
column93: despite noradrenaline support
column94: levosimendan was started due to sustained hypotension. Norepinephrine was withdrawn on the sixth day. No ventricular arrhythmias were observed on monitoring. Spontaneous diuresis greater than 1500 ml per day with accumulated negative balance. An MRI was performed which confirmed severe ventricular dysfunction and ruled out the presence of intracavitary thrombus. Discharge to the cardiology ward was decided to continue the study. During his stay on the ward he remained stable from the cardiovascular point of view
column95: with no new episodes of chest pain. He began to ambulate with dyspnoea on moderate exertion (NYHA III/IV) with no other signs of heart failure; he also reported no palpitations
column96: syncopal or presyncopal episodes. Pharmacological titration was carried out
column97: verifying progressive tolerance (bisoprolol 5 mg/12h
column98: enalapril 2.5 mg/12h
column99: eplerenone 50 mg/24h
column100: ivabradine 10 mg/12h). Given that the patient had presented two thromboembolic events in different vascular territories
column101: the last of which coincided with withdrawal of acenocoumarol
column102: it was decided to perform a complete thrombophilia study. A CT scan of the abdomen and abdomen and pelvis was performed to rule out tumours and a complete blood analysis was performed. No relevant findings were observed in any of them. The patient was discharged home with follow-up in the heart failure unit with the following treatment regimen: Enoxaparin 80 mg one subcutaneous injection at breakfast and dinner
column103: as a bridge to acenocoumarol. acenocoumarol 1 mg two tablets at lunch. ASA 100 mg one tablet at breakfast. Ticagrelol 90 mg one tablet at breakfast and dinner. Atorvastatin 40 mg one tablet at dinner. Bisoprolol 5 mg one tablet at breakfast and dinner. Ivabradine 5 mg one tablet at breakfast and dinner. Eplerenone 50 mg one tablet at lunch. Enalapril 2.5 mg one tablet at dinner. Furosemide 40 mg one tablet at breakfast. Omeprazole 20 mg one tablet at breakfast.  DIAGNOSIS KILLIP IV STEMI: acute thrombotic occlusion of the ostial LAD. Primary angioplasty with DES implantation in complicated LAD with no-reflow phenomenon and subsequent acute stent thrombosis.   Secondary diagnoses: Severe systolic ventricular dysfunction. Apical aneurysm. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  PERSONAL HISTORY Male
column3: 56 years old
column4: from Colombia
column5: with no known drug allergies. No family history of heart disease or sudden death. His toxic habits include moderate alcohol consumption until several years ago. He was a non-smoker. Cardiovascular risk factors include arterial hypertension and dyslipidaemia
column6: both without pharmacological treatment or control by any physician
column7: and morbid obesity (BMI 57 kg/m2). Other history of interest: severe sleep apnoea syndrome without treatment and hypothyroidism. She denies regular treatment for any of her comorbidities.  CURRENT ILLNESS She came to the emergency department for progressive dyspnoea of 15 days of evolution until she became resting
column8: together with orthopnoea
column9: increased abdominal perimeter and oedema in the extremities. She reported no chest pain
column10: palpitations
column11: dizziness or syncope in the weeks prior to consultation.  PHYSICAL EXAMINATION Weight 171 kg; height 173 cm; body mass index (BMI) 57 kg/m2. Afebrile; blood pressure (BP) 100/60 mmHg; heart rate (HR) 132 bpm; baseline SatO2 98%. Conscious and oriented
column12: normohydrated
column13: eupneic at rest
column14: jugular ingurgitation present at 45 ̊. Cardiac auscultation: arrhythmic heart sounds at 132 bpm without murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation: bibasal crackles. Abdomen: soft
column15: depressible
column16: very globular
column17: not painful to deep or superficial palpation
column18: peristalsis present
column19: without peritonism. Lower extremities: bilateral oedema with pitting up to the knee.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG on admission: atrial fibrillation (AF) with ventricular response at 132 bpm. Q wave in DIII. Low voltages. Chest X-ray: radiological cardiomegaly. Interstitial oedema. Blood tests: biochemistry: glucose 93 mg/dl; HbA1c 6.2%; urea 0.44 g/l; creatinine 1.19 mg/dl; glomerular filtration rate 67 ml/min; total cholesterol 223 mg/dl; LDL cholesterol 150 mg/dl; HDL cholesterol 23 mg/dl; triglycerides 250 mg/dl; sodium 145 mEq/l; potassium 4.8 mEq/l. TSH 2.01 mcU/ml. Normal liver function tests. Haemoglobin 14.8 g/dl; haematocrit 45.7%; leucocytes 8
column20: 100/mm3; platelets 198
column21: 000/mm3. Transthoracic echocardiogram (with Sonovue echocontrast): severely dilated left atrium (A4C: 60 cm2). Thin leaflet mitral valve with preserved mobility and opening; mild regurgitation grade I/IV. Moderately dilated left ventricle (indexed biplane LVEDV: 93 cm3/m2) with severely depressed systolic function (LVEF 32%) due to global impairment. Thin aortic valve with good opening and mobility; no regurgitation. Slightly dilated aortic root. Slightly dilated right atrium (A4C: 26 cm2). Dilated right ventricle (basal diameter 53 mm; mean 37 mm); with slightly depressed contractility (TAPSE 15 mm). Tricuspid valve with good opening and mobility; grade II/IV insufficiency. Dilated inferior vena cava with inspiratory collapse. Estimated pulmonary arterial systolic pressure 51 mmHg. No pericardial effusion. Left heart catheterisation: ventriculography: dilated left ventricle with severe systolic dysfunction. No mitral regurgitation. Coronary angiography: left dominance. No angiographically significant lesions in the epicardial coronary arteries. Respiratory function tests: spirometry: moderate decrease in obstructive ventilatory function. FEV1 2.12 l (59%); FVC 3.38 l (73%); FEV1/FVC 62.67%. Bronchodilator test: positive; significant improvement in FEV1 (+18% = 320 ml). Electrocardiogram at discharge: atrial fibrillation with ventricular response at 80 bpm. Q wave in III. Low voltages.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION Initial cardiological assessment in the emergency department revealed clinical signs of congestive heart failure
column22: atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response at 132 bpm and left systolic dysfunction on echocardioscopy
column23: and the patient was admitted for appropriate treatment and to complete aetiological studies. The patient showed significant clinical improvement during the first days of admission with depletive treatment with intravenous diuretics
column24: reaching a dry weight of 156 kg compared to the initial 171 kg. A regulated echocardiogram was performed with echocontrast due to a poor echocardiographic window
column25: which confirmed the echocardiographic findings
column26: also showing elevated filling pressures with significant pulmonary hypertension and associated right-sided dysfunction. Furthermore
column27: the aetiological study was completed with coronary angiography to rule out ischaemic aetiology of dilated cardiomyopathy
column28: showing no angiographically significant lesions in the epicardial coronary arteries. Therefore
column29: the condition was interpreted as heart failure with reduced ejection fraction in the context of non-ischaemic dilated cardiomyopathy
column30: without being able to rule out a toxic origin (enolic) together with a certain component of associated tachycardiomyopathy. During admission
column31: treatments with prognostic value in heart failure with depressed systolic function were successfully initiated
column32: with good tolerance to them
column33: achieving good heart rate control with beta-blockers at medium doses and being discharged with ACE inhibitors
column34: beta-blockers and antialdosteronics at maximum doses tolerated by blood pressure. In addition
column35: during his hospitalisation the patient received nutritional education for changes in eating habits
column36: as well as instructions to begin physical exercise. In the case of a patient with pre-diabetes and morbid obesity with LDL 150 mg/dl
column37: statins were started to achieve target LDL < 100 mg/dl. In collaboration with the pulmonology department
column38: CPAP treatment was started during admission for his sleep apnoea
column39: with good tolerance. Regarding his atrial fibrillation of uncertain onset
column40: with a CHADS-VASc score of 2 and HASBLED of 0
column41: he was anticoagulated on admission with weight-adjusted LMWH. An initial strategy of rate control was proposed so that
column42: after clinical stabilisation and one month of anticoagulation
column43: programmed electrical cardioversion was performed for rhythm control purposes. Regarding the choice of anticoagulation therapy at discharge
column44: the patient refused to take VKA for personal reasons
column45: which added to his high weight and BMI posed a major dilemma. In agreement with the haematology service
column46: it was decided to start rivaroxaban 20 mg and laboratory measurements of his peak and trough levels were performed to check that they were in therapeutic range. After this
column47: he was discharged with this treatment on a continuous basis. In the outpatient follow-up
column48: the patient has improved clinically
column49: has reduced his weight to 130 kg (BMI 43 kg/m2) and is in functional grade II. Titration of prognostic drugs in heart failure has continued
column50: replacing ACE inhibitors with sacubitrilo-valsartan. Two unsuccessful attempts at electrical cardioversion were made
column51: opting to continue with heart rate control
column52: which was proving adequate. In the control echocardiography after 3 months of optimised medical treatment
column53: an improvement in LVEF of up to 50% was observed.  DIAGNOSIS Heart failure with depressed left ventricular ejection fraction. Non-ischaemic dilated cardiomyopathy (possible toxic damage due to enolism and associated tachycardiomyopathy). Atrial fibrillation (AF) of undetermined onset (CHADSVASc 2
column54: HASBLED 0). Coronary arteries without significant lesions. Very severe sleep apnoea syndrome. Morbid obesity. Arterial hypertension with good control at discharge. column2: CURRENT DISEASE AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION A 37-year-old male of Indian origin with no cardiovascular risk factors (CVRF) was referred to our hospital with a diagnosis of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome. The patient made his debut at the age of 16 years (in 1990) with syncope while playing football. He had no family history of sudden death or relevant diseases. An electrocardiogram (ECG) showed signs of left ventricular (LV) hypertrophy with negative T waves in the precordial leads and pre-excitation. Severe concentric ventricular hypertrophy was corroborated on echocardiography
column3: with a maximum IVS diameter of 22 mm
column4: diastolic dysfunction and mild biventricular systolic dysfunction. He subsequently presented with an episode of pre-excited atrial fibrillation (AF) at more than 200 bpm
column5: and electrophysiological studies demonstrated the existence of a posteroseptal/medioseptal accessory pathway (near the normal conduction system) that could not be ablated by radiofrequency after three unsuccessful attempts in three different procedures
column6: so he was managed with medical treatment. In 2012 (aged 27 years) he presented with an episode of acute pain in the right lower limb
column7: being diagnosed by angio-CT of an acute thrombosis in the femoral artery
column8: presumably due to an embolism secondary to a paroxysm of AF
column9: so treatment with warfarin was started. To better define the myocardium
column10: cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (CMR) was performed and showed severe biventricular hypertrophy with a maximum IVS thickness of up to 30 mm; slightly depressed LVEF and extensive diffuse fibrosis in the areas of hypertrophy. Several 24-hour Holter recordings were performed during the evolution without detecting ventricular tachycardias or frequent ventricular extrasystoles or new episodes of AF
column11: although the patient reported palpitations about twice a month. On arrival at our centre
column12: to which he was referred as a referral unit for cardiomyopathies and other familial heart diseases
column13: the patient had blood pressure (BP) 136/89 mmHg
column14: RS at 52 bpm
column15: without jugular venous engorgement. On auscultation
column16: cardiac tones were rhythmic without murmurs
column17: with preserved vesicular murmur and no pathological sounds. The lower limbs showed no oedema or signs of deep vein thrombosis. There were no skin lesions suggestive of cardio-cutaneous syndromes such as Fabry or Leopard.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG: sinus bradycardia at 47 bpm. PR 140 ms with positive delta wave in V1 suggestive of left accessory pathway. QRS 160 ms. Left axis. Elevated R wave voltages especially in left precordial and deep negative T waves from V1 to V6
column18: in I and aVL and flattened in inferior face. ECG in pre-excited AF: irregular wide QRS tachycardia at more than 200 bpm
column19: with irregularity in QRS morphology and width and in RR. First transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE): concentric hypertrophy of 22 mm and midcavitary obliteration. Severe diastolic dysfunction. Dilated left atrium (LA). LVEF 57%. Moderate right ventricular (RV) dysfunction. CMR: short axis and 4 chambers showing severe biventricular hypertrophy. 3C
column20: D and E: sagittal plane
column21: 4 chambers and short axis late gadolinium enhancement showing extensive and diffuse uptake in areas of hypertrophy. First 24-hour Holter: sinus rhythm at 45-87 bpm. No significant pauses. Low density ventricular extrasystoles. Frequent atrial extrasystoles. Absence of ventricular arrhythmias or AF. No symptoms reported in the diary.
