column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION 53-year-old woman
column3: diagnosed with mild dyslipidaemia for the last 5 years on dietary treatment. No other known risk factors or toxic habits. No medication at home. In the previous 48 hours she presented with episodes of self-limiting central thoracic pain
column4: without seeking medical assistance. At around 10 am
column5: while having breakfast
column6: she suffered a new episode of typical central thoracic pain accompanied by vegetative cortex
column7: for which she went to the emergency department accompanied by her family (11:20 am). After syncopal symptoms in the triage area
column8: she was transferred to observation
column9: and VT was observed at 220 bpm. Basic CPR manoeuvres were started (5 min duration)
column10: followed by CVE at 200 J
column11: with an asystole rhythm. 2 mg of atropine is administered. Advanced CPR for 5 min
column12: achieving pulse (total CPR 10 min) and sinus rhythm at 85 bpm with significant ST elevation in anterior leads. Amiodarone infusion (1
column13: 200 mg) was started and the patient was transferred to the haemodynamics ward for urgent catheterisation. During the transfer
column14: an episode of NSVT at 200 bpm was recorded
column15: followed by sinus rhythm and complete AVB after 10-15 min. Advanced CPR was performed again for 30 minutes with orotracheal intubation and adrenaline perfusion was started. In the haemodynamics room
column16: a transient pacemaker was implanted via the right femoral artery and cardiac catheterisation was performed via femoral access
column17: which revealed 3-vessel coronary artery disease and complete revascularisation was performed. In addition
column18: an intra-aortic balloon pump was placed with 1:1 assistance. During catheterisation
column19: a nasogastric tube is inserted and 300 mg of ASA and 180 mg of ticagrelor are administered. A bolus of abciximab is administered and the intravenous infusion is continued. A few minutes later
column20: she started bleeding in the oral cavity and through the endotracheal tube
column21: and abciximab was discontinued. At the end of the catheterisation
column22: the adrenaline infusion was withdrawn. She arrived at the ICU without vasoactive drugs
column23: connected to mechanical ventilation. She suffered another cardiorespiratory arrest
column24: her third
column25: this time in asystole. She was resuscitated for 15 minutes (2 mg of adrenaline)
column26: leaving in sinus rhythm. Examination on admission to the ICU revealed BP 100/80 mmHg
column27: HR 100 bpm
column28: RR 18 rpm. Neurological examination: bilateral mydriasis
column29: Glasgow Coma Scale score of 3. Pulmonary auscultation with bibasal crackles. Cardiac auscultation rhythmic
column31: counterpulsation noises. Extremities with peripheral coldness
column32: weak distal pulses
column33: no signs of deep vein thrombosis.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG after 1st CRP: RS at 85 bpm
column34: PR 200 ms
column35: QRS 120 ms
column36: significant ST-segment elevation in anterior leads V1 to V4. Urgent cardiac catheterisation: 3-vessel coronary artery disease. Lesions in DA (proximal occlusion)
column37: CX (OM with 90% stenosis) and CD (mid-level occlusion). Complete revascularisation with 2 stents in LAD
column38: 1 in OM and 1 in DC. Chest X-ray on admission: non-selective orotracheal intubation. Bilateral alveolointerstitial pattern. Echocardiogram in ICU: left ventricle not dilated
column39: not hypertrophic
column40: with moderately depressed systolic function (EF 35-40 %)
column41: with septal akinesia
column42: anterior and apical segments. Better contractility in basal and medial lateral and basal and medial anterior. Right ventricle not dilated
column43: with normal systolic function by TAPSE. Left atrium not dilated. Normal aortic root. Inferior vena cava not dilated
column44: collapsing on inspiration. Laboratory tests on admission: haemoglobin 14.8 mg/dl
column45: leucocytes 11
column47: platelets 376
column48: 000/ul. Glucose 130 mg/dl
column49: creatinine 1.7 mg/dl
column50: Na 139 mEq/l
column51: K 4.6 mEq/l
column52: GOT 571 IU/l
column53: LDH 1
column54: 854 IU/l
column55: peak CK 3
column56: 254 IU/l

column80: oliguric renal dysfunction and pulmonary oedema with severe respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation and FiO2 of 100%. It was decided to place cardiorespiratory support in the form of venoarterial ECMO
column81: which was performed in the operating theatre by Cardiac Surgery after 8 hours of stay in the ICU. After ECMO placement
column82: haemodynamic improvement was observed with withdrawal of vasoactive agents after 24 hours. Assistance was started with 4 l/min
column83: which was progressively reduced until weaning was achieved on the fourth day after placement. Echocardiography showed moderate ventricular dysfunction with an estimated LVEF of 35-40%. Initially
column84: the patient presented mild delirium and tetraparesis
column85: which recovered quickly
column86: waking up clearly
column87: without neurological focality. Given his stability and improvement

column90: ACE inhibitors and amiodarone until she became asymptomatic from the cardiological point of view. She presented significant elevation of transaminases

column95: HDL 34 mg/dl and triglycerides 580 mg/dl despite treatment with ezetimibe 10 mg and fibrates. It was decided to start treatment with PCSK9 inhibitors (evolocumab 140 mg every 15 days) and she was included in a cardiac rehabilitation programme. She started with very low capacity
column96: which gradually increased
column97: with very good progress. She completed a total of 60 treadmill sessions and completed the cardiac rehabilitation programme without complications. Improvement in functional class for dyspnoea
column98: Borg scale 3-4. Training HR: 85-100 bpm. No clinical signs of angina with the effort achieved. Adequate LDL control is achieved with figures of 31 mg/dl.  DIAGNOSIS Resuscitated cardiorespiratory arrest. Acute anterior myocardial infarction
column99: Killip IV. 3-vessel coronary artery disease
column100: urgent complete revascularisation. Moderate-severe LV systolic dysfunction. Transient ECMO support. Hypercholesterolemia with intolerance to statins. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION We are dealing with a 70-year-old patient with no known drug allergies or toxic habits; no known diabetes mellitus but hypertensive and dyslipidaemic. He has a family history of ischaemic heart disease. The patient's cardiological history began in July 2012
column3: when Holter monitoring was requested after presenting symptomatic bradycardia that required chronotropic drugs during arthroscopy. The 24-hour recording showed spells of atrial fibrillation with MVF 100 bpm (max 150) alternating with the patient's baseline rhythm which was sinus bradycardia (45 bpm). An echocardiographic study was completed
column4: with no abnormalities. In November 2012
column5: a bicameral pacemaker was implanted via the subclavian artery and anticoagulation with acenocoumarol was started. Due to persistent atrial fibrillation with poor clinical control
column6: electrical cardioversion was performed and she was discharged with amiodarone 200 mg/24 h and bisoprolol 2.5 mg/24 h
column7: in addition to anticoagulation. In January 2014
column8: he was referred to the outpatient cardiology department for dyspnoea and chest tightness related to exertion of 2 months' duration. An echocardiogram was performed showing LV with moderately depressed EF. Depletive treatment was started (furosemide and eplerenone) and an analytical study and coronary angiography were requested. Coronary angiography showed stenosis of the proximal anterior descending artery (DAp) 80%
column9: circumflex at the level of the exit of the first obtuse marginal (Cx- OM1) 100% and proximal right coronary (CDp) 90%
column10: and middle (CDm) 60%
column11: opting for surgical revascularisation. The intervention was performed in September 2014
column12: with triple coronary puncture to the middle LAD with internal mammary artery (IMA) and sequence with saphenous vein (SVF) to 1st OM and posterolateral branches. Postoperative evolution was torpid with multiple admissions for dyspnoea and cardiac decompensation. SPECT was performed and showed mild lateral ischaemia
column13: so a new coronary angiography was requested
column14: showing patency of all bypasses performed. The MCP was reviewed
column15: revealing MCP dysfunction
column16: which was corrected by modifying the programming. Since then
column17: asymptomatic in functional class II. Treatment with amiodarone was withdrawn and replaced with dronedarone due to hypothyroidism. He repeatedly consulted for muscle pain related to statins (simvastatin 10 mg and atorvastatin 10 mg)
column18: for which he was referred to the Lipidology unit of reference
column19: despite which the myalgias always recurred with the reintroduction of statins. Finally
column20: given the high cardiovascular risk
column21: intolerance to lipid-lowering drugs and severe dyslipidaemia
column22: treatment with IPCSK9 was started with good tolerance and LDL levels were reduced to 88 mg/dl from an initial level of 218 mg/dl.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Blood tests 12-07-16 (patient's baseline): creatinine 0.98 mg/dl

column71: asymptomatic for chest pain and tolerating medication without incident. The last echocardiogram showed recovery of the ejection fraction
column72: which was classified as preserved in the last echocardiogram. Due to back pain that had been present for months
column73: an abdominal CT scan was performed
column74: which revealed an abdominal aortic aneurysm
column75: pending surgery for the placement of an endoprosthesis. This is therefore a patient at very high cardiovascular risk due to ischaemic heart disease
column76: aortic vascular disease and dyslipidaemia in whom treatment with statins was not possible due to intolerance
column77: in whom the introduction of IPCSK9 has managed to reduce his LDL-c levels by more than 50%
column78: and he is increasingly close to reaching the desired level for his high cardiovascular risk
column79: which is less than 70 mg/dL.  DIAGNOSIS Chronic ischaemic heart disease with 3-vessel disease. History of triple aorto-coronary bypass with IMA to LAD and SFN sequence to MO1 and PD. Transient left ventricular dysfunction (currently normal LVEF). Abdominal aortic aneurysm pending endovascular repair. Stable heart failure in functional class II. Sinus dysfunction with paroxysmal AF. Carrier of normofunctioning DDD MCP at the present time. Severe dyslipidaemia. Intolerance to statins. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION A 50-year-old man came to the emergency department for chest pain. No known allergies. No toxic habits. No habitual treatment. No CVRF. Only previous history of tonsillectomy in childhood and left meniscectomy. Asymptomatic from the cardiological point of view
column3: until the early morning of admission (4:00 a.m.). He started with shooting pains in the jaw. Subsequently
column4: they radiate to the anterior region of the thorax
column5: become oppressive
column6: of moderate intensity
column7: without vegetative cortex. They subside spontaneously one hour later. She had several recurrences
column8: of greater intensity
column9: and so she went to the emergency department. Arrives more than 6 hours after the onset of the symptoms
column10: with slight residual discomfort. She improved after conventional analgesia. On arrival she was haemodynamically stable. BP 119/83 mmHg; HR 68 bpm; SatO2 98 % on room air; Ta 36.1°C. Glasgow Scale: 15/15. Conscious
column11: oriented in all 3 spheres. Eupneic at rest
column12: well hydrated
column13: nourished and perfused. AC: rhythmic without murmurs or extratonos. PA: vesicular murmur preserved in both lung fields with no extra sounds. Abdomen: hydro-aerial sounds present
column14: soft
column15: not painful on deep or superficial palpation. Renal fist percussion (-). Extremities: no oedema
column16: no signs of DVT. Basic neurological examination was normal.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG: sinus rhythm at 68 bpm. Poor R wave growth in precordial leads
column17: isolated Q wave in lead III
column18: with no other alterations. No evolutionary changes in subsequent electrocardiograms. Portable echocardiogram (Vscan in the ER): LV not dilated or hypertrophic
column19: with normal global and segmental systolic function. Normal aortic root. RV not dilated. No significant valvulopathies. No pleural effusion. Haemogram: leucocytes 5
column20: 200/uL; neutrophils 61.3 %; lymphocytes 27.2 %; Hb 15.5 gr/dl; Htc 43.4 %; MCV 87.1 fl; platelets 180
column21: 000/uL. Haemostasis: APTT 29.3 sec; INR 1. Biochemistry: glucose 112 mg/dl
column22: creatinine 1.07 mg/dl
column23: sodium 141 mmol/l
column24: potassium 4 mmol/l
column25: total protein 6.3g/dl
column26: albumin 3.7g/dl
column27: calcium 8.6mg/dl
column28: phosphorus 3.4 mg/dl
column29: uric acid 7.6 mg/dl
column31: cholesterol 163 mg/dl
column32: GOT 114 U/l
column33: GPT 119 U/l
column34: GGT 95 U/l
column35: alkaline phosphatase 63 U/l
column36: LDH 496 U/l
column37: total bilirubin 1.91 mg/dl
column38: direct bilirubin 0.52 mg/dl. Enzyme serology: 1a: CK 766 U/l
column39: troponin I 25.89 ng/ml (normal < 0.06 ). 2a: CK 727 U/I troponin I 36.13 ng/ml. 3a: CK 696 U/I
column40: troponin I 27.52 ng/ml. Chest X-ray: no signs of CHF or parenchymal infiltrates. Serology: IgM HAV: negative; IgG anti HBc: negative; Anti HCV: negative; IgM anti CMV: negative; IgM against VCA: negative; Anti HIV: negative; Toxoplasmosis IgG IgM: negative. MRSA culture: negative. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) (Image 2): LV with preserved systolic function. Late gadolinium enhancement in basal and medial
column41: anterior
column42: lateral and inferior segments of the left ventricle
column43: respecting only the interventricular septum and apex. The enhancement shows subepicardial distribution without transmural involvement
column44: being compatible with myocarditis. Coronary angiography: LCT
column45: LAD and DC within normality. Mild stenosis of 20-30% in the middle CX. LVEF preserved in ventriculography. No images suggestive of coronary anomalies
column46: dissection or thrombosis.  EVOLUTION Given the clinical manifestations of chest pain and enzyme elevation
column47: the initial diagnosis of NSTEACS was established. He was admitted to the ICU and treatment was started with double antiplatelet therapy and anticoagulation
column48: statins and beta-blockers. He remained haemodynamically stable
column49: asymptomatic
column50: with no heart rhythm disturbances or evidence of CHF. Serialisation of markers of myocardial damage showed a clear increase
column51: in addition to continuing with mild chest pain. Coronary angiography was performed and no coronary pathology was found to justify the clinical picture. Laboratory tests showed an increase in transaminases and bilirubin with no clinical alterations on examination at the digestive level
column52: so a viral serology study was requested. In view of the coronary angiography findings
column53: the patient was questioned again and reported that in the last 2 months he had presented catarrhal symptoms and pharyngitis with clinical symptoms the week prior to admission of general malaise
column54: myalgia and dysthermic sensation with fever of up to 37.4°C
column55: with good response to paracetamol. In the presence of coronary arteries without significant lesions
column56: chest pain after respiratory infection and elevated markers of myocardial damage
column57: myocarditis was suspected. Treatment for NSTEACS was suspended. The patient remained stable on the ward
column58: with no recurrence of chest pain
column59: heart failure or arrhythmias. An echocardiographic study prior to discharge showed preserved LVEF with no alterations in global or segmental contractility. No evolutionary ECG changes during admission. Clinical evolution was favourable
column60: with treatment with ACE inhibitors. MRI was requested 48 hours later
column61: which confirmed the diagnosis of myocarditis.  DIAGNOSIS Acute myocarditis of probable viral aetiology. column2: CURRENT DISEASE AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION We present the case of a 65-year-old male type 2 diabetic of 8 years of evolution (on metformin treatment) who was admitted to our centre (on treatment with metformin) who was admitted to our centre for congestive heart failure (CHF). The patient had been a smoker until March 2014
column3: with a pack-year index of 30. In addition
column4: he was overweight (fulfilling metabolic syndrome criteria)
column5: hypertensive and hypercholesterolaemic (both under medical treatment with enalapril 5 mg/12 h
column6: bisoprolol 5 mg/24 h and atorvastatin 40 mg/24 h). His past history of interest included an inferior myocardial infarction in 1997
column7: with no information on interventionism and no subsequent follow-up
column8: as well as permanent atrial fibrillation anticoagulated with acenocoumarol. In 2014 he developed ischaemic colitis and a Forrest III gastric ulcer requiring hospital admission. This was complicated by a new non-ST-elevation type II infarction in the context of rectal bleeding. Once the patient was stabilised
column9: coronary angiography revealed severe 3-vessel coronary artery disease: proximal anterior descending (LAD) occlusion
column10: severe proximal circumflex and first obtuse marginal (OM1) lesion
column11: severe proximal bisector lesion and right coronary artery (RCA) occlusion. The transthoracic echocardiogram showed a severely depressed left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) (LVEF 25%). For all these reasons
column12: it was decided in a medical-surgical session to perform coronary revascularisation surgery
column13: which was finally carried out with the implantation of four vascular grafts (mammary artery to distal LAD
column14: saphenous vein in "Y" to bisector and OM1 and saphenous vein to mid-distal DC). Subsequent evolution was satisfactory
column15: but in 2015 the patient began to present symptoms of CHF
column16: requiring a first hospital admission in relation to dietary transgression. Since then
column17: he had been on treatment with 60 mg of furosemide daily and 25 mg of spironolactone
column18: in functional class (FC) II/IV ambulatory. She was admitted to our centre in October 2016 due to decompensation of severe CHF with acute hypertensive pulmonary oedema
column19: requiring management in the acute unit with non-invasive mechanical ventilation (NIMV) and intravenous medication. He also initially required inotropic support with dobutamine
column20: which was successfully withdrawn via a course of levosimendan. The electrocardiogram on admission showed atrial fibrillation with ventricular response at 90 bpm
column21: with QRS of 100ms
column22: QS in V1-V3 and flattened T in V5-6
column23: similar to previous records. As part of the diagnostic study
column24: a new coronary angiography was performed
column25: which showed patency of the previous grafts
column26: as well as a cardiac magnetic resonance imaging
column27: which showed an LVEF of 24%
column28: together with a transmural late enhancement pattern in the LAD territory. In addition
column29: the patient had moderate right ventricular systolic dysfunction. The hospital evolution was again favourable
column30: and after discussion with the Heart Team
column31: it was decided to implant a subcutaneous single-chamber implantable cardioverter defibrillator (ICD). After optimisation of pharmacological treatment (enalapril 10 mg/12 h; bisoprolol 5 mg/24 h; furosemide 80 mg/24 h; spironolactone 25 mg/24 h)
column32: a lipid profile control was performed
column33: showing LDL-cholesterol levels of 65 mg/dl and total cholesterol of 160mg/dl. Likewise
column34: the glycosylated haemoglobin value was 7.9%
column35: outside the therapeutic target
column36: so it was decided
column37: together with the Endocrinology Department
column38: to optimise treatment with oral antidiabetic drugs. As the patient was at high cardiovascular risk
column39: with several decompensations due to CHF
column40: regular blood pressure control and metabolic syndrome
column41: it was decided to add empaglifozin 10 mg daily to the previous treatment with metformin. The patient was discharged from hospital and continued to be closely monitored in the Cardiology day hospital.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Posteroanterior and lateral chest X-ray: global cardiomegaly
column42: increased bronchovascular tract compatible with interstitial and alveolar oedema
column43: cisural effusion
column44: sternotomy suture. Electrocardiogram: atrial fibrillation with ventricular response at 90 bpm
column45: with QRS of 100 ms
column46: QS in V1-V3 and flattened T in V5-6. Transthoracic echocardiogram: moderately dilated left ventricle
column47: with normal wall thickness. Severely depressed global systolic function (LVEF 20% by visual estimation). Akinesia and thinning of the septum
column48: apical (segment 17 aneurysm) and inferior face and mid and distal segments of the lateral-inferior. Single wave mitral filling. Left atrium slightly dilated. Mildly dilated right atrium. Right ventricle severely dilated
column49: with global systolic function at the lower limit of normal. TAPSE of 14 mm. Mitral valve with calcium ring
column50: thickening of the leaflets and restriction of the posterior leaflet opening. Mild insufficiency. Sclerosed aortic valve
column51: without pathological transaortic gradients. Mild insufficiency. Morphologically normal tricuspid valve. Moderate insufficiency. Pulmonary artery systolic pressure estimated at 65 mmHg. Dilated inferior vena cava (24.54 mm)
column52: without inspiratory collapse. No pericardial effusion. Epicardial fat. Aortic root 30 mm. Ascending aorta 37 mm. Pre-surgical coronary angiography: right dominance. Truncus: no lesions. Anterior descending: chronic occlusion at proximal level
column53: observed by heterocoronary circulation
column54: being a vessel of good calibre and development. Circumflex: artery of good development and calibre. It presents a severe lesion at the proximal level (85-90%)
column55: just after the exit of OM1
column56: the rest of the vessel is of good calibre and development. OM1 is a vessel of good development and calibre
column57: with a significant calcified lesion at the proximal level
column58: the rest of the vessel is of good calibre and development. Bisector branch: vessel of good calibre and development
column59: with severe calcified disease at the proximal level
column60: the rest of the vessel with diffuse mild atheromatosis. Right coronary description: right dominant. Chronic occlusion at the middle level
column61: distal vessel is observed by heterocoronary circulation being a vessel of good development. Diagnostic findings: severe 3-vessel coronary artery disease (chronic occlusion of DA and CD)
column62: severe Cx lesion (proximal Cx
column63: OM1 and bisector branch). Cardiac MRI: severely dilated left ventricle (VTD 295 ml
column64: VTS 225 ml)
column65: with normal wall thickness. Severely depressed global systolic function (LVEF 24%). Akinesia and thinning of the septum and anterior face and distal third of all faces. Inferior face akinesia. Late enhancement is observed transmurally affecting the apex and distal third of inferior
column66: lateral
column67: anterior and septum
column68: 75 % subendocardial in mid and distal segment of anterior face and septum
column69: and 50 % in the basal segment of anterior face and septum. 75 % enhancement in lower basal segment. Moderately dilated left atrium (apical plane area 43 cm2). Right atrium slightly dilated (32 cm2). Right ventricle not dilated (VTD 111 ml
column70: VTS 77 ml)
column71: with moderately depressed global systolic function with global hypokinesia. RVEF 31%. Conclusion: dilated cardiomyopathy of ischaemic aetiology with severely depressed global systolic function and late enhancement pattern of ischaemic aetiology with multivessel involvement. Absence of viability in the territory of the anterior descending artery. Moderate right ventricular systolic dysfunction.  EVOLUTION Three months after hospital discharge
column72: the patient has a glycosylated haemoglobin of 7.3%
column73: has lost 3 kg in weight
column74: maintains good blood pressure control with current figures around 120/70 mmHg and has not been admitted again for CHF
column75: remaining in ambulatory functional class II and having allowed a decrease in diuretic treatment to 60 mg of furosemide. He has not been discharged from the ICD either. As this is a young patient at high cardiovascular risk
column76: it was decided to titrate empaglifozin to 25 mg to improve glycaemic control. At the next outpatient review
column77: four months after the previous one
column78: the glycosylated haemoglobin value was 6.8%
column79: the patient had continued to lose weight
column80: with good control of the rest of the CVRF
column81: no hospital admissions
column82: no ICD discharges and in functional class II.  DIAGNOSIS Chronic heart failure with LVEF 24% and RVEF 31% by cardiac magnetic resonance imaging. Chronic ischaemic heart disease with 3-vessel coronary artery disease revascularised by quadruple bypass. Chronic inferior and anterior infarction. Absence of viability in the territory of the anterior descending artery. Carrier of Biotronik single-chamber ICD in primary prevention. Permanent atrial fibrillation anticoagulated with sintrom. Diabetes mellitus in treatment with metformin and empaglifozin. Arterial hypertension. Dyslipidaemia. Exobtachism. column1: We present the case of a 36-year-old male
column2: hypertensive
column3: with abnormally high plasma levels of LDL-cholesterol
column4: triglycerides and glycated haemoglobin
column5: who presents with ischaemic heart disease.  HISTORY
column6: CURRENT DISEASE AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  Personal history Hypertensive for more than 5 years on treatment with enalapril (he had stopped treatment). Ex-smoker. Hypertriglyceridaemia. Undiagnosed type 2 diabetes mellitus. No known previous heart disease or other medical illnesses of interest.  Family history: father with AMI at the age of 50. Young hypertensive mother. Grandmother and maternal aunt with type 2 diabetes mellitus (DM) and hypertension.  Previous treatment: omeprazole 20 mg
column7: 1/day
column8: enalapril 20 mg
column9: 1/day.  Present illness A 36-year-old male patient came to the emergency department for a week with a clinical presentation of central thoracic pain that he described as oppressive
column10: non-radiating and without vegetative cortex
column11: which did not increase with pressure. He reports that it starts in the morning and that after an hour of pain it usually subsides
column12: without palpitations. In the last two days she noticed that the pain appeared with exertion and decreased with rest. She went to her health centre for the same reason
column13: where they observed supraventricular tachycardia and a tendency to hypertension (she has stopped taking the treatment)
column14: which was treated with antihypertensives and benzodiazepines without improvement.  Physical examination Killip class: I no heart failure - Weight 102.0 kg. Height 1.74 m. BMI 33.69. BP 135/95. HR 166 bpm. Ta 37
column15: 7°C. Sat O2 % 97; no tendinous xanthomas or xanthelasmas. Normal ocular examination
column16: no corneal arcus. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic heart sounds without murmurs and without pericardial friction. Pulmonary auscultation: VCM without added pathological sounds. MMII without oedema with symmetrical peripheral pulses.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Emergency ECG (first): sinus tachycardia 146 bpm. Normal PR. Normal electrical axis. Narrow QRS with R wave > S in V2-V3 and ST depression of 1.5 mm from V2-V5 that normalises in subsequent ECGs after controlling HR. Meets Sokolow-Lyon criteria for LVH. Chest X-ray: cardiothoracic index not increased
column17: sinus costo and cardiophrenic sinuses free
column18: without congestive hilarity or vascular redistribution. No parenchymal masses or nodules were observed. Urgent laboratory tests (icteric and lipemic serum): glucose 309 mg/dl; urea 31 mg/dl; creatinine 0.9 mg/dl
column19: sodium 134 mEq/l; K+ 4.5 mEq/l; haemoglobin 16.4 g/dl; haematocrit 45.7%; MCV 80.7 fl; platelets 308.0 10e3/ul; leukocytes 14.81 10 e3/uL; CrCl (Cockcroft-Gault) 163.7 ml/min; TUS 420-440-610 ng/l. D-dimer 354. Laboratory tests: glucose 213 mg/dl; urea 48 mg/dl; creatinine 0.85 mg/dl; total cholesterol 274 mg/dl; triglycerides 893 mg/dl; HDL cholesterol 34 mg/dl
column20: with non-HDL 210; sodium 140 mEq/l; potassium 4.1 mEq/l; haemoglobin 16.0 g/dl; haematocrit 47.7 %; MCV 85.5 fl; platelets 274.0 10e3/ul; leukocytes 9.08 10e3/ul; HbA1c 10.6 %; CRP 8.6 mg/dl; T4L 1.08 ng/dl; TSH 0.76 IUI/ml; CrCl (Cockcroft-Gault) 173.33 units ml/min. Echocardiography: non-dilated left ventricle
column21: normal thickness. Hypokinesia (no thinned wall) of basal-medial segments of lateral and posterior face
column22: with normocontractility of the remaining segments and slightly depressed residual LVEF (biplane EF 44 %). Slight left atrial dilatation
column23: normal sized RA. Tricommissural aortic valve
column24: normal. Mitral
column25: tricuspid and pulmonary valves of normal morphology and mobility. Right ventricle not dilated
column26: of normal thickness
column27: without alterations of regional contractility and with preserved global systolic function. No significant pericardial effusion. Inferior vena cava and suprahepatic vein not dilated
column28: with adequate inspiratory collapse
column29: which excludes the presence of significant systemic venous hypertension. Doppler findings: mitral Doppler compatible with impaired left ventricular relaxation. Absence of tricuspid insufficiency allowing quantification of pulmonary artery systolic pressure. Conclusions: Alterations of segmental contractility in Cx territory. Residual LVEF 44%. Coronary angiography: left common trunk without lesions. Anterior descending artery with some irregularities along its course and moderate lesion in the proximal third of the 1st diagonal of good development. Circumflex occluded in the proximal third
column30: visible from heterocoronary circulation; obtuse system of good calibre. Right coronary artery with irregularities along its entire length
column31: moderate plaque in the middle third and severe focal lesion on the posterolateral side
column32: this being an artery of good calibre. Intervention: the occlusion was successfully passed with microcatheter support and the artery was opened with balloon crescents. A long lesion is observed from the distal third to the proximal third
column33: which is covered with two overlapping drug-eluting stents. They are post-dilated for correct apposition with a good final result and without complications.  EVOLUTION The patient evolves favourably without recurrences of chest pain or clinical signs of heart failure or significant arrhythmic events. During his admission
column34: he was assessed by endocrinology
column35: who started hypoglycaemic drugs with metformin and empagliflozin with good tolerance. On discharge
column36: it was decided to refer the patient to the cardiac rehabilitation programme at our hospital and to closely monitor him in the cardiology consultations to control cardiovascular risk factors
column37: advise on lifestyle changes and achieve therapeutic compliance.  DIAGNOSIS Acute non-ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) Killip I. Proximal circumflex occlusion
column38: treated by PTCA and coated stent implantation. Severe focal lesion in posterolateral right coronary artery and moderate lesion in 1st diagonal untreated. Basal and medial posterior and lateral hypokinesia with mild systolic dysfunction (LVEF 44%). Recently diagnosed type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypercholesterolemia under study. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION 56-year-old male
column3: with no known drug allergies
column4: with a history of arterial hypertension being treated with two drugs and dyslipidaemia; with no personal or family history of heart disease
column5: heart failure or sudden death. Three days ago she reported an episode of oppressive chest pain radiating to the jaw
column6: left upper limb and back
column7: after intense exertion (carrying a weight)
column8: of several hours' duration
column9: accompanied by vegetatism. She did not consult for this episode. On the day she sought medical attention
column10: she presented a new episode of chest pain similar to the previous one
column11: while making intense effort
column12: and so she called the Emergency Medical Service. On initial assessment: BP 123/99 mmHg
column13: HR 105 bpm and SatO2 100% with nasal goggles at 2 L/min. Initial physical examination revealed a pansystolic murmur in the mesocardium. An electrocardiogram was performed with pain
column14: showing sinus rhythm
column15: AV block Mobitz I. Narrow QRS. Pathological Q waves in inferior face and inferior ST elevation with DIII>DII maximum of 4 mm in DII and specular decrease in DI and aVL of up to 5 mm. ST elevation V3-V6 with negative anterior T waves. The AMI code was activated and the patient was transferred to our centre. Acetylsalicylic acid 250 mg
column16: clopidogrel 600 mg
column17: enoxaparin 30 mg and fentanyl 50 mcg were administered. During the transfer
column18: hypotension with BP 73/42 mmHg. He was transferred to the haemodynamics ward for urgent coronary angiography. During the procedure
column19: dobutamine and noradrenaline were started
column20: requiring dose increases up to 20 mcg/kg/min and 20 ml/h respectively. Coronary angiography revealed 3-vessel coronary artery disease: Two severe lesions (90 %) in tandem in the anterior descending (AD) at the level of the middle third (pre- and post-exit of the second diagonal) with involvement of the ostial-proximal segment of the second diagonal (80 %); first marginal occlusion at the middle level (100 %) with no distal bed visualisation and proximal occlusion of the right coronary artery (RCA) (100 %). PCI was performed to the proximal-medial DC with implantation of a 3 x 36 mm non-drug-eluting stent at 20 atm
column21: with good results. Urgent transthoracic cardiac ultrasound was performed during the procedure
column22: which showed an anfractuous ventricular septal defect (VSD) located in the basal septum
column23: about 30 mm in diameter
column24: with a hypocontractile RV; therefore
column25: intra-aortic balloon counterpulsation (IABP) was implanted. After the procedure
column26: he was admitted to the Coronary Unit for stabilisation. The case was discussed with the Coronary Unit of our reference centre and he was transferred for surgery. Physical examination: conscious and oriented in all three spheres. Signs of poor distal perfusion. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic heart tones
column27: pansystolic murmur in mesocardium III/VI not radiated. Jugular ingurgitation +++. Respiratory auscultation: physiological vesicular murmur without added pathological sounds. No declining oedema.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG: RS
column28: BAV Mobitz I
column29: narrow QRS
column30: inferior Q waves and inferior ST elevation with III > II of maximum 4 mm in III and specular decrease in I and aVL of up to 5 mm; also ST elevation in V3-V6 with negative anterior T wave. CBC: glucose 290 mg/dl
column31: urea 65 mg/dl
column32: creatinine 2.05 mg/dl
column33: CK 1199 U/L
column34: troponin I 37.73 ng/ml
column35: sodium 136 mmol/l
column36: potassium 4.62 mmol/l. Leukocytes 13430
column37: haemoglobin 14.2 g/dl
column38: haematocrit 41.5%
column39: platelets 95
column40: 000. Emergent coronary angiography: right dominant coronary arteries: significant stenosis. Truncus description: good calibre
column41: no significant lesions. Description of the anterior descending artery: vessel of good calibre and extension. Two severe tandem lesions at the level of the middle third (pre- and post-exit of the second diagonal) with involvement of the ostial-proximal segment of the second diagonal. Rest of the vessel with non-significant diffuse irregularities. Good distal bed
column42: TIMI 3 flow. Circumflex description: occluded at the level of the first middle marginal with no distal bed visible. Intermediate branch developed
column43: no lesions. Right coronary description: occluded proximally. Procedure: cannulation of the DC ostium with AR2 catheter
column44: passing a guide wire distally from the posterior descending artery. Thrombus extract is passed
column45: which is productive and TIMI 2 flow appears
column46: and a 3 x 36 mm non-drug-eluting stent is implanted at 20 atm
column47: with good results. Conclusions: right dominance. Three-vessel disease. PCI to proximal-medial DC. Wide VSD Transthoracic cardiac ultrasound: ventricular septal defect with an anfractuous course located in the basal septum
column48: about 30 mm in diameter
column49: RV hypocontractile. Transthoracic cardiac echocardiography prior to hospital discharge: non-hypertrophic left ventricle
column50: slightly dilated
column51: with severely depressed systolic function (EF 27%) due to extensive septal and inferoposterior akinesia
column52: patch at the level of the interventricular septum
column53: with no flow between the two ventricles; mild aortic insufficiency and moderate-severe functional mitral insufficiency. Right ventricle slightly dilated. Depressed right ventricular dynamics (TAPSE 11). Mild tricuspid insufficiency that allows estimating normal PAPs.  EVOLUTION On arrival at the reference centre
column54: in a situation of cardiogenic shock refractory to pharmacological treatment and IABP due to large post-infarction VSD; urgent transthoracic cardiac ultrasound was performed which showed a globally normal contractile left ventricle
column55: midbasal inferoposterior akinesia
column56: dilated right ventricle
column57: slightly hypocontractile; and a wide ventricular septal defect of up to 4 cm in anteroposterior diameter and 3 cm in apicobasal diameter. An ECMO (extracorporeal membrane oxygenation) peripheral venous-arterial system was implanted as a bridge to corrective surgery for VSD. Subsequently
column58: there was a tendency towards stability
column59: allowing a progressive decrease in vasoactive amine support with adequate ECMO functioning. On the fourth day of admission
column60: VSD closure of the basal and middle posterior septum was performed with a bovine pericardial patch and bypass of the internal mammary artery to the anterior descending artery. Echocardiogram was performed after surgery
column61: decreasing support with ECMO
column62: in which stable left ventricular function
column63: hyperdynamic segments with preserved mobility. Non-dilated right ventricle
column64: with severe dysfunction. Eccentric tricuspid insufficiency directed to the low interatrial septum. No ventricular septal defect. It was decided to continue ECMO support and treatment was associated with levosimendan. The patient continued to evolve well
column65: decreasing ECMO litres and tolerating IABP 1:4. In view of the favourable evolution
column66: it was decided to withdraw ECMO with 1:1 IABP support and dobutamine at 8 mcg/kg/min. Subsequent good evolution
column67: allowing withdrawal of IABC and inotropes
column68: and introduction of oral treatment with beta-blockers
column69: ACE inhibitors and aldosterone receptor antagonists. Complications during admission included: paroxysmal atrial fibrillation
column70: prolonged respiratory weaning
column71: requiring percutaneous tracheostomy for prolonged orotracheal intubation; due to respiratory failure secondary to alveolar haemorrhage and acute respiratory distress syndrome; nosocomial pneumonia in the right lower lobe (Enterobacter cloacae and Citrobacter koseri) and urinary tract infection by multidrug-resistant Serratia marcescens. The patient progressed favourably
column72: tolerating neurohormonal treatment
column73: with negative water balance and low-dose diuretics. A control ultrasound was performed prior to hospital discharge

Mild-moderate pericardial effusion with a maximum thickness of 1.2 cm in the lateral aspect of the LV. Paratracheal mediastinal adenopathies (2 cm short axis)
column135: in right hilum (2.2 and 1.8 cm) compatible with sarcoidosis. Middle sternotomy wires.  EVOLUTION The transthoracic echocardiogram showed a slightly dilated and hypertrophic LV with preserved systolic function and the existence of a trivalve aortic valve with severe insufficiency at the expense of the right coronary leaflet that appears to present a flail. On the other hand
column136: given the findings of the examination
column138: which ruled out an infectious origin. Laboratory data showed hypercalcaemia and elevated ACE (angiotensin-converting enzyme) levels as the most relevant findings and
column139: together with the chest X-ray showing a prominence of both pulmonary hilums compatible with lymphadenopathy
column140: a diagnosis of sarcoidosis with parotid and cardiac involvement was established. Chest CT showed multiple mediastinal
column142: as well as a predominant interstitial pattern in the vertex and bases. To confirm the diagnosis
column143: it was decided to perform a parotid FNA and finally fibrobronchoscopy with biopsy of one of the lymph nodes with the presence of non-caseating granulomas
column144: confirming the diagnosis of sarcoidosis. The patient underwent aortic valve replacement. The valve was described as a very thin
column146: with no aortic annulus in that area
column147: with prolapse of the left leaflet and retraction of the non-coronary leaflet
column148: for which reason it was decided to implant a mechanical prosthesis. The surgical specimen was sent for anatomopathological examination
column149: which confirmed the existence of non-caseating granulomas compatible with sarcoidosis. Two months after surgery
column150: cardiac MRI showed a slightly dilated and hypertrophic LV with pathological Gadolinium uptake in the subepicardial region
column152: compatible with cardiac involvement in the context of systemic sarcoidosis. At present
column153: the patient is asymptomatic from the cardiovascular point of view with functional grade I/IV in outpatient follow-up by internal medicine and cardiology and with treatment with corticoids without having presented new episodes of decompensation since hospital discharge.  DIAGNOSIS Systemic sarcoidosis with cardiac involvement. Severe aortic insufficiency due to sarcoid valve involvement. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION 53-year-old male admitted to the Cardiac Intensive Care Unit (CICU) after recovering from cardiorespiratory arrest in the street.  Personal history Arterial hypertension under treatment with enalapril 20 mg. Type 2 diabetes mellitus being treated with metformin. Hyperuricaemia with several episodes of gouty arthritis. On treatment with allopurinol.  Present illness Witnesses report that
column3: while working (cook) and without reporting any previous symptoms
column4: he fainted with loss of consciousness. After the initial approach by the witnesses
column5: 112 was contacted
column6: the absence of breathing or signs of life was detected and basic cardiopulmonary resuscitation manoeuvres were started. After 7 minutes
column7: following the arrival of Basic Life Support (112)
column8: a defibrillable rhythm is detected by AED. Up to 4 shocks with the corresponding 30:2 cycles were applied together with 2 boluses of adrenaline and 300 mg of amiodarone. After the fourth shock
column9: the patient recovered sinus rhythm at 92 bpm and was transferred to the CICU sedated
column10: intubated and connected to mechanical ventilation.  Physical examination Sedoanalgesia. RASS -4. Pupils isochoric
column11: miotic and reactive. BP 95/45; HR 125 bpm; peripheral O2 saturation 100% with FiO2 of 100%. Rhythmic
column12: tachycardic heart sounds without murmurs. Bladder murmur preserved bilaterally. Abdomen slightly distended and tympanic. Bowel sounds present. Lower limbs without oedema and bilateral pulses present and symmetrical.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS CBC: haemoglobin 14.5 g/dl; leucocytes 12
column13: 900 (36 % N); platelets 191.000; prothrombin activity 100 %; creatinine 1.2 mg/dl; GFR (MDRD-4) 67 ml/min; glucose 293 mg/dl; BUN 17 U/L; sodium 142 mee/l; potassium 3.9 meq/l; GOT 197 U/l; GPT 159 U/L; troponin I 0.045 ng/ml; NT-proBNP 636 pg/ml; CRP < 5 mg/l. Peak troponin I: 3 ng/ml. Urine toxicity: cocaine
column14: amphetamines
column15: cannabis negative. Chest X-ray: slight increase in cardiothoracic index. No evidence of infiltrates. Endotracheal tube is centred and normally positioned. A-B balance on arrival: pH 7.34; pO2 427; pCO2 48; HCO3 25.9; lactic 7.6 mmol/l. Transthoracic echocardiography: slightly hypertrophic left ventricle with segmental alterations of contractility. Moderately reduced left ventricular systolic function. Prolonged left ventricular relaxation (E/é 9). Absence of valvular heart disease. Right ventricle of normal size with normal systolic function. Cranial CT: no significant alterations in the density of the brain parenchyma. Ventricular system of normal size and morphology
column16: without displacements with respect to the midline. No signs of intracranial bleeding were observed. Cardiac magnetic resonance: non-dilated left ventricle with moderate left ventricular dysfunction. Intramyocardial patchy intramyocardial enhancement in anterior and posterior mid-apical face. Findings compatible with acute myocarditis.  EVOLUTION The patient was admitted to the CICU and femoral venous access was channelled for induced hypothermia for the first 24 hours at 33°C. He was kept sedated and anaesthetised. He remained sedated and relaxed
column17: with a tendency to bradycardia and arterial hypotension. The internal environment was corrected and lactacidemia and pH were normalised. After 24 hours of hypothermia
column18: progressive rewarming began
column19: relaxation was withdrawn and sedation was gradually discontinued. Seventy-two hours after admission
column20: the patient presented with abnormal movements
column21: such as shivering
column22: coinciding with an increase in temperature (38°C)
column23: for which reason an EEG was requested
column24: which ruled out the presence of status convulsus. Antibiotic therapy was intensified (ceftriaxone + clindamycin) after finding a right basal infiltrate on X-ray
column25: probably related to aspiration during intubation. Weaning progressed to extubation on the 5th day. The cranial CT scan after extubation showed no alterations of interest. Monitoring in the CICU detected the presence of ventricular extrasystoles without sustained arrhythmias. Coronary angiography showed coronary arteries free of significant obstructive lesions. Once on the hospital ward
column26: he remained in asymptomatic rehabilitation. Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging showed patchy intramyocardial uptake compatible with myocarditis and left ventricular function was moderately depressed (38%). Two weeks after admission
column27: a single-chamber ICD was implanted
column28: without incident
column29: for secondary prevention of sudden death secondary to cardiomyopathy due to myocarditis.  DIAGNOSIS Cardiorespiratory arrest recovered. Aspirative pneumonia. Cardiomyopathy secondary to myocarditis. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: We present the case of a 33-year-old man who presented with ventricular fibrillation and cardiorespiratory arrest after taking ibuprofen.  HISTORY
column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  Personal history No known hypertension
column3: diabetes mellitus or dyslipidaemia. Mental and behavioural disorder due to alcohol consumption
column4: in remission. Mixed adaptive distress. Intrinsic rhinitis and bronchial asthma and history of atopy since childhood. Very doubtful drug allergy years ago
column5: she does not remember to which drug
column6: which has not been studied. No previous cardiological history. No chronic treatment.  Current illness She came to the emergency department with an incised-contuse wound on the right forearm following an accident at work with an iron. The wound was treated locally
column7: requiring suturing and bandaging. Gamma globulin and a first dose of tetanus vaccine were administered. On discharge a series of recommendations were given: treatment with ibuprofen 600 mg every 8 hours for 5-7 days in the presence of pain and amoxicillin-clavulanic acid 500-125 mg every 8 hours for 8 days. In the evening
column8: the patient
column9: because of severe pain in the forearm
column10: decided to take 1 tablet of ibuprofen. Thirty minutes after taking it
column11: he began to feel nausea
column12: vomiting
column13: sweating and sudden dyspnoea
column14: so his wife called 061. On arrival of the ambulance
column15: the patient was pale and sweaty
column16: suffering cardiorespiratory arrest in their presence
column17: so they started CPR manoeuvres and performed an ECG which showed ventricular fibrillation. The patient was resuscitated for 75 minutes and required 5 defibrillations at 200 J
column18: 450 mg intravenous amiodarone
column19: 12 mg adrenaline
column20: 1 M intravenous bicabonate and orotracheal intubation for mechanical ventilation. Referred to ICU for further care after recovery of pulse.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS 061 electrocardiogram: ventricular fibrillation. ICU blood tests: troponin T 21 ng/ml (normal up to 0.05 ng/ml)
column21: creatinine 1.47mg/dl
column22: urea 42 mg/dl
column23: sodium 140 mEq/l
column24: potassium 4.1 mEq/l
column25: glycaemia 159 mg/dl. Haemoglobin 17 g/dl
column26: haematocrit 51%
column27: leucocytes 16
column29: platelets 359
column31: aPTT ratio 2 (0.8-1.3). Arterial blood gases (FiO2: 50 %): pH 7.30
column32: PCO2 41
column34: bicarbonate 19
column35: lactate 4.2. Electrocardiogram on admission to ICU: sinus rhythm at 78 bpm
column36: PR < 200 ms
column37: electrical axis deviated to the right. Wide QRS with image of complete right bundle branch block with secondary repolarisation alterations. Chest X-ray in AP: cardiothoracic index not assessable. Free costophrenic and cardiophrenic sinuses. Right hilar slightly congestive. No parenchymal nodules or masses or pleural pathology. Simple skull CT scan: findings compatible with significant diffuse cerebral oedema. Echocardiogram: LV neither dilated nor hypertrophic
column38: severe systolic dysfunction
column39: global hypokinesia (probably secondary to stunning) and akinesia in the LAD territory. Normal valves. No tricuspid insufficiency or indirect data of pulmonary hypertension. Normal atria. Normal RV. Severe systolic dysfunction of probable ischaemic origin in the LAD territory and stunning component. Cardiac catheterisation: epicardial arteries without angiographically visible lesions.  EVOLUTION On arrival at the ICU the patient was intubated
column40: comatose with 3 points on the Glasgow scale. Pupils are mydriatic
column41: reactive and symmetrical. The patient remains under hypothermia protocol at 34°C under sedation and connected to invasive mechanical ventilation. Anticoagulated at that time with enoxaparin and double anti-aggregation with ASA and clopidogrel in the presence of clinical suspicion of AMI. The electrocardiogram showed the patient in sinus rhythm with a right bundle branch block which was not known to be present previously. An urgent CT scan of the brain showed significant cerebral oedema and an echocardiogram showed severe systolic dysfunction
column42: alterations in contractility in the LAD territory and a stunning component. Given the results of the echocardiogram
column43: cardiac catheterisation was performed
column44: showing epicardial coronary arteries without lesions
column45: and intensive care continued in the ICU. The patient died two days later. Given the relationship with the intake of NSAIDs and the symptoms suggesting a high probability of anaphylactic shock
column46: the patient was finally classified as probable Kounis syndrome with a fatal outcome.  DIAGNOSIS Out-of-hospital cardiorespiratory arrest in ventricular fibrillation
column47: resuscitated. Related to taking ibuprofen in a patient with a previous history of drug allergy and bronchial asthma. Severe LV systolic dysfunction with segmental alteration in the LAD territory. Coronary arteries without angiographic lesions. Presumptive diagnosis of Kounis syndrome type I. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: A 44-year-old man was referred to the emergency department after attending a private clinic for his annual company medical check-up
column2: because an alteration was detected in the ECG reported as "arrhythmic conduction of the P waves
column3: with suspected atrioventricular block of 2nd degree".  HISTORY
column4: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  Personal and family history No known cardiovascular risk factors. Never smoked
column5: occasionally drinks some wine or beer with meals. He is a recreational sportsman: he cycles to work and goes on longer outings at weekends
column6: also goes hiking and occasionally plays football or paddle tennis. No known heart disease or other medical or surgical history of interest. Mother with non-ischemic dilated cardiomyopathy
column7: currently with moderate systolic dysfunction
column8: pacemaker wearer since the age of 55 and with radiofrequency ablation of sustained monomorphic ventricular tachycardia (SMVT) at the age of 61.  Present illness The patient went to a private clinic for an annual company check-up and the ECG showed what was described as "arrhythmic conduction of the P waves
column9: suspected 2nd degree AVB" and he was referred to his health centre. His family doctor performed a new ECG and referred him to the emergency department. The patient denies any related symptoms (no dizziness
column10: no asthenia
column11: no syncope). He does not understand why he is here.  Physical examination BP 119/73 mmHg. HR 57 bpm. Ta 36°C. Good general condition. Arrhythmic cardiac auscultation by extratonos
column12: without murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation with preservation of vesicular murmur. Abdomen and extremities normal
column13: without oedema and with normal pulses.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG: sinus rhythm at 90 bpm with complete atrioventricular block and escape rhythm at 45-50 bpm. EV monomorphic
column14: with BCRDHH morphology and inferior axis (isolated
column15: with some duplet). CBC: glucose 89 mg/dl
column16: urea 34 mg/dl
column17: creatinine 0.87 mg/dl

column19: triglycerides 88 mg/dl
column20: HDL cholesterol 32 mg/dl

column24: troponin I 0.044 (normal

column28: haematocrit 43.9%
column29: MCV 83.9 fl
column32: leucocytes 7
column33: 520. Echocardiogram: LV slightly dilated (LVEDD 59 mm
column34: LVEDV 183 cc) with normal wall thickness. Mild LA dilatation. Marked asynchrony of contraction at the level of the interventricular septum
column35: with mild global hypokinesia and LVEF by volumetry of 43% (mild systolic dysfunction). Trivalve aortic valve
column36: normal. Mitral
column37: tricuspid and pulmonary valves of normal morphology and mobility. Mitral filling pattern with E>>A wave with no data suggesting increased LV filling pressures. Right ventricle not dilated
column38: of normal thickness
column39: without alterations of regional contractility and with preserved global systolic function. Mild TR with PSAP estimated at 26 mmHg. Inferior vena cava and suprahepatic veins were not dilated
column40: with adequate inspiratory collapse
column41: which excludes the presence of significant systemic venous hypertension. Cardio MRI: LV of normal thickness
column42: slightly dilated (248 mL TVD; 115 mL/m2 of CS) with slightly reduced ejection fraction (EF 48%)
column43: normal segmental contractility. RV of normal global and segmental dimensions and contractility. Linear mesocardial enhancement is identified in the basal septum
column44: with extension to the mid-segment. Conclusions: mild LV dilatation and systolic dysfunction
column45: with basal mesoseptal linear fibrosis extending to the mid-segment (His bundle area). Chest X-ray (post-implantation): normal cardiothoracic index
column46: no images of pneumothorax or other complications. Atrial and ventricular electrode well positioned and generator at left subclavicular level. Exercise echocardiogram: 9.30 min of Bruce protocol exercise. The test is stopped due to fatigue at 93% of maximum theoretical heart rate. Basically and up to minute 7
column47: sinus rhythm conducted by ventricular stimulation by the pacemaker; in minute 7 there is alternation of pacemaker rhythm with own rhythm and ventricular extrasystoles
column48: causing a marked irregularity in the heart rate; from 130 bpm it remains in own rhythm with subsequent reappearance of the pacemaker rhythm in the immediate post-exercise. Normal tension response. Contractility slightly depressed at baseline with global hypokinesia and estimated LVEF of 40-45%
column49: with improvement of around 10 points with exercise. The test was clinically and echocardiographically negative for ischaemia
column50: with a pattern of improvement in contractility with exercise (contractile reserve) suggesting cardiomyopathy. ECG not assessable due to baseline pacemaker rhythm.  EVOLUTION Although the patient was completely asymptomatic and the block was detected by chance
column51: it was decided to admit him to hospital with continuous ECG monitoring
column52: and he remained in complete AVB at all times
column53: although with adequate escape rhythm and totally asymptomatic. It was decided to implant a definitive bicameral pacemaker
column54: with prior cardiac MRI. Twenty-four hours after the procedure
column55: once complications related to the procedure had been ruled out
column56: the patient was discharged from hospital. If familial dilated cardiomyopathy associated with atrioventricular conduction disorders is suspected
column57: the patient is referred to the Family Cardiopathies Unit (UCF) of reference for genetic study. Likewise
column58: a schedule of visits is programmed for review of the device and follow-up in Cardiology consultations. At subsequent check-ups
column59: the patient reported feeling well. Following pacemaker implantation
column60: he has moderated his sporting activities considerably
column61: following medical recommendations. A stress echocardiogram was performed with the results described
column62: so moderate physical exercise was not contraindicated. In the periodic reviews of the device
column63: several episodes of NSVT were detected (about 10 in a year
column64: of short duration). We insisted on the family history and the patient commented that his maternal grandmother
column65: who died suddenly at the age of 69
column66: had been considered for a pacemaker implant during her lifetime
column67: which was never carried out. She has 3 brothers
column68: one of whom (a 47-year-old male) has just been diagnosed with a 2nd degree atrioventricular block (he lives in another Community; during follow-up
column69: a permanent pacemaker was implanted). She has two other sisters and two children aged 12 and 8
column70: with no evidence of heart disease after screening of family members. Finally
column71: more than a year after the pacemaker implantation
column72: the results of the genetic analysis were received
column73: in which 34 genes involved in conduction system diseases were evaluated
column74: reporting that the patient is a heterozygous carrier of the Glu444* truncation
column75: considered to be pathogenic or associated with disease. A defibrillator implantation is proposed
column76: which the patient accepts.  DIAGNOSIS Asymptomatic complete atrioventricular block. Carrier of a definitive bicameral pacemaker. Familial dilated cardiomyopathy with associated AV conduction disorder due to laminopathy A/C. Mild LV systolic dysfunction (LVEF 45-50%). Repeat NSVT
column77: asymptomatic (detected by pacemaker). Defibrillator implantation in primary prevention. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column1: A 57-year-old woman presented with dyspnoea and fever
column2: diagnosed with infective endocarditis on native valve due to Lactobacillus rhamnosus (a rare bacterium
column3: widely used as a probiotic).  HISTORY
column4: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  Personal history No known drug allergies. Toxic habits: smoker of 1 pack/day. Intervened for pneumothorax more than 15 years ago. Admitted 11 days earlier to the Respiratory Department with the diagnosis of probable moderate COPD and respiratory infection treated with levofloxacin for 7 days with good evolution. Blood cultures during this admission
column5: positive for Lactobacillus rhamnosus
column6: interpreted by the laboratory as possible contamination. Current treatment: citalopram 20 mg
column7: inhaled glycopyrronium and paracetamol. Baseline functional status: higher functions preserved
column8: works as a shop assistant in a clothing shop. Lives with her husband and children.  Present illness Progressive dyspnoea of 3 days evolution. Today dyspnoea at rest. 4 days ago
column9: fever peak of up to 37.8°C and pain in right hip which subsided on its own
column10: for which she did not consult.  Physical examination BP 110/62
column11: HR 115 bpm
column13: O2 Sat (Ventimask 40 %) 95 %. Tachypnoea of 18 rpm. On inspection
column14: the patient was normal colour
column15: with good hydration of skin and mucous membranes. On cardiac auscultation
column16: the heart is rhythmic
column17: with systolic murmur mitral focus. Pulmonary auscultation shows crackles in the middle and lower fields and scattered wheezing. The abdomen is soft and depressible
column18: painless on palpation with sounds present. The lower extremities are free of oedema and the paedial pulses are present and symmetrical.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG: sinus tachycardia at 115 bpm. Chest X-ray: cardiac silhouette at the upper limit of normality. Laboratory tests: PO2 80 mmHg; PCO2 34 mmHg; pH 7.49; HCO3 25.9 mmol/l; lactate 10 mg/dl. Glucose 112 mg/dl; creatinine 0.63 mg/dl; GPT 15 U/l; Na 137 mmol/l; K 3.99 mmol/l; CK 16 U/l; LDH 194 U/l; CRP 11.29 mg/dl; PCT 0.18 ng/ml. Hb 10.3 g/dl; platelets 207
column19: 000/μL; leukocytes 9
column20: 200/μL (N 78.5 %). IP 100 %; INR 1. Transthoracic and transesophageal echocardiogram: the left ventricle is not dilated or hypertrophic
column21: with good global systolic function and hyperdynamic. The mitral valve shows several images
column22: the largest measuring 19 x 6 mm
column23: compatible with endocardial vegetations. The posterior leaflet shows a large perforation leading to massive regurgitation. The aortic valve shows an image in the LVOT dependent on the non-coronary leaflet (13 x 6 mm)
column24: which appears perforated and there is a significant coaptation defect leading to severe regurgitation in relation to the involvement of the right coronary artery. The right ventricle is not dilated
column25: with good systolic function. No pericardial effusion was observed Coronary angiography: coronary network without lesions.  EVOLUTION In view of the findings described above
column26: the patient was admitted to the Coronary Unit
column27: where the TEE was performed. Treatment was started with intravenous ampicillin and gentamicin. Given that she was admitted with heart failure
column28: she underwent double valve replacement within 24 hours
column29: aortic (Carbomedics Top Hat no. 21) and mitral (Bicarbon Fitline no. 27). The cardiac surgery was uneventful
column30: with an ischaemia time of 102 min and CPB time of 123 min. The surgeon described the following intraoperative findings: warts on the posterior leaflet of the mitral valve
column31: warts on the non-coronary leaflet of the aortic valve with the rings of both valves well preserved. The specimen was sent to anatomical pathology and microbiology for culture
column32: subsequently confirming infection by Lactobacillus rhamnosus. He arrived at the Coronary Unit
column33: from the operating theatre
column34: haemodynamically unstable with noradrenaline at 0.2 μg/kg/min
column35: in sinus tachycardia 135 bpm with BP 80/50 mmHg. Echocardioscopy (V-Scan) was performed
column36: showing severe biventricular dysfunction (estimated LVEF 10%)
column37: without pericardial effusion. The findings were confirmed
column38: as well as the normofunction of both prostheses by TEE. Therefore
column39: intensive serum therapy was started and noradrenaline (up to 2 μg/kg/min)
column40: dopamine (up to 20 μg/kg/min) and adrenaline (up to 0.4 μg/kg/min) were progressively administered in increasing doses. With this
column41: we achieved a MAP 65-70 mmHg
column42: CVP 18 mmHg
column43: HR 110 bpm
column44: CO 3.2 L/min and IC 2.3 L/min/m2. However
column45: he persisted with oliguria and increasing lividity in the atria and lower extremities in an ascending manner. Intra-aortic balloon counterpulsation implantation was chosen. Despite counterpulsation (1:1) and the "stability" of haemodynamic parameters
column46: the data of cardiogenic shock with peripheral hypoperfusion were increasing (lactate 10 --> 145 mg/dl; creatinine 0.63 --> 2.19 mg/dl; GPT 15 --> 3
column47: 068 U/l). Therefore
column48: veno-arterial ECMO implantation with peripheral access is indicated
column49: guided by TEE
column50: which is carried out successfully. Subsequently
column51: the patient evolved favourably
column52: with a progressive decrease in the analytical parameters of peripheral hypoperfusion
column53: and the doses of inovasoactive drugs were gradually reduced. Finally
column54: after 14 days
column55: IABP was withdrawn and 24 hours later
column56: ECMO was withdrawn
column57: with good haemodynamic tolerance. After 30 days in the Intensive Care Unit
column58: she was discharged to the hospital ward.  DIAGNOSIS Infective endocarditis on native mitral and aortic valves due to Lactobacillus rhamnosus
column59: complicated by heart failure. Mitral and aortic valve replacement surgery. Cardiogenic shock after cardiac surgery requiring assistance with intra-aortic balloon counterpulsation and ECMO
column60: with good evolution. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column1: We present the case of an 81-year-old man with no known previous heart disease who was admitted to our department for dyspnoea and oedema in the lower limbs.  HISTORY
column2: CURRENT DISEASE AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  Personal history HYPERTENSION. Dyslipidaemia. Diabetes Mellitus type II. Morbid obesity. COPD. SAHS in treatment with CPAP. Benign prostatic hyperplasia. Episode of deep vein thrombosis in the right lower extremity. Usual treatment: torsemide 10 mg (1-0-0)
column3: valsartan/hydrochlorothiazide 160/12.5 mg (1-0-0)
column4: simvastatin 10 mg (0-0-1)
column5: metformin 850 mg (0-1-0)
column6: doxium 500 mg (1-0-1).  Present illness The patient was admitted from the Emergency Department with slowly progressive dyspnoea for approximately two months
column7: until minimal effort
column8: together with oliguria and oedema in the lower extremities. A week ago he presented a catarrhal condition consisting of nasal congestion
column9: cough and whitish expectoration
column10: for which reason he attended his health centre
column11: increasing diuretic treatment and starting empirical antibiotic treatment with amoxicillin-clavulanic acid 875/125 mg for a week. With little improvement of the symptoms after 5 days of treatment
column12: she went to the emergency department.  Physical examination BP 160/80 mmHg
column13: HR 71 bpm
column14: SatO2 92 % on room air
column15: Ta 36.7°C. Conscious and oriented in time and place. Obese. Well hydrated
column16: good peripheral perfusion. Slight tachypnoea at rest
column17: no signs of work of breathing. Jugular venous pressure not measurable. AC: muffled cardiac tones with no clear murmurs. PA: crackles in both bases. Abdomen globular
column18: depressible
column19: without pain on palpation. Extremities with oedema with fovea up to the root of the thighs
column20: signs of chronic venous insufficiency.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG: atypical atrial flutter with controlled ventricular response at 75 bpm. HRBBB with secondary repolarisation alterations. Laboratory tests on admission: glucose 92 mg/dl
column21: urea 60 mg/dl
column22: creatinine 1.6 mg/dl
column23: albumin 3.76 g/dl
column24: liver function normal
column25: sodium 145 mmol/l
column26: potassium 3.81 mmol/l
column27: CRP 0.6 mg/ml
column28: haemoglobin 12.9 g/dl
column29: leucocytes 5
column31: platelets 128
column32: 000 10^3/μl. Chest X-ray: no cardiomegaly. Bilateral pleural effusion. Transthoracic echocardiogram: non-dilated LV
column33: hypertrophic
column34: with good global and segmental systolic function. Mitral valve with slight ring calcification and mild-moderate regurgitation. Aortic root not dilated. Thickened aortic valve
column35: with an image of intermediate echogenicity
column36: without being able to rule out endocardial involvement
column37: with maximum and mean gradient of 50 and 26 mmHg respectively. Moderate-severe AoI. TEE is recommended for better assessment of these findings. Moderately dilated LA. Right chambers not dilated
column38: RV with good function. Mild tricuspid regurgitation with Vd-Ad gradient of 34 mmHg. Estimated PsAP of 40 mmHg. No pericardial effusion. Transesophageal echocardiogram: thickened aortic valve with points of calcification
column39: with severe regurgitation (IV/IV) with an image compatible with perforation at the level of the non-coronary leaflet. Small mobile image in the LVOT
column40: somewhat hyperechogenic
column41: measuring 0.7 x 0.3 cm
column42: dependent on the leaflet. Mitral valve with mild-moderate regurgitation without pathological images.  EVOLUTION During his stay on the hospital ward
column43: intravenous depletive treatment was started with slowly progressive improvement of the congestive signs. After a first episode of heart failure
column44: a transthoracic echocardiogram was performed followed by a transesophageal echocardiogram with the findings described
column45: compatible with endocarditis. The Infectious Diseases Department was contacted for an interdisciplinary assessment of the condition. Despite the atypical nature of the symptoms
column46: panbacterial PCR was requested
column47: as well as blood and urine cultures
column48: empirical treatment was adjusted for possible endocarditis (ampicillin + cloxacillin + gentamicin) adjusted to renal function and a new transesophageal echocardiogram was scheduled for follow-up
column49: in which no significant differences were observed with respect to the previous study. During the following days
column50: the cultures collected (blood and urine cultures) were negative and
column51: despite increased intravenous diuretic treatment
column52: the patient recorded a significant weight gain and worsening of oedema in the lower limbs with the appearance of phlyctenas
column53: so given the unfavourable evolution of the condition
column54: the case was discussed with Cardiac Surgery
column55: who decided to perform aortic valve replacement with a biological prosthesis
column56: maintaining antibiotic treatment while awaiting the microbiological results of the extracted heart valve. Among the analyses requested
column57: the serology for Coxiella burnetti was positive
column58: with high titres
column59: allowing a diagnosis of endocarditis due to Q fever
column60: so the antibiotic treatment regimen was modified and the patient was started on doxycycline + hydroxychloroquine
column61: and he was discharged from hospital. During the months following discharge
column62: the patient presented several episodes of decompensation of heart failure with bilateral pleural effusion
column63: which required hygiene and dietary educational measures
column64: intravenous depletive treatment
column65: thoracentesis and inclusion of the patient in the heart failure telemonitoring programme
column66: and he is currently in a situation of clinical stability with regular controls by the Cardiology and Infectious Diseases outpatient clinics.  DIAGNOSIS Endocarditis due to Q fever on native aortic valve. Aortic insufficiency due to perforation of the non-coronary aortic leaflet. Secondary congestive heart failure. Aortic valve replacement surgery for biological prosthesis. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
