column1: The patient was an 85-year-old woman with a biological aortic valve prosthesis and double coronary artery bypass graft who was admitted to the Cardiology hospital ward for acute heart failure. The echocardiogram showed a rupture of one of the prosthesis leaflets with severe aortic insufficiency.  HISTORY
column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  Personal history Intolerance to calcium antagonists due to oedema. No toxic habits. Hypertension
column3: dyslipidaemia and type 2 diabetes under treatment. Sclerodegenerative aortic valve disease and common trunk disease
column4: undergoing aortic valve replacement surgery for biological aortic prosthesis (Perimount 21) and double aortocoronary bypass (AMI-DA
column5: SF-Cx) at a private centre in 2001. Subsequent check-ups by cardiologist
column6: asymptomatic. Last echocardiogram (June/2015): non-dilated LV with severe concentric hypertrophy and preserved global and segmental systolic function. Severe calcification of the mitral valve
column7: without significant stenosis. Mild-moderate mitral regurgitation. Carpentier Perimount 21 biological prosthesis with calcified
column8: degenerated leaflets. Slightly elevated gradients. Normal RV. Normal pulmonary pressure.  Usual treatment: gliclazide 30 mg (0-1-0)
column9: sitagliptin 100 mg (1-0-0-0)
column11: doxazosin 8 mg (0-0-1)
column12: carvedilol 25 mg (1-0-1)
column13: candesartan/HCTZ 32/12.5 mg (1-0-0)
column14: pravastatin 40 mg (0-0-1).  Present illness An 85-year-old woman was admitted to the emergency department of our hospital for progressive dyspnoea over the last month
column15: which had been increasing until it became minimal effort. She reported orthopnoea and episodes of paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea. He also has increased oedema in the lower extremities up to the knees and decreased diuresis. She has increased the dose of diuretic with little improvement. Afebrile and with no other associated symptoms.  Physical examination BP 150/50 mmHg
column16: HR 110 bpm
column18: baseline SO2 85%. Conscious and oriented. Tachypnoea and respiratory work. Afebrile. Good hydration and perfusion status. Chest: mid sternotomy scar. AC: rhythmic
column19: fast
column20: systolic-diastolic murmur (V/VI) in aortic focus. PA: crackles in the lower half of both hemithoraxes. Abdomen: globular
column21: soft and depressible
column22: not painful on palpation
column23: with no signs of peritoneal irritation. Lower extremities: oedema with bilateral fovea up to the knees. No signs of deep vein thrombosis. Pedial pulses present. Saphenectomy scar.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG on admission: sinus rhythm at 60 bpm
column24: known LBBB with secondary repolarisation alterations. Chest X-ray on admission: cardiomegaly
column25: bilateral perihilar alveolar infiltrates
column26: compatible with pulmonary oedema. Laboratory tests on admission: arterial pH 7.41
column27: PaCO2 56 and PaO2 59 mmHg
column28: bicarbonate 35.5 mEq/L
column29: SatO2 88 %
column31: urea 79 and Cr 1.35 mg/dl. Na 137 and K 5.07 mEq/l. CRP 10.8 mg/l. NT-proBNP 10195 pg/ml. Troponin T 62 ng/L. Leukocytes 9200/mm3
column32: Hb 11.3 g/dl
column33: Hto 39 %
column34: MCH 26 pg
column35: MCHC 29.2 g/dl
column36: platelets 94000/mm3. T. Prothrombin 76 %
column37: INR 1.19
column38: APTT 30 sg. Transthoracic echocardiogram on admission: non-dilated LV with severe concentric hypertrophy and preserved global systolic function. Severe annular calcification of mitral valve without significant stenosis. Moderate central MI. Dysfunctioning
column39: degenerated Perimount 21 biological aortic prosthesis
column40: with moderate transprosthetic gradient and severe new onset aortic insufficiency possibly related to rupture of one of the leaflets. Moderately dilated RV with mild systolic dysfunction. Moderate TR. Severe PH. Transesophageal echocardiogram: dysfunctional Perimount 21 biological aortic prosthesis
column41: with degenerated leaflets
column42: calcified and with one of the leaflets broken
column43: which protrudes into the left ventricular outflow tract in diastole
column44: leading to very severe aortic insufficiency. Severe mitral annular calcification
column45: with moderate central mitral insufficiency. Moderate tricuspid insufficiency due to annular dilatation (39 mm). Severe pulmonary hypertension. Mildly dilated right ventricle
column46: with moderate global systolic dysfunction. Coronary angiography: common trunk: severe ostial lesion. Anterior descending: irregular borders
column47: without significant stenosis. Circumflex: irregular borders
column48: without significant stenosis. Right coronary: dominant. Minimal irregularities
column49: without significant lesions. Grafts: IMA to LAD: patent. Saphenous to OM: patent. Angio-CT aorta: thoracic aorta of normal calibre and morphology with slight atheromatous changes. Abdominal and iliac aorta of normal calibre and morphology with mild-moderate atheromatous changes
column50: predominantly in infrarenal abdominal aorta and proximal common iliac aorta
column51: at postbifurcation level. Discrete focal eccentric calcification in the right common femoral artery prior to bifurcation.  EVOLUTION The patient is an 85-year-old woman
column52: with a biological aortic valve prosthesis and double coronary artery bypass grafting who was admitted with acute pulmonary oedema and severe aortic insufficiency was detected on echocardiography due to rupture of one of the leaflets of the biological aortic prosthesis. The patient was admitted in severe heart failure
column53: requiring high doses of intravenous diuretics. After clinical stabilisation
column54: a transesophageal echocardiogram was performed which confirmed the rupture of one of the aortic prosthesis leaflets
column55: resulting in very severe aortic insufficiency. Given the severity of the valve disease
column56: the case was presented at a medical-surgical session. Given the patient's advanced age and previous cardiac surgery in 2001
column57: it was decided to implant an aortic valve prosthesis inside the previously implanted prosthesis
column58: percutaneously from femoral access (TAVI valve in valve). Coronary angiography showed no new lesions and aortic CT angiography showed favourable femoral accesses for the procedure. By means of a catheter introduced through the left femoral arterial access
column59: the correct right femoral arterial access is checked
column60: through which it is passed by means of an Extra-Stiff guide. The Ewards Sapien 3 No 23 expandable prosthesis is advanced over this guide. It is expanded in the aortic position
column61: remaining slightly under-expanded at the level of the ring of the previous Perimount prosthesis (Video 3 and 4). Transesophageal echocardiography is used to verify the normal position of the valve
column62: the absence of regurgitation and the transvalvular gradients (max 37 mmHg). The absence of aortic regurgitation and absence of leakage after Prostar closure of the right femoral access is verified by angiography. The left femoral access is closed with Angio-Seal. After the procedure
column63: the patient was admitted to the Coronary Unit extubated
column64: haemodynamically stable
column65: with initially fair O2 saturations in the context of sedation after the procedure and signs of mild pulmonary congestion
column66: which evolved well with diuretic treatment. He also presented with acute renal failure prior to the procedure
column67: with a creatinine peak of 2.2 which resolved during admission (urea 122 at discharge
column68: creatinine 1.06). He remained in his own rhythm during admission (sinus with LBBB and long PR
column69: already present before the procedure)
column70: with no other arrhythmic events in telemetry
column71: so the transient jugular PM was removed. On the hospital ward
column72: he had a very good clinical evolution. Congestion data disappeared
column73: remaining stable at all times. A control echocardiogram showed residual moderate aortic stenosis after the procedure
column74: without aortic insufficiency. Good appearance of the femoral arterial accesses
column75: with slight haematomas
column76: without major complications. In good clinical condition
column77: she was discharged home.  DIAGNOSIS Acute heart failure due to severe aortic insufficiency. Biological aortic prosthesis with severe insufficiency due to leaflet rupture. Implantation of Edwards Sapien 3 (valve in valve) percutaneous valvular aortic prosthesis. LV function borderline-slightly depressed. Acute renal failure
column78: resolved. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION A 67-year-old man attended a Cardiology consultation due to worsening dyspnoea. Cardiovascular risk factors: Ex-smoker (20 packs/year) and hypertensive under treatment. Cardiological history: left bundle branch block as an incidental finding in a routine electrocardiogram; diagnosis of hypertensive heart disease with moderate LV hypertrophy and mild systolic dysfunction in the echocardiogram. The Holter study was completed and showed frequent ventricular extrasystoles (asymptomatic). Medical treatment: nevibolol 5 mg
column3: torasemide 5 mg and amlodipine/valsartan 5/160 mg once daily. Current history: previously in NYHA functional class I
column4: he consulted Cardiology for worsening of his dyspnoea of one year's evolution
column5: to the point of moderate exertion. He denied syncope
column6: palpitations or other symptoms. Physical examination showed no relevant findings. Head and neck with no increase in jugular venous pressure or carotid murmurs. Rhythmic cardiac auscultation with abundant extrasystoles
column7: but no murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation showed decreased generalised vesicular murmur
column8: with no other superimposed sounds. The abdomen was globular with no masses or megaliths and the lower limbs were free of oedema and there was no evidence of deep vein thrombosis.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG: sinus rhythm at 60 bpm
column9: normal PR
column10: left bundle branch block (QRS of 150 ms). Holter: sinus rhythm throughout the recording. Monomorphic ventricular extrasystoles of slight-moderate density
column11: with some triplets. Occasional supraventricular extrasystoles with isolated episodes of supraventricular tachycardia. No pauses. Echocardiogram
column12: new study: non-dilated left ventricle
column13: with moderate septal hypertrophy (1.5 cm) and alterations in segmental contractility: basal hypokinesia of the inferior
column14: anterior
column15: anteroseptal and anterolateral faces
column16: with anomalous septal movement. Mild systolic dysfunction (LVEF 45%). Grade II diastolic dysfunction
column17: with pseudonormal pattern. Normal right ventricle. Slightly dilated atria (LA 25 and RA 21 cm2). Minimal aortic insufficiency
column18: without other valvulopathies. Cardiac MRI: left ventricle slightly dilated
column19: with moderate to severe concentric increase in wall thickness
column20: maximum thickness measured in the inferior septum of the middle segment of 22 mm. Significant increase in myocardial mass (116 gr/m2)
column21: global hypokinesia and moderate systolic dysfunction (LVEF 37%). Right ventricle neither dilated nor hypertrophied with normal function (RVEF 59%). Moderately dilated left atrium with thickening of the interatrial septum in its most caudal area. Absence of pericardial and pleural effusion. Late enhancement sequences show a diffuse uptake pattern
column22: with greater intensity in the subendocardium in the middle segments of the lateral and inferolateral face
column23: diffuse intramyocardial uptake of the basal and middle septum and at the level of the posterior septum at the insertion of the free wall. There is also subepicardial enhancement in the free wall of the right ventricular outflow tract. The wall of both atria shows diffuse uptake
column24: as well as the interatrial septum
column25: mitral valve and aortic wall. On the STIR sequence
column26: no oedema is seen. The T2 sequence shows no evidence of iron overload. Salivary gland biopsy: no amyloid deposition. 99mTc-DDP scan: myocardial deposition of the radiotracer
column27: indicative of cardiac amyloidosis. Endomyocardial biopsy: (sampling from 2 different sites in the right ventricle) positive deposit of amyloid substance transthyretin (TTR). Genetic study: (NGS sequencing 17 genes panel
column28: including TTR): negative.  EVOLUTION Patient known to Cardiology with a previous diagnosis of hypertensive heart disease. After worsening of his CF
column29: the echocardiogram was repeated
column31: diastolic dysfunction with pseudonormal pattern and data of increased end-diastolic pressures. With the suspicion of infiltrative cardiomyopathy
column32: cardiac magnetic resonance imaging was requested
column33: which showed findings highly suggestive of cardiac amyloidosis. The patient was studied by quantification of immunoglobulins
column34: electrophoresis and immunofixation of proteins and 24-hour urine study
column35: ruling out multiple myeloma. Bone scintigraphy 99 mTc-DDP was also requested
column36: with cardiac uptake of the radiotracer
column37: compatible with senile and/or hereditary amyloidosis due to TTR deposition. The precise diagnosis was made by endomyocardial biopsy
column38: which showed TTR deposition. Finally
column39: genetic testing was performed to discern between hereditary and senile amyloidosis. Once the latter was diagnosed
column40: it was not necessary to study the patient's relatives. The patient was managed conservatively
column41: with treatment aimed at systolic dysfunction
column42: diuretics and antihypertensive drugs
column43: with a good clinical response after 2 years of follow-up.  DIAGNOSIS Cardiac amyloidosis due to transthyretin deposition. Senile type. Moderate systolic and diastolic dysfunction of vi. Compensated heart failure in NYHA functional class I after medication. Asymptomatic ventricular arrhythmias
column44: ventricular extrasystoles of mild to moderate intensity. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column1: 54-year-old woman. She consulted the Hereditary Cardiomyopathies department for a genetic study due to family history.  HISTORY
column2: CURRENT DISEASE AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  Personal history CVRF: family history of early sudden death
column3: early complete atrioventricular block
column4: early complete AVB and dilated cardiomyopathy. No known hypertension
column5: diabetes mellitus or dyslipidaemia. No previous cardiological history. No other history of interest. No home medication.  Family history: 63-year-old brother (index case): atrial fibrillation (AF) and complete AVB with pacemaker implantation at age 50. DCM (LVEF 34%) with normal coronary angiography. Monomorphic SVT and syncope with ICD implantation at 57 years of age. 59-year-old brother with complete AVB and pacemaker implantation at age 49. Normal TTE. 55-year-old brother with complete AVB and pacemaker implantation at age 50. TTE this year with LVEF 30-35%. Mild-moderate dilatation of the left ventricle (LV). All of them have LMNA p332fs mutation. Two maternal uncles
column6: mother and brother died of sudden death before the age of 55.  Current disease Consultation for screening for LMNA p332fs mutation. Asymptomatic. Asthenia in the last year which has not prevented her from leading a normal life. After finding a complete AVB in the ECG
column7: she was admitted.  Physical examination Afebrile. HR 50 bpm. BP 143/83 mmHg. SatO2 99 %. AC: RsCsRs with mitral systolic murmur II/VI. AP: VCM. Abdomen nondescript. EEII without oedema.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG: AF at 37 bpm with complete paroxysmal AVB. Transthoracic echocardiography: mild LV dilatation. Slightly depressed systolic function (LVEF 45%). Mild-moderate functional MR. Telemetry: asymptomatic slow AF with self-limited bouts of full BAV with narrow QRS nodal escape and no pauses or VT. Blood count and coagulation: normal. Biochemistry: normal CK and NT-proBNP 1238 pg/ml. Genetic study: carrier of LMNA p332fs mutation.  EVOLUTION During hospitalisation
column8: telemetry showed asymptomatic slow AF with self-limited bouts of complete AVB with narrow QRS nodal escape and no pauses
column9: remaining asymptomatic. The problem we faced was to decide which device to implant in this patient (conventional pacemaker
column10: ICD
column11: ICD-CRT) and also to continue the family screening study for the mutation. Finally
column12: the decision was made to implant an ICD-CRT
column13: in accordance with the available scientific evidence (see discussion).  DIAGNOSIS Slow atrial fibrillation with spells of complete atrioventricular block. Familial dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) with dilated left ventricle with mild-moderate systolic dysfunction (LVEF 45%). Carrier of LMNA p 332fs mutation. Extensive family history of sudden death
column14: complete AVB and dilated cardiomyopathy. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: CURRENT DISEASE AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION We present the case of a 47-year-old male diagnosed with HCM at the age of 44 years
column3: following a family screening after his 7-year-old daughter presented with a recovered sudden death. Genetic testing showed a troponin I mutation (TNNI3) in the index case
column4: our patient being a carrier. At the time of diagnosis
column5: he was oligosymptomatic from the cardiovascular point of view: he reported NYHA functional class I-II and denied symptoms of palpitations
column6: chest pain
column7: dizziness or syncope.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG: sinus rhythm. Narrow QRS with -30o axis. Left ventricular overload voltage criteria. CBC: Hb 13 g/dl
column8: Cr 1 mg/dl
column9: normal ions
column10: NT-proBNP 1
column11: 000 pg/ml. Chest X-ray: cardiomegaly. Mild vascular redistribution to upper fields. Echocardiogram: LV of normal diameter with moderate asymmetric septal hypertrophy (15 mm) with no obstruction across the left ventricular outflow tract
column12: no systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve. Mild left ventricular systolic dysfunction (EF 48-50 %) and grade 1 diastolic dysfunction. Dilated left atrium (67 mm). Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI): late gadolinium enhancement irregularly distributed in the medial wall of the entire septum
column13: anterior wall and free wall of the right ventricle. IVS 15 mm. Severe left atrial dilatation. Ergometry: sinus rhythm during recording. Supraventricular extrasystoles and ventricular extrasystoles (with BRDHH morphology) isolated.  EVOLUTION After the studies performed
column14: an intermediate risk of sudden death was estimated (HCM 5-year SCD rate 4.7%)
column15: and ICD implantation was decided for primary prevention of sudden death. After a stable period of 3 years
column16: he reported progressive clinical worsening in the last 6 months
column17: presenting deterioration of functional class (CF NYHA III/IV). Physical examination revealed elevated jugular venous pressure and crackles on pulmonary auscultation. Laboratory tests showed elevated NT-proBNP up to 5
column18: 000 pg/ml
column19: with the rest of the parameters in the normal range. The electrocardiogram was in sinus rhythm. A control echocardiogram was performed
column20: which showed LV with moderate asymmetric septal hypertrophy
column21: which had not progressed
column22: with deterioration of LV systolic function (EF 40-45%). No dynamic gradient was observed in the LV outflow tract. He also had grade 3 diastolic dysfunction
column23: with evidence of elevated filling pressures. Ergospirometry was performed
column24: showing peak oxygen consumption of 16 ml/min/kg (57% of predicted) and right heart catheterisation
column25: with evidence of postcapillary pulmonary hypertension (pulmonary capillary pressure: 24 mmHg
column26: systolic pulmonary pressure of 55 mmHg
column27: mean pulmonary artery pressure 32 mmHg). RV end-diastolic pressure was 16 mmHg. Neurohormonal treatment was started and
column28: due to severe dilatation of the left atrium and thrombotic risk in case of falling into atrial fibrillation
column29: oral anticoagulation was also started. The evolution in the following year was unfavourable despite optimal medical treatment
column31: with two admissions for decompensation of heart failure. A new determination of oxygen consumption was performed
column32: estimating VO2 max of 12 ml/kg/min. Given the significant and progressive limitation of his functional capacity
column33: he was referred to a reference centre as a candidate for heart transplant
column34: undergoing a pre-transplant study and is currently on the waiting list for elective transplant.  DIAGNOSIS Non-obstructive hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Mutation in the troponin I 3 gene (TNNI3). Recovered sudden death in first-degree relative. ICD carrier. Mild left ventricular dysfunction. Stage D heart failure. NYHA functional class III/IV. Candidate for elective heart transplant. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  The patient is a 48-year-old male
column3: dyslipidaemic
column4: with non-ischaemic dilated cardiomyopathy with severe ventricular dysfunction known since 2010. Years earlier
column5: a genetic study had been performed
column6: with the finding of an LMNA variant of uncertain significance in a gene related to laminopathy
column7: consistent with the patient's phenotype: non-ischaemic dilated cardiomyopathy associated with conduction disorder and ventricular arrhythmias
column8: which had required multiple ablation procedures in the course of his disease. In addition
column9: the patient had had a mechanical prosthesis ATS no. 25 since 2012 for a bicuspid aortic valve with severe insufficiency. During 2016
column10: the patient was in advanced heart failure
column11: in NYHA functional class IV
column12: with severe LV systolic dysfunction on echocardiography requiring repeated admissions for severe decompensation. He was therefore included on the elective list for heart transplantation (INTERMACS 4). In the following weeks he presented progressive worsening despite periodic cycles of levosimendan
column13: with increasingly frequent decompensations due to low output and congestion
column14: the last of which did not improve despite inotropic support (INTERMACS 2). It was decided to implant a balloon counterpulsation device and to place him on urgent cardiac transplant list 1. Three weeks later
column15: heart transplantation was performed by bicave technique
column16: with good biventricular function at pump output. Immediate postoperative period without complications: little need for haemodynamic support
column17: no rhythm disorders
column18: extubation in the first twelve hours
column19: no neurological deficit. No complications from the infectious point of view
column20: she received prophylaxis according to the centre's protocol with norfloxacin
column21: nystatin
column22: cotrimoxazole (recipient with negative toxoplasma and unknown donor) and valganciclovir for 15 days due to intermediate risk (positive cytomegalovirus in donor and recipient).  Immunosuppression also according to protocol
column23: consisting of: Two doses of basiliximab 20 mg on the first and fourth day. Intensive corticotherapy with methylprednisolone 125 mg every 8 h on the first day
column24: followed by prednisone 1 mg/kg/day
column25: in a descending pattern. Tacrolimus
column26: starting at 0.03 mg/kg/12 h and adjusting according to levels to target between 10 and 15 ng/ml at baseline. Mycophenolate mofetil sodium
column28: 000 mg/12 h. Without evidence of rejection in successive biopsies and with serial echocardiograms with normofunctioning graft
column29: preserved left and right ventricular ejection fraction
column30: without valvular heart disease or pericardial effusion. In this context
column31: while stable on the cardiology ward after an uncomplicated endomyocardial biopsy three hours earlier
column32: he presented with an episode of eye twitching with sustained blinking
column33: during which he was able to respond to commands
column34: lasting one minute. This was followed by tonic-clonic movements of all four limbs lasting one minute. A few minutes after cessation
column35: during which time he remained with visual disturbances and nystagmus to the left
column36: he presented a new episode of generalised seizure
column37: more prolonged
column38: which ceased with benzodiazepines (10 mg diazepam)
column39: as well as levetiracetam 1
column40: 000 mg in perfusion
column41: both intravenous. After resolution
column42: the patient remained conscious
column43: oriented and speech preserved. The threat reflex was bilaterally absent and at the time the patient reported exclusively shadow vision. Pupils were isochoric
column44: normoreactive; leftward nystagmus maintained in primary gaze position. He was able to move all four limbs symmetrically
column45: with the rest of the examination being unremarkable. Blood pressure was 160/90 mmHg. Once he improved
column46: the patient admitted having had a mild holocranial headache in the previous days.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Blood tests: haemoglobin 12.1 g/dL
column47: Ht 37%
column48: RDW 24%
column49: platelets 107
column51: the rest without alterations. Coagulation: APTT 24.7 s
column52: the rest without alterations. Biochemistry: glycaemia 106 mg/dl
column53: GGT 285 IU/l
column54: protein 5.8 g/dl. Renal function preserved (creatinine 0.88 mg/dl
column55: GFR MDRD-4 > 60 ml/min). Ions in normal range (Na+ 138 mmol/l
column56: K+ 4.4 mmol/l). CRP <0.1 mg/L. Venous blood gases: pH 7.21
column57: bicarbonate 18 mg/dl
column58: lactate 13.1 mg/dl
column59: the rest without alterations Cranial CT scan: multiple posterior temporal and parieto-occipital hypodense lesions
column60: as well as right frontal and in both cerebellar hemispheres
column61: although also predominantly on the right. Brain MRI: vasogenic oedema symmetrically affecting the subcortical white matter of almost all of both occipital lobes and occipito-parieto-temporal regions. In these areas
column62: multiple millimetric foci of hypointensity and cortico-subcortical distribution can be seen
column63: which are compatible with microbleeds.  EVOLUTION The patient was immediately evaluated by Neurology
column64: who
column65: given the finding of seizures together with previous headache and visual disturbances in a patient being treated with tacrolimus
column66: suspected the most likely diagnosis to be posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome (PRES). Both CT and MRI
column67: the latter being the technique of choice
column68: showed images highly suggestive of this condition. He was transferred to the intensive care unit for strict control of blood pressure and monitoring of new critical episodes. From the point of view of management
column69: tacrolimus was withdrawn and cyclosporine was started slowly
column70: as this was the most commonly used regimen in the literature in these cases. Mycophenolate was increased and high doses of corticotherapy were maintained until adequate therapeutic levels of calcineurin inhibitors were reached. Despite these changes
column71: no rejection data were documented
column72: either by ultrasound or endomyocardial biopsy. No new episodes of seizures. Progressive overall recovery
column73: with somewhat slower recovery of visual disturbances. He was discharged 12 days after the event
column74: neurologically asymptomatic and with control MRI
column75: with significant improvement with respect to the previous study.  DIAGNOSIS Reversible posterior encephalopathy syndrome (PRES) probably secondary to treatment with tacrolimus. Generalised tonic-clonic seizures secondary to the above. Normofunctioning orthotopic heart transplant in a patient with non-ischaemic dilated cardiomyopathy with severe left ventricular dysfunction

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION 45-year-old male. Native of Conakri
column3: capital of Guinea
column4: resident in Spain since May 2016. Diagnosed with untreated diabetes mellitus on admission; no personal or family history of heart disease
column5: history of heart failure or sudden death. He consulted the emergency department of our centre due to progressive dyspnoea on exertion
column6: until becoming minimal effort (walking less than 5 metres) in the last year. He reported stopping at least three times to climb a flight of stairs. He also presents palpitations
column7: oedematisation of the lower limbs and increased abdominal perimeter. He reports orthopnoea and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea. He denies angina on exertion. On physical examination
column8: eupneic at rest
column9: tolerating decubitus at 20o
column10: well perfused. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic heart tones
column11: tachycardic
column12: with S3 and systolic murmur II/VI in tricuspid focus that increases with inspiration. Jugular ingurgitation. Pulmonary auscultation: light bibasal crackles. Distended abdomen with hepatomegaly of 3 tracts. Oedema in the lower limbs up to the thighs and in the abdominal wall.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Electrocardiogram: sinus tachycardia at 102 bpm. QRS with axis at -60o. BRDHH and HBAIHH. QR pattern in right precordial leads suggestive of right ventricular growth and overload
column13: with ST underleveling and negative T waves in the same. Poor R wave progression in precordial leads. V5-V6 notching with rsr ́s ́ complexes. Electrocardiogram during admission: sinus rhythm at 78 bpm. Axis at -60o. BRDHH and HBAIHH. qR in right precordials with ST underleveling and negative T waves in the same. Notching in V5-V6. CBC: Glucose 124 mg/dl. Creatinine 1.34 mg/dl. GOT 41 U/l. GPT 16 U/l. Sodium 138 mmol/l. Potassium 4.55 mmol/l. Haemoglobin 13.7 g/dl
column14: platelets 205
column15: 000/μL. Leukocytes 5
column16: 670/μL. Slight iron deficiency (iron 34 μg/dl) with normal transferrin and ferritin. TSH 1.95 U/l. HbA1c 7.1%. Total cholesterol 167 mg/dl
column17: LDLc 114 mg/dl
column18: HDLc 34 mg/dl
column19: triglycerides 95 mg/dl. Coagulation: INR 1.43
column20: PTTA 29.5. Factor II 57 %. Factor V 66 %. Factor VII 40 %. Factor X 57 %. Chest X-ray: cardiomegaly at the expense of right cavities. Signs of vascular redistribution and fluid in minor fissure. Serology: Toxoplasma
column21: Echinococcus
column22: Trypanosoma
column23: Treponema pallidum
column24: Strongyloides stercoralis
column25: Schistosoma negative. Peripheral blood parasitaemia negative. Plasmodium IgM negative and IgG 1:80 (recent infection). Trichinella
column26: Fasciola
column27: Taenia negative. HIV negative. HAV IgM negative with positive total Ac. HBV: HBcAc positive
column28: antiHBe undetermined and AntiHBs positive. Transthoracic echocardiogram: LV endomyocardial fibrosis. Severe LV systolic dysfunction with LVEF 20% and restrictive diastolic pattern. Low cardiac output. Dilated RV
column29: hypocontractile with TAPSE of 11 mm
column30: without clear image of apical occupation. Slight left atrial dilatation and moderate dilatation of the RA. Mild functional MR. Severe functional TR. Severe pulmonary hypertension. Slight right retroauricular pericardial effusion. Angio-CT pulmonary arteries and cardiac CT: minimal focal repletion defect in the periphery of the posterior basal segmental branch and lateral subsegmental branch of the LID
column31: compatible with chronic PTE. Cardiomegaly with signs of right HF. Atheromatosis in aortic arch and coronary arteries. Increased fat density in the middle mediastinum not individualising the oesophageal wall
column32: non-specific. Coronary angiography: coronary artery disease of 1 vessel. Anterior descending with critical ostial lesion
column33: diffusely diseased vessel with borderline calibre and TIMI 2 distal flow. The apical portion is filled by homocoronary circulation from epicardial vessel coming from circumflex.  EVOLUTION Admitted to the cardiology ward for heart failure on debut
column34: predominantly right heart failure
column35: CF III/IV NYHA; restrictive cardiomyopathy compatible with LV endomyocardial fibrosis
column36: with severe LV systolic dysfunction and restrictive LV filling pattern associated with dilated and dysfunctional RV with severe TR and data of pulmonary hypertension was observed on echocardiography. Depletive treatment was started with good response and progressive titration of neurohormonal treatment (bisoprolol 2.5 mg/24 hours
column37: ramipril 5 mg/24 hours
column38: eplerenone 25 mg/24 hours). Angio-CT of the pulmonary arteries was requested with a diagnosis of chronic PTE and thoracic CT to assess the extent of endomyocardial fibrosis
column39: with absence of endomyocardial calcification
column40: showing coronary atheromatosis. Coronary angiography showed coronary artery disease of the anterior descending artery with critical ostial lesion
column41: visualising a diffusely diseased vessel of borderline calibre. The patient was screened for infections as an aetiopathogenic factor of the endomyocardial fibrosis. Given the patient's characteristics
column42: absence of angina
column43: LV dysfunction secondary to endomyocardial fibrosis
column44: ASA and statins were associated with the medical treatment already prescribed and the case was presented in a medical-surgical session (endomyocardial resection +/-CABG). The patient was rejected for surgery to resect masses and revascularise the LAD due to high surgical risk. Oral anticoagulation was not started due to a significant language barrier and high risk of non-compliance with treatment. During follow-up
column45: the patient did not attend outpatient check-ups.  DIAGNOSIS Debut heart failure related to restrictive cardiomyopathy due to LV endomyocardial fibrosis. Severe pulmonary hypertension. Chronic pulmonary thromboembolism. Severe functional tricuspid insufficiency. Ischaemic heart disease. 1-vessel coronary artery disease
column46: without clinical signs of angina. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION 60-year-old patient with a history of hypertension
column3: dyslipidaemia
column4: COPD
column5: left temporoparietal ischaemic stroke with no subsequent sequelae
column6: dilated heart disease of ischaemic origin
column7: which debuted in the form of inferolateral AMI 20 years earlier
column8: with subsequent echocardiogram showing severely dilated left ventricle with severe ventricular dysfunction (LVEF 20%) secondary to inferoposterior akinesia and hypokinesia of the remaining segments
column9: with mild mitral insufficiency
column10: without other significant valvulopathies. It was decided to implant an ICD as primary prevention and CRT
column11: with improvement in systolic function (LVEF 35%). The patient consulted the emergency department for dyspnoea of 4 days' duration
column12: accompanied by cough and fever. Haemodynamically
column13: BP 96/65 mmHg
column14: febrile at 38°C
column15: 02 saturation 92 % with KVM 24 %. Physical examination revealed abundant rhonchi and wheezing predominantly in right fields
column16: with bibasal crackles
column17: systolic murmur predominantly in mitral focus
column18: bimalleolar oedema and jugular ingurgitation. Arterial blood gas with Fi02 of 24 % showed pH 7.476
column19: pC02 34 mmHg
column20: p02 59 mmHg
column21: HCO3 24.5 mmol/L. CBC with minimal elevation of acute phase reactants (CRP 1.74 mg/dl) and leukocytosis 11910/L with neutrophilia 81 %
column22: slightly altered renal function (creatinine 1.32 mg/dl and GFR 54 ml/min)
column23: correct ionogram. Chest X-ray with signs of vascular redistribution as well as a consolidating image in the right middle lobe
column24: suggestive of pneumonic process. ECG in sinus rhythm 95 bpm
column25: with ventricular rhythm stimulated by CRT. The patient was diagnosed with respiratory infection and decompensation of heart failure in a patient with chronic ischaemic heart disease in the dilated phase. Diuretic treatment and antibiotic therapy were started.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Chest X-ray: signs of vascular redistribution as well as a consolidating image in the right middle lobe
column26: suggestive of a pneumonic process. ECG: sinus rhythm 95lpm
column27: with ventricular rhythm stimulated by CRT. Echocardiogram on admission: LVEF 35-40 %. Severe mitral insufficiency with restriction of the posterior leaflet and probable prolapse of the anterior leaflet. Severe dilatation of left ventricle slightly-moderately hypertrophic
column28: with moderate reduction of motility due to inferolateral and inferior akinesia. LVEF 35-40 %. Moderate left atrial dilatation. Right ventricle with preserved motility. Device lead in right cavities. Mild tricuspid insufficiency that allows estimating PAPs 46 mmHg. No pericardial effusion. Transesophageal echocardiogram: severe mitral insufficiency secondary to restrictive movement of the posterior leaflet and prolapse of the anterior leaflet at the level of A2 with an image of chordal rupture. Coronary angiography: right dominance. Truncus description: lesion 20% distal. Description of the anterior descending artery: long development
column29: very calcified. Lesion 50 % to the middle tract. Circumflex description: very calcified. Lesion 30% proximal. Right coronary description: occluded proximally (since 2002). Bad distal vessel. Echocardiogram during implantation: implantation of two MitraClip (x2) at level A2 P2 segments of the mitral valve. Well positioned devices with slight residual leak (grade I/IV). Fluoroscopy: implantation of 2 MitraClip.  EVOLUTION During hospitalisation the patient shows improvement from the infectious point of view. However
column30: his heart failure worsened and he went into cardiogenic shock
column31: requiring non-invasive mechanical ventilation and inotropic support. A transthoracic echocardiogram showed severe mitral insufficiency
column32: with restriction of the posterior leaflet and possible prolapse of the anterior leaflet. To better visualise the mechanism of mitral insufficiency
column33: a transesophageal echocardiogram was performed which confirmed severe mitral insufficiency secondary to restrictive movement of the posterior leaflet and prolapse of the anterior leaflet at the level of A2 with an image of chordal rupture. Coronary angiography showed moderate lesions of the left coronary artery with chronic occlusion of the right coronary artery
column34: already present in previous studies. The patient had a torpid clinical evolution
column35: with cardiogenic shock refractory to medical treatment
column36: requiring orotracheal intubation
column37: invasive mechanical ventilation and implantation of aortic balloon counterpulsation. The case was assessed jointly with the Cardiac Surgery and Haemodynamics team and
column38: given the high surgical risk
column39: MitraClip implantation was decided. The patient arrived in the haemodynamics room with inotropic support with dobutamine
column40: aortic balloon counterpulsation
column41: orotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation. The procedure was guided by transesophageal echocardiography and scopy. Given the difficulty of the case
column42: a strategy with at least 2 clips was considered from the beginning. The first clip was successfully implanted after multiple attempts
column43: and a second
column44: more lateral clip was subsequently implanted
column45: thereby reducing the MR from grade 4 to 1. Subsequently
column46: the patient had a good clinical evolution
column47: being able to remove the counterpulsation balloon
column48: ionotropic and ventilatory support
column49: and was discharged haemodynamically stable with no signs of heart failure. Echocardiogram at discharge showed an estimated EF of 25-30%
column50: MitraClip implantation (x2) at segment A2 P2 level of the mitral valve with well-positioned devices with mild residual leak (grade I/IV). Six months after discharge
column51: the patient persists in NYHA functional class I-II
column52: with no cardiac decompensation.  DIAGNOSIS Community-acquired right middle lobe pneumonia. Heart failure with biventricular dysfunction. Cardiogenic shock. Severe mitral insufficiency secondary to restrictive movement of the posterior leaflet and prolapse of the anterior leaflet at A2 level with chordal rupture image. column1: We present the case of a middle-aged patient with hypertrophic sarcomeric cardiomyopathy
column2: with symptomatic left ventricular outflow tract obstruction
column3: in whom alcohol septal ablation is proposed as a therapeutic option.  HISTORY
column4: CURRENT DISEASE AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  Personal history No known adverse drug reactions. No family history of interest in relation to his heart disease. Maternal aunt with a history of arterial hypertension and moderate parietal thickening of the left ventricle
column5: deceased at 92 years of age. No history of sudden death in the family. Healthy parents
column6: siblings and children. Smoker of 5 cigarettes/day. Consumption of 1 litre/day of beer. Arterial hypertension
column7: altered basal glycaemia and recently diagnosed hypercholesterolemia. Antral ulcus in 2005. Tension headaches studied in Neurology. Treatment: enalapril/hydrochlorothiazide 20/12.5 mg at breakfast.  Present illness A 48-year-old female patient
column8: who began with sudden onset symptoms of palpitations
column9: associated with a sensation of dyspnoea and chest tightness radiating to the throat
column10: as well as cold sweat and blurred vision
column11: attended the emergency department of her medical centre where she was documented
column12: without any electrocardiographic record provided
column13: a regular QRS tachycardia at 200 bpm
column14: with a retrograde P wave inscribed in the terminal portion of the QRS
column15: and she was referred to the Emergency Department of our hospital where she arrived in sinus rhythm at 100 bpm
column16: and was discharged. From that day on
column17: high blood pressure levels were detected
column18: and she was started on the antihypertensive treatment indicated above. Apart from this episode

column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION 60-year-old woman
column3: whose personal history included: smoker
column4: no other cardiovascular risk factors
column5: severe hypoacusis
column6: paroxysmal atrial fibrillation without anticoagulation by CHA2DS2-VASC 1 and obstructive sleep apnoea syndrome. She was being treated with bisoprolol and had no family history of interest. The patient came to the emergency department for progressive dyspnoea on minimal effort for a week with orthopnoea and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea. She also had palpitations without chest pain. She had no other symptoms.  Physical examination showed BP 110/65 mmHg
column7: 150 beats per minute
column8: oxygen saturation of 90% at baseline
column9: slight tachypnoea at rest without jugular ingurgitation
column10: arrhythmic without audible murmurs on cardiac auscultation
column11: crackles in both lung bases

An echocardiogram showed left ventricular dimensions at the upper limit of normality with a left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) of 50-55%. column15: haemoglobin 11.4 g/dl
column16: platelets 265 mil/mc
column17: glycaemia 105 mg/dl
column18: urea 69 mg/dl
column19: creatinine 1.28 mg/dl
column20: CPK 21 IU/L

column23: QRS axis at -9o
column24: with narrow QRS
column25: no other electrocardiographic abnormalities of note. Chest X-ray: signs of pulmonary congestion
column26: no pleural effusion with increased cardiothoracic index. Echocardiogram: non-dilated left ventricle with mild hypertrophy and preserved LVEF without segmental alterations of contractility. Diastolic pattern with single E wave and lateral E/E" of 12. Mitral insufficiency grade II and slight atrial dilatation. Normofunctioning trivalve aortic valve. Non dilated right chambers with mild tricuspid insufficiency with estimated PSAP of 55 mmHg. Inferior vena cava 22 mm with reduced collapse and absence of pericardial effusion. Echocardiogram in coronary unit: severely depressed LVEF with moderate dilatation of the left ventricle (82 ml/m2)
column27: mitral insufficiency grade III-IV
column28: mild dilatation of the left atrium. Estimated PSAP of 65 mmHg. EVOLUTION On the hospital ward
column29: heart rate control was achieved with bisoprolol and a transthoracic echocardiogram was performed which showed normal left ventricular volumes with preserved LVEF and mild-moderate mitral insufficiency. Three days after admission
column30: the patient presented AF-RVR again with haemodynamic instability and respiratory failure secondary to pulmonary oedema
column31: so she was transferred to the Coronary Unit and electrical cardioversion was performed
column32: which was ineffective after several attempts at maximum energy. Digoxin was administered and haemodynamic support was instituted with noradrenaline
column33: orotracheal intubation and invasive ventilation. A repeat echocardiogram showed dilatation and severe dysfunction of the left ventricle with moderate-severe functional mitral regurgitation. Progressively
column34: after haemodynamic improvement
column35: beta-blockers were introduced
column36: achieving rate control and withdrawing haemodynamic and ventilatory support. Coronary angiography showed angiographically normal coronary arteries and she was transferred to the ward where the echocardiogram was repeated and showed recovery of LVEF and left ventricular dimensions. The patient was discharged with atrial fibrillation and controlled ventricular response and a diagnosis of tachycardiomyopathy under treatment with bisoprolol 5 mg every 12 hours and sintrom. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION A 53-year-old woman with no remarkable pathological history except for smoking 20 cigarettes/day. She attended the Emergency Department for aphasia and hypoaesthesia in the left arm that had appeared 12 hours earlier. On arrival she was haemodynamically stable. On physical examination she was in good general condition
column3: conscious
column4: cooperative and oriented
column5: afebrile and eupneic. Hypoaesthesia in the right arm and aphasia. PCA: arrhythmic heart sounds
column6: with holosystolic and panfocal diastolic murmur. Minimal crackles in both lung bases.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS The electrocardiogram showed a previously unknown atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response
column7: although he recognised that he had felt palpitations for months.  Laboratory tests showed no significant alterations. A CT scan of the brain showed no ischaemic lesions at that time and she was finally admitted to the Neurology Department with a diagnosis of transient ischaemic attack dependent on the middle cerebral artery. She had a very satisfactory evolution with a control CT scan showing a small ischaemic spot in the right parietal area
column8: suggesting a cardioembolic cause. Since the risk of haemorrhagic transformation was low
column9: it was decided to start anticoagulant treatment with acenocoumarol. As part of the cardioembolic source study
column10: echocardiography was performed. The study was performed in AF with very rapid ventricular response
column11: showing the difficulty to control the rate with beta-blocker therapy. A large mass (99 mm x 71 mm) dilating the left atrium was observed. The mass had heterogeneous echogenicity
column12: multiple lobes and a 36 mm wide implantation pedicle. One of its lobes was interposed between the leaflets of the mitral valve
column13: generating severe insufficiency and obstruction (with a high mean gradient 12 mmHg) and a concomitant severe insufficiency justifying the difference between mean and peak gradient 20 mmHg. In addition
column14: he had moderate tricuspid regurgitation and severely depressed left ventricular ejection fraction (EF 30 % by Simpson).  EVOLUTION With this information the patient was presented for cardiac surgery
column15: the most likely diagnosis being myxoma. No previous clinical manifestations classically associated with myxomas
column16: such as weight loss or fever
column17: were found. She only presented progressive dyspnoea
column18: which we attributed mainly to the double mitral lesion caused by the myxoma. The myxoma was removed from the left atrium without complications. The mitral and tricuspid valves were not damaged
column19: so mitral and tricuspid anuplasty was performed to solve the severe insufficiencies described. Pathological analysis of the atrial mass revealed a myxoma measuring 9 × 7 × 4 cm with patches of calcification and thrombi on its surface.  DIAGNOSIS Giant atrial myxoma with embolic phenomenon. Severe mitral stenosis and mitral insufficiency secondary to myxoma. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History 84-year-old patient
column3: with no known pharmacological allergies and a personal history of: arterial hypertension (AHT) of long evolution; diabetes mellitus (DM) type 2 of 8 years of evolution
column4: with diabetic retinopathy
column5: in treatment with oral antidiabetics; chronic renal disease stage 4 of arteriosclerotic origin due to AHT and DM of long evolution (usual creatinine 2 mg/dl; estimated GFR CKD-EPI 29 mL/min/1.73 m2); benign prostatic hyperplasia and operated on for left inguinal herniorrhaphy.  Present illness The patient presented two episodes of syncope in the last 12 hours
column6: with prodrome (general malaise and nausea without vomiting) and subsequent loss of consciousness lasting about 10 seconds with subsequent recovery without post-critical state. Associated sphincter relaxation. No tonic-clonic convulsions or tongue biting. The patient relates the symptoms to possible hypoglycaemia
column7: so he has taken glucose orally without going to a medical centre. In the first episode he suffered cranioencephalic trauma with an incised-contuse wound to the scalp. After the second episode (witnessed by his relatives) he was brought to the emergency department for assessment. The patient reported epigastric pain of approximately one week's duration
column8: episodic
column9: unrelated to ingestion or movement
column10: and associated with nausea. During the anamnesis
column11: the patient presented a new episode of syncope
column12: preceded by nausea and vegetative cortex
column13: lasting a few seconds
column14: with complete recovery of the level of consciousness afterwards
column15: without subsequent confusional state.  Physical examination Vital signs: BP 120/57 mmHg. HR 80 bpm. Ta 36.5°C. SatO2 97 %. Capillary blood glucose 320. Conscious. Orientation. Normal colour. Normohydrated. Eupneic. No jugular ingurgitation. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic heart sounds without murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation: normal vesicular murmur. Abdomen: soft
column16: depressible
column17: not painful on palpation
column18: normal peristalsis. Lower extremities: no oedema or signs of deep vein thrombosis.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG 1 (performed in the emergency department): sinus rhythm at 60 bpm. Second-degree atrioventricular block
column19: Mobitz 1. ST suprasystolic level in II
column20: III
column21: aVF with a decrease in I and aVL. ECG 2 (performed in the ED): sinus rhythm at 60 bpm. Second-degree atrioventricular block
column22: Mobitz 1. ST elevation in II
column23: III
column24: aVF with a decrease in I and aV; somewhat less marked than in previous ECG. Emergency laboratory tests: troponin I 10.46 ng/ml. Myoglobin 400 ng/ml. ProBNP 10400 pg/ml. Glucose 315 mg/dl. Urea 90 mg/dl. Creatinine 2.21 mg/dl. Chlorine 102 mEq/l. Sodium 135 mEq/l. Potassium 4.8 mEq/l. Leukocytes 17
column26: 400 neutrophils). Hb 11.9 g/dl. VCM 98. Prothrombin activity 85 %. Cranial CT scan: centred midline. Corticosubcortical atrophy according to age. Calcification of epiphysis and choroid plexus. No signs suggestive of bleeding or other significant radiological alterations. Urgent coronary angiography: left main coronary artery (LMCA): no angiographic disease. Anterior descending (AD): very severe lesion (90-95%) in the proximal segment encompassing the origin of the first diagonal
column27: with significant disease in the middle segment. Distal bed with significant localised patchy involvement. Circumflex (CX): severe proximal disease (85-90 %). Distal bed formed by three left marginal branches
column28: two of them with significant proximal ostial disease. Right coronary (RC): dominant. Moderate proximal and medial diffuse disease. Acute thrombotic occlusive lesion involving middle segment and first elbow
column29: both calcified. Distal TIMI 1-2 flow. After opening it
column30: a diffusely diseased distal segment with limited calibre was observed. Percutaneous coronary intervention: predilatation with low-pressure balloon with good results
column31: implantation of two drug-eluting stents in tandem. Embolisation to the distal segment
column32: treated with repeated intracoronary nitroprusside boluses and multi-segment low-pressure balloon dilatation. Contained dissection in proximal segment of most proximal stent treated with another drug-eluting stent in tandem. Good final result with TIMI 3 in the entire vessel with recovery of sinus rhythm with first-degree atrioventricular block. Transthoracic echocardiogram: normal sized left ventricle with preserved global LVEF. Akinesia of the basal and middle segments of the inferior wall and hypokinesia of the apical inferior segment. Mild diastolic dysfunction
column33: with increased LVEDP. Mild MI. Normal aortic valve. Minimal TR with mild-moderate pulmonary hypertension. No pericardial effusion. ECG at discharge: sinus rhythm at 67 bpm. First degree AV block. Q waves in inferior face.  EVOLUTION After the syncope presented in the anamnesis
column34: once the patient had recovered
column35: an ECG was performed which showed Mobitz I grade 2 AV block (AVB) with ST supralow leveling in the inferior face
column36: so the patient was monitored with a defibrillator-monitor and an infarction code was activated with a diagnosis of STEACS in the inferior face. An urgent cranial CT scan was performed to rule out post-traumatic cranioencephalic haemorrhage and therapy was started with loading doses of double platelet antiplatelet therapy with aspirin and clopidogrel. Urgent coronary angiography was requested. While the patient was being monitored
column37: he suffered a new syncope lasting seconds and the monitor showed transient evidence of high-grade atrioventricular block (phases of second-degree AVB type Mobitz II)
column38: which subsequently reverted to grade 2 AVB Mobitz I. Urgent coronary angiography was performed
column39: which revealed an acute thrombotic occlusive lesion in the right coronary artery
column40: responsible for the symptoms
column41: and percutaneous coronary intervention was performed with the implantation of 3 drug-eluting stents after balloon dilatation. The transthoracic echocardiogram after the episode showed a left ventricle of normal size
column42: with preserved ejection fraction and the ECG at discharge showed sinus rhythm at 67 beats per minute
column43: first-degree atrioventricular block and Q waves in the inferior face. Given the recovery of the atrioventricular block after coronary reperfusion
column44: pacemaker implantation was not necessary. Subsequently
column45: the case was discussed with haemodynamics to consider revascularisation of the severe lesions of the anterior descending and circumflex arteries
column46: and conservative treatment was decided given the absence of angina
column47: anaemia
column48: chronic renal disease and diffuse distal involvement of the LAD. The patient is currently being followed up in cardiology consultations
column49: with good quality of life and absence of angina with medical treatment.  DIAGNOSIS Acute coronary syndrome with ST-segment elevation (STEACS) inferoposterior Killip I. Right coronary artery with acute thrombotic occlusive lesion in mid-distal segment. Percutaneous coronary intervention with implantation of 3 drug-eluting stents in tandem. Grade 2 Mobitz i atrioventricular block with phases of high-grade atrioventricular block of ischaemic origin due to involvement of the right coronary artery. After revascularisation: first-degree atrioventricular block. Syncope of cardiogenic origin with cranioencephalic trauma
column50: without acute cerebral haemorrhagic lesions. Incised-contuse scalp injury. Severe ischaemic multivessel multi-segment ischaemic heart disease. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION Female patient aged 43 years
column3: without CVRF or toxic habits. No medical or cardiological history
column4: without taking regular medication.  Present illness She presented with syncope during her work activity
column5: preceded by a feeling of dizziness and instability with rapid recovery afterwards. He began with central thoracic oppression and interscapular irradiation
column6: haemodynamic instability
column7: with an electrocardiogram suggestive of LMCA involvement. A chest CT scan was requested which ruled out acute aortic syndrome
column8: the Infarction Code was activated
column9: a loading dose was administered (ASA 300 mg and ticagrelor 180 mg) and the patient was referred to the reference hospital for urgent coronary angiography.  Physical examination (on arrival at the haemodynamics ward) Poor general condition. Conscious and oriented
column10: generalised pallor. Tachypnoea
column11: sweating
column12: hypoperfused BP 60/40 mmHg
column13: HR 120 bpm. SatO2 (with Oxiplus at 8 litres): 92 %. Afebrile. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic without audible murmurs
column14: tachycardic. Pulmonary auscultation: bilateral crackles up to midfields. Abdomen: soft
column15: depressible
column16: non-painful
column17: no masses or megaliths
column18: no signs of peritoneal irritation
column19: no oedema or indirect signs of DVT.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG (initial): sinus rhythm
column20: PR 0
column21: 18. Axis 60 o. ST elevation suggestive of subepicardial lesion up to 3 mm in I
column22: avL
column23: V5 (V6 without elevation due to probable artefact
column24: V6 poorly positioned). Concomitant ST-segment elevation in inferior face up to 4 mm. Blood tests: cardiac markers (peak numbers) Trop I 56.39
column25: myoglobin 300
column26: proBNP 9500. Biochemistry: glucose 140 mg/dl
column27: urea 24
column28: creatinine 0.62 mg/dl
column29: Chlorine 99 mEq/l
column31: K 4.6 mEq/l. Thyroid function: TSH 6
column32: 30. T4L 0.89. Iron metabolism: ferritin 265.9
column33: transferrin 250
column34: SatTf 15.4 %. Vitamin B12 and folic acid normal. Autoimmunity and coagulation studies negative. Haemogram: 25
column35: 500 leucocytes
column36: Hb 12.2 g/dl
column39: 000 platelets. Coronary angiography: aortography: no images suggestive of acute aortic syndrome. Coronary angiography: right dominance. Left main coronary artery (LMCA): subocclusion compatible with spontaneous mid-distal dissection involving the ostium of the anterior descending (LAD) and proximal segment of the CX. Anterior descending: except ostial dissection
column40: vessel of good calibre and development without lesions
column41: initial flow TIMI 1-2. Cx: ostial and proximal dissection involving first marginal (Mo) of small entity. Second Mo of good development without lesions. Right coronary: no significant angiographic lesions. Percutaneous coronary interventionism: PCI on LMCA: during the procedure he presented sustained ventricular tachycardia at 160 bpm
column42: with haemodynamic instability
column43: which required synchronised CVE at 100 J with success. Synergy 4 x 24 mm direct drug-eluting stent was implanted in the LMCA with good results
column44: TIMI 3 flow in the LAD
column45: with angiographic improvement of the ostial-proximal CX. It was decided to finalise the procedure by implanting an intra-aortic balloon counterpulsation device (IABP) and noradrenaline perfusion.  Transthoracic echocardiogram (at discharge): LV slightly dilated (LVEDD 54 mm). Severe systolic dysfunction (LVEF estimated by Simpson "s 30%). Medial and apical septal akinesia and all apical segments
column46: medial lateral (these segments being thinned). Inferoapical dyskinetic aneurysm. Medial lateral and anterior medial hypokinesia. Rest of segments contractility preserved. Pseudonormal diastolic pattern
column47: without current data of elevated preload. Left atrium of normal dimensions. Normal right chambers
column48: RV normocontractile. Normal aortic root and visualised portion of proximal ascending aorta. MV: thin leaflets
column49: mild central reflux. VAo: trivalva
column50: thin leaflets
column51: competent. Minimal TR. IVC not dilated with inspiratory collapse. Estimated normal PAPs. Slight pericardial effusion adjacent to the right cavities
column52: with no current signs of haemodynamic echocardiographic compromise. Intravenous contrast was administered which ruled out the presence of apical thrombus
column53: but slow flow in the area of inferoapical aneurysm.  EVOLUTION Admitted to the coronary ICU in cardiogenic shock and acute pulmonary oedema requiring high-dose inotropic support
column54: non-invasive mechanical ventilation (NIV) and IABP
column55: presenting at the acute moment with SVT and haemodynamic instability requiring effective ECV. Slow and progressive clinical improvement allowed withdrawal of IABP and lowering of inotrope
column56: with a control echocardiogram in ICU showing moderate LV dysfunction (low intravenous inotrope)
column57: with no secondary mechanical complications. During his stay on the ward
column58: he was clinically stable
column59: with no arrhythmic events. A repeat echocardiogram at discharge showed severe LV dysfunction
column60: with akinesia of apical segments
column61: inferoapical dyskinetic aneurysm
column62: with no evidence of systemic congestion or significant valvular heart disease. She presented fair blood pressure figures that prevented treatment with ACE inhibitors and beta-blockers
column63: so ivabradine was started for optimal heart rate control; double antiplatelet therapy was maintained for at least one year
column64: eplerenone and diuretics at low doses
column65: and she was discharged. A new control echocardiogram was performed in 40 days with no improvement in echocardiographic data
column66: so it was decided to implant a subcutaneous ICD for primary prevention. She continued to be reviewed by the Heart Failure and Cardiac Rehabilitation Unit
column67: with current functional class II/IV NYHA.  DIAGNOSIS Acute coronary syndrome with ST segment elevation (STEACS) anterolateral Killip IV. Spontaneous coronary artery dissection of LMCA to LAD and CX. Percutaneous coronary intervention on LMCA-AD (1 drug-eluting stent). Severe LV dysfunction with contractile segmental asymmetries. Subcutaneous ICD implantation for primary prevention. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
