Two hypermetabolic foci were identified in the colon
column53: one in the descending colon (SUVmax 8.09) and the other in the sigma (SUVmax 9.13)
column54: which we recommend evaluating by colonoscopy to rule out malignant tumour pathology. Doppler ultrasound of supra-aortic trunks: Left carotid axis with a small plaque at the level of the bulb
column55: predominantly fibrolipid
column56: with a smooth and regular surface
column57: which does not cause haemodynamic alterations. Normal flows in left CCA
column58: ICA and CEA. Right carotid axis with normal echostructure. Vertebral arteries permeable and orthodromic. Abdominal X-ray: dilated large bowel loops with an image suggestive of cecal volvulus in the right hypochondrium.  Computed tomography of the abdomen: cecal volvulus
column59: probably partial
column60: of the cecal scale type. Mural endoluminal polyps in the splenic angle of the colon
column61: measuring 15 mm
column62: and in the rectosigmoid junction
column63: measuring 11 mm
column64: both with uptake in the previous PET-CT study. Radiological improvement of the signs of vasculitis of the celiac trunk and superior and inferior mesenteric arteries. A more prominent perivascular cuff persists in the primitive and external iliac vessels with probably significant stenosis of femoral arteries. Colonoscopy: the ileum is reached. In the cecum there are aphthae arranged in a linear fashion
column65: covered with fibrin compatible with ischaemic colitis. Two polyps were observed: one of them measuring about 15 mm in the descending colon. No other lesions were observed. Biopsy of skin
column66: subcutaneous cellular tissue
column67: muscle and sural nerve: non-specific inflammatory findings with no evidence of vasculitis. Electroneurography/electromyography: patchy involvement of motor and sensory fibres of the right ulnar
column68: peroneal and tibial nerves suggesting mononeuritis multiplex. Echocardiography at discharge: severely dilated left ventricle (indexed VTD 158 ml/m2). Akinesia with thinning of all apical segments. Medial anterior akinesia and medial anterior
column69: medial anterolateral and medial inferolateral septum. Medial inferior hypokinesia and basal inferior septum. Severe systolic dysfunction (biplane Simpson calculation with Sonovue LVEF 25%). No apical thrombus after echocontrast injection. Restrictive pattern diastolic dysfunction with elevated filling pressures. Severe left atrial dilatation. Mild right atrial dilatation. Normal sized right ventricle with preserved function. Severe functional mitral regurgitation. Thin leaflets with symmetrical tenting of the leaflets. Central regurgitant jet with dense
column70: wide
column71: holosystolic flow with severe regurgitation. ERO 0.6 cm2. Mild aortic insufficiency. Mild tricuspid insufficiency. Pulmonary hypertension at rest.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION In the coronary unit
column72: amiodarone perfusion and oxygen therapy with high-flow glasses was started
column73: achieving clinical stabilisation in the first 24 hours
column74: with reversion of flutter to sinus rhythm at 90 bpm
column75: negative balances of almost 3 litres and marked clinical improvement. The first echocardiography and coronary angiography were performed. In view of the catheterisation findings
column76: an assessment was requested from the internal medicine department with the suspicion of a vasculitic condition as the cause of the coronary lesions. That same day
column77: treatment was started with corticosteroid boluses
column78: oral prednisone and later methotrexate as an immunosuppressant. From the clinical point of view
column79: the patient was admitted for a very long time
column80: with a hospital stay of almost 40 days. Cardiologically
column81: the patient showed a rapid and favourable evolution during the first week and was discharged to the conventional hospital ward. However
column82: on the seventh day of admission (after the PET scan)
column83: he presented an arrhythmic storm with three episodes of sustained ventricular tachycardia that required electrical cardioversion and multiple non-sustained episodes. For this reason
column84: he had to be transferred again to the coronary unit and was started on lidocaine perfusion
column85: midazolam and beta-blocker with a good response. He did not suffer any more arrhythmic events and presented a slow but adequate evolution of his heart failure. During the second week
column86: the patient suffered a paralytic ileus
column87: with suspicion of associated cecal volvulus (which was the reason for requesting an abdominal CT scan and colonoscopy) which improved with digestive rest
column88: nasogastric tube and antibiotic treatment without the need for surgery. Lastly
column89: it should be mentioned that on admission the patient had very severe skin involvement
column90: with erythroderma secondary to his psoriasis
column91: as well as involvement of the hands and feet with signs of poor perfusion that slowly improved with medical treatment. As for the aetiological diagnosis
column92: computed tomography angiography showed lesions suspicious of vasculitis in the visceral arteries and in both iliac arteries without involvement of the supra-aortic trunks. The complete blood test showed a rather anodyne result with elevation of several non-specific inflammatory markers (CRP
column93: ferritin
column94: complement
column95: IL-6...) but with negative results in the key tests (ENA
column96: ANCA
column97: cryoglobulins
column98: antiphospholipid antibodies
column99: HBV
column100: HCV and HIV serology...). In view of the results
column101: PET-CT was ordered in the hope of confirming inflammation data at the vascular level to support the presumptive diagnosis (at that time Takayasu-type large vessel vasculitis was the main candidate). However
column102: the absence of uptake in the supra-aortic trunks ruled out this pathology. Following this setback
column103: multiple diagnostic studies were requested with the intention of confirming medium-vessel vasculitis (mainly polyarteritis nodosa
column104: PAN). A skin
column105: subcutaneous tissue and nerve biopsy was performed
column106: as well as an electromyogram/electroneurogram. It is worth mentioning that the initial intention was to perform a direct arterial biopsy of the iliac/femoral territory (a territory known to be affected by the scan data). However
column107: this option was discarded following vascular surgery assessment which considered
column108: given the calibre of the vessels involved
column109: that the risk of complications (ischaemia and/or haemorrhage) was too high. The biopsy found no data suggestive of vasculitis
column110: but the electromyogram showed a pattern of mononeuritis multiplex
column111: very typical of PAN. The clinical course was favourable and he was discharged after implantation of an automatic defibrillator (ICD) for secondary prevention. As for the diagnosis
column112: it was concluded (given the vascular involvement
column113: the multiple mononeuritis and the improvement with anti-inflammatory drugs) that the most likely cause of the patient's clinical picture was polyarteritis nodosa. However
column114: given the multiple cardiovascular risk factors (including cocaine use)
column115: early atherosclerosis was always considered as a possible alternative. She was discharged with immunosuppressive and steroid treatment
column118: statins and full medical treatment of heart failure
column119: to continue outpatient follow-up in the advanced heart failure unit.  DIAGNOSIS PAN type vasculitis with coronary
column121: mesenteric and femoral involvement. Ischaemic dilated cardiomyopathy with severe left ventricular dysfunction. Heart failure in acute pulmonary oedema on admission
column122: euvolemic on discharge. Non-revascularisable three-vessel coronary artery disease (diffuse arterial disease compatible with vasculitis). Arrhythmic storm. ICD implantation in secondary prevention. Uncommon atrial flutter with rapid ventricular response
column123: pharmacological cardioversion to sinus rhythm. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History Cardiovascular risk factors: arterial hypertension (AHT). Dyslipidaemia. Obesity. Diabetes mellitus type 2. Smoker of 20 cigarettes/day. Chronic alcoholism 8 UBEs/day. Persistent atrial fibrillation anticoagulated with acenocoumarol. Other history: chronic bronchitis without obstructive pattern
column3: sleep apnoea hypopnoea syndrome (SAHS) in treatment with nocturnal continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP). Usual treatment: glimepiride 2 mg/day
column4: metformin/dapagliflozin 850/5 mg every 12 hours
column5: atorvastatin 30 mg every 24 hours
column6: acetylsalicylic acid 100 mg per day
column7: spironolactone 25 mg per day
column8: amlodipine 5 mg per day
column9: acenocoumarol as prescribed
column10: bisoprolol 2.5 mg every 24 hours
column11: furosemide 40 mg every 24 hours
column12: omeprazole 20 mg daily
column13: indacaterol/glycopyrronium bromide 85/43 mcg 1 capsule inhaled every 24 hours.  Present illness A 57-year-old patient attended the emergency department with worsening functional class to the point of presenting dyspnoea on minimal effort
column14: orthopnoea
column15: episodes of paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea
column16: subjective decrease in diuresis and oedema associated with weight gain.  Physical examination Weight 108 kg
column17: height 1.71 m. Body mass index (BMI) 36.9 kg/m2. Blood pressure (BP) 178/92 mmHg. Heart rate (HR) 138 bpm. Oxygen saturation (SatO2) 90% with nasal goggles at 2 l/min (FiO2 28%). Tachypneic at rest. Jugular venous pressure increased. Positive hepatojugular reflex. Cardiac auscultation: irregular
column18: no murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation: bibasal hypophonesis of right predominance with scattered rhonchi. Extremities: tibiomalleolar oedema up to the root of the thighs and in the upper limbs. Peripheral pulses were preserved and symmetrical.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG on arrival at the ED: atrial fibrillation at 130 bpm. Narrow QRS. AXIS: 0o. Poor progression of the septal vector in precordial leads. No repolarisation alterations.  CBC: haemoglobin 10.4 g/dl
column19: haematocrit 30%
column20: platelets 344
column22: leukocytes 7400/μl. International normalised ratio (INR) 1.8. Basal blood glucose 260 mg/dl. Urea 27 mg/dl
column23: creatinine 0.81 mg/dl
column24: sodium 134 mEq/l
column25: potassium 3.7 mEq/l. HbA1C: 8.6%. Biomarkers of myocardial damage (normal value range 0.0-11.6 ng/l): troponin I (hsTnI) 28 ng/l --> 33 ng/l. proBNP 2680 pg/ml. CA125 474 IU/ml. RT-PCR for SARS-CoV2: negative. Iron metabolism: ferritin 78 mcg/l
column26: IST 4.5%.  Chest X-ray: centred cardiomediastinal silhouette. Cardiothoracic index greater than 0.5. Bilateral interstitial infiltrate with apical vascular redistribution. Bilateral pleural effusion
column27: predominantly on the right.  Echocardiograms: Echocardiogram on admission: left ventricle of increased diameters and volumes with moderate ventricular dysfunction secondary to generalised hypokinesia (LVEF 37%). Aortic root normal diameters. Dilated left atrium. Mild mitral insufficiency (MI). Normal filling pressures. Dilated right ventricle with depressed systolic function. Mild-moderate tricuspid insufficiency (TI) allowing estimation of systolic pulmonary artery pressure (PAPS) at 45 mmHg. Absence of pericardial effusion. Dilated inferior vena cava (IVC) without inspiratory collapse greater than 50%. No images compatible with thrombus in the left atrial appendage. Study performed in atrial fibrillation. Control echocardiography 3 months after discharge: left ventricle with increased diameters and volumes with preserved global systolic function (LVEF 55%). Aortic root normal diameters. Dilated left atrium. Mild MI. Normal filling pressures. Right ventricle of normal diameters with normal systolic function. Mildly moderate TR allowing estimation of PAPS at 40 mmHg. Absence of pericardial effusion. IVC of normal diameters with inspiratory collapse greater than 50%. Study performed in sinus rhythm.  Haemodynamics: coronary angiography during admission. Epicardial coronary arteries with diffuse atheromatosis without significant stenosis.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION A patient with decompensated heart failure with ventricular dysfunction of probable multifactorial aetiology
column28: who presented atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response
column29: left atrial appendage thrombus was ruled out by transesophageal echocardiography and two ineffective electrical cardioversions were performed. Coronary angiography was performed and no significant stenosis was observed. Treatment was administered with high-dose bolus intravenous diuretics
column31: braking treatment with beta-blockers and oral treatment to prevent alcohol deprivation syndrome. Good clinical and diuretic response during admission. Difficult to control blood glucose and blood pressure. Discharged 9 days after admission paucisymptomatic and in atrial fibrillation with controlled ventricular response. Treatment at discharge: metformin/dapagliflozin 850/5 mg every 12 hours
column32: atorvastatin 30 mg every 24 hours
column33: acetylsalicylic acid 100 mg daily
column34: amlodipine 5 mg daily
column35: rivaroxaban 20 mg daily
column36: bisoprolol 2.5 mg every 24 hours
column37: furosemide 80 mg every 24 hours
column38: omeprazole 20 mg daily
column39: indacaterol/glycopyrronium bromide 85/43 mcg 1capsule inhaled every 24 hours
column40: amiodarone 200 mg daily
column41: eplerenone 50 mg daily
column42: sacubitrile/valsartan 24/26 mg every 12 hours
column43: clomethiazole 192 mg every 12 hours
column44: semaglutide 0.25 mg once a week for four weeks
column45: then 0.5 mg once a week for four weeks and then 1 mg once a week. He attended a follow-up appointment with the local cardiology department 3 months later
column46: with improvement in functional class (NYHA I)
column47: smoking cessation and alcohol abstinence. Physical examination revealed significant weight loss (12 kg) and no signs of congestion. Complementary tests showed sinus rhythm
column48: HbA1C decreased to 7.2% and proBNP 86.8 pg/ml. Echocardiography showed increased diameters and preserved global systolic function. Subsequent follow-up was asymptomatic from the cardiovascular point of view
column49: with good glycaemic control (HbA1C 6.2%) and no recurrence of atrial fibrillation.  DIAGNOSIS Decompensated heart failure with depressed LVEF. Dilated cardiomyopathy (tachycardiomyopathy versus enolic). Persistent atrial fibrillation. Obesity. Type 2 diabetes mellitus. HYPERTENSION. Dyslipidaemia. Iron deficiency. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History Cardiovascular risk factors (CVRF): diabetes mellitus
column3: ex-smoker
column4: dyslipidaemia. Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma
column5: treated with chemotherapy 10 years ago
column6: in complete remission. Chronic heart failure: non-ischemic dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM)
column7: LVEF 33%
column8: generalised hypokinesia.  Current disease A 63 year-old male under follow-up by the heart failure unit of our hospital for dilated cardiomyopathy of non-ischaemic aetiology. The patient is in NYHA II
column9: with no signs of peripheral congestion.  In the successive analytical controls since the consultation
column10: absolute iron deficiency (ferritin 84 ng/ml and STAT 13%) and Hb of 13 g/dl were observed. Normal renal function: creatinine 0.84 mg/dl
column11: GFR 85.94 ml/min/1.73 m2
column12: and Nt-proBNP 3
column13: 657 pg/ml. The patient was included in the protocol for the study of iron deficiency in patients with HF and reduced LVEF.  Chronic treatment: insulin Toujeo 50 IU/day
column14: metformin/empagliflozin 1000/12.5 mg/12 h
column15: sacubitril/valsartan 49/51 mg/12 h
column16: bisoprolol 5 mg/day
column17: furosemide 40 mg/day and eplerenone 12.5 mg/day.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS As part of the study protocol
column18: the following tests were performed: Baseline echocardiogram: left ventricle of normal diameters (LVEDD 48 mm)
column19: without hypertrophy of its walls and with severe depression of global systolic function (EF 35%) secondary to generalised hypokinesia. Aortic root of normal diameter with sigmoids of normal thickness and opening. There is no evidence of valve dysfunction. Mitral valve with leaflets of normal thickness and mobility. Trivial mitral insufficiency. LV diastolic pattern suggestive of impaired relaxation (E/A 0.7) with normal estimated filling pressures (E/e' 9). Normal sized atria. Non-dilated right ventricle with slightly depressed systolic function. No tricuspid insufficiency (TI). Absence of pericardial effusion. Global longitudinal strain (GLS) of -12.2%. Baseline cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR): left ventricle with preserved wall thickness
column20: slightly increased diastolic volume (IVTDVI 97 ml/m2; IVTSVI 64 ml/m2) and severely depressed global systolic function (LVEF 34%)
column21: secondary to generalised hypokinesia. Right ventricle with preserved morphology and volumes (IVTDVD 75 ml/m2; IVTSVD 38 ml/m2) and slightly depressed systolic function (LVEF 49%). Left atrium of size at the upper limit: 39 mm
column22: 26 cm2
column23: 15 cm2/m2. Aorta and great vessels of normal diameter and morphology. Bilateral pleural effusion. T1 myocardium: 1082 ms. T2* myocardium: 35 ms. Electrocardiogram (ECG): sinus rhythm at 95 bpm
column24: PR 160 ms
column25: narrow QRS
column26: normal axis. Atrial extrasystoles.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION According to protocol
column28: 000 mg of intravenous iron carboxymaltose (Ferinject ®) was administered weekly for 2 weeks
column29: and after confirming normalisation of the iron profile with analytical tests
column30: a new structural assessment was performed. CMR after 4 weeks of iron treatment: left ventricle with preserved wall thickness and diastolic volume (IVTDVI 84 ml/m2; IVTSVI 48 ml/m2). Moderately depressed global systolic function (LVEF 43%)
column31: secondary to generalised hypokinesia. Right ventricle of preserved morphology and volumes (IVTDVD 65 ml/m2; IVTSVD 30 ml/m2) and borderline systolic function (LVEF 54%). Left atrium of normal size: 34 mm
column32: 23 cm2
column33: 13 cm2/m2. Aorta and great vessels of normal diameter and morphology. T1 myocardium: 1037 ms T2* myocardium: 38 ms. There was significant improvement in LV ejection fraction estimated by CMR (LVEF 43% at 30 days)

column1: We present the case of a 71-year-old patient diagnosed with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction of ischaemic aetiology
column2: who was admitted for an episode of decompensation. During his stay
column3: he underwent global management beyond diuretic therapy
column4: which led to an improvement in his functional class.  HISTORY
column5: CURRENT DISEASE AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History Cardiovascular risk factors (CVRF): hypertension and dyslipidaemia. No toxic habits. Permanent atrial fibrillation (AF) anticoagulated with acenocoumarol. Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction of ischaemic aetiology. Acute non-ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) in 2002 with three-vessel disease and severe ventricular dysfunction without improvement after complete surgical revascularisation in June 2002. Implantable defibrillator with cardiac resynchronisation therapy (ICD-CRT) in primary prevention since 2016. Last TTE performed in consultation (01/2021): severely dilated left ventricle with severe systolic dysfunction (LVEF by Simpson biplane: 24.5%). Septal
column6: apical
column7: inferior and inferolateral akinesia. Anterior and lateral hypokinesia. Severe mitral insufficiency (MI) of probable mixed mechanism. Severe dilatation of the right ventricle (RV) with preserved function. Severe dilatation of both atria. Moderate aortic stenosis. Moderate tricuspid insufficiency (TI) grade III. Estimated systolic pulmonary artery pressure (SPAP) of 50 mmHg. Peripheral arterial disease assessed by vascular surgery with no need for follow-up. Hyperuricaemia. Usual treatment: furosemide 40 mg (2 tablets daily)
column8: eplerenone 25 mg (1 tablet at lunch)
column9: valsartan 80 mg (half a day)
column10: carvedilol 3.25 mg (at breakfast and dinner)
column11: acenocoumarol as prescribed
column12: atorvastatin 20 mg (at dinner)
column13: nitrate patch 5 mg
column14: allopurinol 300 mg (at dinner)
column15: omeprazole 20 mg (at breakfast).  Current disease Previously in functional class (FC) I-II
column16: he reported increasing dyspnoea until minimal effort
column17: associated with orthopnoea and episodes of paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea (PND). In addition
column18: oliguria
column19: oedematisation of the lower extremities (LES) and weight gain. He relates the worsening to the reduction of valsartan doses a few weeks ago due to recurrent episodes of hypotension. Physical examination Weight 88.5 kg (dry weight not recorded)
column20: height 1.65m. Body mass index (BMI) 32 kg/m2. Blood pressure (BP) 109/84 mmHg
column21: heart rate (HR) 108 bpm
column22: oxygen saturation breathing room air 96%
column23: afebrile. Eupneic at rest
column24: slight increase in jugular pressure
column25: absent hepatojugular reflux. Cardiac auscultation irregular and without murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation: bibasal crackles. Extremities with bimalleolar oedema. Peripheral pulses weak but preserved and symmetrical.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Electrocardiogram (ECG) on arrival at the emergency department: atrial fibrillation at 80 bpm
column26: ventricular pacing mediated by ICD-CRT. Chest X-ray: mild cardiomegaly (cardiothoracic index [CTI] 0.52)
column27: mild vascular redistribution
column28: ICD-CRT generator and electrodes normally positioned
column29: without costophrenic sinus impingement. Blood tests on admission: haemoglobin 13.3 g/dl
column31: platelets 103000 /Ul. Biochemistry: glucose 86 mg/dl
column32: creatinine 1.26 mg/dl
column33: urea 48 mg/dl
column34: estimated glomerular filtration rate 57 ml/min/1.73 m2
column35: sodium 137 mg/dl
column36: potassium 3.6 mg/dl
column37: total bilirubin 4.2 mg/dl
column38: direct bilirubin 3.2
column39: lactate dehydrogenase 241 U/l
column40: alanine aminotransferase (ALT) 20
column41: total protein 44 g/l
column42: albumin 36 g/l. TSH 2.16 mU/l. Troponin T 46 ng/l-> 50 ng/l (< 14 ng/l). NT-proBNP 2154 pg/l (< 300 pg/l). Ferrokinetic profile: iron 87 uG/dl (59-156)
column43: transferrin saturation index 23% (16-45)
column44: ferritin 90 ng/ml (30-400). Transesophageal echocardiography performed during admission: severe ischaemic mitral insufficiency. Posterior leaflet of 7 mm. Thrombus in left atrial appendage. Moderate IT grade III. Moderate aortic stenosis with AVA of 1.3. IT signal allows estimating PAPS of 54 mmHg.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION On admission
column45: intravenous furosemide was started with a good diuretic response. In addition
column46: given the elevation of direct bilirubin
column47: abdominal ultrasound was requested
column48: which revealed liver stasis in the context of heart failure. The CRT device was checked and the pacing % was found to be in an adequate range.  Transesophageal echocardiography was requested to expand studies on the severe MI described in the last transthoracic echocardiography performed in consultations
column49: which confirmed the severity of the Ml of ischaemic origin and visualised an image compatible with thrombus in the left atrial appendage. The patient had normal haemoglobin levels
column50: with normal iron and transferrin saturation index
column51: but ferritin less than 100 ng/l. In this context
column52: in view of the iron deficiency situation
column53: it was decided to start iron therapy with an infusion of 1
column54: 000 mg of iron carboxymaltose. During admission
column55: she showed clinical improvement with a loss of up to 5 kg compared to her admission weight after diuretic therapy and great symptomatic improvement. Throughout his hospital stay
column56: his blood pressure was around 100/70 mmHg
column57: with symptoms of orthostasis when attempting to increase anti-humoral therapy
column58: so it was decided not to start sacubitril/valsartan. Finally
column59: he was discharged with a change of valsartan to losartan 25 mg
column60: bisoprolol 1.25 mg (at breakfast and dinner) instead of carvedilol
column61: and discontinuation of acenocoumarol and start of edoxaban 60 mg (daily) together with furosemide 40 mg (2 tablets daily)
column62: eplerenone 25 mg (1 tablet at lunch)
column63: atorvastatin 20 mg (at dinner)
column64: allopurinol 300 mg (at dinner)
column65: omeprazole 20 mg (at breakfast). In addition
column66: an outpatient cardiac CT scan was requested to assess the viability of implanting a Tendyne prosthesis as a treatment for mitral insufficiency and to evaluate the persistence of thrombus in the left atrial appendage after correct oral anticoagulation. One month after discharge and after 3 weeks in NYHA functional class I
column67: the patient came for a check-up. He presented blood tests showing sudden anaemisation with haemoglobin levels of 10.5; in addition
column68: the patient reported clinical manifestations of melena since discharge. It was decided to request invasive studies to investigate the aetiology of the anaemia
column69: with gastroscopy and colonoscopy
column70: which were normal. The patient is currently awaiting capsule endoscopy.  DIAGNOSIS Heart failure with reduced EF of ischaemic aetiology with episode of decompensation due to systemic congestion. Severe ischaemic mitral regurgitation. Moderate grade III tricuspid regurgitation. Ferropenia with normal haemoglobin levels. Permanent atrial fibrillation. Thrombus in left atrial appendage. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History This is a 72-year-old man with multiple cardiovascular risk factors (CVRF) (hypertension
column3: type 2 diabetes mellitus
column4: hypercholesterolemia
column5: ex-smoker)
column6: permanent atrial fibrillation anticoagulated with warfarin (previously with acenocoumarol; the anticoagulant was changed in 2017 after finding a thrombus in the left atrial appendage despite correct INR levels) and rheumatic valve disease with valve replacement in 2004 with mechanical prostheses in mitral and aortic position
column7: without significant lesions in pre-surgical coronary angiography and with a subsequent LVEF of 30%. During follow-up
column8: he presented a tendency towards asymptomatic moderate hyperkalaemia (maximum figure of 6.3 mEq/l) that prevented correct titration of neurohormonal medication
column9: remaining in NYHA functional class III/IV. In September 2019
column10: he attended the emergency department due to worsening of his usual dyspnoea to minimal effort
column11: orthopnoea
column12: bendopnoea
column13: decreased diuresis rate and the appearance of oedema in the lower limbs.  Physical examination Blood pressure (BP) 110/55 mmHg
column14: heart rate (HR) 90 bpm. Temperature 36.2 oC. Oxygen saturation 95% basal. Acceptable general condition. Conscious
column15: oriented and cooperative. Normal colour
column16: normohydrated and normoperfused. Discreetly tachypnoeic at rest
column17: with intolerance to decubitus.  Cardiac auscultation: arrhythmic heart sounds. Prosthetic metallic clicks. No murmurs were heard. Pulmonary auscultation: bilateral crackles up to midfields
column18: no other superimposed sounds. Lower extremities: symmetrical pulses present and symmetrical. Bilateral pitting oedema up to the knees. No signs of deep vein thrombosis. Current treatment: candesartan 4 mg (0-0-1)
column19: furosemide 40 mg (1-0-1)
column20: simvastatin 20 mg (0-0-1)
column21: bisoprolol 2.5 mg (1-0-1)
column22: warfarin 5 mg as prescribed
column23: metformin 850 mg (0.5-0-0.5)
column24: pantoprazole 20 mg (1-0-0) Given that this was his first episode of decompensation of heart failure
column25: admission to the conventional cardiology ward for depletive treatment and study was decided.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Laboratory tests on admission: haemoglobin 15.1 g/dl (11.4-15.1 g/dl)
column26: creatinine 1.78 mg/dl (0.50-0.90 mg/dl)
column27: glomerular filtration rate (GFR) 41 ml/min/1.73 m2 (> 90 ml/min/1.73 m2)
column28: sodium 139 mEq/l (135-145 mEq/l)
column29: potassium 5.6 mEq/l (135-145 mEq/l)
column31: potassium 5.6 mEq/l (3.50-5.00 mEq/l)
column32: GPT 21 U/l (5-35 U/l)
column33: GOT 22 U/l (5-27 U/l)
column34: NT-proBNP 2651 pg/ml (<= 125 pg/ml)
column35: glycosylated haemoglobin 6.9% (4.0-6.0). Electrocardiogram (ECG) on admission: atrial fibrillation with ventricular response at 85 bpm. Wide QRS with right bundle branch block (RBBB) morphology. Chest X-ray on admission: mid-sternotomy cerclages. Mechanical prosthesis in mitral position. Signs of pulmonary congestion (vascular redistribution
column36: bilateral pleural effusion). Transthoracic echocardiogram: left ventricle (LV) severely dilated (Dd 63 mm
column37: VTD 201 ml
column38: VTDi 118 ml/m2)
column39: with slight concentric hypertrophy. Global hypokinesia. Biplane Simpson LVEF 20%. Right ventricle of borderline size (Dd 40 mm)
column40: with severely depressed global systolic function. Mechanical prosthesis in mitral and aortic position well seated
column41: with normal disc motion
column42: no gradient elevation or periprosthetic insufficiency.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION Intravenous diuretic treatment was started with an excellent response and clear improvement in the congestive signs and symptoms
column43: which led to discharge home after 8 days of hospitalisation. Serial analyses showed normalisation of renal function. In this context
column44: it was decided to start a potassium chelator (patiromer at a minimum dose
column45: i.e. one 8.4 g sachet per day) with the aim of normalising serum potassaemia figures in order to be able to start neurohormonal treatment. Follow-up was initiated in the Transversal Heart Failure Programme of our centre. A blood test was performed one month later
column46: which showed serum potassaemia of 4.1 mEq/l
column47: so it was decided to increase the dose of ARA-II (candesartan 8 mg every 24 hours). On review in consultation (November 2019)
column48: the patient reported improvement in his functional class to NYHA II/IV
column49: with potassium levels remaining in the normal range. Given the good tolerance
column50: it was decided to change to sacubitril/valsartan at low doses (24/26 mg every 12 hours)
column51: with which the improvement in functional class progressed to NYHA I/IV (December 2019): the patient reported that he could walk 2-4 km on level ground
column52: as well as climb slopes and several flights of stairs without having to stop.  As serum potassaemia remains in range
column53: a mineralcorticoid receptor antagonist (low-dose spironolactone) is started. At the next check-up
column54: a new blood test showed slight hyperkalaemia (5.58 mEq/l)
column55: so it was decided to increase the dose of patiromer to two sachets (16.8 g) per day. With this
column56: serum portasium levels were again normalised; at this time (February 2020) the patient was taking sacubitril/valsartan 24/26 mg every 12 hours and spironolactone 25 mg every 24 hours
column57: and it was decided to maintain this treatment unchanged. Due to the SARS-CoV-2 pandemic
column58: he was seen again in September 2020
column59: when he presented serum potassaemia of 6.30 mEq/l
column60: so the patiromer was titrated up to the maximum dose (25.2 g every 24 hours) and the dose of spironolactone was reduced to 12.5 mg every 24 hours. Three months later
column61: potassium levels were at the upper limit of normal (5.19 mEq/l)
column62: so the same treatment was maintained. In January 2021
column63: a control transthoracic echocardiogram was performed
column64: showing an increase in LVEF to 35% and a clear improvement in adverse remodelling with a decrease in ventricular volumes
column65: as well as normalisation of right ventricular function
column66: with the prostheses remaining normal. The patient remains in good functional class (NYHA I-II/IV)
column67: and analytically there was a clear decrease in NT-proBNP during follow-up
column68: with no notable adverse effects.  DIAGNOSIS Chronic heart failure with severely depressed LVEF of valvular origin. Carrier of mechanical prosthetic aortic and mitral valves. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History This is a 66-year-old female patient with no family history of early ischaemic heart disease or sudden death. Mother died of stroke at 73 years of age.  Personal history: No documented drug allergies. Lifestyle: active life
column3: walks 45-60 minutes daily with her group of friends. Currently retired. Previously employed in perfumery. Cardiovascular risk factors: ex-smoker for 25 years (IPA 10 packs/year)
column4: slightly overweight (body mass index 27 kg/m2). No other risk factors. Cardiovascular history: symptomatic non-valvular paroxysmal paroxysmal atrial fibrillation since 2017 (EHRA 3: could not keep up with her companions while walking). No structural heart disease on echocardiogram (left atrium of borderline size and preserved LVEF). Radiofrequency ablation of pulmonary veins was performed in January 2018
column5: still paroxysmal) achieving bidirectional isolation. He presented acute reconnection during the procedure through the ligament of Marshall
column6: successfully ablated in the anterior carina region. During the blanking period she was treated with flecainide 100 mg/12h and dabigatran 150 mg/12h. The patient underwent cardiac rhythm self-measurements every 48 h with a Kardia device and a 24 h Holter at 3 months without evidence of arrhythmic recurrence being documented in any of these controls. Anticoagulation was discontinued due to CHA2DS2VASc 1 point (female) and the antiarrhythmic was progressively reduced until discontinuation. Other history: untreated mild psoriasis. No history of asthma
column7: nor previous need for bronchodilators.   Current illness Since the summer of 2020
column8: she presents clinical deterioration
column9: which she refers to as recurrence of palpitations
column10: mainly with exertion
column11: but also during periods of rest
column12: which she describes as similar to those prior to the diagnosis of atrial fibrillation (AF) and limitation of physical activity with a marked feeling of "tiredness". These episodes have increased in frequency and duration
column13: persisting for several hours. No orthopnoea
column14: paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea (PND) or oedema of the lower extremities. No associated chest pain at rest or on exertion. She has never presented syncopal or presyncopal symptoms. With the suspicion of recurrence of atrial fibrillation
column15: in a first consultation
column16: an electrocardiogram (ECG) in sinus rhythm was performed and the patient was again urged to use her ECG monitoring device when symptoms recurred. Similarly
column17: a new
column18: regular echocardiogram was requested.  Physical examination in consultation Good general condition
column19: blood pressure (BP) 125/60 mmHg
column20: heart rate (HR) 80 bpm. Basal oxygen saturation 99%. Afebrile. Head and neck: no jugular venous engorgement. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic sounds at 75 bpm without murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation: normoventilation in all fields. Abdomen: nondescript. Lower extremities: no oedema or signs of deep vein thrombosis.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Initial ECG consultation: sinus rhythm at 90 bpm
column21: PR 170ms
column22: narrow QRS with normal axis
column23: without repolarisation alterations. Normal QTc. ECG tracings obtained with a closed loop recorder (Kardia)
column24: symptomatic and non-symptomatic: there were several recordings in sinus rhythm and increasingly frequent events labelled as possible atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. When analysing these recordings in detail
column25: there is a clear RR irregularity and absence of P waves
column26: highly suggestive of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular rate. Echocardiogram (performed in sinus rhythm) (video 1): left atrium (LA) slightly dilated (AP diameter at PEL: 41 mm
column27: Vol index: 40 ml/m2). Thin leaflet mitral valve with preserved mobility and opening; mild insufficiency. Diastolic pattern of impaired relaxation
column28: with no increase in filling pressures (E/e ́septal=12). Left ventricle slightly dilated
column29: not hypertrophied (IVS= 11 mm; LVED= 59 mm; PP= 10 mm) with moderately depressed systolic function (biplane LVEF 34%)
column31: without clear segmental alterations. Thin
column32: trivalve aortic valve with good opening and mobility; normal flow (max. v. 1.2 m/s). Valvular annulus and aortic root of normal dimensions. Right ventricle not dilated; preserved contractility (TAPSE= 21 mm). Tricuspid valve with good opening and mobility; minimal regurgitation that does not allow estimation of systolic pulmonary artery pressure (PAPS). Inferior vena cava (IVC) not dilated. No evidence of pulmonary hypertension. No pericardial effusion. Coronary and LA CT scan prior to AF ablation procedure: coronary calcium score 26. Non-invasive coronary angiography: epicardial coronary arteries without angiographically significant lesions. Left atrial study: slight left atrial dilatation (25 cm2). Four pulmonary veins are identified: two left pulmonary veins and two right pulmonary veins. The dimensions of the ostia are: IPSV 19x15 mm; IIPV 18.5x12.2 mm; DPSV 20x15.8 mm and IDPV 17.8x11.6 mm. The oesophagus is 3 mm from the posterior wall of the left venous trunk. There is no persistence of right superior vena cava. Transesophageal echocardiogram during ablation: absence of intracavitary thrombi and left atrial appendage with good flow measured by pulsed Doppler (v: 0.6 m/s). Atrial septum intact with no patent foramen ovale. Left ventricle with mildly moderate depression of contractile function. No pericardial effusion. A first manoeuvre was performed to approach the fossa ovalis with a puncture needle
column33: locating a puncture site somewhat close to the aortic root. Due to this proximity
column34: another approach manoeuvre is performed
column35: placing the needle in a more posterior location (video 3). Finally
column36: transseptal puncture was monitored and passed without complications.  Electrophysiological study and ablation:  Diagnostic mapping assessment of the LA: after effective electrical cardioversion
column37: a detailed mapping of the left atrium is performed. This chamber is accessed via transseptal puncture. Using the navigation system and traversing a large number of points of the atrial wall with the catheter
column38: a reproduction of the volume and geometry of the left atrium is obtained
column39: representing it in three-dimensional form on a computer application that allows virtual mobility of the established geometry in all directions of space. A cartography map of the pulmonary veins is also drawn up using the same technique described above and labelled
column40: establishing the existence of 4 pulmonary veins (2 left and 2 right). In the same way
column41: the mitral valve annulus is conformed and labelled. Reconnection of the left superior pulmonary vein (LSPV) was confirmed
column42: and a pace and map manoeuvre was performed to locate the gap
column43: which was finally located in the posterosuperior region of the LSPV. Voltage mapping of both atria was performed
column44: with no areas of low voltage. A protocol was initiated to assess atrial fibrillation triggers not originating from pulmonary veins by infusion of isoproterenol at increasing doses until reaching 20 mcg/kg. Under this perfusion
column45: frequent extrasystolic activity and small spurts of AT began
column46: mapping early extrasystolic activity as a possible trigger of atrial fibrillation from the posterior roof of the left atrium and superior vena cava
column47: where even an initiation of AF was recorded without catheter contact with the venous wall. Ablation procedure (temperature controlled up to 43 oC and 30W power). An LSI of 5 in posterior zones and 5.5 in anterior zones is limited. Two radiofrequency applications are performed in the posterosuperior region (better pace and map with a venous-atrial conduction time of 50 ms achieving bidirectional isolation in VPSI). Two lines of applications are performed
column48: delimiting a box in the posterior roof
column49: encompassing the focus of the left atrial roof that could not be delimited in its exact location
column50: joining antral ablation lines of previous pulmonary veins that presented conduction block. A total of 21 applications were made between the two lines. Subsequently
column51: electrical isolation was checked by blocking the outflow of this region. Next
column52: in AD
column53: a crown of applications is formed encompassing the superior vena cava
column54: with a total of 27 applications (714 seconds). In applications of the external face of this venous antrum
column55: stimulation is performed at maximum output prior to applications to ensure the absence of phrenic capture and minimise the risk of phrenic paralysis. Effective isolation of the vein is achieved after the last few applications inside the ablation line
column56: in the area of greatest premature extrasystoles. Verification: after 30 minutes of waiting
column57: isolation and blockage verification manoeuvres carried out previously are repeated
column58: verifying the absence of acute reconnection and persistence of conduction blockage of previous isolation lines. By administering i.v. adenosine (12 mg)
column59: the absence of dormant conduction in the pulmonary veins and superior vena cava is verified. The catheters are removed
column60: normal contractility of the cardiac silhouette is checked and the procedure is concluded.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION In the consultation for review of the results
column61: the patient showed increasingly frequent and long-lasting ECG recordings in atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. The echocardiogram showed moderate systolic dysfunction due to diffuse involvement
column62: but no segmental alterations in contractility. At the time of consultation
column63: he was again in sinus rhythm
column64: but with abundant supraventricular extrasystolic activity. Anticoagulant treatment was started with dabigatran 150 mg/12 h (CHA2DS2VASc score of 3 points (age 1
column65: female 1 and heart failure or reduced LVEF 1 point) and antiarrhythmic treatment with amiodarone 200 mg/24 h
column66: ramipril 2.5 mg/24 h and bisoprolol 2.5 mg/24 h. It was first suspected that the left ventricular dysfunction could be caused by tachycardiomyopathy
column67: and for this reason
column68: together with the presence of symptomatic paroxysms of atrial fibrillation
column69: a new ablation procedure was indicated. However
column70: given the patient's age and history of ex-smoking and slight overweight
column71: assessment of the coronary tree was considered. As the patient required a CT scan of the left atrium and pulmonary veins prior to ablation
column72: this test was used for non-invasive coronary angiography
column73: which showed no significant lesions in the coronary arteries. One month after starting anticoagulation and after discontinuation of antiarrhythmic medication
column74: a second atrial fibrillation ablation procedure was performed. During the procedure
column75: VPSI reconnection was verified
column76: and the VPSI was isolated and checked again. Subsequently
column77: triggers not originating from the pulmonary veins were sought by infusion of isoproterenol
column78: locating a focus in the posterior roof of the left atrium
column79: which was treated by performing a posterior roof box up to the venous antrum and another focus in the superior vena cava
column80: which required circumferential isolation of the same. After the procedure
column81: the patient presented no complications and
column82: given her good evolution
column83: she was discharged from hospital after 24 hours
column84: previously restarting anticoagulant medication and her antiarrhythmic treatment. One month after ablation (still in the blanking period)
column85: the patient came for a check-up with evident clinical improvement
column86: being in NYHA functional class I
column87: and with no sensation of tachycardia. She provided ECG recordings which were all in sinus rhythm and in the echocardioscopy performed during the consultation
column88: the LVEF had improved significantly and appeared to be preserved/borderline. A further consultation was scheduled 3 months after the ablation procedure.  DIAGNOSIS Paroxysmal AF in a patient with probable tachycardiomyopathy (absence of coronary artery disease on CT scan prior to ablation). Left superior pulmonary vein reconnection. Presence of extrapulmonary foci manifested by isoproterenol infusion in the posterior roof of the left atrium and superior vena cava. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History 43-year-old woman
column3: with the following history: No known drug allergies. No known toxic habits or cardiovascular risk factors. Iron deficiency anaemia on intermittent treatment with oral iron. Anxiety-depressive syndrome
column4: on anxiolytic treatment on demand. No family history of heart disease or early cardiovascular disease. Usual medication: folic acid 5 mg/24 h
column5: lorazepam 1 mg (on demand).  Current illness Consultation due to an episode of oppressive central thoracic pain
column6: with accompanying vegetative symptoms
column7: which started abruptly while standing up while working in a kitchen at high temperature and associated with a great feeling of stress. On arrival at the hospital
column8: with progressive clinical improvement
column9: no electrocardiographic alterations suggestive of ischaemia or mobilisation of myocardial damage enzymes were recorded. He denied previous history of angina
column10: palpitations
column11: syncope or presyncope. He reported progressive dyspnoea on moderate exertion of about 6 months' duration
column12: without orthopnoea
column13: oedema or reduced diuresis. Finally
column14: it was decided to admit him to the cardiology department for further tests.  Physical examination Asymptomatic
column15: normal colour
column16: well perfused
column17: without jugular ingurgitation or hepatojugular reflux.  Blood pressure (BP) 110/60 mmHg
column18: heart rate (HR) 80 bpm. Eupneic at basal saturation 99%. On auscultation
column19: rhythmic heart tones
column20: with systolic murmur II/VI panfocal but predominantly pulmonary
column21: radiating to the carotids and more noticeably to the interscapular region. Abdomen: normal examination
column22: with no pathological findings. Radial and pedial pulses symmetrically preserved. Absence of oedema.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Electrocardiogram (ECG): RS at 57 bpm
column23: normal axis
column24: without atrioventricular (AV) or intraventricular conduction disorders
column25: without repolarisation disorders.  Chest X-ray: cardiothoracic index (CTI) at the upper limit of normality
column26: with an increase in the pulmonary vascular pattern.  Laboratory tests: Initial blood tests (ED): hypochromic microcytic anaemia with haemoglobin 9.3 g/dl (similar to previous ones)
column27: MCV 84 fl
column28: MCH 25.9 pg
column29: rest of haemogram normal. Renal function
column30: hepatobiliary profile and ions normal. Creatine phosphokinase normal. TnT 9-16 ng/l.  Analytical studies during admission (summary): Blood count: haemoglobin stable at around 10 g/dl
column31: the rest without alterations. Deficiency profile: serum iron 67.20 g/dl
column32: IST 19%
column33: ferritin 13.70 g/l
column34: transferrin 282.40 mg/dl
column35: vitB12 normal
column36: folic acid 2.4 g/l. Biochemistry: renal function ions and liver function markers normal. Metabolic and other profile: TSH normal. HbA1C 5.8%. Lipid profile normal. Normal acute phase reactants. Negative autoimmunity markers (RF
column37: ANA
column38: ANCA
column39: C3
column40: C4). ProBNP 167 pg/ml.  Transthoracic echocardiogram: left ventricle (LV) slightly dilated by volumes (DTDVI 52 mm
column41: BP vol 165 ml)
column42: not hypertrophied. Dilated left atrium indexed to body surface area (44 ml/m2). Normal right chambers. Aorta of normal calibre and flow in its accessible sections. Absence of significant valvulopathies. No evidence of pulmonary hypertension. An anomalous filling jet is visualised in the left atrium
column43: eccentric
column44: which crosses the interatrial septum and reaches the mitral valve
column45: continuous
column46: with a Vmax of 3.4 m/s. Normal LV systolic and diastolic function
column47: without contractility alterations. Normofunctioning right ventricle. No pericardial effusion or other findings. Contrast-enhanced CT angiography of coronary arteries and aorta: coronary arteries normal
column48: without lesions. Fistula from the descending thoracic aorta to the left atrium
column49: with saccular dilatation of the right posterior wall. Cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR): LV of normal diameter and morphology
column50: with indexed end-diastolic volume of 78 ml/m2 (slightly dilated). Preserved LVEF
column51: without segmental alterations of contractility. In cine sequences there was an evident aorto-atrial fistula (very fine jet at the level of the roof of the left atrium)
column52: the rest of the study with no significant findings.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION Given the clinical data and initial complementary tests
column53: the probability of ischaemic heart disease was considered low. However
column54: given the exploratory findings
column55: congenital heart disease was suspected
column56: and the echocardiographic study showed an anomalous filling jet in the left atrium. Angio-CT of the coronary arteries was requested
column57: ruling out arteriosclerotic disease
column58: but a fistulous tract of saccular morphology was found between the descending thoracic aorta and the left atrium
column59: with a suspected genetic origin in the absence of surgical history
column60: trauma
column61: or semiology compatible with current or previous endocarditis. During her admission she remained asymptomatic and the single episode of chest pain was attributed to an anxiety crisis
column62: as the location of the fistulous tract did not justify in this case a possible coronary steal phenomenon. The study was completed on an outpatient basis with CMR
column63: confirming the findings already described by echocardiogram and coronary CT
column64: with data of incipient remodelling of the left chambers (dilatation and hyperflow). For this reason
column65: a consensus was reached at a medical-surgical meeting on endovascular repair by means of percutaneous implantation of a thoracic aortic stent
column66: which was carried out without complications
column67: with good sealing of the leak in the control angiography.  DIAGNOSIS Chest pain of multifactorial cause: anxiety crisis
column68: hyperdynamic state. Angiographically normal coronary arteries by CT angiography. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  A 79-year-old woman attended the emergency department due to gait instability.  History Cardiovascular risk factors (CVRF): hypertension. Dyslipidaemia treated with diet. No previous cardiological history. Cardiology assessment in another centre in 2017
column3: at that time normal electrocardiogram (ECG). Other history: depression: recent start of sertraline. Phakectomy. Traumatic brain injury (TBI) secondary to a fall at home (no syncope). Previous medication: acetylsalicylic acid 100 mg (0-1-0)
column4: hydroferol (1 ampoule every 15 days)
column5: hydrochlorothiazide/amiloride 5/50 mg (1-0-0)
column6: sertraline 50 mg (1-0-0).  Present illness He reports gait instability of a week's duration prior to admission
column7: which he relates to the initiation of sertraline due to depressive mood. Denies presyncope/syncope. He has a history of a fall with secondary cranioencephalic trauma
column8: assessed in a private centre by means of a CAT scan and laboratory tests
column9: which were normal. He denies chest pain at all times. No dyspnoea
column10: orthopnoea or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea. No other cardiovascular symptoms. No fever or infectious
column11: respiratory or gastrointestinal symptoms.  We were alerted by elevated markers of myocardial damage and electrocardiogram alterations.  Physical examination Blood pressure (BP) 117/70 mmHg

column21: narrow QRS
column22: deep and symmetrical negative T wave in inferior face
column23: I and aVL and V2-V6. Ambulatory blood test (day of TBI): sodium 142 mmol/l
column24: potassium 4.0 mmol/l

column27: platelets 310000
column28: leucocytes 21700 (neu19800
column29: lin 500). INR 1.02

Cranial CT scan: no evidence of acute intracranial pathology in the post-traumatic context of the patient. Right frontal epicranial contusion/hematoma without bone fractures.  Echocardiogram: left ventricle not dilated
column55: with normal wall thickness. Akinesia of middle and distal segments of all faces and apex. Hyperkinesia of the basal segments. Moderately depressed global systolic function. LVEF 30-35%. Pseudonormalised transmitral filling pattern. Slightly dilated left atrium. Right atrium not dilated. Aneurysm of the interatrial septum displaced towards the right atrium as an indirect sign of increased left atrial pressure. Right ventricle not dilated
column56: with normal global systolic function. Rest normal. Cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR): left ventricle: a) size and function: normal size
column57: with normal thickness. Hypokinesia of the distal segments of all faces and apex. Basal segments are hypercontractile. Global left ventricular function at the lower limit of normality (LVEF 52%). b) T2-STIR: a hyperintense transmural zone affecting the middle and distal segments of all the faces is observed. c) First-pass perfusion: no alterations. d) Late enhancement: no alterations. Right ventricle: a) Size and function: normal size
column58: not hypertrophic
column59: normocontractile. b) T2-STIR: hyperintensity is observed at the level of the apical segment. c) Late enhancement: no alterations. Left atrium not dilated. Right atrium of normal size. Mitral valve with thin leaflets
column60: normal opening. Aortic valve trivalve
column61: functionally normal. Bilateral pleural effusion. Perihilar opacities more suggestive of heart failure. Conclusions: study compatible with stress cardiomyopathy (tako-tsubo syndrome). Data compatible with myocardial oedema affecting the middle and distal segments of the left ventricle
column62: without evidence of late enhancement or segmental perfusion alterations. Global systolic function at the lower limit of normal (LVEF 52%). Coronary angiography: smooth coronary arteries.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION The patient presented with instability in the context of severe hypoosmolar hyponatraemia (sodium 104 mml/l on admission) euvolaemic with normal urine osmolarity in the probable context of recent initiation of sertraline and potentiated by the concomitant use of hydrochlorothiazide/amiloride. Cranial CT scan with no acute findings. There was also associated hypomagnesaemia and hypokalaemia. In this context
column63: he had an elevated troponin plateau (8500-->8400 ng/l)
column64: ECG with anterior QS and residual ST elevation and echocardiogram with previously unknown LVEF 35% and alterations in segmental contraction compatible with takotsubo syndrome/stress cardiomyopathy. Admission to cardiology for monitoring was decided. Sertraline was discontinued and intravenous sodium replacement with serotherapy was started
column65: as well as oral potassium and magnesium replacement
column66: with progressive improvement in natraemia without residual neurological focality. Coronary angiography ruled out obstructive coronary disease. Cardiopathy study was completed with findings compatible with stress cardiomyopathy with LVEF 30-35% on admission
column67: which recovered to near normal (50-55%) on discharge. As the probable origin of the hydroelectrolytic disorder
column68: the use of drugs (thiazides + SSRIs) + SIADH secondary to TCE (Na levels tested in September 2020
column69: normal) is proposed. As a cause of the tako-tsubo syndrome
column70: the main option is severe hyponatraemia present on admission associated with creaneoencephalic trauma.  At discharge asymptomatic
column71: afebrile
column72: haemodynamically stable
column73: with sodium of 139 mmol/l. Follow-up in the cardiology day hospital
column74: with normalisation of ventricular function and asymptomatic.  DIAGNOSIS Stress cardiomyopathy secondary to severe hyponatremia. Coronary arteries without lesions. Ventricular function severely depressed
column75: recovered. Severe hypoosmolar euvolaemic hyponatraemia of probable pharmacological cause + SIADH to TBI. Cranioencephalic trauma. Arterial hypertension. Dyslipidaemia. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History 50-year-old male patient
column3: independent for basic activities of daily living and without cognitive impairment. Single
column4: lives alone in a small town in our autonomous community. Cardiovascular risk factors: ex-smoker for 2 years
column5: with an accumulated consumption of 30 packets/year
column6: ex-drinker for 6 months with a previous daily consumption of 5-6 UBE/d. No known metabolic disorders. Cardiological history: no cardiological history of interest. No family history of heart disease or sudden death. Other history: no personal history of note. Treatment: no chronic home treatment. Occasional use of NSAIDs.  Current illness The patient consulted his regional referral hospital due to a fever and general malaise of 15 days' duration accompanied by inflammatory pain in the lumbar region. He also presented with slightly localised abdominal discomfort
column7: with an accompanying feeling of nausea. No other infectious symptoms at any other level. No chest pain
column8: dyspnoea
column9: palpitations or other cardiological symptoms. During her stay in the emergency department
column10: tests were started with laboratory tests and abdominal ultrasound. The biochemistry showed elevated inflammatory markers
column11: the haemogram showed leukocytosis with left shift and the abdominal ultrasound showed splenomegaly measuring 18 cm with multiple cystic formations inside. For this reason
column12: a thoracoabdominal CT scan was requested which confirmed the presence of multiple splenic and renal infarctions. Finally
column13: following these findings
column14: a transthoracic echocardiogram was performed which revealed the presence of severe aortic insufficiency of uncertain origin
column15: without being able to confirm the presence of warts. On the basis of these studies
column16: and given the suspicion of infective endocarditis
column17: empirical antibiotic treatment was started with ceftriaxone and ampicillin. After 24 h of admission
column18: and following the growth of Enterococcus faecalis in the blood cultures
column19: it was decided to discuss the case with the cardiology department of our hospital in order to perform a transesophageal echocardiogram
column20: as well as to complete the studies and assess definitive treatment. The patient arrived at our hospital haemodynamically stable
column21: with very mild respiratory work
column22: and with basal crackles
column23: as well as petechiae in the lower limbs as the most relevant findings of the examination. A repeat transthoracic echocardiogram was performed with a result similar to that obtained at his regional hospital
column24: and it was decided to complete the cardiological studies.  Physical examination Vitals: heart rate (HR) 92 bpm; respiratory rate (RR) 29 rpm; blood pressure (BP) 95/48; oxygen saturation 97%. Patient conscious
column25: oriented and cooperative. Good hydration status. Slight skin pallor. No pain gesture. Mild tachypnoea at rest
column26: no intercostal tugging. Head and neck: no jugular ingurgitation and negative hepatojugular reflux. Carotid pulse symmetrical and no murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation: preserved vesicular murmur with crepitant rales in the right base. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic heart sounds. Aortic systolic murmur II/VI with preserved 2nd sound followed by a protodiastolic murmur II/IV. Abdomen: no skin lesions or scars. Preserved hydro-aerial sounds. Soft and depressible
column27: without discomfort on palpation or rebound. Palpable splenomegaly. Lower extremities: extremities warm and with good capillary filling. Petechial lesions on both legs. Radial and pedial pulses present and symmetrical. No signs of chronic venous insufficiency
column28: no oedema and no signs suggestive of deep vein thrombosis (DVT).  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Biochemistry: glucose 113 mg/dl
column29: urea 59 mg/dl
column31: glomerular filtration rate 53 ml/min/1.78 m2
column32: sodium ion 137 mmol/l
column33: potassium ion 4.1 mmol/l
column34: C-reactive protein 17.2 mg/dl; procalcitonin 1.56 ng/ml; NT-proBNP 3.280pg/ml
column35: alkaline phosphatase 107 U/l
column36: AST 21 U/l
column37: ALT 24 U/l
column38: GGT 59 U/l
column39: total bilirubin < 1.0 mg/dl
column40: total cholesterol 126 mg/dl
column41: HDL 10 mg/dl
column42: triglycerides 281 mg/dl
column43: calculated LDL cholesterol 47 mg/dl
column44: HbA1C 4.6%
column45: TSH 2.03 mU/l. CBC: haemoglobin 8.1 g/dl
column46: haematocrit %
column47: red blood cells 2.86x106/μl
column48: leukocytes 10
column50: neutrophils 8
column52: lymphocytes 1
column54: monocytes 530/μl
column55: eosinophils 70/μL
column56: basophils 10/μl
column57: platelets 235
column58: 000/μl. Coagulation: prothrombin time (PT) 15.10 sec; partial thromboplastin time (PTAT) 33.70 sec; INR 1.33; derived fibrinogen: 491 mg/l. Blood cultures: growth of Gram + cocci in the first 24 hours. At 72 h the presence of Enterococcus faecalis sensitive to ampicillin
column59: vancomycin and ciprofloxacin was confirmed. 12-lead ECG performed on arrival at our hospital: sinus rhythm at 90 bpm. P wave of normal size and morphology. PR interval in range without prolongation. Narrow QRS with axis between 0-90o and transition between V3-V4. ST segment without suprathresholds. Normal T wave. QTc interval in normal range. Chest X-ray performed on arrival at our hospital: cardiac silhouette of normal size. Slight vascular redistribution towards apical lung fields suggestive of incipient pulmonary congestion. No pinching of the costophrenic sinuses suggestive of pleural effusion. No parenchymal condensation or pneumothorax. Abdominal ultrasound performed in a regional hospital prior to transfer to our centre: hepatic steatosis without focal lesions. Biliary tract without lesions. Kidneys normal. Pancreas not assessable. Spleen 18cm with cystic formations inside. Empty bladder not assessable. Thoracoabdominal CT scan performed in a regional hospital prior to transfer to our centre: no pulmonary nodules or thoracic adenopathies in pathological range or appearance were observed. Small tongue of bilateral pleural effusions. Hypodense lesions of triangular splenic morphology suggestive of infarction
column60: as well as right renal lesions also probably related to infarction. Diffuse hepatic steatosis with cystic lesion in the LHI. Pancreas
column61: adrenal glands are normal. Transthoracic echocardiogram performed in a regional hospital prior to transfer to our centre: left ventricle neither dilated (VTD 128 ml
column62: VTS 39 ml) nor hypertrophic
column63: without segmental alterations and with preserved LVEF (LVEF 69% by Simpson biplane). Left atrium slightly dilated (AP diameter 43 mm). Right ventricle of normal size and function (TAPSE 26 mm). Mild tricuspid insufficiency with a velocity of 3.22 m/s (PSAP 44 mmHg). Inferior vena cava not dilated. High probability of pulmonary hypertension. Mitral valve with thin leaflets without prolapse
column64: mild mitral regurgitation. Trivalve aortic valve
column65: leaflets appear thin and there are no images suggestive of endocarditis. Central aortic insufficiency which appears severe (THP 112/m/s
column66: VC 7-8 mm)
column67: without being able to determine the mechanism. Aortic root not dilated. No suprasternal or good visualisation of the abdominal aorta to assess the presence of diastolic reverse flow. No pericardial effusion. Transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE): the atrial septum is intact
column68: with no evidence of atrial septal defect. Mitral valve: vegetation in the anterior mitral leaflet
column69: about 6mm long axis; moderate mitral insufficiency is detected. Tricuspid valve normal in structure and function. Trivalve aortic valve; endocarditis on the aortic valve
column70: with a wart of about 11 mm of major axis
column71: with destruction of the non-coronary leaflet
column72: leading to severe aortic insufficiency. No evidence of perivalvular involvement. There is no pericardial effusion. Cardiac CT scan: trivalve aortic valve with focal thickening of the non-coronary leaflet and a 10 mm polypoid image
column73: mobile
column74: close to the implantation point in relation to the clinical suspicion of endocarditis. Rupture of the non-coronary leaflet. No perivalvular complications were identified. Coronary arteries without significant lesions. CT scan of the brain: hyperdense image in the left subcortical sylvian region with discrete surrounding oedema
column75: without significant mass effect
column76: which in the clinical context of the patient suggests a small haemorrhagic embolus
column77: without being able to rule out underlying abscess due to the fact that the study was performed without VSD. No alterations in the density of the brain parenchyma suggestive of subacute ischaemic pathology were observed. Area of encephalomalacia in the right temporal pole with discrete exvacuo dilatation of the homolateral horn
column78: of residual appearance; we do not know the patient's clinical and traumatic history. Discrete signs of chronic small vessel pathology in the base ganglia
column79: no bone lesions of interest are observed. Positron emission tomography with 18F-deoxyglucose (PETTC): head and neck without pathological alterations of the glycemic metabolism. A focus of mild glycemic hypermetabolism is observed adjacent to the aortic valve area (SUVmax 2.83)
column80: which could be related to known endocarditis (the low degree of uptake could be explained by response to antibiotic treatment). No other hypermetabolic foci were detected in the valvular heart area suggestive of endocarditis. Splenomegaly with the presence of several extensive ametabolic lesions
column81: which show increased glycemic metabolism in their periphery (SUVmax 8.27)
column82: with fairly homogeneous characteristics
column83: related to known splenic infarcts
column84: without clear signs suggestive of their superinfection. The hypermetabolism could be explained
column85: at least in part
column86: by extramedullary haematopoiesis secondary to known anaemia. Liver
column87: pancreas
column88: adrenal glands and mesentery without pathological alterations of glycemic metabolism. Kidneys not assessable due to physiological excretion of radiotracer. Diffuse and homogeneous increase in metabolism in the bone marrow
column89: probably related to anaemia. Rest of the study with no findings of interest. Cerebral angio-MRI: in the FLAIR sequence
column90: multiple patchy hyperintensities of bilateral subcortical cortical location and in the right cerebellar hemisphere are observed
column91: with a more extensive area in the right temporal pole
column92: which show late enhancement after contrast. They are compatible with infarcts of cardioembolic origin
column93: several of them with signs of petechial microbleeding
column94: in a subacute-late phase evolving to chronicity. A 10 mm haematoma in the left sylvian region with discrete perilesional oedema
column95: which has not increased with respect to previous CT studies. In the magnetic susceptibility sequence at least 3 millimetric formations are identified in convexity grooves (bilateral frontal and right occipital)
column96: not assessable in the angio-MRI
column97: not being able to rule out distal mycotic aneurysms. No significant alterations were seen at the level of the polygon of Willis. No lesions suggestive of abscesses are identified. Cerebral arteriography: identified by arteriography from the left ICA as a pseudoaneurysm in M2 branch
column98: embolised using a sandwich technique with coils distal and proximal to the neck of the pseudoaneurysm. Good final angiographic result.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION During the first days of admission
column99: a transesophageal echocardiography was performed
column100: as well as a cardiac CT scan
column101: which confirmed the presence of aortic vegetation with involvement of the non-coronary leaflet
column102: with rupture of the same
column103: leading to severe aortic insufficiency. In addition
column104: data suggestive of a previously undescribed vegetation at the mitral level and coronary arteries without lesions were also observed. With these findings
column105: it was decided to discuss the case in a multidisciplinary endocarditis session
column106: with the participation of the radiology
column107: infectious diseases and cardiac surgery departments
column108: with a view to assessing valve replacement. Given the history of splenic infarction
column109: it was decided to request extension studies prior to surgery to rule out embolisms at other levels and to re-evaluate the state of spleen involvement. On the same day
column110: a cranial CT scan was performed which showed the presence of a haemorrhagic lesion in the region of Sylvius compatible with the rupture of a mycotic aneurysm and a PET-CT scan showed marked splenic involvement
column111: with large necrotic areas. At this point
column112: with the presence of valvular involvement
column113: splenomegaly with multiple areas of large infarction
column115: it was decided jointly with the neurology
column116: cardiac surgery and general surgery services to establish an order of action to treat the set of complications developed by the patient. Initially
column117: an arteriography with embolisation of the mycotic aneurysm affecting the M2 branch of the left middle cerebral artery was performed (after study with cerebral angio-MRI). The procedure was performed without incident and without secondary neurological sequelae. Subsequently
column118: it was decided to perform a splenectomy. The reason for initially resecting the spleen rather than the heart was to avoid the risk of bleeding that could have been caused by the extracorporeal circulation (ECC) and subsequent heparinisation. One week after embolisation
column119: splenectomy by laparotomy was performed without complications. Finally
column121: the patient underwent surgery for his valve disease. The aortic valve was resected and a St. Jude No. 23 biological prosthesis was implanted. It is noteworthy that during the operation: both the intraoperative TEE and the visual inspection did not reveal the mitral involvement described in the previous report; only a grade II/IV mitral insufficiency
column122: so it was decided not to operate on it (the same grade was maintained at the discharge control). During admission
column123: the patient was treated with intravenous antibiotics according to the recommendations of the infectious diseases department (ceftriaxone
column124: gentamicin and ampicillin). The patient's evolution during the first weeks of admission was acceptably good. The patient remained practically asymptomatic from the cardiological point of view
column125: with development of mild heart failure (but good clinical tolerance) and improvement in both fever and digestive symptoms. The main complications were marked anaemia
column126: which required repeated transfusions of several red blood cell concentrates. On the other hand
column127: he also had a deterioration of renal function that made it necessary to space contrast studies and maintain adequate hydration. After the two surgeries
column128: the patient remained in hospital for a little over a month
column129: with a very poor evolution due to complications derived from his abdominal surgery. This even necessitated reoperation for drainage of the abdominal abscess and the patient's admission to the chronic wound unit for management of the laparotomy incision. In the end
column131: the patient can be discharged home to continue his recovery there.  DIAGNOSIS Acute E. faecalis endocarditis on native aortic valve. Non-coronary aortic valve leaflet rupture with secondary severe aortic insufficiency. Aortic valve replacement with St. Jude biological prosthesis no 23. Acute heart failure with preserved LVEF in the setting of infective endocarditis. Epicardial arteries without lesions. Splenic and renal infarcts of embolic mechanism secondary to infective endocarditis. Splenectomy by laparotomy with subsequent drainage of purulent collection. Mycotic cerebral aneurysm in M2 branch of left middle cerebral artery secondary to infective endocarditis. Embolisation of cerebral mycotic aneurysm by arteriography. Multifactorial normocytic anaemia (bleeding
column133: deterioration of renal function...). Multifactorial acute renal failure (hypotension
column135: diuretics...). |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
