column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History 71-year-old patient
column3: no known allergies. Ex-smoker for 2 years (EA 40 packs/year). Cardiovascular risk factors include high blood pressure
column4: insulin-dependent type 2 diabetes mellitus with good control and dyslipidaemia. Cardiological history includes permanent atrial fibrillation. The last echocardiography in 2016 showed LVEF 52%
column5: mild mitral regurgitation and estimated systolic pulmonary artery pressure (PAPS) of 35 mmHg. Patient in NYHA functional class II
column6: with no previous admissions for heart failure. The main comorbidity was chronic renal failure being monitored by nephrology and with baseline creatinine levels around 1.5-2 mg/dl (estimated glomerular filtration rate [eGFR] of 40 ml/min/1.73 m2)
column7: peripheral vascular disease with intermittent claudication and multifactorial anaemia with endoscopic study within normal limits. Usual medication: acenocoumarol
column8: manidipine 10 mg/day
column9: doxazosin 8 mg/day
column10: furosemide 40 mg/day
column11: atorvastatin 40 mg/day
column12: insulin glargine 18U
column13: ferroglycine sulphate 100 mg/d; darbepoetin alfa 1 injection/week.  Present illness The patient came to the emergency department in February 2020 due to an increase in his baseline dyspnoea of 1 week's evolution to minimal effort accompanied by orthopnoea and oedematisation of the lower limbs together with a subjective decrease in diuresis. Since then
column14: he has had rapid palpitations. As a triggering factor
column15: he presented with a cough with scanty whitish expectoration without fever
column16: of 10 days' evolution
column17: for which his primary care physician had prescribed amoxicillin/clavulanic acid 875/125 mg/8 h for 7 days.  Physical examination Vital signs: blood pressure (BP) 175/83 mmHg
column18: heart rate (HR) 120 bpm
column19: baseline oxygen saturation 88%. Cardiac auscultation with irregular
column20: tachycardic sounds. Pulmonary auscultation with hypoventilation at the bases and crackles up to midfields
column21: together with isolated rhonchi. Tibiomalleolar oedema with grade 2 fovea.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG: atrial fibrillation with mean ventricular response at 120 bpm
column22: QRS 100 ms. ST-segment depression of 1 mm V4-V6
column23: I and aVL. CBC: glucose 138 mg/dl
column24: urea 140 mg/dl
column25: creatinine 1.75 mg/dl
column26: glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) 38.5 ml/min/1.73 m2
column27: sodium (Na+) 147 mmol/l
column28: potassium (K+) 5.2 mmol/l
column29: NT-proBNP > 35
column31: CA125 415 U/ml. AP chest X-ray: cardiomegaly. Aortic elongation. Bilateral pleural effusion predominantly on the right. Signs of vascular redistribution and interstitial oedema. Transthoracic echocardiography. Parasternal long-axis plane and apical 4-chamber plane: dilated left ventricle (LVED 60 mm)
column32: with moderate hypertrophy and moderate depression of global systolic function (LVEF 37%) secondary to generalised hypokinesia. High filling pressures (E/e' 19). Non-dilated right ventricle with borderline systolic function by longitudinal parameters (TAPSE 18 mm). Severe left atrial dilatation (volume 126 ml). Aortic valve sclerosis. Mitral valve with normal opening sclerosed leaflets and mild central regurgitation. Mild tricuspid insufficiency (TI) with estimated PAPS 45 mmHg. Absence of pericardial effusion. Dilated vena cava (24 mm) with plethora. B lines in both lung fields suggestive of significant pulmonary congestion. Pulsatile renal venous flow (moderate renal congestion). Cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR). Cine sequences: dilated left ventricle with eccentric hypertrophy pattern and moderately depressed systolic function (LVEF 38%). Right ventricle with normal volume and systolic function. Dilated left atrium. Provocation of ischaemia with negative regadenoson. Absence of myocardial necrosis. Intramyocardial fibrosis in the entire basal septum and in the area of intersection of the right ventricle in the medial septum.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION The patient was admitted for decompensated heart failure in the context of respiratory infection and rapid atrial fibrillation. On admission
column33: impaired renal function and mild hyperkalaemia were observed. Imaging tests showed dilated cardiomyopathy of non-ischaemic origin with moderately depressed LVEF and borderline right function
column34: without significant valvular heart disease. Intravenous diuretic treatment was administered
column35: with clinical improvement
column36: and the patient was discharged from hospital. Bisoprolol 2.5 mg/day
column37: valsartan 40 mg/day and furosemide was increased to 80 mg/day. Subsequently
column38: the patient made two visits to the emergency department for heart failure
column39: and intravenous diuretics were administered without requiring admission
column40: and the oral diuretic regimen was adjusted. In August the patient was admitted again for decompensation of heart failure and severe hyperkalaemia. Blood tests showed creatinine 2.24 mg/dl
column41: GFR 28.4 ml/min/1.73 m2
column42: Na+ 141 mmol/l
column43: K+ 6.7 mmol/l
column44: NT-proBNP 24.5011 pg/ml
column45: CA125 240 U/ml. After depletive treatment and correction of hyperkalaemia on discharge
column46: chlorthalidone 25 mg every other day and resincalcium were added to his treatment and he was referred to the heart failure unit of our centre. On the first visit
column47: the patient was in NYHA functional class III with significant orthopnoea. Laboratory tests showed creatinine 2.97 (eGFR 20 ml/min/1.73 m2) and K+ 5.7 mmol/l. Treatment was started with patiromer 16.8 g/day and a subcutaneous furosemide pump was prescribed. At the next visit the patient had a creatinine of 2.74 mg/dl (eGFR 23 ml/min/1.73 m2) and K+ of 4.2 mmol/l. It was then decided to add sacubitril/valsartan 24/26 mg/12h. In November
column48: he was admitted twice more for heart failure due to recurrent bilateral pleural effusion
column49: predominantly on the right
column50: which required several thoracentesis and finally the placement of a permanent pleural drainage. At the follow-up visit in December
column51: the patient reported improvement in functional class (NYHA II) and orthopnoea
column52: with no signs of congestion. Laboratory tests showed an improvement in renal function (creatinine 2.5 mg/dl
column53: eGFR 25 ml/min/1.73 m2) and K+ 3.6 mmol/l. To date
column54: the patient remains in good functional class
column55: with no new episodes of heart failure decompensation
column56: and pleural drainage has been removed due to the absence of debit. Images 4
column58: 6 and 7 show the evolution of creatinine
column59: potassium and prognostic and congestion biomarkers NT-proBNP and CA125 during the patient's evolution.  DIAGNOSIS Heart failure with reduced LVEF. Non-ischaemic dilated cardiomyopathy. Chronic renal disease. Cardiorenal syndrome. Hyperkalaemia. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History Male
column3: 73 years of age
column4: his medical history includes: No known ADRs. Cardiovascular risk factors (CVRF): hypertension with poor control and dyslipidaemia. Severe aortic stenosis with valve replacement with a biological prosthesis in 2016. Chronic ischaemic heart disease: moderate lesion of 40-50% in non-revascularised anterior descending artery. Surgical interventions: aortic valve replacement
column5: shoulder arthroplasty
column6: tonsillectomy
column7: inguinal herniorrhaphy. Usual treatment: acetylsalicylic acid 100 mg
column8: atorvastatin 80 mg
column9: amlodipine 5 mg
column10: bisoprolol 2.5 mg
column11: imidapril 10 mg.   Present illness The patient came to the emergency department of our hospital 7-10 days ago
column12: complaining of fatigue
column13: dyspnoea and a feeling of dizziness with light to moderate exertion
column14: which had been triggered by a previous episode of severe stabbing chest pain. For the last 3 months he has been experiencing intermittent chest pain
column15: for which reason he has been seen at the cardiology outpatient clinic. A stress test was requested
column16: with negative results for ischaemia
column17: and a stress cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (CMR) is pending.  Physical examination Blood pressure (BP) 170/90 mmHg
column18: heart rate (HR) 60 bpm. Oxygen saturation 95% (FiO2 0.21). Cardiac auscultation: regular heart sounds
column19: aortic systolic murmur II/VI. Pulmonary auscultation: preserved vesicular murmur without pathological sounds. Abdomen: soft and depressible
column20: without signs of defence
column21: masses or visceromegaly. No peripheral oedema. Pulses symmetrical and normal.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS ECG: sinus rhythm at 60 bpm. First degree atrioventricular block (AVB) (PR 480 ms). Narrow QRS with axis at 0o in frontal plane. No pathological alterations in repolarisation. Laboratory tests during admission: glucose 111 mg/dl
column22: urea 35 mg/dl
column23: creatinine 0.87 mg/dl
column24: sodium 144 mmol/l
column25: potassium 4.5 mmol/l
column26: uric acid 4.4 mg/dl
column27: cholesterol 151 mg/dl
column28: calculated LDL 102 mg/dl
column29: HDL 38 mg/dl
column31: total bilirubin 0
column32: 76 mg/dl
column33: GPT 27 U/l
column34: GOT 32 U/l
column35: GGT 19 U/l
column36: alkaline phosphatases 74 mU/ml
column37: haemoglobin 14.4 g/dl
column38: haematocrit 44%
column39: MCV 93 fl
column40: leucocytes 7900
column41: platelets 201000
column42: NT-proBNP 296 pg/ml
column43: CRP 14.1 mg/l
column44: procalcitonin 0.05 ng/ml. Chest X-ray: normal cardiac silhouette
column45: no signs of heart failure. Transthoracic echocardiogram: left ventricle of normal dimensions with moderate hypertrophy of its walls (IVT 15 mm). Preserved global systolic function (LVEF 65%) without segmental alterations of contractility at rest. Ventricular filling wave fusion with normal E/e" ratio. Slightly dilated left atrium. Biological prosthesis in normofunctioning aortic position (maximum gradient 35 mmHg
column46: mean gradient 18 mmHg)
column47: without regurgitation. Mitral valve with normal opening and minimal valvular insufficiency. Right ventricle of normal dimensions with borderline function by longitudinal parameters (TAPSE 16 mm
column48: tricuspid s" 9.5 cm/s) after cardiac surgery. Absence of tricuspid insufficiency. Normal inferior vena cava (16 mm) with inspiratory collapse > 50%. Absence of pericardial effusion. Continuous renal venous flow. Exercise test: maximal exercise test
column49: negative for ischaemia
column50: stopped in stage 3 of Bruce protocol due to muscle exhaustion. Work achieved 11 METs. AV conduction 1:1 throughout the test. Good chronotropic and tension response. Functional capacity adequate for his age. Stress CMR: left ventricle with increased septal thickness predominantly (17 mm) and preserved mass (71 g/m2)
column51: normal MPR (1.18). Volumes (IVTDVI 60 ml/m2; IVTSVI 17 ml/m2) and segmental and global systolic function within normal (LVEF 72%). Right ventricular volumes (IVTDDI 56 ml/m2; IVTSVD 19 ml/m2) and systolic function within normal (RVEF 66%). Atria of normal size. Biological valve prosthesis in aortic position. Peak systolic velocity of 3.5 m/s. Periprosthetic collection surrounding the valve annulus and contrast uptake in relation to surgery. Slight dilatation of root (37 mm
column52: 20 mm/m2) and tubular portion (38 mm
column53: 20 mm/m2). Rest of thoracic aorta of preserved calibre. Provocation of ischaemia with i.v. Regadenoson (400 mcg i.v.
column54: well tolerated) negative. Baseline: 58 bpm and 135/85 mmHg. Stress: 82 bpm and 122/77 mmHg. Baseline ECG: PR of 0.480 s
column55: without complications during regadenoson stress. Gadoteric acid is administered i.v. at 0.15 mmol/kg without complications. Absence of myocardial fibrosis or necrosis. Only contrast uptake in periprosthetic collection. In summary
column56: absence of inducible ischaemia. Biological aortic valve prosthesis with contrast-enhancing periprosthetic collection of uncertain significance. PET-CT: biological aortic prosthesis with intense hypermetabolism (SULmax 6.6 g/ml
column57: late 9.07 g/ml) accompanied by mural thickening of the ascending aorta
column58: suggestive of endocarditis due to prosthetic infection. Hypermetabolic right upper and lower right paratracheal (SULmax 2.8 g/ml)
column59: subcarinal and bilateral hilar (SULmax 3.7 g/ml) contrast-enhancing hypermetabolic adenopathies suggestive of an infectious process secondary to endocarditis. Absence of metabolic activity in cephalic lymph node stations or bone marrow. Physiological glandular and encephalic uptake. Absence of pathological metabolic activity in cervical or axillary ganglion stations. Subsegmental hypermetabolic atelectasis of the upper segment of the lower lobe of the right lung. No pleural or pericardial or pleural effusion. Sternal sternotomy band with physiological hypermetabolism. Hepatic
column60: splenic
column61: pancreatic
column62: renal and adrenal parenchyma without significant metabolic alterations. Small bowel loops with diffuse metabolic activity
column63: with no significant pathological accumulations of activity. Absence of metabolic activity in abdominal
column64: retroperitoneal
column65: pelvic and inguinal lymph node stations. No free abdominal fluid. Circumferential mural thrombosis in the abdominal aorta with partial obstruction of the right common iliac artery with diffuse atheromatosis. No evidence of significant morphological or metabolic alteration in the bone framework. Conclusions: focus of hypermetabolism in aortic valve prosthesis suggestive of endocarditis
column66: with reactive mediastinal and pulmonary adenopathies. Circumferential mural thrombosis of the abdominal aorta and partial obstruction of the right common iliac artery.  CLINICAL COURSE In the case of a patient with a conduction disorder presenting with exertional dyspnoea and dizziness
column67: it was decided to admit him to cardiology to complete the study. A new exercise stress test was requested to assess the reaction to exercise
column68: and an adequate chronotropic response and 1:1 conduction was observed throughout the test. A transthoracic echocardiogram was performed
column69: which ruled out prosthetic dysfunction
column70: without observing segmental contractility alterations suggestive of ischaemia. After the absence of relevant findings in the examinations performed
column71: it was decided to discharge the patient from hospital with withdrawal of beta-blockers. Given the persistence of atypical chest pain with a history of previous coronary artery disease
column72: stress CMR was brought forward with outpatient monitoring in cardiology outpatient clinics. The following week a stress CMR was performed
column73: with negative results for ischaemia
column74: but a periprosthetic collection with contrast uptake was found
column75: of uncertain significance
column76: which could correspond to postoperative inflammatory activity or an infectious process. On assessing the results
column77: taking into account the remoteness of the intervention (> 3 years) and given the possibility of infective prosthetic endocarditis
column78: it was decided to readmit the patient to cardiology to complete the study and start antibiotic treatment. Empirical treatment with ampicillin
column79: cloxacillin and gentamicin was started in agreement with the infectious diseases unit. Blood cultures and serology for endocarditis were requested
column80: with negative results. It was decided to complete the imaging study with PET-CT
column81: which showed the presence of hypermetabolism in the aortic valve prosthesis suggestive of endocarditis
column82: with reactive mediastinal and pulmonary adenopathies; as an incidental finding
column83: a circumferential mural thrombosis of the abdominal aorta and partial obstruction of the right common iliac artery were found. With the above findings
column84: the case was discussed in a joint medical-surgical session between cardiology
column85: cardiac surgery and the infectious diseases unit. Since the patient was stable
column86: with no evidence of prosthetic dysfunction or acute complications
column87: initial antibiotic treatment was chosen for 6 weeks
column88: changing the previous regimen to daptomycin
column89: ceftriaxone and doxycycline
column90: with subsequent re-evaluation. After the first 10 days of treatment
column91: the patient remained clinically stable
column92: and it was decided to discharge him to the home hospitalisation unit (HHU) to complete the antibiotic regimen. Also
column93: with a history of coronary heart disease and the finding of peripheral arterial disease with mural thrombosis of the abdominal aorta
column94: lipid-lowering treatment was intensified with the addition of a combination of atorvastatin/ezetimibe. After 6 weeks of antibiotic therapy
column95: a new control PET-CT scan was performed
column96: in which periprosthetic hypermetabolism persisted but of less intensity than previously
column97: with disappearance of the reactive adenopathies. With the good response to treatment
column98: it was decided to complete 4 more weeks of antibiotic treatment
column99: replacing doxycycline with rifampicin
column100: which would subsequently be maintained in monotherapy until completing 6 months of treatment.  DIAGNOSIS Late infective endocarditis on biological aortic prosthesis. First-degree atrioventricular block (AVB) secondary to aortic endocarditis. Circumferential mural thrombosis of the abdominal aorta. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History 61-year-old woman. Personal history: No known drug allergies. No cardiovascular risk factors. Recent admission to internal medicine for community-acquired pneumonia and debut of heart failure. No surgical interventions. Other history: depressive syndrome
column3: vertiginous syndrome since 2017
column4: dorsalgia (followed up by rehabilitation). Usual treatment: betahistine 8 mg (1-0-1)
column5: bromazepam and paracetamol/codeine on demand. Family history: diabetic father
column6: with CKD requiring haemodialysis and unspecified heart disease. Mother with atrial fibrillation and brother with acute non-ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) at 54 years of age.   Current illness: Consultation for several months of dyspnoea progressing to minimal effort with orthopnoea
column7: paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea (PND)
column8: cough with purulent expectoration

column10: heart rate 98 bpm

column13: 800 /μl (79.8% neutrophils)
column14: haemoglobin 12.4 g/dl
column15: haematocrit 37.3%
column16: platelets 160

column27: TSH 1.04. Cardiac markers: ultrasensitive troponin I 10.2
column28: NT-proBNP 8026 pg/ml. Antigenuria: pneumococcal antigen positive

column31: normal PR
column32: right axis
column33: incomplete right bundle branch block of the HH
column34: Rs in V2-V4
column35: without repolarisation disorders. Laboratory tests on the hospital ward: serum proteinogram: total proteins 6.4
column36: albumin 3.37 g/dl (52.6%)
column37: alpha-1-globulins 0.35 g/dl (5.5%)
column38: alpha-2-globulins 0.79 g/dl (12.5%)
column39: B-globulins 1.14 g/dl (17.8%)
column40: gamma-globulins 0.75 g/dl (11.7%)

column42: corresponds to an IgA kappa band. Serum free kappa light chains 4040 mg/l
column43: serum free lambda light chains < 5 mg/l. Immunoglobulins: IgG 413 mg/dl
column44: IgA 952 mg/dl
column45: IgM < 20 mg/dl. Autoimmunity profile: negative. Urine study: protein/creatinine ratio 0.61
column46: proteinuria in 24 hours 480 mg
column47: kappa light chains in urine 17.7 mg/dl
column48: lambda light chains < 1.5 mg/dl. Transthoracic echocardiogram (videos 1 and 2): left ventricle of preserved dimensions
column49: with severely increased concentric wall thickness (16 mm)
column50: LVEF 68%
column51: no segmental contractility defects. Diastolic dysfunction grade II
column52: psudonormalised pattern (E/A 1.8 E/e" 17). Severe mitral insufficiency
column53: dilated left atrium (50 mm). Right ventricle of preserved dimensions and systolic function
column54: estimated PAPS 52 mmHg. Reduced global longitudinal Strain
column55: preserved in apical segments
column56: with deterioration in the basal region. Cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR): anterior ascending (AD) area in 4C 25 cm2
column57: right ventricle (RV) 76X46X52 mm. Left atrium (LA) area 28 cm2
column58: left ventricle (LV) 50X40X69 mm. T1 non-enhanced. Interventricular septum 19.5 mm
column59: slight circumferential pericardial effusion of subcentimetric thickness. Non-dilated left ventricle
column60: with severe septal hypertrophy and moderate circumferential hypertrophy at baso-medial level
column61: contractility without segmental deficits. After i.v. contrast
column62: difficulty in myocardial signal cancellation in LL sequence
column63: showing diffuse endocardial enhancement of basal predominance
column64: almost transmural in basal lateral face and mid-apical transmural mottling
column65: with some respect for the basal septum. Probable endocardial enhancement in left atrium. Slightly hypertrophic right ventricle with tricuspid insufficiency (TI)
column66: mitral insufficiency (MI) and LVOT acceleration jet
column67: without clear SAM. Brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI): broad-based bony overgrowth affecting the posterior wall of the left internal auditory canal
column68: compatible with exostosis. Pyrophosphate cardiac scan: Perugini grade 1 uptake. Abdominal subcutaneous cellular tissue biopsy: no relevant lesions
column69: Congo red negative. Bone marrow biopsy: Congo red negative
column70: slightly hypercellular with mature forms of the three series and mild-moderate interstitial plasmacytosis (21-24%) and restriction of kappa light chains.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION The patient was admitted to the internal medicine department for symptoms compatible with community-acquired pneumonia with associated small pleural effusion. Antibiotics were administered with ceftriaxone plus clarithromycin for 7 days
column71: with partial improvement of cough
column72: but still with persistent dyspnoea
column73: orthopnoea and development of oedema in the lower limbs. A control chest X-ray showed a slight increase in pleural effusion. In addition
column74: blood tests showed an elevation of NT-proBNP disproportionate to the clinical picture. Following the findings observed in the echocardiogram
column75: cardiology assessment was requested and the patient was transferred to the cardiology department. During admission to the cardiology ward
column76: the patient remained stable
column77: but persisted with occasional dizziness and oedema in the lower limbs despite diuretic treatment. The echocardiogram showed symmetric concentric hypertrophy of the left ventricle associated with diastolic dysfunction
column78: high filling pressures and altered strain. In the aetiological study of the condition
column79: CMR was performed with findings highly suggestive of cardiac amyloidosis. To establish a differential diagnosis between AL cardiac amyloidosis and ATTR
column80: pyrophosphate scintigraphy was performed
column81: which showed mild myocardial uptake
column82: as well as a proteinogram and immunofixation in blood and urine
column83: which detected a monoclonal IgA kappa-type component. Abdominal fat biopsy with Congo red stain was negative for amyloidosis. Bone marrow biopsy was then performed with plasmacytosis greater than 20%. These findings were compatible with multiple myeloma. Finally
column84: a salivary gland biopsy was performed and was positive for amyloidosis. The patient was transferred to haematology and started treatment with bortezomib-cyclophosphamide-dexamethasone protocol.  DIAGNOSIS Acute heart failure with preserved LVEF. AL cardiac amyloidosis. Multiple myeloma IgA kappa. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History The case is a 37-year-old woman
column3: with no known drug allergies
column4: a former smoker for 20 years
column5: who in 2016 presented with central retinal vein obstruction
column6: complicated by vitreous haemorrhage that eventually required vitrectomy. In addition
column7: she has a probable antiphospholipid syndrome
column8: for which she is being treated with hydroxychloroquine 200 mg/24 h and acetylsalicylic acid 100 mg/24 h. The patient was being followed up by a private cardiologist due to the accidental finding of a murmur during an examination at work. The echocardiogram (TTE) showed moderate aortic insufficiency (AIo) with mild stenosis
column9: normal mitral valve
column10: non-dilated left ventricle (LV) with preserved LV ejection fraction (LVEF)
column11: and no evidence of pulmonary hypertension (PH). Pregnant at 20 weeks
column12: she was referred from obstetrics for cardiology follow-up during pregnancy. Monthly follow-ups were started to rule out the appearance of cardiac decompensation. Special attention was paid to the appearance of congestive symptoms or signs: the patient only reported dyspnoea on moderate exertion. Serial analyses were performed
column13: including NT-proBNP
column14: which was normal
column15: and TTE
column16: which showed a non-dilated LV with normal LVEF
column17: severe mitral (MR) and aortic insufficiency
column18: with no evidence of pulmonary hypertension. The patient had presented proteinuria since early gestation. At around week 30
column19: she started with arterial hypertension (AHT)
column20: with blood pressure around 140/72 mmHg
column21: plateletopenia and incipient oedema.  Present illness In week 34 she was referred to the obstetrics emergency department for high blood pressure of 168/84 mmHg: complementary tests showed proteinuria and plateletopenia
column22: so it was decided to admit her for pulmonary maturation and observation on suspicion of possible pre-eclampsia versus alterations secondary to antiphospholipid syndrome.  Initially
column23: vaginal delivery was attempted (because it was associated with less blood loss and less risk of infection and venous thromboembolism)
column24: but due to the risk of loss of foetal well-being
column25: caesarean section was finally indicated. The patient had remained stable from a cardiological point of view during admission
column26: but 12 hours after the caesarean section
column27: cardiology was notified due to desaturation up to 77%. The patient only reported having started
column28: while at rest
column29: with a feeling of warmth and dizziness
column31: clear dyspnoea
column32: orthopnoea or chest pain. Physical examination She was conscious and oriented
column33: well perfused
column34: blood pressure (BP) 160/90 mmHg
column35: heart rate (HR) 75 bpm and oxygen saturation (SO2) 91-92% with oxygen therapy with nasal goggles (NG) at 2 l/min
column36: eupneic at rest and tolerating decubitus. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic with diastolic and systolic murmur. Pulmonary auscultation in the anterior plane: preserved vesicular murmur. Slight oedema with pretibial fovea similar to that of that morning.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Laboratory tests: hypoxaemia with hypocapnia
column37: with normal pH and lactic acid
column38: mild renal failure with ions in range
column39: NT-proBNP of 1466 ng/dl
column40: and leukocytes with left deviation and CRP of 75 mg/l. Electrocardiogram (ECG): sinus rhythm at 80 bpm
column41: with a normal PR and a narrow QRS without repolarisation alterations. Echocardioscopy: non-dilated and non-hypertrophic LV with preserved LVEF
column42: without alterations in segmental contractility. Aortic root not dilated. Trivalve aortic valve
column43: with thickened leaflets
column44: especially at the level of the free edge
column45: which generates a central coaptation deficit
column46: resulting in severe AoI and mild stenosis. Mitral valve with diffusely thickened leaflets
column47: with involvement of the subvalvular apparatus that restricts the movement of the posterior leaflet generating moderate-severe MR
column48: directed towards the lateral wall of the left atrium and with a Coanda effect. Right ventricle normal in size and function. Tricuspid valve of normal appearance
column49: without tricuspid insufficiency. No evidence of pulmonary hypertension. No pericardial effusion.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION After a joint assessment with gynaecology and resuscitation
column50: it was decided to transfer the patient for a computed tomography (CT) scan
column51: which showed extensive bilateral alveolar consolidations and septal thickening affecting both lungs
column52: suggestive of bilateral pneumonia. Mild bilateral pleural effusion. In addition
column53: a small repletion defect was identified in a segmental branch of the left lower lobe
column54: compatible with pulmonary thromboembolism
column55: without overload of the right heart chambers. During the CT scan
column56: the patient presented intense dyspnoea without desaturation
column57: which improved with sitting and increased oxygen therapy. In view of the findings of the complementary tests
column58: it was decided to admit her to resuscitation for treatment of the suspected bilateral pneumonia
column59: in addition to diuretic treatment to force a negative water balance. During her stay
column60: she had a very good clinical evolution
column61: with very abundant diuresis
column62: resolution of dyspnoea
column63: and improvement in SO2 that allowed her to de-escalate from oxygen therapy with high-flow glasses (HFG) to NG
column64: and later withdrawal of the same
column65: so that the picture was more likely to be one of acute heart failure (HF). The patient was discharged to the obstetrics ward after 48 hours in resuscitation
column66: where she presented a good clinical evolution with resolution of the congestive semiology
column67: and was finally discharged. Since her discharge
column68: the patient has continued to undergo cardiological check-ups
column69: initially more closely
column70: which have been spaced out to be performed every three months. Her blood pressure remains practically normal
column71: and the clinical signs of heart failure have completely resolved: she has no dyspnoea
column72: orthopnoea or oedema
column73: which has allowed complete suspension of the diuretic without the need to reintroduce it. The last echocardiogram showed severe aortic insufficiency with moderate-severe mitral insufficiency and preserved biventricular function. The decompensation that occurred during the puerperium was interpreted in the context of the haemodynamic changes that occur during pregnancy
column74: so for the time being a wait-and-see attitude is maintained with close clinical and echocardiographic monitoring.  DIAGNOSIS Preeclampsia (gestational hypertension + severity criteria - thrombopenia). Acute pulmonary oedema
column75: favoured by severe mitral and aortic insufficiency
column76: with preserved LVEF. Antiphospholipid syndrome (carrier of lupus anticoagulant and B2-glycoprotein
column77: with thrombotic episodes). |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O O O O O B-FARMACO column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History 59-year-old woman. No cardiovascular risk factors or previous pathological history. No chronic treatment.   Present illness On 8 March the patient was giving a speech at a rally for Women's Day. Suddenly and before she could finish reading her manifesto
column3: she suffered a sudden syncopal episode
column4: without prodromes and with spontaneous recovery after a few seconds. On regaining consciousness she presented with epigastric pain radiating to the left hemithorax with associated vegetative cortex. The patient had no palpitations or dyspnoea prior to syncope. Unable to finish her speech
column5: she was referred to the emergency department for assessment.  Physical examination Blood pressure 104/60 mmHg
column6: heart rate 75 bpm
column7: oxygen saturation by pulse oximetry 97% on room air. Afebrile. Good general condition. Conscious and oriented. Eupneic at rest
column8: tolerates decubitus. No jugular ingurgitation. Cardiac auscultation: regular
column9: rhythmic heart sounds
column10: no murmurs or pathological sounds. Pulmonary auscultation: normal ventilation in all lung fields. Abdomen: soft
column11: depressible
column12: non-painful
column13: without megaliths. Lower extremities: no oedema
column14: distal pulses present.    COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Electrocardiogram on admission: sinus bradycardia at 58 bpm. Normal PR. Narrow QRS
column15: normal axis at -10o. ST segment elevation of 1mm in V5-V6. QTc 388 ms. Electrocardiogram at discharge: sinus bradycardia at 44 bpm. Normal PR
column16: narrow QRS
column17: axis at 0o. Negative T wave in V4-V6
column18: I and aVL
column19: II; flat T wave in III and aVF. QTc 391 ms. Chest X-ray: normal cardiothoracic index. No alveolar consolidation or pleural effusion. Laboratory tests: biochemistry: normal thyroid function. Creatinine 0.57 mg/dl. Total cholesterol 225 mg/dl (HDL 31 mg/dl; LDL 176 mg/dl). Serum total bilirubin 0
column20: 59 mg/dl. Total proteins 6.1 g/dl
column21: albumin 3 g/dl. Chlorine 108 mEq/l
column22: potassium 4.7 mEq/l
column23: sodium 141 mEq/l. CK 138 U/l
column24: FA 87 U/l
column25: GGT 19 U/l
column26: GOT 32 U/l
column27: GPT 13 U/l
column28: LDH 158 U/l. Glycosylated haemoglobin 5.5%. Troponin I 4
column29: 468 ng/l (normal < 11.6 ng/l)
column31: 909 pg/ml. Haemogram: leucocytes 5000/mm3 (N 2
column34: haemoglobin 14.2 g/dl
column35: platelets 171
column36: 000/mm3.  Cardiac catheterisation: Coronary angiography: right dominance. Left common trunk without angiographic stenosis. Anterior descending (AD) with angiographically mildly moderate stenosis in the proximal third
column37: the rest of the main vessel has no angiographic stenosis. Rest of vessels without angiographic stenosis. Optical coherence tomography (OCT) was performed on the LAD
column38: which in the proximal segment showed a minimal luminal area of 4.22 mm2 with integrity of the endothelium despite plaque burden. Functional assessment shows RFR 0.93
column39: after hyperemia with i.v. adenosine FFR 0.90 and microcirculation study shows CFR 2 and IMR 44: evidence of microvascular dysfunction. Ventriculography shows a left ventricle (LV) of normal size with akinesia of all apical segments and hypercontractility of the basal segments. No intraventricular or aortic transvalvular gradient was detected.  Cardiac magnetic resonance: findings compatible with takotsubo syndrome. Diffuse hypersignal indicating the presence of oedema in the middle segments
column40: apical segments and apex segment in T2-weighted T2-weighted TSE-FAT SAT sequences in short axis and two chambers. Absence of late gadolinium enhancement. Currently no apical dyskinesia is identified (with synchronous and homogeneous contractility)
column41: left ventricular ejection fraction 71%. No associated apical thrombus is observed. Right ventricle (RV) with normal function.  Echocardiogram at discharge: left ventricle of normal size and thickness. Left ventricular ejection fraction normal
column42: without contractile asymmetries. Left ventricular end-diastolic pressure data not elevated. Right ventricle normal in structure and function. Mitral valve normal in structure and function with minimal insufficiency. Normal tricuspid valve
column43: with minimal tricuspid insufficiency allowing estimation of a pulmonary artery systolic pressure (PSAP) of 25 mmHg. Trivalve aortic valve. The aortic root is of normal size. There is no pericardial effusion.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION The patient was referred to the emergency department of our hospital
column44: where an electrocardiogram was performed
column45: showing ST segment elevation of 1 mm in the lower lateral face. It was decided to perform emergent coronary angiography. Cardiac catheterisation revealed a coronary tree with no lesions
column46: except for angiographically mild-moderate stenosis in the proximal LAD. To assess the stenosis of the LAD
column47: it was decided to perform an optical coherence tomography (OCT) study. The OCT showed a luminal area greater than 4 mm2 with integrity of the endothelium. The haemodynamic study was completed with an assessment of the microcirculation showing microvascular dysfunction with a low coronary flow reserve (CFR) and a high microvascular resistance index (MRI). Ventriculography was performed
column48: showing akinesia of the apical segments with hypercontractility of the basal segments; all highly suggestive of tako-tsubo syndrome. The patient was admitted haemodynamically stable and pain-free to the cardiac intermediate care unit. She progressed favourably
column49: with no new chest pain
column50: no signs of heart failure and no arrhythmic events. Electrocardiographically
column51: there was a progressive negativisation of the T wave in the anterolateral and inferior face. The study was completed with a cardiac MRI scan showing oedema in the middle and apical segments with absence of late gadolinium enhancement
column52: findings compatible with tako-tsubo syndrome. Prior to discharge
column53: an echocardiogram was performed showing recovery of myocardial contractility. In view of the good evolution
column54: hospital discharge was decided with treatment with bisoprolol 2.5 mg every 24 hours
column55: enalapril 2.5 mg every 24 hours and atorvastatin 40 mg every 24 hours.  DIAGNOSIS Tako-tsubo syndrome. Microvascular dysfunction. Global and segmental left ventricular systolic function recovered at discharge. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History 54-year-old woman. No known allergies. No cardiovascular risk factors or toxic habits. Bilateral pneumonia due to COVID-19
column3: requiring hospital admission and treatment with high-dose corticoid. During admission she reported lumbar pain and was diagnosed by CT scan with a fracture of L2
column4: being treated conservatively. She was discharged 4 days before the current episode. On treatment with omeprazole 20 mg every 24 hours
column5: dexamethasone 2 mg every 24 hours
column6: metamizole 575 mg every 8 hours if required due to pain and enoxaparin 40 mg every 24 hours.  Current illness Patient presented to the emergency department with progressive dyspnoea for 48 hours with central thoracic pressure that improved with sitting. The pain does not change with inspiration. The patient reports progressive swelling of the lower limbs and increased abdominal perimeter since discharge from hospital for COVID-19 pneumonia (4 days ago). She denies fever or dysthermic sensation. Pain with mechanical characteristics persists in the upper lumbar region
column7: secondary to L2 fracture during the previous admission.  Physical examination Blood pressure 100/50 mmHg

column89: ESR 76.  CLINICAL COURSE The patient was initially seen in the emergency department of our hospital. Given the signs of heart failure predominantly on the right and the central thoracic pain
column90: together with the elevation of acute phase reactants in the laboratory tests
column91: it was decided to admit the patient for further investigation. During her stay in the ED
column92: the patient presented a peak fever of 38.2oC and blood cultures were taken. The echocardiogram on admission showed severe pericardial effusion with signs of echocardiographic repercussions
column93: but no clinical signs at that time. Blood cultures showed growth of SAMS. Suspicion of purulent pericarditis led to subxiphoid pericardial drainage and antibiotic therapy was started with cefazolin and daptomycin. Pericardial fluid cultures were sterile but the biochemical characteristics of the fluid were infectious. The patient's symptoms did not clearly improve despite drainage of the pericardial fluid
column94: so a transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) was requested to rule out the presence of endocarditis and to evaluate the progression of the effusion. This TEE showed constrictive physiology data suggestive of effusive-constrictive pericarditis. In addition to the cardiorespiratory symptoms
column95: the patient presented pain in the upper lumbar region
column96: both shoulders and left lower extremity. In view of the suspicion of septic foci
column97: the study was completed with thoracoabdominal CT and magnetic resonance imaging of both shoulders and lumbar region. Imaging studies confirmed the presence of septic arthritis in both shoulders
column98: spondylodiscitis at L2-L3 and multiple abscesses in bilateral psoas. The patient also presented a lesion on the left lower extremity compatible with cellulitis.  Due to the persistence of fever
column99: despite targeted antibiotherapy
column100: the abscesses in the psoas muscle were drained and SAMS was again isolated in the fluid culture. The control echocardiogram showed slight pericardial effusion with no signs of haemodynamic compromise or constrictive physiology. Slow evolution of the patient
column101: with progressive disappearance of the different infectious foci and clinical improvement without new episodes of fever. Periodic blood cultures were negative. Finally
column102: after 8 weeks of intravenous antibiotics
column103: she was discharged for outpatient follow-up. Treatment at discharge was omeprazole 20 mg every 24 hours
column104: dexketoprofen 25 mg every 12 hours
column105: colchicine 0.5 mg every 24 hours
column106: paracetamol 1 g every 8 hours and bemiparin 7
column107: 500 IU every 24 hours.  DIAGNOSIS Persistent SAMS bacteraemia with multiple foci (purulent pericarditis
column111: bilateral septic shoulder arthritis). column1: Personal history We present the case of a 56-year-old Caucasian woman
column2: administrative profession. She had no known cardiovascular risk factors
column3: except obesity. Her cardiological history included an admission one year earlier for an episode of unstable angina with cardiac catheterisation that revealed a critical lesion of the ostial left main coronary artery (LMCA)
column4: on which a drug-eluting stent was implanted
column5: with no significant lesions in the rest of the coronary arteries. The transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) performed during this admission showed a left ventricle of normal size and thickness
column6: with normal global systolic function and segmental contractility and no significant valvulopathies. His medical history included a diagnosis of autoimmune hepatitis since 1998
column7: for which he was receiving chronic treatment with immunosuppressants (azathioprine) in addition to bisoprolol 2.5mg/24 hours
column8: lansoprazole
column9: acetylsalicylic acid
column10: clopidogrel and atorvastatin 20 mg.  Current illness and physical examination In the last few months
column11: the patient reported symptoms of asthenia and dyspnoea
column12: without chest pain
column13: with progressive worsening of the functional grade up to NYHA functional grade III/IV
column14: for which reason a stress test had been requested. The exercise test was stopped early due to hypertensive crisis with dyspnoea and electrical positivity. That same day
column15: hours after the exercise stress test
column16: he attended the Emergency Department of our hospital due to a sudden episode of dyspnoea and acute pulmonary oedema. On arrival at the ED he had a BP in MSI of 95/60 and in MSD of 146/70 mmHg
column17: a heart rate of 85 bpm
column18: a baseline saturation of 92% and was afebrile. On cardiac auscultation he had rhythmic heart sounds
column19: with aortic diastolic murmur III/IV and mitral systolic murmur III/VI. He had bilateral crackles up to the upper fields with no oedema in the lower limbs. In the upper limbs
column20: there was a decrease in radial and brachial pulses in the left upper limb (MSI) compared to the right upper limb (MSD).  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Blood count: Hb 12.9g/dl
column21: leukocytes 10
column23: platelets 480
column24: 000. Coagulation: PT 98%
column25: FD 700. Urgent blood biochemistry: Glc 158 mg/dl
column26: U 39 mg/dl
column27: Cr 0.98 mg/dl
column28: Na 139 mmol/l
column29: K 4 mmol/l
column31: TnT (ultrasensitive
column32: upper limit 35 ng/l): 27 ng/l. Complete biochemistry: Glc 89 mg/dl
column33: U 46 mg/dl
column34: Cr 0.83 mg/dl
column35: eGFR >60ml/min/1.7
column36: urate 7 mg/dl
column37: Na 141 mmol/l
column38: K 4 mmol/l
column39: Ca 2.36 mmol/l
column40: phosphate 1.51 mmol/l
column41: CK 65 U/l
column42: LDH 178 U/l
column43: FA 57 U/l
column44: ALT 11U/L
column45: BrT <1 mg/dl
column46: total protein 66 g/l
column47: creatinine 133 mg/dl
column48: CRP 2.2 mg/dl. Immunological study: positive ANAs autoantibodies at 1/320 titre
column49: with nucleolar pattern. The rest was normal.  Electrocardiogram: sinus rhythm
column50: left anterior hemiblock and subepicardial ischaemia in the anterolateral region. Chest X-ray: compatible with acute pulmonary oedema. Transthoracic and transesophageal echocardiogram: left ventricle slightly dilated and hypertrophic
column51: with moderately depressed systolic function (LVEF estimated by Simpson at 42%) at the expense of a global hypokinesia
column52: more marked in anterior and lateral regions. The aortic valve was trivalve
column53: with no evidence of vegetation or prolapse and presented severe aortic insufficiency with a central regurgitant jet originating at the level of the entire commissure between the non-coronary and left coronary leaflets with coaptation defect of the leaflets
column54: suggesting leaflet retraction at this level as the underlying mechanism. The aortic root was of normal size. At mitral valve level a mitral insufficiency (MI) grade 2 was detected and at tricuspid level a severe tricuspid insufficiency (TI) which estimated a pulmonary artery systolic pressure of approximately 80 mmHg. Cardiac catheterisation: occlusion of the right coronary artery at the ostial level which was filled by collateral circulation. The patency of the stent previously implanted at the level of the left main coronary artery persisted. Angio-CT of the thoracic aorta: thickening of the arterial wall of the common carotid arteries and of the left subclavian artery
column55: which is occluded with filiform tracts affecting the occlusion at the origin of the left vertebral artery
column56: and of the superior mesenteric artery
column57: which is also occluded with hypertrophy of the pancreaticoduodenal arcade. There is no calcium deposit in any of the lesions
column58: ulcerations
column59: dissection or aneurysm. Infectious serology: HBsAg
column60: anti-HCV
column61: HIV Ag+Ac and Syphilis G+M negative. Biopsy (aortic valve): the sample submitted as aortic valve with presence of myxoid degenerative changes and chronic lymphocytic inflammatory infiltrate.  EVOLUTION We present the case of a 56-year-old woman with a cardiac history of ostial LMCA disease revascularised percutaneously with a drug-eluting stent one year earlier
column62: who was admitted with acute pulmonary oedema. Physical examination of the patient revealed the presence of murmurs in aortic and mitral foci
column63: suggestive of valve disease at these levels
column64: which were not present in the echocardiogram of a year earlier
column65: as well as a clear decrease in pulses in MSI together with a significant discordance between systolic blood pressure between both upper limbs (BP in MSI of 95/60 and in MSD of 146/70 mmHg). In addition to a more marked global hypokinesia in the anterior and lateral regions
column66: the presence of severe aortic insufficiency (AIo)
column67: the mechanism of which appeared to be a coaptation defect of the non-coronary and left coronary leaflets due to their retraction
column68: with a normal-sized aortic root. Given the ischaemic alterations in the ECG on admission and the segmental alterations in contractility in the echocardiogram
column69: coronary angiography was performed in the following 24 hours
column70: which showed the previous stent in the IVC to be permeable and without restenosis
column71: and occlusion of the ostial right coronary artery
column72: which at that time was pending a decision on revascularisation strategy. Given the findings consisting of asymmetry in pulses and blood pressure in both upper limbs
column73: ostial coronary lesions and severe aortic insufficiency of subacute onset
column74: together with a history of autoimmune involvement and in a patient without CVRF
column75: an aortic CT angiography was requested with suspicion of aortitis
column76: in addition to complete immunological studies
column77: acute phase reactants (APR) and serology. Angio-CT showed thickening of the arterial wall of both common carotid arteries and left subclavian
column78: left vertebral and superior mesenteric arteries. A diagnosis of aortitis in the context of large vessel vasculitis was established. Treatment was started with glucocorticoids at a dose of 1.5 mg/kg with a subsequent tapering regimen
column79: and the dose of azathioprine that the patient was taking was doubled. After presenting her case at a medical-surgical session (Heart Team)
column80: surgical treatment was decided once the patient was stabilised
column81: with resolution of the acute pulmonary oedema. After 10 days of treatment with oral glucocorticoids
column82: the aortic valve was replaced with a metallic prosthesis no. 21 and coronary revascularisation by means of aorto-coronary bypass from the saphenous vein to the middle anterior descending artery and proximal right coronary artery. During surgery
column83: the aorta was also affected
column84: with marked thickening of both the aortic wall and the wall of the coronary arteries
column85: as well as friability of these tissues and the aortic annulus. After the procedure
column86: she presented haemodynamic instability
column87: requiring high-dose amines and intra-aortic balloon counterpulsation. 24 hours later the patient was in cardiogenic shock related to perioperative infarction. She presented a slow evolution in the following days with poor tolerance to amine weaning and removal of the balloon with severe haemodynamic instability and progression to multi-organ failure
column88: and finally exitus. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History 44-year-old woman
column3: who years ago suffered a skin reaction compatible with allergy to ibuprofen and metamizole
column4: without subsequent confirmation by allergology. Active smoker of 10 cigarettes a day for about 20 years (IPA approximately 10)
column5: denies alcohol habit. History: hypercholesterolemia
column6: on treatment with atorvastatin 80 mg for 5 years
column7: Graves' disease with mild orbitopathy (at last check-up she was euthyroid) and bronchial asthma being monitored by pulmonology and treated with salmeterol/fluticasone propionate every 12 hours and salbutamol on demand. Family history: father with hypercholesterolemia and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Mother with hypercholesterolemia. Three siblings
column8: no data known. Two children
column9: one 15 years old pending analysis and one 13 years old with LDL 215 mg/dl on treatment by her paediatrician with rosuvastatin 20 mg/ezetimibe 10 mg and pending genetic study of HFHe).  Current illness She came to the emergency department for clinical symptoms that began 3 weeks earlier
column10: consisting of progressive dyspnoea until minimal effort
column11: increased oedema in the lower limbs
column12: paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea crisis
column13: palpitations with a sensation of irradiation to the neck
column14: multiple ecchymosis in the upper and lower limbs and hypoaesthesia in the left lower limb. He denies orthopnoea or diuresis curtailment. She has not presented chest pain. No arthralgias or arthritis
column15: nor oral aphthous ulcers. No fever at home.  Physical examination Blood pressure 129/84 mmHg
column16: heart rate 85 bpm
column17: respiratory rate 18 rpm
column18: temperature 37.6 oC. Acceptable general condition
column19: conscious
column20: oriented and cooperative. Well hydrated and perfused
column21: normal colour. Slight tachypnoea at rest
column22: with slurred speech although maintaining baseline oxygen saturation 97%
column23: mild dysphonia. Glasgow 15/15. Cardiac auscultation showed rhythmic tones at a good frequency without murmurs
column24: without pericardial friction. Respiratory auscultation showed minimal bibasal crackles and some isolated wheezing. The abdomen is unremarkable. The neurological examination showed isochoric pupils that were normoreactive to light
column25: preserved cranial nerves
column26: diminished gross tactile sensitivity in the left lower limb
column27: more marked in the anterior thigh region. Gait was not examined. The lower limbs showed oedema with fovea up to mid-leg
column28: with signs of chronic venous insufficiency
column29: without signs of deep vein thrombosis
column30: with peripheral pulses present and symmetrical. There were multiple small ecchymoses on the upper and lower limbs.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS On arrival at the ED: Analysis: high sensitivity troponin I 855.40 ng/l (normal 2-15.6) and C-reactive protein 32.7 mg/l (normal < 5). Haemoglobin 14.2 g/dl
column31: leucocytes 10.08 x10^3/μl
column32: with eosinophils 1.68 x10^3/μl (normal 0.02-0.55) and platelets 79 x10^3/μl. Coagulation was normal except for D-dimer 1
column33: 785 ng/ml (normal < 500). Electrocardiogram on arrival: sinus rhythm at 93 bpm
column34: PR 0.14 s constant
column35: QRS 0.10 s
column36: electrical axis over +90o
column37: ST depression of 1 mm in II
column38: III
column39: aVF
column40: V3-V6
column41: flattened T waves in inferior leads and negative in V3-V6. Chest X-ray showed no cardiomegaly or parenchymal condensation. Prominent hilarity was present. No pleural effusion or costophrenic sinus impingement was observed. Given the findings
column42: myocardial damage marker serology was requested
column43: as well as a chest CT angiography for suspected pulmonary thromboembolism. Chest CT angiography: no signs of pulmonary thromboembolism were observed
column44: the pulmonary parenchyma showed no alterations
column45: subcentimetric adenopathies of probably reactive appearance were observed at the para-aortic
column46: right paratracheal
column47: hilar and subcarinal levels of 1.5 cm. Control laboratory tests at 4 hours: troponin I increased to 1
column49: with normal CK. During his stay in the intensive care unit and on the internal medicine hospital ward: given the clinical suspicion
column50: an autoimmune panel was urgently requested
column51: in which positive anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies were found with positive anti-myeloperoxidase antibodies (IgG) (19.1 IU/ml [0-6])
column52: the rest negative. Serialisation of myocardial damage markers was continued
column53: with a peak value of troponin I of 5
column54: 065 ng/l. The peak value of brain pro-brain natriuretic peptide was 6
column55: 819.8 pg/ml (high probability of heart failure in patients under 55 years of age if > 450 pg/ml). In the routine analysis
column56: extracted 72 hours after admission
column57: glucose 157 mg/dl
column58: LDL cholesterol 261 mg/dl
column59: HDL cholesterol 59 mg/dl
column60: triglycerides 155 mg/dl
column61: lactate dehydrogenase 449 U/l (125-220)
column62: complement C3 61 mg/dl (90-180) with normal C4
column63: thyrotropin 0.34 μUI/ml (0.35-4.94)
column64: free thyroxine 0.85 ng/dl (0.7-1.48)
column65: free triiodothyronine 1.62 pg/ml (1.71-3.71). HIV screening and other infectious immunodiagnostic tests were negative. The bedside echocardiogram performed in intensive care on admission showed a non-dilated left ventricle (LV) with preserved systolic function
column66: even hypercontractile with concentric hypertrophy with an interventricular septum of 14 mm and a posterior wall of 13 mm. Aortic root not dilated. Dilated right ventricle (RV) with a basal diameter of 39 mm
column67: 10 mm lateral wall with hyperechoic image adjacent to the lateral wall. Triscuspid insufficiency with estimated pulmonary arterial systolic pressure (PSAP) of 100 mmHg. Dilated right atrium (RA) with an area of 22 cm2. Normal mitral flow pattern. Mild pericardial effusion adjacent to LV. Echocardiogram performed by cardiology 72 hours after admission showed (body surface area 1.9 m2). Non-dilated LV (DTD 47 mm
column69: without hypertrophy at baseline (IVS 9
column70: PP 9 mm)
column71: although progressive thickening from mid segments and especially apex (15 mm)
column72: with preserved global systolic function (EF 71% 4C)
column73: without evident alterations of segmental contractility. Restrictive mitral filling pattern
column74: with E/A 2.2
column75: e' 6 cm/s
column76: E/e' 14. Dilated right chambers (RV 42 mm basal
column77: RA 18 cm2). RV normocontractile (TAPSE 19 mm
column78: s-wave 12 cm/s). Dilated left atrium (LA) (38 ml/m2). Without good visualisation of the aortic root
column79: apparently not dilated. Dilated inferior vena cava (IVC) (27 mm)
column80: with little inspiratory collapse. Dilatation of suprahepatic veins. Slight inferior pericardial effusion (2 mm)
column81: with no signs of haemodynamic compromise. No apparent intracavitary thrombus. Trivalve aortic valve with preserved mobility. Normal aortic flow. Normal mitral valve morphology. Mild central mitral insufficiency. Mild tricuspid and pulmonary insufficiency
column82: estimating PSAP of 49 mmHg (V max 2.9 m/s) and PMAP of 30 mmHg (V max 1.9 m/s). Pulmonary TA 105 ms. In short
column83: he presented a pattern of myocardial restriction
column84: non-dilated LV with preserved EF
column85: apical hypertrophy
column86: severe diastolic dysfunction
column87: slightly dilated RV with preserved EF
column88: high probability of pulmonary hypertension
column89: biauricular dilatation
column90: mild mitral and tricuspid insufficiency
column91: mild pericardial effusion. Given the clinical history
column92: compatible with Löffler's endocarditis. After a week of admission
column93: left and right cardiac catheterisation was performed. After obtaining 6F radial access
column94: a good calibre LMCA with no angiographic lesions
column95: a good calibre anterior descending artery (ADA) with no angiographic lesions and good distal flow
column96: a good calibre circumflex artery (Cx) with no angiographic lesions and good distal flow
column97: and a dominant right coronary artery (RCA) with good calibre
column98: no angiographic lesions and good distal flow were visualised. The left ventriculography showed a non-dilated left ventricle with severe apical hypertrophy
column99: preserved systolic function with LVEF 64.5%
column100: mild mitral insufficiency
column101: LV end-diastolic pressure of 29 mmHg. Regarding right catheterisation
column102: AD pressure = 25 mmHg
column103: RV systolic pressure = 43 mmHg
column104: RV diastolic pressure = 11 mmHg
column105: mean RV pressure = 15 mmHg
column106: pulmonary systolic pressure = 45 mmHg
column107: pulmonary diastolic pressure = 28 mmHg
column109: diastolic transpulmonary gradient = PAMP - PCP = 4 mmHg
column110: concluding in isolated postcapillary pulmonary hypertension. Right ventriculography showed significant apical hypertrophy with preserved ejection fraction (RVEF 52%)
column111: mild tricuspid insufficiency and mild pulmonary insufficiency. An endomyocardial biopsy was performed with 3 samples taken (right ventricle). The septal biopsy showed a fibrous cap of normal thickness overlying myocardium
column113: with no histological criteria for endocarditis. The apex biopsy is a minimal fragment of lax fibrous tissue without inflammatory changes and haematic material
column114: unsatisfactory for diagnosis. The basal biopsy is a small fragment of endocardium
column117: suggestive of reactive and slight haematic infiltrate secondary to biopsy
column118: without inflammatory infiltration. Cardiac MRI performed prior to the start of cyclophosphamide showed non-dilated ventricles with preserved systolic function
column119: findings compatible with biventricular endomyocardial fibrosis
column120: with organised left ventricular apical thrombus
column121: secondary to granulomatosis with polyangiitis (late-stage endomyocardial fibrosis)
column122: tethering of the inferior papillary muscle and slight hypokinesis of apical segments and apex of the left ventricle
column123: as well as of the apical segment of the right ventricular free wall
column126: pericarditis with signs of active inflammation and slight pericardial effusion. Myocardial septal thickness 10 mm; anterior 11 mm; lateral 10 mm; inferior 11 mm. End-diastolic diameter 49 mm; end-systolic diameter 35 mm. Relative wall thickness 0.24. Indexed mass: 39 g/m2. Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging at 4 months (video 2) showed a significant decrease in the thickness of the distal segments with respect to the previous study
column127: no tethering of the inferior papillary muscle
column128: ventricles with slightly reduced volumes and normal systolic function and slight pericardial effusion. In short
column130: there was a great improvement in ventricular thicknesses and apical thrombus
column131: which has disappeared. Measurements: left ventricle: septum 5 mm
column152: LVEF 58%. Left atrium: area in 4 chambers 16 cm2. Right atrium: area in 4 chambers 19 cm2. Sinus aorta (diameter in sinuses of Valsalva): 28 mm. Ascending aorta: 25 mm. Descending aorta: 19 mm.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION After first-level complementary tests were performed in the emergency department with the findings described
column154: which was ruled out by angio-CT. Given the clinical picture and the analytical data
column155: it was decided to admit the patient to intensive care. This unit consulted with internal medicine for assessment. Due to his history (sinusitis
column163: etc.) and echocardiographic data of myocardial infiltration compatible with Löffler's endocarditis
column164: it was suspected that it could be APEEG
column165: and an urgent ANCA ELISA study was requested
column166: which was positive (myeloperoxidase). Steroid treatment was started immediately with boluses of 1 g of 6-methylprednisolone for 3 consecutive days
column167: with significant clinical improvement reflected in the analytical parameters (thrombopenia
column169: to be continued with 60 mg of prednisone daily. After 7 days of hospitalisation
column170: cyclophosphamide was administered in boluses of 500 mg (fixed dose) every 15 days
column171: which were programmed to complete 6 boluses. Right and left cardiac catheterisation was performed with biopsy
column172: which did not clarify the diagnosis. Clinically and haemodynamically stable
column173: she was discharged from hospital after 2 weeks of admission
column174: under treatment with prednisone 60 mg at breakfast (which was progressively reduced to 15 mg)
column176: ibandronic acid (1 tablet monthly at fasting)
column178: acetylsalicylic acid 100 mg (1 tablet at lunch)
column179: omeprazole (1 capsule at breakfast) and atorvastatin 80 mg (1 tablet at dinner).  Outpatient follow-up showed total cholesterol 413 mg/dl
column180: non-HDL cholesterol 326 mg/dl and triglycerides 308 mg/dl
column181: and treatment was started with anti-PCSK9 (evolocumab 140 mg subcutaneous every 2 weeks) and omega-3 acid ethyl esters (two capsules every 12 hours). The response was spectacular
column182: with LDL cholesterol reduced to 62 mg/dl
column183: HDL cholesterol 66 mg/dl and triglycerides 125 mg/dl. Dyspnoea did not return and acute phase reactants remained normal
column184: with no eosinophilia.  DIAGNOSIS Congestive heart failure and isolated postcapillary pulmonary hypertension related to acute myocarditis (Loeffler's endocarditis) with myocardial restriction pattern and severe diastolic dysfunction in the context of eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis. Apical thrombus in the left ventricle resolved. Moderate thrombopenia of autoimmune origin resolved. Euthyroid patient syndrome. Primary familial hypercholesterolemia (very probable HFHe). column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History Male
column3: 72 years old. No known drug allergies. No toxic habits. Arterial hypertension of 10 years of evolution
column4: in treatment with bisoprolol and enalapril. Altered basal glycaemia of 2 years of evolution
column5: on dietary treatment. No known cardiological history. No other medical or surgical history of interest. Home treatment: bisoprolol 5 mg (two tablets every 24 h); ramipril 5 mg (1-0-0).  Present illness He presented to his health centre with nausea and general malaise of two hours' duration. No palpitations or chest pain. No syncope. No evidence of heart failure. During his stay at the health centre
column6: frequent episodes of incessant wide QRS tachycardia with rapid rates (200 bpm) were recorded on the monitor and he was transferred to hospital.  Physical examination Blood pressure (BP) 120/70 mmHG
column7: heart rate (HR) 80 bpm
column8: oxygen saturation 100%. Good general condition. Normal skin and mucous membrane colouring. No jugular plethora. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic heart tones
column9: no murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation: preserved vesicular murmur.  Abdominal examination: soft
column10: depressible
column11: no megaliths
column12: no pain
column13: preserved peristaltic sounds. Extremities: no oedema
column14: with preserved peripheral pulses.   COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Baseline electrocardiogram (ECG): atrial fibrillation with controlled ventricular response. QRS of 120 ms
column15: intraventricular conduction disorders. No signs of acute ischaemia. Presence of frequent ventricular extrasystoles (VE) with right ventricular outflow tract (RVOT) morphology. Electrocardiogram during tachycardia: wide QRS tachycardia
column16: with morphology of complete left bundle branch block
column17: left inferior axis
column18: cycle 260 ms. Regular R-R. Prior to the onset of tachycardia we observed frequent right ventricular outflow tract extrasystoles with a different morphology to that of the tachycardia (R more prominent and positive in III). Laboratory tests on admission: haemoglobin 15.9 g/dl
column19: leucocytes 5.20 10^3/μl
column20: platelets 113.0 10^3/μl. Prothrombin time (PT) s 14.4. Quick's index 65%. INR 1.33. APTT (T. cephalin) s 47.1. Glucose 93 mg/dl
column21: urea 22.0 mg/dl
column22: creatinine 0.95 mg/dl
column23: uric acid 5.1 mg/dl
column24: albumin 4.3 g/dl
column25: total protein 7.0 g/dl. Total cholesterol 148 mg/dl
column26: HDL cholesterol 34.5 mg/dl
column27: non-HDL cholesterol 113.5 mg/dl
column28: LDL cholesterol 102.9 mg/dl
column29: VLDL cholesterol 10.6 mg/dl
column31: sodium 136 mm/l
column32: potassium 4.0 mm/l
column33: phosphorus 2.7 mg/dl
column34: total bilirubin 0.98 mg/dl. GPT (ALT) 28.4 U/l
column35: GOT (AST) 35.7 U/l
column36: gamma GT 34.5 U/l
column37: alkaline phosphatase 53.0 U/l
column38: LDH 221.5 U/l
column39: creatine kinase 288 U/l
column40: glycosylated haemoglobin A1c (DCCT) 6.0%. Thyroid stimulating hormone 0.310 mIU/l
column41: free T3 - free triiodothyronine 2.54 pg/ml
column42: free T4 - free thyroxine 0.84 ng/dl. Myocardial damage markers (troponin I and CK-MB) were normal serially x 3. Chest X-ray: normal. Cardiothoracic index (CTI) within normal. Transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) on admission: non-dilated left ventricle (LV) with moderate concentric hypertrophy. Moderate-severe ventricular dysfunction (LVEF 35% by Simpson biplane)
column43: global hypokinesia with worse anterior contractility. Slightly dilated left atrium. Structurally normal mitral valve with mild insufficiency. Aortic valve trivalve
column44: sclerotic
column45: normofunctioning. Normal tricuspid valve. Non-dilated right ventricle (RV) with good systolic function. No pericardial effusion. Transthoracic echocardiogram at one week: non-dilated LV with moderate concentric hypertrophy. Global systolic function preserved without contractility alterations. LVEF by Simpson BP 55%. Rest unchanged with respect to previous study. Coronary angiography: left vascular tree without lesions. Dominant right coronary artery (RCA)
column46: with lesion of doubtful significance in the middle third. After intravascular ultrasound (IVUS)
column47: 70% stenosis was found. Revascularisation: right coronary: direct drug-eluting stent implantation (Resolute Onix 4 x 12 mm) in the middle third. Good final angiographic result. Electrophysiological study (EEF): with right femoral venous access. There is evidence of atrial fibrillation (AF) with EV with left bundle branch block morphology (LBBB) ID axis with other advanced complexes and wide QRS presenting LBBB with axis II. A pathological HV of 80 msg is evident
column48: which is difficult to maintain stable. High-dose aleudrine increased atrioventricular (AV) conduction to a HR of 120-130 without aberrant conduction. After TEE ruled out thrombi in the left atrium (LA)
column49: electrical cardioversion (ECV) was performed with a switch to SR with 200 J in biphasic mode. Aleudrine induced ventricular tachycardia in a fairly reproducible manner (periods without AV ratio 1x1
column50: with AV dissociation with morphology equal to the clinical one [LBBB and with transition in V4-V5])
column51: well tolerated and with a cycle of 260 msg. In the case of suspected branch-branch ventricular tachycardia (BRVT)
column52: attempts are made to obtain stable His
column53: which is impossible using Josephson tetra
column54: His tetra and deflectable decapolar. Neither is it possible to analyse pacing from the RA because of the large pacing artefact that prevents verification of the QRS morphology. However
column55: we concluded that it was RRVT with other criteria: return cycle from RV apex of 0 and electrogram of right ventricular apex early on the onset of the QRS. Right bundle branch ablation was performed using a conventional 4 mm FJ catheter
column56: which was achieved after three applications. The right bundle branch was found not to lead for 30 minutes. Subsequently
column57: a DDDR Boston bicameral pacemaker was implanted.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION With the diagnosis of probable ventricular tachycardia
column58: treatment was started with beta-blockers and amiodarone
column59: and he was admitted to the cardiology ward with telemetry. Forty-eight hours after admission
column60: during his stay on the ward
column61: a transthoracic echocardiogram was performed
column62: showing the presence of severe global LV dysfunction
column63: with worse contractility in the anterior territory
column64: which recovered completely one week after admission. Coronary angiography was performed
column65: which revealed an intermediate lesion in the mid-right coronary artery. Revascularisation with a drug-eluting stent was considered. Given the clinical presentation (no chest pain
column66: no signs of acute ischaemia in the electrocardiogram and no elevation of myocardial damage markers)
column67: the presence of severe global ventricular dysfunction that recovered early after control of the arrhythmia was considered as dysfunction secondary to tachycardiomyopathy. Finally
column68: an electrophysiological study was performed which documented
column69: firstly
column70: that it was a ventricular tachycardia (existence of VA dissociation) and subsequently
column71: by means of manoeuvres
column72: that it was a branch-branch ventricular tachycardia (electrogram of the right ventricular apex early on the start of the QRS) and
column73: another fundamental fact
column74: the return cycle was very short (10 ms) after the tachycardia was triggered from the RV apex. Right bundle branch ablation and DDD pacemaker implantation was performed (due to HV lengthening up to 100 ms). Once discharged
column75: the patient's evolution has been excellent. No arrhythmic recurrences. Ejection fraction remained preserved. In addition
column76: he was referred to neurology consultations to rule out the possibility of neuromuscular disease (due to its association with this type of tachycardia in patients without heart disease)
column77: and an electromyogram and genetic study were performed
column78: which ruled out this possibility.  DIAGNOSIS Branch-branch ventricular tachycardia (BRVT). Tachycardiomyopathy. Preserved left ventricular function at discharge. Intermediate lesion in the middle DC. Revascularisation by drug-eluting stent implantation. Right bundle branch ablation. Implantation of DDDR Boston pacemaker. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO O B-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO
