column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION We present a 65-year-old man with no known drug allergies. Background As personal history
column3: he is being treated with ezetimibe/atorvastatin 10/80 mg for familial hypercholesterolaemia (last available LDL 50 mg/dl). No other known cardiovascular risk factors
column4: no toxic habits. Body mass index (BMI) 26.7 (overweight). With regard to family history
column5: history of early ischaemic heart disease in a brother at 50 years of age (he died for this reason).  Current disease A 65-year-old patient with the aforementioned history came to the emergency department referred by 061 after presenting at home with oppressive central thoracic pain with associated vegetative crusade lasting 15 minutes. He had not presented with previous episodes of chest pain. The electrocardiogram performed by the emergency department showed anterolateral ST elevation
column6: so ticagrelor (180 mg) and aspirin (300 mg) were administered and the infarction code was activated.  Physical examination During transfer by 061 and on arrival at the haemodynamics room
column7: the patient was haemodynamically stable
column8: well perfused
column9: with the need for low-flow oxygen. Vital signs: blood pressure 121/85 mmHg
column10: heart rate 75 bpm. Oxygen saturation 93% with nasal goggles at 2 bpm. Eupneic at rest. On cardiac auscultation rhythmic tones without audible murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation with bibasal crackles. No megaliths
column11: mild jugular ingurgitation. No oedema in the lower extremities.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Electrocardiogram (ECG): sinus rhythm at 75 bpm
column12: q v1-v2
column13: ST V1-V4
column14: I and AVL with specular decrease in inferior face. Blood tests on admission: acid-base balance PH 7.44
column15: PCO2 34 mmHg
column16: bicarbonate 23.1 mmol/l
column17: lactate 3.8 mmol/l
column18: sodium 142 mmol/l and potassium 3.6 mmol/l. Biochemistry urea 37mg/dl
column19: creatinine 1.24 mg/dl. Troponin I ultrasensitive peak 196000 μg/l. NT-proBNP 8682 pg/ml. Coronary angiography: Acute complete occlusion of distal common trunk (CT). Left anterior descending artery (LAD): occluded vessel with homolateral perfusion TIMI 0. After opening
column20: ectasia is seen in its proximal portion
column21: with diffuse mild to moderate involvement of the entire vessel and thin distal bed. Second septal branch ectatic
column22: with a long course and severe ostial lesion. Left circumflex artery (CX) proximal occluded vessel with homolateral perfusion TIMI 0. Right coronary artery (CD): dominant vessel
column23: large calibre
column24: ectatic and with moderate diffuse disease. Percutaneous coronary intervention was performed by implanting drug-eluting stents at distal CT level directed towards the LAD and subsequently at distal CT level towards Cx-first obtuse marginal. Echocardiogram (prior to discharge): dilated left ventricle (LV) (LVED 61 mm) with severe systolic dysfunction. Estimated LVEF 34% with contractile asymmetries. Right chambers of normal size and contractility. Mild aortic insufficiency (AIo). Moderate mitral insufficiency (MI) (II/IV). Estimated pulmonary pressure normal. Blood tests prior to discharge: NT-proBNP 6009 pg/ml (previous 8682)
column25: urea 36 mg/dl
column26: creatinine 0.89 mg/dl
column27: LDL 51 mg/dl
column28: chlorine 105 mEq/l
column29: sodium 139 mEq/l
column31: haemoglobin 10.7 g/dl
column32: haematocrit 31.5%
column33: HbA1c 6.6%. Echocardiogram (after completion of phase II of cardiac rehabilitation; videos 5 and 6): Dilated LV (LVED 61 mm) with slightly depressed function. Estimated LVEF 46% with contractile asymmetries. Right chambers of normal size and contractility. Mild AoI. Moderate MI (II/IV). Blood tests after end of phase II: NT-proBNP 2178 pg/ml
column34: creatinine 1.25 md/dl
column35: LDL 50 mg/dl
column36: HbA1c 6.3%.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION During the percutaneous intervention in the haemodynamics room
column37: our patient presented a progressive clinical worsening. Tendency to arterial hypotension with poor peripheral perfusion
column38: requiring the initiation of vasoactive drugs (dobutamine and noradrenaline) at medium doses
column39: as well as respiratory failure requiring non-invasive mechanical ventilation. Prior to leaving the haemodynamic ward
column40: a balloon counterpulsation device (IABP) was implanted. During his stay in the intensive care unit he evolved favourably
column41: allowing the weaning of vasoactive drugs and the removal of the IABP on the fourth day. During admission to the hospital ward (18 days of hospitalisation)
column42: congestive data persisted with very slow resolution despite forcing a negative water balance with intravenous diuretic
column43: as well as borderline blood pressure and transient worsening of renal function that made it difficult to initiate neurohormonal treatment
column44: and he was discharged in NYHA functional class (FC) II. The echocardiogram performed showed severely depressed ventricular function. Regarding treatment at discharge
column45: priority was given to oral diuretic treatment with furosemide and eplerenone
column46: together with low doses of beta-blockers
column47: given the circumstances described above. After hospital discharge
column48: our patient was referred to the cardiac rehabilitation unit (CRP) and
column49: in parallel
column50: began follow-up in the advanced heart failure unit. During phase II of the CRP
column51: our patient underwent the educational programme
column52: dietary recommendations
column53: review of cardiovascular risk factors (CVRF) and home medical treatment. Subsequently
column54: he successfully completed 8 weeks of face-to-face training guided by ergospirometry
column55: supervised by the cardiologist and rehabilitation physician. Regarding treatment
column56: drugs with prognostic benefit were prioritised (quadruple therapy)
column57: suspending furosemide treatment and reducing the dose of eplerenone
column58: which allowed the progressive initiation
column59: with close monitoring of renal function
column60: of sodium-glucose cotransporter type 2 inhibitor (iSGLT2) and angiotensin receptor neprilysin inhibitor (ARNI) at low doses. Finally
column61: intravenous ferric carboxymaltose was administered on an outpatient basis in day hospital (iron profile: iron 50 μg/dl
column62: ferritin 150 ng/dl
column63: haemoglobin 13.3 g/dl
column64: haematocrit 44%). After close comprehensive management
column65: our patient showed a clear improvement 4 months after the event
column66: improving both in functional class (stable CF I) and in analytical data (final NTproBNP 2178 pg/ml; initial 8682 pg/ml) and echocardiographic data
column67: with an estimated ventricular function of 46%.  DIAGNOSIS Acute ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) anterior Killip-Kimball IV Coronary artery disease of the common coronary trunk: distal CT occlusion Ischaemic dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) with severely depressed ventricular function Impaired basal glycaemia Iron deficiency anaemia. Familial hypercholesterolaemia. |O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-FARMACO I-FARMACO O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  History Male
column3: 61 years old. No known allergic reactions to medication. Cardiovascular risk factors: arterial hypertension. Obesity grade 2 (body mass index 37.86 kg/m2). No diabetes mellitus or dyslipidaemia. No toxic habits. Surgical history: operated for left trimalleolar fracture with osteosynthesis of peroneal malleolus with 6-hole tube third plate and osteosynthesis of tibial malleolus with a screw in 2009. Non-cardiological medical history: Moderate chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
column4: under follow-up by the outpatient pulmonology department of his referral hospital. Sleep apnoea-hypopnoea syndrome (SAHS) being treated with continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) and home oxygen. Prostate adenocarcinoma diagnosed in 2016
column5: treated with radiotherapy and hormone blockade. Unfiliated renal tumour
column6: first detected in 2017. Not operated on at his referral hospital due to high surgical risk. Abdomino-pelvic CT scan performed at his reference hospital in 2020: mixed nodule measuring 20 x 18 mm in the right kidney
column7: close to the lower pole
column8: eccentric
column9: without clear perirenal fatty infiltration. Stability in radiological follow-up
column10: so it has been considered non-malignant. Cardiological history: non-ischaemic dilated cardiomyopathy diagnosed in 2003
column11: with severe left ventricular dysfunction. Loss of follow-up until 2012. In 2012 the patient returned to the cardiology outpatient clinic at his referral hospital. Echocardiogram at that time showed a severely dilated left ventricle (LV)
column12: with biplane EF 29%
column13: with diffuse global hypokinesia. Coronary angiography showed irregularities in the right coronary artery
column14: the rest of the coronary tree showed no alterations. Implantable cardioverter defibrillator implantation with cardiac resynchronisation therapy (ICD-CRT) was decided in March 2012 for primary prevention of sudden death.  An appropriate shock due to non-sustained monomorphic ventricular tachycardia (NSMVT) occurred in December 2012. In reviews of the ICD
column15: multiple episodes of sustained monomorphic ventricular tachycardia (SMVT) treated with overstimulation were detected
column16: so amiodarone was started. In February 2020
column17: a new ventricular tachycardia (VT) occurred with appropriate ICD discharge
column18: and the patient was admitted to his referral hospital. The last transthoracic echocardiogram
column19: performed during this admission
column20: showed a severely dilated left ventricle (DTD 104 mm
column21: VTDi 207 ml/m2
column22: VTSi 157 ml/m2)
column23: with severe depression of function (LVEF 23% biplane)
column24: with severe global hypokinesia. Dilated left atrium (34 cm2). Diastolic dysfunction grade I with signs of increased filling pressures (E/e" 20). Mitral valve with mild regurgitation due to dilatation of the annulus. Aortic flow with slightly increased gradients (11/5 mmHg)
column25: without aortic insufficiency. Mild tricuspid insufficiency (LAD electrode) that does not allow adequate estimation of systolic pressure in the pulmonary artery. Dilated right ventricle (44 mm baseline)
column26: with RVEF at the lower limit (TAPSE 18 mm). No pericardial effusion. Usual treatment: atorvastatin 80 mg (1 tablet daily)
column27: amiodarone 200 mg (1 tablet every 12 hours)
column28: furosemide 40 mg (2 tablets daily)
column29: carvedilol 12.5 mg (1 tablet every 12 hours)
column31: esomeprazole 20 mg (1 tablet every 24 hours)
column32: indacaterol/glycopyrronium bromide 85/43 mcg (1 inhalation every 24 hours)
column33: tamsulosin 0.4 mg (1 tablet per day). Present illness A 61-year-old male who
column34: referred from his referral centre
column35: was admitted in May 2020 to the cardiology inpatient ward of the advanced heart failure and heart transplant unit to assess treatment options. The patient was diagnosed with dilated cardiomyopathy with severe left ventricular dysfunction in 2003 and had stopped attending check-ups until 2012. At present
column36: the patient reports NYHA functional class III/IV
column37: with sustained symptoms for the last few months. He has orthopnoea. He can walk only 50 metres without having to stop
column38: with difficulty climbing a floor. No episodes of palpitations
column39: syncope or presyncope
column40: nor new ICD discharges. No other associated symptoms. Physical examination Conscious and oriented
column41: eupneic at rest. Blood pressure 118/71 mmHg
column42: heart rate 53 bpm

column44: height 172 cm

column46: no murmurs or audible friction rubs. Pulmonary auscultation: preserved vesicular murmur with no added sounds
column47: although some generalised hypoventilation was observed. Extremities: slight tibiomalleolar oedema with fovea
column48: with no signs of deep vein thrombosis (DVT).  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS 12-lead electrocardiogram on admission: sinus bradycardia at 50 beats per minute
column49: with ventricular rhythm due to pacemaker in VAT. Chest X-ray on admission PA: no infiltrates or masses were identified. No costophrenic sinus impingement. ICD-CRT correctly positioned. column52: indexed DVIts (cm/m2) 4.1 cm/m2). Left ventricular systolic function is severely reduced (EF [Teich] 13.8%). Estimation of EF by Simpson's method is poorly assessable due to poor acoustic access. Right ventricle of normal dimensions (baseline RV dimensions 3.8 cm

column98: which decided that the patient was not a candidate for bariatric surgery due to a history of prostatic neoplasia under active treatment (less than 5 years). On discharge
column99: his usual treatment was maintained. However
column100: given that during admission he was diagnosed with diabetes mellitus (HbA1c 6.4%)
column101: it was decided to start treatment with semaglutide 0.5 mg
column102: one injection per week for 4 weeks
column103: subsequently increasing to 1 mg per week indefinitely
column104: with good tolerance.  Treatment was also started with dapagliflozin 10 mg 1 tablet per day and eplerenone 25 mg 1 tablet per day. Education in heart failure is started. Periodic scheduled admissions were decided (the patient lives far from our hospital) for treatment with levosimendan under monitoring. During successive admissions
column105: all of which were uneventful
column106: a gradual weight loss was observed as follows: in June 2020
column107: the patient weighed 107 kg
column109: and in August 2020 he weighed 94 kg. The patient reports a marked improvement of his functional class
column110: almost NYHA class I. Laboratory tests show a reduction in glycosylated haemoglobin (HbA1c) from 6.4% in May to 5.7% at 3 months. On admission in September 2020
column111: the patient weighs 89 kg and in October 2020
column112: the weight is maintained at 89 kg. Subsequent outpatient follow-up is carried out at our hospital. The patient indicates that he has reduced his weight to 84 kg (BMI 28.39 kg/m2
column113: overweight grade 2). He reports some fatigue on exertion
column114: but denies dyspnoea. He is able to climb several floors without stopping. He has stopped taking furosemide tablets. Therefore
column116: since the introduction of antidiabetic treatment (semaglutide 1 mg weekly and dapagliflozin 10 mg daily)
column117: the patient has started a progressive and constant weight reduction until reaching a weight of 84 kg
column118: managing to maintain the loss over time. From an initial weight of 112 kg and a BMI of 37.86 kg/m2 (grade 2 obesity)
column119: the patient reduced his weight by a total of 28 kg in approximately 6 months
column120: reaching a BMI of 28.39 kg/m2 (grade 2 overweight). At the same time
column121: the patient reports progressive improvement in symptoms and functional class. Initially
column123: he was considerably limited by his heart disease
column125: and was practically asymptomatic on discharge from our centre (NYHA class I). As a result

column127: and was therefore followed up by the cardiology department of his referral hospital.  DIAGNOSIS Heart failure with severely reduced left ventricular ejection fraction. Non-ischaemic dilated cardiomyopathy.  Other diagnoses: Obesity grade 2. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXPLORATION 60-year-old male.  Personal history No known adverse drug reactions. Cardiovascular risk factors: ex-smoker (pack-year index 60)
column3: risky alcoholism
column4: obesity. No previous cardiological history or family history of heart disease or sudden death. Usual treatment: none.  Current illness She attended the emergency department due to deterioration of functional class of about 2 weeks of evolution
column5: presenting progressive dyspnoea until minimal effort. Accompanied by orthopnoea and dry cough. No peripheral oedema. No syncope

column7: heart rate (HR) 90 bpm

Pulmonary auscultation with hypophonesis in both lung bases with crackles up to the middle third bilaterally. Lower limbs with pretibial oedema. Peripheral pulses present and symmetrical. Well perfused.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Electrocardiogram: sinus rhythm at 90 beats per minute

column10: narrow QRS with normal positioned axis
column11: adequate R wave transition in precordial leads
column12: negative T waves in I

column35: TSI 21%; thyroid profile TSH 3.2 U/l; HbA1c 11.1%. Microbiology: SARS-CoV-2 PCR negative. Chest X-ray on admission: poorly inspired study. Increased cardiothoracic index. Increase of the bilateral perihilar vascular network
column36: pinching of both lateral costophrenic sinuses
column37: compatible with heart failure component. Increased density in both lung bases
column38: which seems to be due to hypoventilation changes. Transthoracic echocardiogram (videos 1-4): moderately dilated left ventricle
column39: with normal wall thickness. Akinesia of inferior face
column40: inferior septum and inferior lateral face. Severe hypokinesia of the rest. Severely depressed global systolic function (LVEF 25% by visual estimation). Pseudonormalised filling pattern. Slightly dilated left atrium. Non-dilated right atrium. Non-dilated right ventricle
column41: with normal global systolic function. Mitral valve with apicalisation of the coaptation point of both leaflets
column42: mild-moderate insufficiency (II/IV). Aortic valve morphologically and functionally normal. Tricuspid valve morphologically normal. Mild insufficiency. RV-AD gradient 26 mmHg. Inferior vena cava poorly visualised. No pericardial effusion. Aortic root not dilated. No evidence of coarctation. Coronary angiography (videos 5-6): access via right radial artery
column43: contrast 70 cc. Left coronary trunk without lesions. Anterior descending artery of good development and calibre with diffuse mild atheromatosis (mild plaque in the middle segment of 30%). Early diagonal branch of moderate calibre but without significant lesions. Circumflex of good development and calibre with diffuse mild atheromatosis. There are two marginal branches: first obtuse marginal branch with moderate plaque at the origin of a subbranch
column44: the obtuse marginal branch being of borderline calibre at this level. Dominant right coronary artery
column45: of good development and calibre with diffuse mild atheromatosis without significant lesions.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION The patient was admitted for a first episode of decompensation of heart failure
column46: with predominantly pulmonary congestion. He remained haemodynamically stable at all times
column47: with no evidence of anterograde heart failure. Admitted to the conventional hospital ward in respiratory failure requiring support with oxygen therapy using low-flow nasal cannulas and diuretic treatment with intravenous furosemide. Good evolution with adequate diuretic response and progressive decongestion
column48: with weight loss of up to 6 kg. Once close to euvolemia
column49: prognostically beneficial treatment was started with beta-blockers
column50: ARNI and antialdosteronics with adequate tolerance. The discharge medication included bisoprolol 5 mg/24h
column51: sacubitril/valsartan 24/26 mg/12h
column52: eplerenone 50 mg/24h. In addition

column55: diagnostic criteria for type 2 diabetes mellitus were met (due to altered baseline glycaemia and elevated HbA1c levels)
column56: and so
column57: upon debut with HbA1c > 10%
column58: insulinisation was started together with oral antidiabetic drugs appropriate to the patient's clinical profile (established cardiovascular disease
column59: obesity with BMI > 30 kg/m2). Thus
column60: diabetes treatment at discharge consisted of insulin toujeo 24 IU/24 h
column61: metformin/dapagliflozin 1000/5 mg (0.5 comp/12 h the first week and then 1 comp/24 h) and subcutaneous semaglutide (0.25 mg weekly for the first 4 weeks and then 0.5 mg weekly). The patient is being followed up in heart failure and endocrinology consultations
column62: with no new admissions for heart failure. Significant improvement in LVEF up to 35% and NT-proBNP levels (400-> 150 ng/l) was observed after 6 months of treatment
column63: as well as a decrease in HbA1c levels (11.1 -> 8.5%) and weight during follow-up (currently 91 kg and BMI 29.7 kg/m2). Newly diagnosed type 2 diabetes mellitus. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  Personal history 37-year-old woman with the following personal history: No adverse drug reactions. She denies drug use. No known cardiovascular risk factors. Bronchial asthma without chronic treatment. Gynaecological history: two full-term pregnancies
column3: vaginal delivery. No usual treatment.  Current history A 37-year-old woman with the aforementioned history presented at rest with oppressive non-radiating central thoracic pain with vegetative crust. She attended her health centre for this reason
column4: where an electrocardiogram (ECG) was performed with pathological alterations
column5: so it was decided to administer a loading dose of 250 mg of acetylsalicylic acid (ASA) and 300 mg of clopidogrel
column6: sublingual nitroglycerine and contact was made with the critical care and emergency department (DCCU) for transfer to her reference hospital.  Physical examination Acceptable general condition. Conscious
column7: oriented and cooperative. Eupneic at rest. Normal weight. Blood pressure (BP) 95/50 mmHg
column8: heart rate (HR) 80 bpm. Jugular venous pressure normal. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic tones at a good frequency
column9: no murmurs or extratonos. Pulmonary auscultation: preserved vesicular murmur without added pathological sounds. Abdomen soft and depressible
column10: not painful on palpation. No masses or megaliths are palpable. Hydro-aerial sounds present. No oedema in the lower limbs or sloping areas. Radial
column11: femoral and pedal pulses were preserved bilaterally.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Initial ECG: sinus tachycardia at 115 bpm competing with accelerated idioventricular rhythm (RIVA). In the sinus beats
column12: normal PR
column13: narrow QRS
column14: ST segment elevation of 2 mm in V1 and aVR
column15: and 1 mm in V2-3
column16: with ST descent of 1-2 mm in inferior face and from V4 to V6. Blood tests on admission: haemoglobin 13.5 g/dl
column17: haematocrit 40%
column18: leukocytes 14
column19: 000/μl with neutrophilia 12
column21: platelets 222
column22: 000/μl. Coagulation: INR 1.1
column23: TTPa 28 sec. Biochemistry: urea 22 mg/dl
column24: creatinine 0.66 mg/dl
column25: sodium 135 mEq/l
column26: potassium 3.87 mEq/l. CPK total/MB 252/43 -> 2.256/264 U/l. Initial high sensitivity Troponin T 176 -> peak 2
column27: 910 ng/l (normal < 13.9 ng/l). Lipid profile: total cholesterol 113 mg/dl
column28: triglycerides 81 mg/dl
column29: HDL cholesterol 54 mg/dl
column31: VLDL cholesterol 16 mg/dl. Echocardioscopy on arrival at the emergency department: non-dilated left ventricle with normal wall thickness
column32: severe hypokinesia of the apical cap and hypokinesia of apical segments and middle segment of inferolateral
column33: lateral and anterior faces
column34: with hypercontractility of the remaining segments. Moderate-severe left ventricular dysfunction
column35: estimated LVEF 30-35%. Right chambers of preserved size with preserved function. Non-dilated atria. Mild-moderate mitral insufficiency by colour Doppler. No pericardial effusion. Inferior vena cava 16 mm with adequate inspiratory collapse. Urgent diagnostic coronary angiography (video 1): significant stenosis of the left coronary trunk due to probable intramural haematoma causing extrinsic compression of the lumen
column36: without significant angiographic lesions in the rest of the coronary tree. Urgent CT angiography: thoracoabdominal aorta of normal calibre
column37: with no signs of acute pathology. No images compatible with acute aortic syndrome. Bilateral pulmonary alveolar lesions distributed throughout the upper lobes and apical segment of the lower lobes
column38: suggesting an aspiration aetiology. Nutcracker's phenomenon with varicose dilatation of the left gonadal vein due to stenosis of the left renal vein in the aortomesenteric clamp. Bilateral adnexal cysts
column39: functional type and free fluid in Douglas recess. No other findings of interest. Coronary revascularisation coronary angiography: the left coronary trunk was probed with an EBU 3.5 guide catheter
column40: a guide was passed to the distal vessel of the anterior descending artery and contrast injection was performed
column41: proving spiroid dissection of the left coronary trunk with preserved distal flow
column42: Onyx Resolute 4 x 26 mm drug-eluting stent was implanted at 16 atm in the trunk towards the anterior descending artery with a good final angiographic result
column43: without residual dissection. Post-catheterisation ECG: sinus tachycardia. Normal PR. Narrow QRS
column44: axis at 30o with QS of V1-V3
column45: QR in aVL. Persistent ST-segment elevation in aVL
column47: ST-segment depression of 1 mm in inferior leads and negative T in aVL. Regulated transthoracic echocardiography prior to discharge: left ventricle of normal dimensions with normal wall thickness. Mild global hypokinesia more accentuated in mid-apical segments of inferolateral and lateral region. Mild systolic dysfunction (estimated LVEF 48%). Left atrium of normal dimensions. Aortic root not dilated. Right chambers not dilated. Right ventricle with normal contractility. No organic valvular pathology. No pericardial effusion. Inferior vena cava of normal calibre. Left ventricular filling with restrictive transmitral flow pattern. Flow at the level of the pulmonary veins
column48: with diastolic predominance. No indirect signs of significant pulmonary hypertension. Normal antegrade flow. Mild degenerative mitral regurgitation. ECG at discharge: sinus rhythm at 75 bpm. Normal PR. Narrow QRS with QS in V1-V3. Millimetre ST subleveling in V3. Negative T in DI
column49: aVL and V1-V5. Blood tests at discharge: Haemogram: haemoglobin 12.8 g/dl
column50: leucocytes 8
column51: 940/μl with neutrophils 6
column53: platelets 158
column54: 000/μl. Coagulation normal. INR 1. Biochemistry: glucose 82 mg/dl
column55: creatinine 0.60 mg/dl
column56: potassium 3.28 mEq/l
column57: CRP 47.62 mg/l
column58: total CPK 188 U/l
column59: troponin T at discharge 658 ng/l
column60: ProBNP 5
column61: 147 pg/ml.   CLINICAL EVOLUTION On arrival at the ED
column62: the patient was hypotensive (blood pressure 95/50 mmHg
column63: heart rate 80 bpm)
column64: saturating at 97% with nasal spectacles at 2 litres/minute and with persistent chest pain. Urgent echocardiography showed moderate to severe left ventricular systolic dysfunction and segmental alterations
column65: and the patient was transferred to the haemodynamics department for urgent coronary angiography. The coronary angiography showed significant stenosis of the left main coronary artery due to a probable haematoma causing extrinsic compression
column66: with no significant angiographic lesions in the rest of the coronary tree. Before proceeding to revascularisation
column67: acute aortic syndrome was ruled out by urgent aortic CT angiography. After this
column68: percutaneous revascularisation was chosen
column69: so coronary angiography was repeated in the following hours and a stent was implanted in the left coronary artery towards the anterior descending coronary artery with good angiographic results. During the procedure
column70: he presented hypotension and sinus tachycardia requiring continuous perfusion of noradrenaline (0.31 microg/kg/minute). She returned to the coronary unit asymptomatic
column71: maintaining the noradrenaline perfusion which could be progressively withdrawn in the first 48 hours after revascularisation. After a favourable evolution
column72: he was transferred to the hospital ward. Initially
column73: double antiplatelet therapy was maintained with ASA 100 mg and clopidogrel 75 mg; however
column74: given the high thrombotic risk due to stenting in the left coronary trunk
column75: it was decided to switch to ticagrelor 48 hours after catheterisation. In the post-revascularisation echocardiographic control
column76: severe left ventricular systolic dysfunction persisted
column77: so treatment for heart failure was started with good tolerance
column78: presenting mild ventricular dysfunction at hospital discharge. After hospital discharge
column79: she was included in the cardiac rehabilitation programme
column80: which she completed without incident. She is currently being monitored in cardiology consultations and has remained asymptomatic from the cardiovascular point of view. Follow-up echocardiography showed that left ventricular systolic function had recovered and was preserved one year after the event. Treatment at discharge: ASA 100 mg (every 24 hours)
column81: ticagrelor 90 mg (every 12 hours for one year)
column82: bisoprolol 1.25 mg (every 24 hours)
column83: ivabradine 5 mg (every 12 hours)
column84: ramipril 1.25 mg (every 24 hours)
column85: omeprazole 20 mg (every 24 hours).  DIAGNOSIS Anteroseptal ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome (STEMI). Present illness A 76-year-old man with the above-described history presented to the emergency department of our hospital with decompensated heart failure. column2: CURRENT ILLNESS AND PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  The patient was a 21-year-old male
column3: with no known drug allergies. With regard to his toxic habits
column4: he was a social drinker
column5: non-smoker
column6: denying the consumption of other toxic substances. He denied cardiovascular risk factors
column7: cardiological history of interest and did not follow any outpatient treatment. He came to our emergency department with a fever of up to 39oC of three days' evolution. In the last 24 hours he began to experience abdominal pain in the mesogastrium
column8: more accentuated in the right iliac fossa
column9: which did not change with ingestion and was more accentuated when standing upright. There was no loss of appetite. He denied nausea or vomiting
column10: alteration of transit
column11: externalisation of bleeding or urinary symptoms. Blood pressure was 132/89 mmHg
column12: oxygen saturation 100% baseline
column13: temperature 36.4oC
column14: acceptable general condition
column15: conscious
column16: oriented and cooperative
column17: good hydration and perfusion
column18: eupneic at rest and without neurological focality. Cardiac and pulmonary auscultation showed no relevant findings. The abdomen was soft
column19: depressible
column20: with hydro-aerial sounds present
column21: without palpable masses or megaliths
column22: with intense pain on palpation of the right iliac fossa but without signs of peritoneal irritation. Given the suspicion of appendicitis
column23: urgent analysis
column24: abdominal CT scan and PCR for SARSCoV- 2 of the protocol prior to admission
column25: initially in charge of the digestive system
column26: were requested.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS With regard to the tests performed in the emergency department: In the urgent analysis
column27: the biochemical analysis showed total bilirubin of 2.58 mg/dl (0.3-1.2) with direct bilirubin of 0.5 mg/dl (0-0.5) and C-reactive protein of 180 mg/l (0-5). The haemogram showed discrete leukocytosis of 11.69 x10^3/μl (4-11) with neutrophilia of 9.68 x10^3/μl. Coagulopathy was present
column28: with prothrombin time of 51% (75-140) and calculated fibrinogen of 841 mg/dl
column29: with normal activated partial thromboplastin time. Urinalysis showed urobilinogen 8 mg/dl and ketone bodies 60 mg/dl. PCR for SARS-CoV-2 was performed and was positive
column30: with gene amplification in late cycles
column31: probably compatible with residual RNA. Abdominal CT scan without contrast showed normal liver and spleen
column32: with no obvious focal lesions
column33: normal-sized gallbladder
column34: alliasic
column35: with no signs of acute cholecystitis or bile duct dilatation. Pancreas without significant alterations. Normal sized kidneys with no evidence of lithiasis or hydronephrosis. Inflammatory changes were identified in the cecum
column36: ileocecal valve and terminal ileum. The terminal ileum had a thickened wall with marked inflammatory changes in the vicinity. There were also multiple reactive lymphadenopathies in the right iliac fossa. There was an amina of free fluid in the right paracolic gutter. The cecal appendix showed minimal enlargement of its base
column37: probably secondary to the described inflammatory changes and the proximity to the ileum. Distally the appendix was of normal calibre. Therefore
column38: these findings were more suggestive of ileitis with associated inflammatory changes (slightly affecting the base of the appendix) than appendicitis. During admission to the gastrointestinal department and later cardiology: a study of hepatotropic viruses and HIV
column39: anti-transglutaminase and thiopurine methyltransferase antibodies was carried out
column40: which were negative. A determination of orosomucoid acid alpha-1-glycoprotein was requested
column41: which was 198 mg/dl (50-120) and ferritin 940 ng/ml (21-274). A stool culture showed dysbacteriosis due to gram-positive microorganisms. Seventy-two hours after admission
column42: chest pain analysis was requested
column43: with elevated troponin I (high sensitivity) of 522.8 ng/l (5-34) and C-reactive protein 352 mg/l. Subsequent enzyme serum serology showed a troponin I peak of 13
column44: 418 ng/l
column45: which subsequently decreased progressively
column46: as well as CK 671 U/l (30-200) and NTproBNP 3405 pg/ml. An electrocardiogram was performed with chest pain
column47: showing sinus tachycardia at 103 bpm. PR 120 ms constant. QRS 90ms
column48: normal electrical axis. No repolarisation alterations. The electrocardiogram on the ninth day of admission showed sinus rhythm at 64 bpm. PR 160 ms constant. QRS 88 ms
column49: normal electrical axis. QTc 429 ms. Negative T wave in III and flattened in aVF. Electrocardiogram prior to discharge showed sinus rhythm at 85 bpm. PR 140 ms constant. QRS 84 ms
column50: normal electrical axis. Biphasic T waves on the inferolateral side. An urgent echocardiogram was performed on suspicion of myocarditis
column51: showing: left atrium (LA) not dilated (21 ml/m2). Left ventricle (LV) not dilated (DTD 49 mm/62 ml/m2) not hypertrophic (septum 7 mm pp 7 mm mass 55 g/m2 RWT 0.29). Global hypokinesia with moderate LV systolic dysfunction (biplane Simpson EF 42%). Normofunctioning mitral valve. Filling pattern with fusion of E and A. Normofunctioning trivalve aortic valve. Aortic root and ascending aorta not dilated. Right chambers of normal size
column52: right ventricular (RV) systolic function at low limit of normality (TAPSE 16 mm S-wave DTI 10 cm/s). Mild tricuspid insufficiency (TI) with V max 2 m/s
column53: estimated normal PAPS. Normal pulmonary acceleration time. Dilated inferior vena cava (IVC) without adequate inspiratory collapse. No pericardial effusion. The control echocardiogram performed 5 days later showed improvement of the previously described global hypokinesia.  CLINICAL EVOLUTION A new PCR was performed 48 hours after admission
column54: which was negative
column55: and COVID isolation was lifted. Subsequently
column56: serology was performed with positive IgG for SARS-CoV-2. Seventy-two hours after admission
column57: she began to experience repeated episodes of central thoracic pain described as stabbing
column58: radiating to the neck
column59: which increased with deep inspiration. They were accompanied by sweating and
column60: on occasion
column61: vomiting. Following the findings described in the complementary tests (analysis with elevated acute phase reactants and markers of myocardial damage
column62: electrocardiogram with sinus tachycardia and echocardiogram with global hypokinesia)
column63: treatment was started with beta-blockers and he was transferred to the coronary unit where he was monitored without arrhythmic events of interest. After 48 hours he was transferred to the cardiology hospital ward to complete the study and treatment. During his stay on the ward he remained asymptomatic
column64: with no evidence of heart failure. Treatment was started with angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACE inhibitors) and beta-blockers. A repeat echocardiogram showed normalisation of systolic function
column65: although slight hypokinesia persisted in the basal segments of the septum and anterolateral face. The control electrocardiogram showed sinus rhythm alternating with bouts of nodal rhythm without relevant clinical translation (he did not present syncope or other alarm symptoms)
column66: so the beta-blockers were discontinued and he was monitored with telemetry and these episodes were observed during sleep
column67: which could be secondary to vagal hypotonia or be in the context of the evolution of myocarditis. From the digestive point of view
column68: he presented significant clinical improvement
column69: without pain and with normalisation of intestinal transit. He completed empirical antibiotic therapy with ceftriaxone and metronidazole
column70: started on admission. At discharge he had good oral tolerance. After progressive tests showed a clear decrease in myocardial enzymes
column71: practically normalised
column72: and in acute phase reactants
column73: in a stable clinical and haemodynamic situation
column74: he was discharged from hospital after 10 days of hospitalisation.  DIAGNOSIS Myocarditis and acute ileocolitis in the context of late-stage SARS-CoV-2 infection. Ventriculography: dilated left ventricle with irregular contour on the underside (small aneurysms). LVEF 25%. Moderate MI. TDVI 24 mmHg. Severe ventricular dysfunction. Endomyocardial biopsy: fragment of myocardium with mild hypertrophic features without inflammation or granulomas. No interstitial fibrosis is seen. No iron or glycogen deposition. column1: History 69-year-old woman No known drug allergies High blood pressure (HBP) Hypercholesterolemia Bronchial asthma and pneumonia in 2009 Chronic atrophic gastritis and chronic hepatitis C virus (HCV) liver disease Chondrocalcinosis Calcifying tendinitis of the right shoulder Osteoporosis Hyperparathyroidism with parathyroidectomy in 2001 Bilateral sensorineural hearing loss Dry eye syndrome  Cardiological history In 1978 he underwent mitral and aortic valve replacement with biological prostheses. In 1990
column2: both prostheses malfunctioned
column3: so a new replacement with two mechanical prostheses was performed. The aortic prosthesis was implanted at the level of the coronary ostium
column4: so it was necessary to perform two aortocoronary grafts (saphenous vein to the anterior interventricular and right coronary artery). In 2002 he was admitted for heart failure and haemolytic anaemia related to late periprosthetic dehiscence
column5: so a new mitral valve replacement was performed with another mechanical prosthesis and new aortocoronary grafts (saphenous vein to the middle anterior descending artery and to the right coronary artery). In 2003
column6: DDD pacemaker implantation was performed due to symptomatic sinus node disease with paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. Cardiologically asymptomatic until 2014
column7: when she was admitted several times for heart failure
column8: the last one in August 2014.  Current illness Patient admitted for a new episode of heart failure in December 2014. A control transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) was performed
column9: followed by a transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) which confirmed the presence of two mitral periprosthetic leaks (one septal and one posterior). Taking into account the patient's morbidity and the high surgical risk
column10: the patient was scheduled for percutaneous leak closure. This procedure was performed on 08/01/2015 under general anaesthesia and with transesophageal echocardiography control in the haemodynamics room. Initial access was via the right femoral vein and
column11: after transseptal puncture
column12: an attempt was made to cross the posterior mitral leak (as it was the largest) in an antegrade manner
column13: without success. Therefore
column14: it was decided to puncture the left femoral artery and cross the mechanical aortic prosthesis with a guide and a catheter with good haemodynamic tolerance. The posterior leak is crossed and the guidewire is captured in the left atrium (LA) with a loop
column15: externalising via the right femoral vein
column16: thus creating an arteriovenous (AV) shunt. The size of the defect by 3D TEE is 10x4 mm
column17: so a 10x5mm Vascular Plug device is chosen for closure. A release sheath is advanced from the right femoral vein through the defect into the left ventricle (LV) and the device is released from the LV to the LA with good placement and effective closure of the defect (video 3 and figure 1). The procedure is completed and the left femoral artery puncture is closed with good results. The patient was extubated in the ward and transferred to the coronary unit for evolutionary control in good clinical condition.  Physical examination BP: 110/48 mmHg. HR: 107 bpm. Sat.02: 100% (Reservoir at 100%). Afebrile. Conscious and oriented
column18: good skin and mucous membrane colouring
column19: good peripheral perfusion
column20: eupneic at rest. Head and neck: no jugular ingurgitation. Cardiac auscultation: rhythmic
column21: no murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation: preserved vesicular murmur. Abdomen: soft
column22: depressible
column23: not painful on palpation
column24: no signs of peritoneal irritation
column25: no masses or megaliths. Sounds present. Lower extremities: no oedema. Pedial pulses present and symmetrical. No haematoma in puncture sites. Sensibility and mobility preserved.  COMPLEMENTARY TESTS Preoperative TTE: LV neither dilated nor hypertrophic
column26: with good global systolic function
column27: apical aneurysm. The mechanical mitral prosthesis has a slight systolic Doppler signal. Aortic root not dilated. Mechanical aortic prosthesis with mild regurgitation and maximum gradient of 40 mmHg. Moderately dilated LA. Dilated right chambers. Right ventricle (RV) with moderate dysfunction. Moderate tricuspid regurgitation with RV-RA gradient of 65 mmHg. Estimated PsAP of 80 mmHg. RV pacing lead. No pericardial effusion. Preoperative TEE: mitral prosthesis with two periprosthetic leaks
column28: one septal and one posterior
column29: both moderate.  EVOLUTION In subsequent outpatient controls
column31: with improvement in her functional capacity. She has lost weight. In the subsequent control TTE she presented mild periprosthetic mitral insufficiency. From the bicave plane
column77: autocontrast and mobile thrombus can be seen at the mouth of the inferior cava (which is not seen again later in the study). RV not dilated with systolic function at the lower limit of normality. Conclusions: Mitral prosthetic thrombosis that does not cause significant stenosis. Multiple thrombi in LA. Severe LV dysfunction (coronary embolism?).  Clinical course In view of the TEE findings
column78: on-call Cardiac Surgery was notified and it was decided to perform coronary angiography (due to the contractility alterations and ECG changes) and then urgent surgery
column79: both procedures being carried out in the following hours. Catheterisation showed no angiographically significant coronary lesions
column80: and once again the non-mobility of one of the prosthetic discs was confirmed. During the surgical procedure
column81: a large amount of LA thrombus and thrombus causing occlusion of the aforementioned disc was observed. Remnants of the posterior mitral leaflet that may have contributed to the occlusion were observed. It was decided to remove the prosthesis and implant a new one. During CPB
column82: with the heart at low preload
column83: marked LV hypocontractility was observed
column84: mainly at the expense of the middle and apical regions (septum and basal region with good mobility). He was connected to an epicardial pacemaker for sinus bradycardia. Times: ECC 138 min. Anoxia 78 min. Temperature 32 oC. He left the operating theatre with significant inotropic support (dobutamine at 10 μg/kg/min + noradrenaline at 0.3 μg/kg/min + adrenaline at 0.3 μg/kg/min + levosimendan at 0.05 μg/kg/min)
column85: maintaining AMT around 80-85 mmHg. He also presented a significant coagulation alteration
column86: which was controlled with transfusion of blood products (800 cc plasma + 1 pool of platelets + 4 g of fibrinogen + 2 red blood cell concentrates). In the immediate postoperative period he presented abundant bleeding through the drains and anaemisation
column87: which again required transfusion of blood products. The patient is currently still in the ICU
column88: under sodium heparin p.c. and with good prosthetic function. In the last few hours he has been extubated and has no neurological deficits on examination
column89: and is progressing favourably.  Diagnosis - Mitral prosthetic thrombosis in a poorly anticoagulated patient. Urgent fibrinolysis partially effective with thrombotic release to the left chambers. - Severe LV dysfunction with alterations in contractility and ECG changes in this context
column90: with no evidence of coronary embolism. - Impaired renal function secondary to low output
